Hud was completely annoying, in fact it was a relief that he died. Frankly, I wish that the camera had been totally demolished when the Statue of Liberty head fell on the street. When I pay to watch a movie, I expect to see the movie. Watching the 85 minutes of motion blur is not my idea of exciting. In fact, the only intensity I experienced was the intense hatred of hand held cameras and moronic people who think that this is somehow heightening the experience. Maybe some people find this edgy in place of a real story, but the visual experience I had was that of motion sickness. Perhaps the sequel to this film should be done on a video phone, or maybe stop motioned from someone's Iphone camera. In fact, screw it, just toss up 85 minutes of random photography and we'll call that edgy and frightening. I was not held in any form of suspense and can only say that I really don't care to get my money back, I want the 85 minutes of my life back. I could do something more useful with it, like kick a puppy or get unnecessary surgery. Maybe I'll remove the part of my brain that says that if I want a story told entirely in dialog without any visual reference, I'll read a book. When I go to a movie, I want to see what happens. Don't forget, the Blair Witch had some element of story. Terrible camera work that made the average movie goer nauseous, but it at least had something mildly compelling. So for anyone that thinks that this will be a fun cool film that will make you jump in your seat, the only thing I did was stare at the lights flashing by as a group of totally vapid characters who evoke less emotion then the cast of Waterworld screamed a lot. Terrible movie. Shame on whoever green lit this piece of crap.

title: Crap
review:
Actually this is 0/10. This is a waste of money and waste of time. Not at all entertaining.

The story is weak. Nothing in it actually. No plot, weak character, screenplay? define screenplay please. Direction? This film doesn't have direction at all. Nothing! But I will give credit to the editors for sitting for long period of time watching and screening which shaky camera movement should they put in the movie because the writer, director, cinematographer or should i say VIDEOgrapher didn't do their job.

Reeves and Goddard.. stick to TV. If you want to make a good full length film. I suggest you attend film school first and USE YOUR IMAGINATION.

title: Terrible movie!!!!
review:
This was one of the worse movies I have seen in a long time.

You keep waiting for the dumb home video to end to see what is going on at the time the home video was found. Was the monster killed? The whole movie was a home video of what particularly happened on that day, nothing else. I give this movie a huge thumbs down, I should have known better to rent the DVD, there was no good actors in it, and that's usually my rule of thumb, no good actors, don't rent or go see the movie!! What this movie needed was a storyline. Take bits and pieces out of the home movie, but have a story going on around it. Who found the home movie, show these people. What else happened, other than what happened to the handful of people in the home video? What was the result of the attacks to the city? The people responsible for putting this movie out, should quit while they are behind!!

title: So annoying
review: If you want to listen to an idiot yell "Rob! Rob! Hey Rob where you goin? What are you doing?" For 2 hours with a handheld camera you will love this. Most annoying dialogue hard to watch.

title: Blair witch again?
review: A modern day Blair Witch Project with a Godzilla twist/alien invasion, bouncy camera made me want to vomit. Didn't anyone learn about this in the last movie that was filmed in first person. The movie was boring, watched the first 30 min and lost interest with other shiny things. Trailers really played this one up to a horrible let down! I had more interest in in reading the wall street journal, going out to my front yard and watching the rocks grow, The intensity was actually hilarious (maybe about the only good part of the movie) very poor "oh my god were gonna die " acting. Good touch adding the military seems how there all overseas, does that mean the terrorists are going to have free reign on the free world again? Sorry my opinion about this movie is simple, this movie sucks and don't waste your time like I did, granted I didn't have any thing better to do.

title: Name That Storyline Please
review: This movie can't even be called a movie really. Whats the storyline??? Rob? His name is said over 200 times in the film , and in real life, would everyone still follow Rob after so many screw ups? I watched this with 3 of my teenage kids and at the end when it said Do not copy one said (Who would want to.) I seen many ideas from I am Legend, so many goofs, a couple, the Statue of Liberty's head is 5 times bigger in real life and when Hud gets chomped by a creature that just grabbed their chopper from 1,500 feet up, this creature reaches down and chomps him??? That would be like a man reaching down to chomp an ant. The ending sucked!!! I mean good grief I expected at the very least maybe a kid 10 years from now discovering the tape or a foreign Army team watching it to give the affect the monster was a war weapon... The first 30 minutes is dull, very little action in relation to applying common sense to how people would really react and the first scene of the Monster attack was a sickening copycat of 911 when the Towers dropped... As my daughter also pointed out, Hud sure kept a steady hand, I have seen footage in life death scenarios and the cameraman is always shaking... Very well deserving of a one rating, I have seen much better on You tube...

title: A blend of a bad, and s***** movie
review: To me this movie was G-d awful, I mean, to me this was nothing more than the Godzilla movie, the one that was in New York, not the good ones where he was terrorizing Japan, and Blair Witch Project mashed into one. Thats right, the new Godzilla movie = S***, while Blair Witch was just Bad. Now don't get me wrong, it was pretty intense, and defiantly new way of looking through the ideas of if there was a giant monster terrorizing a major city, this is what you would be like if you were in the mess, and lived that long through it, while trying to save a love interest/friend. But after so long, it just got annoying. I also had a problem with one of the monsters, the little ones that were given off. I'm sorry but they look like the Bugs from Starship Troopers with a more spider like look. Which made me feel like the people in charge of monster design, were effing lazy. I'm a person who loves movies, and can't get enough of them, but for the first time ever, I wouldn't even want to own a movie like this, even if it was given to me free... with a small country in the bundle.

title: Jaw Dropping!!!!!!!!!
review:
First of i would like to say that this is hands down the best monster movie made. Some people will say " The Host" which was a great movie, but does not compare to the suspense and terror in Cloverfield. The visual effects in this movie were absolutely stunning. Superbly acted by a mostly unknown cast added to the realty of this movie. Cloverfield definitely tops my list of movies in 2008 so far. A MIND BLOWING movie experience that must be seen.

one more note............. Don't LEAVE THE THEATER TILL AFTER THE CREDITS ROLL!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I warn you DON NOT LEAVE!!!!!!!!! After the long credits, a very important scene takes place that you cant miss. So sit tight and wait. You wont be disappointed.

title: I feel like a fool...
review:
JJ Abrams is a marketing genius.

With all the hype this movie has received ever since its teaser in July of last year, its no wonder Cloverfield made over 40 million dollars opening weekend. People are creatures of curiosity, and in turn could not help themselves from wanting to see this movie.

I'll admit, I was curious too. Afterall, it didn't even have a name until a few months ago and everything was so secretive. With such a big secret, this movie has GOT to be great, or at the very least, unique.

NO.

Not great, not unique, not even worth the sick, dizzy feeling I got from trying to pay attention. I didn't even pay to watch this movie, yet still I want a refund. I want my hour and a half back.

Now before you rip me apart for this, let me say a few things:

1. They spent about 30 million dollars on this movie. WHAT?!? I realize that 30 mil is pretty cheap for a movie budget but come on. Either the set had some really amazing catering or that statue replica was very expensive. Clearly that 30 mil was not spent on actors with talent. BTW 30 mil is about what they spent on Ghostbusters in 1984. At least Ghostbusters was entertaining.

2. And speaking of the actors... I realize that the point of using amateur actors is to give the movie a more "realistic" feel, to make the audience relate to the characters more. No. Screw you. If I wanted to see real people doing realistic things, I would watch reality TV.

3. Yes. The whole "let's shoot this from the perspective of real people with a video camera" idea is a great one. Look at the Blair Witch. But trying to get an audience to feel like this "really" happened is ridiculous. If a giant spider-monster thing attack could really happen, then maybe i'd be able to appreciate the use of "realism" in this movie. It's like trying to create a sense of reality in a movie like Transformers. Totally unbelievable. How about if we use this hand-held idea in a movie about a real natural disaster, or anything else that could possibly happen? Cool idea. Wrong story.

4. Can't anyone come up with any NEW ideas anymore? If Hollywood isn't remaking Japanese horror movies these days, it seems they are just retelling the same stories in a different way. Sure. Cloverfield is not a remake. But how many times has this "monster-attacks-city-and-people-freak" story been told already? Does Hollywood really not have anymore original ideas?

So i've wasted my time watching the movie, ranting about the movie, and writing this review. I just could not believe that so many people are saying how great this movie is. Maybe I missed something. Maybe I'm just upset by how much money is wasted in Hollywood. I'm not sure.

What i am sure about, however, is that I will be hanging my head in shame for giving in to my curiosity and actually wasting my time on this movie.

title: Hope you don't get motion sickness...
review:
I didn't see Blair Witch so this was my first time viewing the first person/home video type of shoot and 30 minutes into the movie I was sick to my stomach with all the camera movements and such...I've never even been car or sea sick before.

I'm sorry but short of immediate family I wouldn't try to go back into hell to save someone, especially a girl who I slept with once and came to my party with someone else on her arm. Am I that disconnected with the rest of the world? I kept thinking that they were all stupid and should die just because they didn't take the safer paths when given the chance.

I'm left with more questions than I began with...Where did the monster come from? What happened in the end, did they nuke New York? The monster looked great though; real enough to feel believable yet weird enough to look off-worldly.

The monster was the real reason to suffer through this movie and the 15 minutes of previews prior to the show.

title: Awesome, just awesome!
review: Cloverfield is nothing like your average Hollywood movie. Entirely filmed from the perspective of a (shaky) handy-cam, one would not expect a very visually attractive movie. This movie proves that this assumption would be so damn wrong. The story starts at a yuppie party, but then crap hits the fan. And when I mean crap hits the fan, it really does hit the fan hard. Cloverfield is a very intense movie and the first person view really makes you feel like you are in the middle of something that you would try to avoid in real life. It has been a long time ago that I sat through a movie with clenched fists and my jaw on the floor most of the time, but this movie managed to do so. Nevertheless the movie still has its funny moments, which are timed right, so it does not take away from the tension. I could say much more about this movie, but it is really something you should see for yourself. Get the tickets now!

title: I really wanted to like this
review:
I should preface this by saying that I watch on average about 1 movie a month at the theater, and it takes a LOT for a movie to disappoint me. With that in mind I will proceed.

I went into this with high hopes with "my main dude" who was equally excited. We had seen the trailers and expected to be thrilled. We walked to the movie theater and ended up having a hot chocolate nearby because after all, it is February. Well, we walked into the large theater and took some seats about 1/3 distance away from the screen, not a big deal because it was a very large room. Suffice it to say I was nauseous near the end of the party scene. The camera work was incredibly jerky, and throughout the film I had to cradle my head and close my eyes. I didn't understand it, I'd never experienced anything like this before. I knew that this movie used this type of filming, and it didn't phase me beforehand because I had seen the Blair Witch Project in the theater and I was fine. Through the whole film I kept saying to myself, why? Why do I feel like crap. Eventually I had to leave the theater to go to the restroom and put my head between my legs, it took ten minutes before I could return to the movie. I'm only 30, but I can honestly say while watching this film I felt it aged me a good 20 years.

Within a couple minutes of returning to the theater the dizzying effects began to take it's toll again. I tried to cradle my head and close my eyes to shield from the whirlwind camera work. It didn't work, the emergency lights that went on when they were rescuing the girl were penetrating my eyelids and the high-pitched noise of the alarm were earsplitting and adding to my discomfort rather than alleviating it by closing my eyes. Why did I stay in the theater do you ask? Well, for one I had never experienced something like this before (well maybe at an amusement park after eating loads of food as a child) while being stationary. I also paid a hefty price for the ticket, and I was determined to see this "ride" through. There were some interesting parts, don't get me wrong. This film had some amazing effects, and of course realistic acting. With all that aside, the plot stunk and the motivations of some of the characters were inane. Before seeing this film I did read some posts here and sneered when I read someone trying to discredit this film because I had my heart on seeing it. To be fair my judgment is largely based on the fact that this movie made me sick, plain and simple, and that's a new one on me. It was almost as if the filmmakers were going for a chaotic effect. Almost as if this film was nothing but crazy filming with screaming mobs of hysterical people and bright flashing lights and continuous loud effects, to be fair it IS a monster movie. It's hard to imagine how this film got such a high rating. Although, I can say this throughout the film, when I caught glimpses that didn't cause me to nearly vomit, I was telling myself that maybe this film is too intense for me, that's why people like it. Then I came to a conclusion, this movie was not intense, it was a joke. I was mistaking the hand held camera work for intense realistic drama. However, at the end of the film no answers were given, nothing was learned, and I paid over ten dollars to get sick watching a movie that wasn't even a hour and a half long. In conclusion, I want to warn anyone who got sick watching the Blair Witch Project, you WILL get sick watching this. Even if you have a strong stomach, like I thought I did, do NOT have a huge cup of hot chocolate beforehand as I did, or food in general. Also, sit as far from the screen as possible! On the other hand, maybe I'm just a wimp, and I'm starting to get old, and no one else will be effected as I was, but my "main dude" got just as sick as I did, but that could be the hot chocolate talking. Yes I was disappointed, not in the actors (they did a good job), not the effects (they were spot on), but in the plot and the maniacal camera man, a.k.a. Hud. Most of all, I was disappointed in myself for falling for the hype that this film promised, and more so for allowing myself to get sick.

title: More than just a monster movie.
review: This movie had me mad with excitement. I was hooked from the opening scene. The effects are top notch even by today's standards and it's just an overall great movie.

title: Shaky Cam at its Absolute Best! Thrillingly Realistic SciFi
review:
If you are gonna do shaky cam,This is the way to do it! This was
an absolutely thrilling and truly terrifying ride! Fantastic acting with realism that makes this movie Gripping and very Intense.
The monster ,especially at the end, is heartstopping in size and appearance, Whoa! I normally hate shaky cam stuff for its uaually reserved for movies with lame acting ,no plotline and bad effects but here, this movie takes that concept and makes it work..the effects are top notch and terrifying as is the sound mastering..The roars of the monster, the buildings crashing, metal creaking, the thuds and explosions are superb! Just a Wow! movie that deserves a look by any scifi fan..

title: One of the Crappiest "Found Footage" Movies Ever...
review:
Just watched this for the first time, ever. I wanted to turn it off sooo many times it isn't even funny. I just kept thinking to myself, "maybe it'll get a tiny bit better", but it never did. There have literally been only about 3-4 movies that I have ever stopped watching part way through, and to those I award 1 star. Since I made it all the way through this, I feel compelled to give it 2, but Boy!, was this a piece of junk, in my opinion. I have seen what I think are great movies that are panned up and down, and then there are some like this that got generally good (even great) reviews that I think are total garbage.

The premise was ridiculous: A skyscraper sized bug/frog/spider thing that is impervious to virtually all known weaponry that basically seems to chase a few people from one end of NYC to the other, for no apparent reason that throws around statues' heads for the heck of it and has little parasite/alien/baby things that cause people to explode. The "found footage" was shaky enough to be totally annoying, but not really shaky enough to be believable, at all. Hud(son) used the camera at some of the stupidest moments in history, and his narrative just about drove me as nuts as he was. Him getting eaten at the end was the only redeeming part of this film! The characters were possibly the most mundane, hate-able, stupidest, most unbelievable bunch they could find in a city of 8 million people: They screamed when there was no reason, didn't scream when there was, ran through subway tunnels in shiny high heels, had inane dialogue for supposedly 7 hours, magically healed themselves when they were mortally wounded.

I just can't go on. Yes, I sat through the whole thing, but it was a complete waste of an hour and a half of my life. Aaaagh!

title: It is very bad film that I watched about science-fiction because of exaggeration and not reality.
review: It is very bad film that I watched about science-fiction because of exaggeration and not reality. I do not like watching film which is recorded their own cameras so this film is that. I allocated time this film until it is finished but it is waste of time. Actually I did not watch the film but my teacher make watching obligatory. The camera swings during films and there is a lot of complicated noise. And then, I did not understand for that reason. I felt dizzy during film. I think it is simply subject but the film is nonsense. I criticized very badly and I think this but recording portable cameras are good idea for maker did not spend a lot of money and so portable cameras are in fashion after the film. Actors in the film will die but they somehow die. The film does not consist of dying for not being boring. They always run away from monster and it is formed like that. The film is bad and complicated as visual because of shaking cameras. I did not recommend you watch for I do not like it. You cannot watch the film. If you want to lose time, you will watch the film. Please not lose time for this film.

title: Awful
review: Within ten minutes of the movie the filming and camera angles made me so dizzy I could barley watch anymore, so dizzy that I actually vomited in the movie theater bathroom. At least eight people walked out of the theater after twenty minutes. Besides the horrific style of filming the end left much to be desired, and didn't clear up or explain a single thing. I understand that the style of filming was meant to make you feel like you were there with them and to make it seem more realistic, but the constant shaking and spinning made it impossible to stand, let alone enjoy this film. Don't bother with this one, it's like the Blair witch project meets Godzilla. Overall very very overrated.

title: Eh
review:
I thought the movie was OK, the preview made it look kinda like Blair witch meets war of the worlds....and it was. the camera shaking actually only bothered me when they ran.... i honestly preferred Blair witches story line, but the characters in cloverfield were less annoying. However i thought there were some major plot holes and i felt that they didn't develop the characters enough. I honestly didn't care when anyone died except maybe the camera guy and his crush. And I'm not even sure if thats because of how they died or if its cause i cared.

I thought the idea for the movie was pretty cool but the movie needed a little something

title: If I had a time machine . . .
review:
If I had a time machine I'd go back and make myself not watch this. What a waste of my time. I'm way over the jerky hand-held gimmick but even that wasn't the worst part of this.

Partially it was the constant feeling of being treated like an idiot by this film. From the camera surviving a nuke, to the cliché lines, the statue of liberty surviving being used as a bowling ball by a monster, a helicopter crashing and only the main characters surviving (of course the soldiers die and the idiots survive?), other stupid gimmicks.

But most of all it was like this movie has no point. Plot is non- existent. Normal disaster movies you get a happy ending with 'humanity working together' and a feel good ride off into the sunset after enjoying some fun special effects. Occasionally you got a scary one which impresses how fragile humans are, blah blah blah. This one? Neither. Everyone dies but you don't really care. The special effects can't be enjoyed because of the nausea inducing filming style, and there is no happy ending.

title: An Aggravating Mix of: "Blair Witch", "The View", & "kraken"
review:
This ?Film? was annoying from the start...

I guess the yuppies couldn't afford a camcorder with Image Stabilization. The entire movie is so shaky it's like "Blair Witch" on METH or in DT's! Meanwhile, I felt as if I was listening to a really bad episode of "The View" with everyone bickering, venting, and- of course- all talking at once! Yikes! The movie is so bad from the beginning that within 15 minutes I was praying that they would at least throw in a storyline about/developing the "Creature"- no such luck.

The movie "idea" had/has rather good potential; unfortunately all is squandered here. It is as if the film makers set out with the idea of "How can we make this film so as to sabotage any chance of it living up to it's real potential"!

title: New kind of a Blair Witch Project
review:
They covered up what this movie is all about very cleverly with its title "Cloverfield". No one would have a clue about what the movie is about from its title. If they did, this movie would have not attracted many audiences. There's really nothing special about this movie in essence. It's a cross between the original Godzilla (creature from the ocean depth), Alien, and Blair Witch Project where the entire movie runs through a video camera of one of the characters.

The plot connects the lives of ordinary young people with the total destruction of Manhattan, which is type of plot that became common in the beginning of the decade first in manga (Japanese comics), where relationship between an ordinary boy and a girl suddenly connects directly with the destruction of the world. Destruction of the world in this case is not the main theme - the relation of the couple who's involved in it is. You can see this clearly if you watch "Saikano" together with this movie. It's my personal taste but taking one's self importance so seriously somehow does not appeal to me. If you take away the connection between the characters personal involvement, which to me is just that - there's nothing that relates back to the audience. The monsters and the special effects are cliché, the production is average, and view point annoying. I couldn't figure out what the point of this movie was all about watching through a very limited visuals of a video camera, all the way to the final non-ending of the movie. The entire movie is about one young guy's video of himself.

So, if you've been intrigued by the title and the nice sci-fi like picture on the box, my recommendation is just leave it at that. The content isn't worth the $$.

title: Realism?
review:
The main problem in the movie is the inconsistency between the technique and the story.

The movie promises an unconventional point of view, and it clearly claims, that it will look as if it was not filtered in any way by the film makers, and this is NOT EASY! OK now, in my opinion this requires a lot more intelligence and mental agility for everyone too keep everything in tact to still keep it a film yet make it raw footage of a disaster. Leaving all the logical flaws throughout the story aside, the film constantly reminds you that the director is still holding onto what he really wants to see. Just the beginning seems a little random, but still almost everything is for the sake of telling the story, there are very rare coincidental things that are recorded(what otherwise might be considered as a waste of time but adds to the reality) That for me is a problem, since the film is claiming to be absolutely natural, I want those random characters and scenes. (They are clearly built up as supposedly random and generic people, but when the action starts, they turn into classic heroes with super-fortified-nerves) The biggest disappointment is the inexplicably unnatural reactions of the characters. Lily is the most obvious example. She is clearly neurotic and unsettled even in a party environment. OK lets say that she likes responsibility and is an organized type of person and that particular party is quite important for her, but how come the monster gets to comfort her? She looks more relaxed after the party is completely ruined and the monster actions emerges.

OK Hud is supposedly stupid, and rob is the hero type situation. There you go... Two classic characters, which battles against the realism that the film promises. They simply are too resilient to be natural human beings. I can not possibly relate to anyone of these characters simply because THIS IS NOT SUPPOSED TO BE VIEWED AS CLEAR-CUT FICTION. I refuse to accept any artistic distortions (which is not there to begin with, they are hanging loosely to the title of characters) of these fabricated characters.

I could be with them all the way, I could feel bad for them, I could value their lives, I could be scared for them, I could relate to their demise, I could feel sad for their losses. If only, they didn't take absolutely the most unrealistic path in their adventure. Even in the end when they were recording themselves reporting their names and such, I felt "No, come on, you're not going to die, you're just pretending you lousy actors" This technique (I mean the shaky hand camera thingie) could be taken advantage of thousand times better than it is in this film.

All in all, I wasn't really expecting much, and I didn't get much. It wasn't a complete unwatchable film but gradually it drives you away from the characters and the story emotionally and mentally.

title: Just a Trash movie with too big a budget.
review:
I got motion sickness because of the constantly moving and always zooming camera that seldom got the focus right.

So maybe that's why I even found the widely acclaimed special effects of explosions, little and big monsters cheesy and cheap. But with such a badly focused camera who could tell?

There are some good things in this flick:

First, the sound effects are really great some times and second:

Most of the main characters die! I really was happy and relieved when the guy with the camera died. But however the camera survived and the sickness went on, but luckily only for a few pathetic moments, just to hear the two other characters die while saying: "Look at me! Look at me! I love you! Uarghffff!"

The acting was decent, but I never got attached to the characters. So it was not that bad. It is fairly fast paced, so I seldom got bored (but I got annoyed towards the end).

85 minutes are enough for a sickening motion picture with little to no story and lots of illogical elements. It leaves quite everything related to the monster unexplained.

But then "King Kong" (1933) and "The Lost World" (1925) really are masterpieces and "Cloverfield" (2008) is just a Trash movie with a too big budget.

title: Don't see it.
review:
Sure, Manhattan has its share of young party-goers, but now we know all New Yorkers are in their 20s, allowing a photogenic cast (whose characters lead boring lives and are annoying enough to have you hoping they die deaths that are as excruciatingly painful as their farewell party -- an exercise in human drabness -- that the film opened with). And to add to the torture: yuppies using colloquialisms that left the ghetto decades ago. So, sorry, director, the intentional over-lameness backfired severely.

Jason's nicely-complected girlfriend Lisa takes the Looks honors but the only skin shots we get are of her legs, with contrasting white high-heels that she sports in half the movie.

It's conceivable that this would be truly terrifying to post-9/11 New Yorkers; that there would be real suspense in the initial possibility that whatever this was, it was caused by terrorists who might follow with other forms of attack. I'd left the room four times during the "party," and after the first explosion, we thought this was going to be a killer movie. Until we saw how mundane the terrorist actually was -- a huge crustacean that spits meteors and sheds man-eating cockroaches.

Some of the sounds added to the film's terror and scariness, like the first attack explosions, the weird baby monster sounds, and the mother monster's bellowing, anguished King Kongish sounds.

The messianic alpha-male hero Rob was peppered throughout the movie with inane questions by his friends who find it so difficult to see or think for themselves, it's no wonder they haven't been invited to be non-Japanese-speaking 24-year-old American VPs in Japan, like Rob. Amazing is the lemming-like behavior that compels them first to try to walk in the dead of night across the bridge (at the urging of authorities -- a 9/11 slam) into Brooklyn whose residents would no doubt welcome a team of Manhattan yuppies with open arms, until Mama Monster attacks the bridge. They then follow Rob back through swarming subway rats and baby monsters, past evacuees going in the opposite direction as fast as they can, to Ground Zero where the monster thrashes skyscrapers, so they can climb across crumbling roofs of skyscrapers leaning at dangerous angles, just to rescue Rob's girlfriend, lovely Beth, who's able to skedaddle just fine -- what's a little impalement?

But the badge of courage goes to the Marlena (Lizzy Caplan) who in a toasted state can swing an ax like A-rod and knocks a monster off Rob's back -- in the process having three-inch chunks of skin removed from her torso by another monster. She unflinchingly applies dressings to them (we all know how easy it is to find clean paper towels and bottled water in subway tunnels!), only asking if the wounds look unattractive. She stoically toughs it out through exposed wounds and dizzy spells until she perishes in a glorious explosion of her own blood.

The DVD's Features reveal Caplan to be brighter and much wittier than the others. She was nominated for a Supporting Actress award. Some of her acting is kind of cool and she seems the only one to portray the depths of their fear and utter despondency, as they rest in the subway with the hope starting to drain out of them. Marlena uses facial expressions well. Hud, trying to hit on her, gets superb disinterested expressions from her. During a lull in the film's questionable dialog, the effects of the sustained assault on the senses and fatigue from the raw terror are spoken in one glazed look at Hud.

But no one seems to have the chance to build on her acting. Some of the improv from Hud, who fashions himself a comedian in real life, was distinctly unfunny, and I wonder if this wasn't the film's worst setback. If his character's intent was to annoy, it succeeded.

The hand-held cam shots are overdone to the point of ridiculousness. This loses the desired realism. It makes a lot of people nauseous and dizzy, or, in my case, caused me to focus just on the DVD subtitles or close my eyes. Even the classic Bourne films used "hand-helds," but judiciously and tastefully. And mostly on shots that couldn't be taken otherwise. Without the shaky video I would have given this film a 4 -- it IS a monster movie. Without the party, a 5.

It's hard to pull off the concept of "the medium is part of the message" without boring, so we could have had much less of the videotaping parts. Hud, the one doing the taping, could have sounded less like a ten-year-old.

But the flashback playback of the videotape being made over an old tape of Rob and Beth DID sort of work. This allows us glimpses of parts that hadn't been completely taped over while watching the movie itself during the military's "presentation" of the recovered tape (whose magnetic domains are immune to NEMP). The last flashback completed the depiction of the once-sweet but shallow relationship between Rob and Beth, and was the vehicle to the film's ending, where, juxtaposed after Rob saying, "If you're seeing this I'm dead," is Beth at Coney Island the month previous, full of life, and saying ironically, "I had a good day."

What the film lacked was dialog, screenplay, suspense, real emotion, and character and relational development. Cheers for the shots of military action and first responders which looked fairly credible. Pretty decent CGI rats or fake human legs because I don't think the actors would have supported those fat, real ones running between their legs. The plot was only mildly interesting -- trying to flee Manhattan, rescuing Beth, then trying to leave again.

FYI, if one can't take hand-held action found in films a refund is normally available at theaters only within the first few minutes of the film.

title: this is the worst movie I have ever seen
review: This is quite possibly the most stupid, annoying film ever made. The main character is a 20-something idiot who carries his hand-held camera around while a giant monster attacks New York City. The whole film is shot through the main character's camera and it is every bit as nauseating as you can imagine. In addition to the amateur cinematography we have the added bonus of hearing, "Oh my God!" every ten seconds or so. At least the filmmaker was smart enough to be the first one to comment on this movie, as anyone else who actually saw it would say that it's terrible. Apparently the viral marketing has worked, though, because it's making a ton of money.

title: Horrible waste of money, audience was irritated
review:
This movies was advertised on every local radio station, especially the opening day, showing the remarkable amount of money that was spent on advertising.

It was tooted as a different movie, both in plot and in cinematic's.

Unfortunately what was suppose to be a good movie ended up being a waste of time, even if offered for free.

I sat through the first 40 Min's, nothing at all is happening and the plot is about absolutely nothing. I was so bored I kept closing my eyes hoping that the creature that was suppose to be in this film would attack the movie theater and kill me.

I thought about leaving many times.

The camera angles were wrong. At times the person (HUD) was suppose to be holding the camera to his head was obviously holding it off to the side. It was too shaky, not at all realistic for normal operation, but the reason for this shakiness was obvious later in the film.

At around the 40 min mark, after watching a film about nothing important or interesting, the creature attacked. The footage of the beast was roughly 2 Min's, followed buy another 15 Min's of nothing at all. This basically continues until the end. We see a pattern of trying to minimize shots of the beast and maximize scenes of drab boring and immensely irritating conversations about what to do next.

Many times I felt as if someone was hitting my head with a rubber mallet. I was immensely annoyed.

Everything, except for the 10 Min's in total you see the beast, was horrible. The plot, were this small posse of intellectual effluent's with their sidekick drunk HUD are trying to rescue this woman that one of the guys slept with ONCE and apparently is in love with (please keep the damn love stories out of action films!) is just too much to bear.

To sum it up.

Cheap film, cheap acting, cheap actors, bad plot. Shaking camera to allow for lower resolution animations and add excitement by making it feel like something is happening. bad beginning, bad ending. horrible!

At the end of the film there was almost complete silence, except for a few people complaining out loud and one man who actually yelled he wanted his money back to the cheer of many in the crowd.

Just like the Blair witch project, bad film with a lot of hype, hoping for the first week to bring in enough money from the 18-24 group before word of mouth spreads that this movie is more boring than taking a rubber chicken for a walk.

Keep your money for something worth while.

title: Oh my GOD it has Skintainium armor!!!
review:
Cloverfield provides mild entertainment but the movie totally ignores the hindrances of the laws of physics, has several discontinuities, and uses several old clichés including some from our good friend the Blair Witch Project.

In the opening scene of action a earthquake rattles Manhattan and everyone at a party runs to the roof after finding out that a oil tanker wrecked near the statue of liberty (cause tipping a oil tanker or ripping one apart while swimming apparently can generate a massive earthquake).

Then the explosion (as seen in trailer) flings flaming debris around the city (cause oil is extremely explosive and oil tankers apparently explode violently just like LPG tankers).

Later the monster is seen by news cameras on the ground with military personnel (who responded in less than 10 minutes) dropping spawns or something that were about human sized and began attacking people (remember this it is important).

After a little walking we randomly stumble upon the monster and the military erupting in a gigantic gunfight. Two different classes of vehicles engage the giant man-whale-squid (monster). The lovable M1A2 Abrams (tank) which fires a 120mm smooth-bore DU armor penetrating sabot at several thousand meters per second (fast) and is capable of lighting up a Russian tank like a Christmas tree (explode) and the M270 MLRS (rocket launcher) whose 12 missiles are each capable of wiping out a football field. Both apparently are no match for the might of man-whale-squids skintainium armor.

Next we discover that the man-whale-squid spawns can be easily destroyed by any convenient blunt object (despite originating from the impervious skintainium monster). We also discover that the bite of a spawn eventually leads to explosive hemorrhaging such as a cheesy films version of being thrown out into space or getting un-pressurized in a pressure vessel in a bond flick.

After some cheesiness we see that man-whale-squid is engaged by aircraft including the F/A-18 Hornet, UH-1 Huey, and B-2 bomber. All three of which prove ineffective with their mavericks, FFARs, dumb bombs and bunker busters against the mighty skintainium armor despite such a volley utterly leveling the great Godzilla (1998).

Finally the military resorts to for some reason strategically nuking the entire island of Manhattan and ends the flick in a poor rendition of how a nuclear blast would have occurred.

So if watching a movie involving the destruction of New York on a shaky first person camera (apparently super high def and impervious to monsters and helicopter crashes) reminiscent of previous flicks and showing a complete disregard for what metal, concussions, and fire do to flesh is your idea of a good time then Cloverfield is for you. For the rest of us just imagine a man-whale-squid crashing through Manhattan being shot at and a man pitted against all odds to try to be with some chick you pretty much got the movie down.

title: Cloverfield Delivers in a MONSTER Way
review:
The first time I saw Cloverfield was when it was first unveiled, at the early showings of Transformers. Everyone in the sold out theater was buzzing after what was truly to be a know-nothing film. Not only that, but it created a MAJOR buzz throughout the WORLD. Rumors were flying everywhere, no truths were handed out.

I was immediately hooked to the movie. A longtime fan of J.J. Abrams, I knew that seeing his name attached to such a mysterious project meant only one thing: drama. And a sh*tload of it.

After seeing Transformers, I went home and got to work on unraveling what Cloverfield could be about. I knew I wouldn't get far, as Abrams tends to NOT lean movie-goers to ANYTHING helpful. Sure, the rumors out there were really juicy, but it took 2 weeks for anything big to happen.

I say all this background because not only does it set up the ENTIRE film, but it also allows for ANYTHING to happen. Nobody knew anything about the film, except that it was directed as if a New Yorker was experiencing it.

And let me tell you. It worked. Big time. Not only did it add to the drama, but you were actually participating in the movie. It added a level of realism to the story that I don't think has ever been achieved otherwise.

And the monster: FANTASTIC. Without ruining too much for you, and actually not at all, but forget everything you knew about this movie. It won't help you. Even if you've seen footage of the film, you were severely mislead. The characters are freakin REAL. This actually happened...and you were there.

This bad guy kicks ass all over the place. Think Godzilla, but for the awesome ass-kicking age we live in now. Action is fast-paced, and whatever Hud(the "director", and/or the one with the camera) sees you see. That includes falling down, personal feelings over monster action, and huge physical jerks from the unknown creature.

In closing, because this review is getting to be a bit lengthy, GO SEE THIS MOVIE. It brings a new feeling and emotion to the big screen, and if you aren't quick enough, you might miss the biggest thing to come out of Manhattan since King Kong.

title: Why do Americans feel the need for stupid, totally unrealistic disaster movies?
review:
Is it politics? Is it psychology? Is it sociology? I have no idea.

This film, at 1 hour and 15 minutes, is far, far too long. My friend who likes 'big' films made me go and see it. The story is about a giant alien thing being terribly frightening and even harmful, sometimes fatally so, to many, many people in New York. No explanation for this unfortunate event is given. The film is filmed on hand-held camera in order to capture the 'gritty realism' of said creature's destructive rampage.

And I feel I must share with the unsuspecting world out there the disgrace that is this awful - terribly awful - film.

The actors are abysmal (in fact, contrary to what I suspect I was meant to feel I actually wanted them all to die within 15 minutes of the start of the film they were so annoying). This is basically a teen flick, monster movie, stealing ideas from reality and fantasy and mixing them together - 9/11 vs Godzilla meets College Frat Party vs Alien.

I may have changed my mind had the acting been better but by God it was pathetic.

Firstly, the point of this film. Why? Why do Americans feel the need for this kind of movie, a film where they are destroyed by a superior external force? Simple, because it's reverse psychology because America has become so powerful it has no fear of anything real, which is why fear manifests itself internally in the psyche, and it's so bloody common and re-occurring, this theme, I suspect it's become pretty close to a whole new cultural archetype for the 21st century. Why, after all, for a country that's got everything, do so many people feel the 'need' for shrinks? Rhetorical question obviously.

So, here we are. Another disaster movie from, guess which country? Yes, America. 10 out of 10, you got it.

I was going to start this sentence saying, it's funny how this is the same country which had 9/11 and still they do this. But it's actually sad. A country so far removed from reality that it makes films inspired by real experiences to try and make them actual again so they can try and try and really try and re-live them in fantasy, 'World Trade Center' for example. Then they release this saying it's a reference to 9/11. Pull the other one. They want danger, they want death. Anything to pluck at what's left of a heart and make them feel alive. A strange sort of death wish.

Yet, in the face of the utter disaster happening on-screen, friends dying and so on, the main kid in this piece of celluloid garbage, after he and his dwindling group have gone 14 miles in tunnels underground and the group all collapses with exhaustion, this boy suddenly heroically states: "you don't need to come, I'll go on alone" (boo hoo). Come on you idiot, you've lost friends, the ones still alive aren't doing too good either and, for goodness sake, they aren't exactly going to turn back now are they? And besides, they'll probably wonder, after all you've been through, why suddenly you've reverted to being your usual insecure self ("what? Really? You want to come WITH me?") mixed with some new-found, Sir Galahad style bravado.....Anyhow, the surviving kids say "No (pant, pant, puff, puff)..we..we....we're comin' with ya". And get this, idiot boy says "ARE YA SURE?". Oh for crying out loud. Does he really need to repeat it? Of COURSE he's bloody sure. NOW is not the time for this sort of nonsense. I despair. I mean, if there's a time not to be paranoid, insecure, or selfishly acting the noble martyr it's now! DEAL with it! Idiot.

Oh and it's all been supposedly shot on hand-held camera. This starts of fairly plausible when being used at a party at the beginning (and for a few more minutes thereafter). But when they get lost in the dark and a fairly powerful torch type light comes on and beams ahead so they can see where they're going I realise this is an expensive piece of equipment these kids have got. And when the infra red, night vision lens came on that really blew me away and told me what we were dealing with here. It starts with B, it ends in T and it has the letters ULLSHI in the middle of it.

And another thing, when your best pal gets her leg blown off and you've all just crash landed in a helicopter and survived, since when do you hobble off and then suddenly realise you better turn back to pick up your camera and keep filming? Ah yes, I know, it's when you're completely detached from reality, that's when. When you can't tell the difference between a film and reality any more.

But OK, aside from that, I need to briefly go back into the whole basis of the film again.

Yup, it's the good ol' American Death Wish.

Let's sum it up: Spent too much time in Disneyland? Well come try the death experience in your own living room - 'grab' a coke while you're at it. Slurp it down and taste that bitter-sweet taste and if you don't do it yourself then hope somebody puts you out your misery.

Or wait until Part 2, maybe that'll help?

title: Cloverfield was Cool!
review:
A few caveats. I'm not a monster-movie person. I didn't even know what Cloverfield was. I didn't know that they had played an advance trailer at Transformer screenings (didn't see Transformers). I didn't know that all the secrecy combined with the street credibility of J. J. Abrams had turned the whole thing into an "event". And I really, really hate movies that make me nauseous with their shaky hand-held camera action (How 'bout a tripod, Paul Greengrass?). That said, my husband told me to show up at 7pm and I did since I'm always up for a free movie and especially for something that is an advance screening (I feel like I am in the cool-kids-club!).

Turns out that I really liked this movie! Uncomfortable chair, small screen and bad audio aside (it was a university lecture hall), I was on the edge of my seat the entire time and didn't relax even after getting home. So what makes this film different? The home/hand held video taping made me feel like I was running around New York City in the dark with the characters (and oddly, I wasn't nauseous!). The characters, mostly unknown actors, seemed like real people I might know or meet at a party and were truly genuine in their fear and their decision-making (i.e., not Drew Barrymore answering the phone). Going down into the subway was a little suspect, but given the action on the streets, I may have made the same decision. I came to like the characters - mostly Hud - and could even stomach the romantic back story. I really wanted them to make it out alive(though not sure where they'd go, Maplewood, New Jersey?). I didn't get a clear view of the monster until late in the movie which kept my attention. The human-sized spider/crab monsters that seemingly rolled off the mama-monster (must be a "she", was pretty angry) were totally creepy and also mysterious. All good stuff.

Just a few things that I question but all are minor. First, how could Lily run around escaping a monster in high heels? Second, how is it that only Marlena was bitten by the mini-monster in the subway (and what happened to her, by the way?) And third, did Hud have a super-duper camera battery? With all the night focusing, that thing should have died long before all the characters did.

After Jason died on the bridge pretty early on, I knew it was a different kind of movie (the anti-Lost, things actually are happening!) and as the characters were killed off one by one, I started to ponder how it was all going to end. And then it did just that, it abruptly ended! I'm usually a guy-gets-girl-happy-ending-closure-type gal and this was definitely not that. So we'll never know what the monster was or what ended up happening to it or New York City or why Cloverfied is formerly Central Park. But I remain one non-monster-movie fan who liked this one. I'm even contemplating taking in a matinée 2nd viewing! Go check it out!

title: A Really bad movie
review: At the end of the movie, i ask myself if it was a joke, the little monsters that attack the people looks very artificial even when their camera appearance is poor, the monster Cloverfield (the big one) looks like a turtle without shell and the effects are too basic not the expensive ones, another thing is with so much explosions, car wrench, destroyed buildings there is no dead people, come on, in twin towers movie are much more hurt people than this movie, it really waste of time see this movie, looks more a combination of Godzilla and Blair Witch Project, even in Blair Witch Project you know what happens, in this movie you try to understand but nothing is clear, the central theme of the movie is the guy that want to say "i love you" to her friend, if the trailer movie was a little more images of the film i think much more on seeing it or not

title: Very original take on the classic monster movie.
review:
Cloverfield in my opinion was excellent. I had been following a bit of the hype and viral marketing that went along with the film and was excited about seeing it.

I just saw the first screening here in NZ and again it was great. The way the movie is all shot with hand held was really cool and made the film really visceral and real. I know people were moaning a bit about the shaky camera, but I actually found myself questioning it in parts because it wasn't shaky enough. The whole thing really worked.

I was a little skeptical about it being a J.J. Abrams production however, as he annoyed me with Lost and never answering questions and replacing them with new ones etc. But there was sufficient info given in the movie as to not feel like you were left severely hanging at the end. There are questions left unanswered which is understandable considering it is just these peoples video account.

The monster was pretty cool and you get to see pretty much the entire thing throughout the film. It also carries some scary cargo which it drops all over the place that make for a tense subway run. All in all I was pretty satisfied with the monster, except for its apparent invulnerability.

Because it was a movie it did have to have a bit of a story and it mostly revolves around the relationship between Rob and his long time friend, recently love interest, Beth. This part was what made me drop this to a 9 and not a 10. It was a little corny that this guy would risk his life and the lives of his friends to go back into the city where a giant monster is, to save his girlfriend who is almost certainly dead anyway. It didn't make a lot of sense and I don't think people can relate to it, I know I really couldn't. I did on many occasions just think "why aren't they getting the hell out of the city?" or "what the hell is he thinking?!". This was my feeling mainly when he decides to go inside Beth's apartment building which has collapsed onto another one, you'll see...

However leaving the main story behind and focusing on the rest of the film it is an awesome ride and a very original monster film. It warrants another watch for the experience of being there all over again. I doubt a sequel will follow however it would be nice to have it wrapped up in a nice neat little package, but I imagine that will spoil the feel of the film.

Although not for everyone (especially those with severe motion sickness), Cloverfield lives up to the hype and is a fabulous way to spend $15. Definitely a must see among the recent releases lately.

title: A Sci-fi lite pop culture garbage
review:
Don't get me wrong - the movie is well made, it's just that 2 hours of Tim Allen scratching the paint off a radiator with a knitting-needle would have been more entertaining than this non-event.

  • and I watched it on the above recommendations - omg.....


1.The cast participate passively in the movies storyline.

2.The plot can be summarised in very few words.

3.The movie has too many mobile phones in it.

4.Even when something exciting happens it is followed by 20 minutes of soap opera Frankly the episodes of Buffy which the writer of this movie once wrote were vastly superior.

Even Under Siege 2 which was one of the directors earlier efforts is a roller-coaster of high adrenaline thrills.

-----SPOILER---- (like you can give much away in a movie like this)

If you're broke and cannot afford this movie, simply splice the last 10 minutes of Ghostbusters with 2 hours of Dawsons Creek and then watch the result in the reflection of a hand mirror and that should give you the same jollies....

title: P.T. Barnum was right!
review:
Don't read this review if you don't like spoilers!!!!!!

When you go to a monster movie, there are a few things you kind of take for granted will be in it.

Like a monster.

"Cloverfield", which I felt was more of a college cinema project, i.e., make a film that shot completely in the first person, follows four New Yorkers and their situations as they try to escape a skyscraper-sized monster. There are many suspensions of disbelief that you are expected to accept. Like how a single video camera can shoot the events of an entire day on one tape (or SD disk, as they explain in the beginning), and on a single charge. I own a video camera, and it conks out after one hour! Our four spunky heroes, navigate through the streets of Manhattan, occasionally catching a glimpse of the monster. They see exploding buildings from afar. They see cars flying through the air. And once, you actually saw a giant claw stomp on some brave little soldiers. But all in all, the 90-minute movie gives the main attraction of the movie (no, not the unbelievably hot women in the movie), a total of 90 seconds of screen time! Even Brando in "Apocalypse Now" had more screen time. Last but not least, with a monster movie, you kind of expect the standard Hollywood Ending, where the monster is vanquished and humanity triumphs.

THERE WAS NO ENDING!!!!!!

The movie just ended. phht!

P.T Barnum once said, "There's a sucker born every minute." In this case, if you package a piece of crap in a pretty enough package and show everyone the pretty box, everybody will want that wonderfully packaged crap. So, if you like video games, especially first-person shooters, then this is the movie for you. Everybody else:

Avoid the box.

title: Monsters movie in which a camera manages to shoot the frightening events that spontaneously happen
review:
When some New Yorkers are celebrating a leaving party the ground starts to shake , with blowing up happening anywhere . They decide to abandon the flat when a monster terrorizes the Great Apple , breaking buildings , and every to get in its ways. Various characters cross paths with the giant beast, and they attempt to escape along with a young carrying a hand-held video camera.

This eerie tale is plenty of thrills, chills, restless horror and suspense . Film itself takes place from point of sight of a cameraman , with camera over shoulders , displaying a documentary style filmed by photographer Michael Bonvilliam . In fact , during the first weekend of the release, many theaters posted signs warning guests that the hand held camera movements may cause motion sickness . The title "Cloverfield"; initially just a codename for the movie, is named for the boulevard in Santa Monica where the Bad Robot offices were located during the making of the film . Good but unknown cast as Michael Sthal , Jessica Lucas, Odette Yusman , Michael Vogel, among others . Well worth watching if you appeal shaky cameras , such as : ¨Blair witch project¨, ¨28 days/ Weeks after¨ or the classic Italian ¨Holocaust cannibal¨; and recently ¨Rec (2007)¨ by Paco Plaza and Jaume Balaguero and its American remake ¨Quarintine (2008)¨ by John Erik . The flick is a crossover between Gozilla picture , catastrophe genre and documentary with Steadicam camera . Lavishly produced by J.J.Abrams (Lost, Star Trek) and Bryan Burk with excellent special effects and monsters made by Phill Tippet studio . The motion picture picture was professionally directed by Matt Reeves . He's a writer, producer (Yards) and director for television (Felicity) and eventually for cinema ; furthermore , usual collaborator of J.J. Abrams . Rating : Interesing and spectacular , above average.

title: Sooo bad
review: I enjoy going to the cinema without knowing what to expect. Every time that I didn't watch a trailer first -which contains all the main parts of the movie nowadays- I was glad. This time I wish I had watched a trailer for THIS one or even asked someone about it. I never regretted going to see a movie in the cinema as much as I regret watching this one. I'm not a sissy, but this is the FIRST movie -that I watched in the cinema, that I didn't watch until the end! After 10 minutes -minimum- I started getting all dizzy because ALL the movie is filmed by a hand camera. It's much worse than Blair Witch Project, the guy doesn't seem to be able to hold the cam steady for just 5 seconds. At first I hoped that the style would change. After a while I hoped that the guy holding the camera would die... I left the cinema 15 Minutes ago and I still feel sick, what a damn movie! I seriously regret getting out of the house and paying 7 Eur for something like that...

title: So bad it made people sick
review:
I think this is the first movie I've been too where there were several people who left the cinema while it was showing sick and disorientated. I had to leave myself I was getting that bad a head ache, one girl was throwing up in the bathroom and several people where so disorientated from all the really bad camera work that they couldn't walk straight for several minutes.

The Monster: You barely see it. Asides from the one shot before Camera Guy gets it, it's either far away or the camera zooms past so fast you can barely figure out what you're looking at. The whole movie was basically a Godzilla movie with out the interest.

Tiny Spider Monsters: These just screamed "Alien" to me. As soon as I saw Malena bitten I knew exactly what was going to happen to her. The way they moved, even their basic design to degree was basically just a rip off.

Plot: if you could call it that. It tried to be too suspenseful but ended up puzzling in a "oooookay, what was that all about?" way. Maleena again with the bite. We never really see what comes out of her, is it just another spider-monster or is it some other creature that is incubated in the human victims? Not only that but it moved so damn quick from them screaming "BITE!" to carting off Marlena to the burst to Rob and co being dragged off else where.

Military: Basically the whole point seemed to be for them to make the refugee camp, arrange for the choppers and for one guy in particular to tell them that there was nothing they could do for their friend.

I saw the ads for this movie and really wanted to go see it, but ended up getting more out of the ads than the movie itself.

title: Frame Your Expectations Appropriately, Or Dismiss Them Entirely.
review:
Cloverfield (2008).

  • Chipper F. Xavier, Esq.


After its shocking release 10 years prior, a repeat viewing of Cloverfield still manages to disgust and terrify. Unfortunately, many viewers do not recognize its genius. Imagine going to a famously hip New York nightclub on a Saturday evening and being shocked that there are heavy, 808-styled drumbeats interspersed throughout the catchy-but-vacuous lyrics as half-drunk people madly carouse about the parquet dance floor. A reasonable person would argue that you should have known what to expect. An open-minded person might even say, "... heck, that was different!" But only a 'hater' would exclaim: "That sucked!"

Cloverfield, directed by Matt Reeves, written by Drew Goddard and produced by J.J. Abrams, is a shaky-camera, found footage horror film which begs the question: What would happen if a gigantic, intelligent, malevolent alien monster attacked New York City? In order to properly frame this fantastical event, the director filmed the movie using a hand-held camera to establish a sense of timely realism and cast relative unknowns as protagonists to force the audience to focus on what was happening within the camera frame. The result is partly unique, partly hilarious, very unexpected and 100% terrifying... But only if you, the viewer, allow a willing suspension of disbelief.

Cloverfield works well because the field of view is grounded by normal twenty-somethings attending a going away party for a friend, brother and paramour, as viewed behind the lens of a handicam. When this banal celebration is interrupted by the surreal experience of unnatural disasters in a population-dense New York City, the fear is amplified and very real as the audience is taken along for a very bumpy ride.

Some of the more original OMG-worthy moments include: 1) The head of the Statue Of Liberty flying through the air to land at the fleeing feet of pedestrians; 2) The giant, rampaging monster disgorging smaller babies from its body that fall to the ground and immediately begin attacking people; 3) The giant, rampaging monster carefully considering the cameraman before ruthlessly biting him in half.

You don't have to like roller-coasters, haunted houses or Santa Claus to enjoy a good horror flick - but you are probably in the minority of the human population if you don't. Escapism only works if you give it permission - or else, you'll always be that person wondering why everyone but you is having such a great time.

title: what a great movie
review: okay, my dad came home from work the other day with four new DVD's, I legend, Alien vs predator,American gangster and clover field. We put on clover field, As being a thriller fan i was drawn right in it was great how the characters were introduced, and how you could go through there life without noticing that they were acting, Sure the start went for to long but it built up to a great story. I was so surprised when they just got attacked and i never saw it coming. It was just so good how the filming Made you feel like you were in the same place as they were and had you at the edge of your seats, Unlike my dad i loved the film and it kept me entertained for the whole 80 Mins i reckon it has to be one of the greatest thriller film ever!

title: Is it over? As I'm still waiting for it to start!
review:
For a start i have to say that i am still waiting for it to start! i feel as if i have paid £5.60 (with my discount, should be £7.20) to see Eastenders (UK Drama)!

My local cinema said it was on for 1:45 (hour/s) and to my disappointment it was on for 1:10 (hour/s) only to have 35 minutes of ads!

So then to the film, watching the ad on the T.V for this film i was ready to see a action packed film with everything to just wow me, but when you find out that its all them films you watched 10 years ago mixed into one you kinda feel...cheated? I mean i remember watching Godzilla at a friends birthday party at the age of 9 and it was so great and this film WOULD be great if i was 9 again but I'm not and every one else in the cinema was not 9. The beginning of the film at the party just dragged it self out so long, i wanted to go to sleep! When the part of the film when the woman gets bitten by one of the "star ship troopers alien lookalikes", she kinda acts like she has not been bitten at all and just walks away after a very fast patch up. Also the woman who had been impaled in that apartment, she recovered very fast for someone who had a metal pole pushed through her inches away from the heart!

JUST Don't WASTE GOOD MONEY ON THIS FILM AND WAIT TILL ITS ON FREE T.V Don't EVEN WATCH IT ON SKY, YOU HAVE TO PAY FOR SKY YOU KNOW.

title: Worst movie, lost money
review: Well, where do I start. The movie starts with a party, okay, that is setting up the stage for the characters. Hmm, but completely irrelevant to the movie! Sucks! Images are blurry, unsteady and often pointed to the ground. Most of the time you get a pain in the neck to compensate the tilted image, so that is yucky sucky too. The monster is only a side-kick, not relevant for the movie. If you would not see it at all (you do see it for about 1 minute in the whole movie), you would not miss it. Where does it come from, why did it appear, what is thriving it... no idea, sucko again. The characters in the movie are heroes or completely stupid. For sure the latter. Any sane man, would run to safety, but no, they return to ground zero and deny any offering of safety. Mr Stupid with the cam has nothing better to do then filming, well yes, everyone would do that! again sucking. Then there are more questionable situations, which are conflicting with any logic, but okay, it is a movie, not reality. Then the end, surely, there will be a sequel, but I am afraid I will not see it, for my appetite was lost within minutes of this movie. The whole audience were not amused about the movie, so I cannot understand the ratings. Even without the hype, it would have created too high an expectancy. JJ Adams completely failed with this movie (Even Reign of fire was better, with lots more monster-shots and action). Too bad, it could have been much better. It had potential. As I do appreciate good movies, this one is rated that low, as a first-timer!

title: Not Intense- boring and pointless
review: I went to this movie because everyone told me how great it was one of the intense movies ever made. There was nothing intense about this movie. The plot was razor thing. Man saves girlfriend while NYC is being evacuated. Where were all the dead bodies? They enter all these buildings but there is nobody dead or alive in them. Near the end the helicoptors are "waiting for them" - to evacuate the city. It took FEMA 5 days to get water to the Superdome but they can evacuate NYC in less then 7 hours when it's under alien attack! Sure! The opening party scene was just dull and not funny or entertaining.. The only good thing about this movie is that it's less than 90 minutes or torture. Not worth wasting your time.

title: Young Hollywood's take on the Monster Genre
review:
My topic alone should tell you straight away if you're going to enjoy this movie or not. There is a group of people who actually enjoy Young Hollywood and their movies, and then there are people, like myself who can't f@ckin stand 90% of the sh!t they feed us. I suppose you can guess from this last sentence what I thought of this movie. There are people in the middle ground where they tend to enjoy Y.Hollywood's flicks more or less, but I'd be the first to shake my head at their tastes....though with an open ear.

Anyways, about the movie. The story is, as you know, found footage of a group of rich, young adults who are filming the destruction of NYC. And as you know again, it's by a giant monster. But what is the movie? Just them running and running just trying to escape, which would be the smart thing to do. No, instead they are on a rescue mission to find a girlfriend, or that's the easiest way to describe their relationship. Big surprise there huh? Y. Hollywood just HAS to include a nonsensical love mission that completely endangers everyone to unimaginable heights. Sure, I'd agree that it's a bold and brave thing to do, but when the guy in charge of this rescue mission is a complete narcissist who has ONLY this one agenda on his mind, it goes from being heroic to completely out-of-line and (insert negative word). How many times do you have to scream his name in his face for him to even glimpse at you?? But he gets away with it. The others obviously don't really care about living that much and I guess are in love with Beth as much as he is. Or do they just love this Hero so much that they'd follow him to the depths of hell? The whole rescue mission really doesn't even pay off very well. The actors are you're typical WB/FOX type pretties, and mixed with that typical Hollywood acting you're also given a very, very Y.Hollywood screenplay. If any of you are even slightly aware of the route Y.Hollywood has taken with humor, you'd know that the coolest humor at the moment is the type of humor the Fat Jewish Kid in Superbad delivers. I enjoyed Superbad by the way. Anyways, the actor using the camera delivers lines incredibly similar to the Fat Kid in Superbad. Though he did sound like Jake Busey....which ain't bad. The humor is very weak and predictable and just lame. But hey, it has it's fans, I'm just not one of them. I can go on and on about how pathetic this group of friends are, but maybe that was what the writer was trying to get across. How self-obsession still remains prevalent even when sh!t hits the fan. They should have dropped that love story right off the bat, but what do you expect from the creators of Felicity.

Getting to the monster. It's cool. It's not bad. But it's a TOTAL rip-off of the PS3 launch title Resistance: Fall of Man. Go ahead, look up the game, and look at the creature designs. The resemblance is uncanny, and if you know of the game, when seeing the monster(s) for the first time, the surprise is nothing of a surprise. But, if you're not like me, you should enjoy the way it looks, it's unique, right Insomniac games? But I do still have another issue related to the Monster. The monster drops little creatures that are about the size of large Capibaras (ha!). Why do all monster movies these days have to include little creatures? Yeah I get that it's heightens the danger factor, but it's officially getting old, and it's pretty lame thinking. Creativity in Y.Hollywood is crap.

And for people looking for scares, no, there are zero genuine scares. There are jump scenes, which use the played out formula combining Incredibly Quick Visuals mixed with Sudden Loud Music/Sound Effects. And even when they're in a tunnel that's pitch dark, you still see the scares coming a mile away. "I can't see!" "Oh it has Night Vision, here let me help you." Okay, what happens when they turn on the night vision? Yep.

The only good aspects to this movie are the impressive visuals, cool monster *ahem*, and when the monster is on screen the movie actually works very well. But there is far, far too much Y.Hollywood bullcrap and no way near enough Monster. This is just more over-hyped Hollywood sh!t, that fails to deliver. But hell, if you do enjoy Y.Hollywood flicks, this movie will be you're film of the year. It's got everything you want, the pretty faces, the lame script, the side story of love....ugh, what a piece of crap. 4.5 outta 10

title: The monster gets the star
review:
Let me begin by saying this film had some seriously tremendous potential. The premise is fantastic and very interesting: a strange monster invades NYC and the entire footage is captured by a group of young people. This idea is rock solid. Unfortunately, it's the execution of the premise and the poor choices made by the director that make this film, once promising, now literally vomit inducing.

For starters, shooting the entire film on hand-held camera is an INCREDIBLE mistake. Yes, there are instances where this approach works well, but for the majority of the film where the characters are running or moving quickly, it just doesn't work. Anytime there's some kind of action, all we see is nothing but blur.

Films are supposed to entertain. What is entertaining about blurs and streaks of blurs in motion on the big screen? Nothing. It's vomit inducing. It's okay for characters to run, so why didn't the crew switch to a production camera during those moments where the cast is scurrying away? We needed to see them running away, but from a third person perspective, not a first person (hand held camera) perspective. It's not like the crew couldn't afford it - especially since they did a spectacular job on all the other aspects of the film (the CGI monster). Failure of the director to recognize this exemplifies his poor integrity skills.

Any kind of sequel to this film is going to be lame. I was glad the characters died or were attacked. Because when they were, that awful camera was stationary and it didn't hurt to look at the screen.

Lots of people on here claim that Cloverfield shakes less than the Blair Witch Project. Utter nonsense. As you get into the middle and end of the film, the shaking is SO bad that the film becomes one for your ears and not your eyes. Roughly 20 people (young and old) left the theater and did not return. The man sitting behind me vomited.

Another reason why I dislike this film is because there's nothing invested in the story. We want answers to what is this monster, where did it come from, what does it want and how do we get rid of it? These questions are NEVER answered.

Again, another instance in which the director is to blame for failure to do his job properly. The shaky camera and unfinished script RUINED the film.

At the end of the day, after all is said and done, this film might make gobs of money. But at what price? At the price of the audience HATING the director as well as the studio? Is all that money worth it to be blacklisted by those you seek to entertain?

Do yourself a favor, skip this film. In fact, if you want, you can grab your own hand-held camera, record yourself shaking it vigorously while you and your friends scream in the background about a monster. Then put it in your DVD player and watch it. If you do, you'll pretty much get the gist of watching Cloverfield, but I'd bet yours is even better than Cloverfield. Why? Because you are an amateur whereas these guys (are supposed to be) professionals. But to me, the quality of work is the same.

And it cost you practically nothing.

title: Disappointed in this movie
review:
I have been waiting for this movie to come out since sitting in the theater watching transformers and what do I get in the end? I "B" movie with a big budget. And this coming from a geek who loves Fantasy, and monster movies.

I have to admit it was an interesting idea, and I can live with the headache from the camera, and the horrible ending, but to be honest the movie was down right boring. The only thing that made it bearable was Hud.

If you liked it more power to you, but I feel this is going to be one of those movies only a cult followers will like.

It figures the one movie I go where people wasn't talking and it sucked

title: I Thought It Was Great
review: I went to see this movie at 12:01 A.M. on Friday morning, the first show, and thought the movie was great. Althoguh I will tell you that if you get motion sickness or easy headaches DO NOT see this film, and if you do move as far away from the screen as possible! My friend got a bad headache and we were halfway up in the biggest theater in at the place which probably holds about 300-400 people. I was not affected because I would just close my eyes for a moment if I felt like it was a lot of moving and it would help my eyes a lot. But I went into this film with no real knowledge of the film and no expectations. The marketing of this film was brilliant, and I believe they delivered a very good film with it! Now people are coming out and saying there was no plot or back story, and felt it was hard to relate or understand the characters, but what people aren't getting is that Cloverfield isn't supposed to be that kind of film. It is a film that we are supposed to watch as if we basically found or were shown footage from an attack on NYC by an unknown creature! I thought the film was effective and I truly felt as if I was with the characters while this all was happening and experiencing it with them, so it's not supposed to be a film with character development or a real plot or explanation. The film feels eerily similar to watching a 9/11 footage video, and when you watch those you feel for the people but don't need or expect a plot about them. Don't get me wrong their is a story within the film, but I'll just leave it at that.
