review: How is it possible to describe that garbage ? I must find the proper words ......... In the beginning I was thinking I was watching the wrong film........the dialogs were so idiotic and then the earthquake... and from there I was unable to stop...laughing ........ the aliens, the dialogs, the situations, the characters...everything was laughable.. the story ? written on a post stamp !It was like watching an amateur film featuring unrealistic aliens in a video game to be watched at a student party !!! Horrible but very funny.........Even the statues'head had the wrong proportions............This thing has such a smell of a post 9/11 film that it stinks. Nothing original........ the characters are lost... In the end a good lesson of geography of New York city.......

title: Poor videography, poor development of plot
review:
I think the movie has a great concept and good premise. It blows it with the character selection of who makes it and who does not. It would be an OK movie if it were not for the videographics. You will get dizzy with in the first 10 minutes of the movie and it only gets worse.

The video is supposed to be as if it was really happening (great concept) but my 5 year old brother could do a better job. Where the screen should have a wide angle shot he zooms into nothing. When he is running he has the video camera any where but where someone would normally have it. Even if it is to express the madness and mayhem at the moment he has wits enough to be video graphing and does not have wits enough to put it on the subject? He never gets a good shot of what is going on at the time because the camera is always going in this direction and that and then your puking from being dizzy.

I had to give it a one, for my having to sit through this awful thing trying to imagine how much better it would be if my 5 year old brother was taping it.

title: If you have nothing else to do...
review:
If you are stuck in a place after a heavy snow for a few days and can't go out and this is the only movie you can watch,then watch it.It can be the best description of 'waste of time' in a dictionary.Nothing new and interesting.You put Blair Witch Project and Godzilla in a blender and turn it on and guess what you have?Cloverfield of course!

The using of the camera was a bit interesting but it's done before.At the beginning I was really curious about what's going to happen and then it felt like 'please,not a monster and disaster movie again'.Good acting could change my idea but couldn't see it.The story could be interesting but it was really classic.Where did that monster come from?Why is it in Manhattan?There could be a few answers about the monster.

It could be more interesting if we wouldn't see the monster that long.If they wouldn't use that camera technique this movie could only get 1 or 2 points.The camera saves the whole movie.If I had a chance I would probably turn it off after 30mins because it was so obvious what was going to happen.The best thing about the movie was to see 'The End'part.

title: Could of been good
review:
How this movie is rated as high as it is bemuses me.

It could of and possibly should of been good but it isn't.

The camcorder view is just rubbish I hate movies where you can't see whats going on this is a terrible invasion/monster movie the characters are all dull and boring you have no interest in any of them and you don't care when one of themdies, there's not enough detail about anything in this movie tbh the whole plot is weak and uninteresting. Please can I have 90 mins of my life back this is just utter rubbish.

I'm losing the will to live trying to write 10 lines about how bad this is.

Sigh

title: Absolutely terrible.
review:
I watched this film a few weeks back and all i'm going to say is that this is such a poor, uninteresting film. Sure, it may have one clever cinematic scene but in general the film is boring.

There is nothing in this film that grips you to your seat which the trailer suggests, it's a bad name to the hand-held video camera genre.

In conclusion, this film is a disgrace and is only another "zombie / alien" film which no action and no violence and definitely no gore. It covers the usual areas in which a film similar to this does. Complete waste of your time, don't consider this as a film which is in anyway thrilling.

title: 7.4!? No wonder Hollywood keeps serving us up steaming piles of poop!
review: Did people rate this movie high because they felt sorry for the people in it? I don't get it. This movie was awful, poorly made, and just annoying. I hate movies where the only camera used is the stupid camcorder someone is holding. Like any other movie of this genre the camera shakes so bad when something is happening you have to close your eyes before you have a seizure. It's because of the success of these types of movies that Hollywood can put together a cheap $18,000 movie with a camcorder and virtually no special effects (because when the action hits they can just shake the camera), put it in theaters, and watch as all the monkeys show up and hand over their money. Has society become this brainless!? No wonder I can't get myself to spend $9 to go see a movie at the theaters anymore, the odds of being disappointed by another 'b-movie' is just too great.

title: Superb Execution - The Best Sci Fi Reality Film Ever
review:
Currently in the middle of watching Cloverfield for the second time and I have to admit the second time round, forgetting all the hype, this is an incredible film. The attention to detail of the film, the production design, the acting and the gritty one camera filming is nothing short of superb and flawless. While watching the film you feel immersed in the action and it really is a good survival guide for disasters, so long as you're single.

If reality TV is so cool, then a reality Movie, even though it is fictional and full of breathtaking effects, is a breath of fresh air for Hollywood and I for one think it's one of the coolest takes on Sci Fi in Hollywood's history.

Two thumbs up for Cloverfield.

title: Crapperfield
review: this is by far, the biggest loser of films to come along. after having read the hype from the media and the internet, my curiosity was piqued. however, I would not offer a glass of water for this film if it were on fire.whatever the message was that the director was trying to get across, missed, by a lot.I am grateful that it only cost me 1.09 to view this pile of rubbish, so take that , Mr. Director, the joke is on you and this movie. by the way, I want my hour and 26 minutes of my life back!I find it odd that movie directors seem to pick on the great city of New York in a post 9/11 era. as for me, I can do without it.if this were written in braille it would still be a loser.

title: Bring your barf bag and aspirin
review: My Son and I went and saw this a couple of weeks ago and by the time I left the theater I thought I was gonna puke and I had a headache. This movie's liberal use of hand held camera was probably the reason for my sickness. I didn't get any kind of similar reaction from The Blair Witch project at all. Anyway, the movie was good as far as the quality of the acting and the other budget related technical details. It was definitely a switch from the usual mega budget comic book character meets the silver screen, which I applaud. I'm not a comic book fan to begin with, but I am definitely sick and tired of all those types of movies. The premise has been well outlined by others, but basically this is Godzilla attacks New York filmed by hand held camera. It's well done and it made for good entertainment, but motion sickness sufferers be warned, its a bumpy ride.

title: A sort of fresh take on a genre that's been there, done that.....
review:
**Warning, this review contains some spoilers**

Cloverfield desperately wants to be an invigorating, fresh take on the monster movie genre. In this quest, it achieves only marginal success. Cloverfield appears to have had the strongest January premiere weekend to date, but time will tell if the film has legs. Negative word of mouth may hurt this movie in the long run.

Cloverfield's premise is one of classified footage of the events in the movie recovered from a site 'formerly known as Central Park' after the fact. The film begins with home movie footage of a couple, post night of romance, then moves on to more footage of a going away party for one of the main characters. The party lasts roughly 20 minutes of screen time and is an obvious attempt to familiarize the audience with the main characters and to gain empathy with them for the ensuing events. The party sequence could have lasted 5 minutes and been just as effective as it tends to drag on, becoming boring, and morph into a very special episode of any of the teen angst drama TV shows.

Eventually, things begin to heat up and events unfold as the monster attacks NYC, people flee, people die, etc. All of this continues to be told from an immediate first-person perspective shot with the same camcorder used in the party. (ala Blair Witch)

My problems with Cloverfield are not with the plot (this is essentially a monster movie, and all of the appropriate suspensions of disbelief need to be made). If you are looking for an accurate portrayal of how real life people might react should a city be attacked by a giant monster, this movie is not for you. (Do I document the almost constant peril my friends and I find ourselves in, or put the camera down and GTFO?) The idea that every last question is not answered (in fact most of them aren't) was refreshing to an extent.

My problems lay with the execution. The shaky cam made me nauseous and from reading many other reviews, I'm not alone. If you get motion sickness, avoid seeing Cloverfield on the big screen and wait until the DVD where the effect will be dramatically lessened. Character development was poor. I felt little empathy for the characters. The ending left many questions, which will annoy some people. (though no one walked out at my theater, there was booing and grumbling)

In the end, the concept of showing a disaster from the perspective of the people who experienced it is somewhat unique, leads to some good moments of suspense, and creates a degree of immersion in a genre that has been there, done that. However, it is woefully overused (but notice how when an important event occurs, Hud suddenly becomes cameraman of the year?) and will make some people sick, ruining the overall effect.

title: Financially deprived director!
review:
I was so excited about seeing this movie. I thought "this is going to be a great movie". Why? Because the previews hadn't revealed any vital plot or character details! It appeared to contain elements of the destruction of part of New York by some sort of monster or god knows what, from who knows where and who knows why! The potential therefore to be completely surprised and exhilarated, mind and body!

The movie starts with a guy holding a camera and as it progresses I think, "I hope this hand holding camera portion eventually ends, it's dizzying and making me want to look away". But I didn't look away and the movie continues to its conclusion, the dizzying, jumping and rather annoying hand held camera action continuing to its very end, which was a great disappointment! You could sense this dissatisfaction as people were leaving the theater, by their comments and quick exit. No need to stick around and relish on the remnants of how this movie has left anyone feeling. Unless of course you'd like to stick around and deal with your astonishment and regret!

So this movie remained in the realm of "potential" as it could have been one of the best all time's alien monster movie. But it fell way short of that with the director opting to present the plot and its characters in the eyes of an amateur hand held camera (not even its owner) user. Maybe the director wanted to copy the method used to film the Blair Witch Project. Or maybe he couldn't afford an experienced camera crew (I say this sarcastically).

So no exhilaration or surprise, except to be surprised when I read some of the reviews! Some saying "it felt like I was there just like when I watched footage of 911". Phooey! It was nothing like watching news or amateur hand held footage. Any hand held footage would have been screened for the best footage and you would not have been subjected to it for 2 hours.

My hope! The director will have some sort of an epiphany and will want to create a sequel at which time he will have collected enough cash to hire an elaborate and otherwise experienced camera crew.

title: Cloverfield Lost Connection? That's really what is driving the hype.
review:
I believe the hype of this movie is being driven by some of the LOST mania. In an interview with JJ Abrams, before the premiere of the movie, he said there are a few LOST connections in there. That's all you really need to do to make anything a success - just say there is a lost connection. You don't even need to have a good product.

"Eyes Wide Shut" was a movie produced by the late, great Stanley Kubrick. Like Abrams, he had a cult following and everyone went to see his movies based on the reputation he had in Hollywood of being a genius. Stanley Kubrick's last movie was terrible and if it was put out there by anyone else it would have been a huge flop. Because of the Kubrick name and the hype associated with it, EWS was much more of a success than it should have been.

Similarly, Cloverfield isn't a good movie. There is really no plot, no character development, no ground breaking cinematography, no fine acting moments. The special effects were decent, but not really any better or worse than any other Hollywood flick out there. It's the first movie I've ever reviewed where I don't have to worry about spoilers because there is no plot to spoil. Everyone knows it's a film where you see a monster destroying a city and not much else.

Another thing that adds to the frustration of watching Cloverfield is that the camera is so shaky it will make you physically ill. Everyone I was with got sick in the theater. I can recall at least three times where the motion sickness got so intense I had to close my eyes until the nausea passed. Then I would open my eyes and the nausea would set in again and I'd have to close my eyes again. Even though my eyes were closed for what seemed like a large portion of the movie, it didn't really make any difference because nothing happened to advance the plot because there wasn't one.

If you really need a lost fix this badly, just spend the night re-watching a season of lost. You'll find some hints and clues you haven't seen before and you won't make yourself physically ill from motion sickness in the process.

title: Dizzy effects with no plot!
review:
Maybe you can say it has a unique perspective but maybe unique isn't always good.

It made me dizzy. It gave me no clues of the monsters beginning (alien or earthly) nor did it have an end. I certainly won't go back for a sequel. The actors were OK but certainly no Morgan Freeman, Brad Pitt or Mell Gibson.

I use the ratings from this site to make a decision whether or not to see a film but in this case I was sadly disappointed. I can't imagine who the folks are that could have enjoyed this film. Well, maybe I just set my standards too high.

title: Motion sickness issue, big time.
review:
This movie is not for people who have easy motion sickness. The camera movement will make you throw up if you have motion sickness easily. The actor's emotion and the action in the movie wasn't realistic. Things were exploding next to you, they are basically standing around for most of the time during the beginning of the movie. When their friends die they basically act like nothing happened 5 minutes later. The monster was childish. It was something out of a comic book. It was straight out of a comic book. The acting was not very good, motion sickness was terrible, and what they were doing and why they were doing in that circumstance was very bad. Some things didn't tie up.

Especially the camera movement is not for viewing. It is always shaking and you can't see anything and makes you want to throw up right then and there.

Not recommended because of the camera movement. Big time motion sickness movie. I had to walk out because it made me sick (the camera movement).

title: One of the worst movies I have ever seen
review: Very hard to follow and very unrealistic. I would love to own a camcorder that works for 7 hours on one tape and one battery! The plot, if you can call it that, was pretty much worthless. I understand the use of the camcorder for effect but not to the extent it was used in the movie. Maybe I am a little behind the times, but I have never been able to purchase a battery for a cell phone that did not have to be charged - but since it was in a movie it has to be true! The only thing worse than the beginning and middle of the movie was the end of the movie. Maybe they are planning a sequel - if so, I at least know where NOT to spend my movie money in the future. Your money is better spent on the popcorn.

title: Cloverfield should be renamed to goldmine
review:
Now let's get one thing straight, Cloverfield is an experimental movie that really hit's the mark, regardless of what retarded people say. The film was shot by hand held camera, and yet everyone complains about motion sickness and knew it was shot hand held. Second, There really is no plot...yet, The only thing we have is the viral marketing, which does give a little bit of the back story. Now there is the other thing people were disappointed about, the ending. The trailer gave hint about the ending, camera retrieved in central park. What does that tell you? Well, many of you would believe The 2 main character's are dead, but the info card makes no mention of no survivors, and not to mention we hear they are alive at the end of the credits. So that really does open for a sequel. Now the reason this movie does not have much of a plot is because it is really placed on the survivors who are like us, not knowing what is going on, just experiencing it. Now Blair Witch didn't do that, all there was in Blair Witch was running around and screaming, Cloverfield has more then that. The visual effects capture you, the actors make the character's real, the action is intense, and the monster is purely original and mega creepy because it Really looked and felt real. Now I have no idea why people complain of motion sickness, the camera really caught a lot of the action, unlike Blair witch did. But if the 2 main character's are dead, then yes is sad but let's remember, this is not a Disney film and sadly...happy endings don't always happen, but keep note nothing is for certain. As for the other character Lily, she survived.

So if your run into people who complain about this film, they are either very weak minded, or very sensitive to little movement. This film is a work of art and I sure hope that they make the sequel or add more to this film when it comes out on DVD. Either way, Regardless of what dumb people say, Cloverfield is a great experience and quiet a ride, and if you are sensitive to motion sickness, then maybe you should rent the movie first and see for yourself.

Acting - 10 Action - 9 Drama - 9 Visual Effects - 10

Language - Moderate throughout Violence - Some mild gore Disturbing or Terrifying Elements - monster is terrifying and somewhat deformed, The action scenes are realistic and characters are always in Peril. Kid Friendly - No

Overall - 10

title: Amazing movie, amazing experience, must see in theaters.
review: I am going to try and keep this as spoiler free as possible, let me start off with this, if you need a movie to spell things out for you or you're not up for doing some research on this movie, you probably will be very unsatisfied. The movie itself doesn't tell you why the monster is here, where it's from, or why it's doing what it's doing. If you watch the movie very closely there are some hints that it gives you, but even those are hard to find and still not clear as to what they are hinting. I suggest you search the internet for more info before you see this movie, interviews with the director, fake websites set up for companies in the movie that more than likely have something to do with the monster, my space pages for the characters, that will help you understand a little bit more. But once again, even after doing all of that, you still won't be positive of what is happening or why, but you will at least have more information to draw your own conclusion. Now for the actual movie review :) I had very high expectations for this movie and it actually blew them away, I think the only other movie I have seen that has done that was the third Lord of the Rings. I have never been sucked into a movie like this before and never caught myself actually being nervous and on the edge of my seat. The only bad things that I can say about the movie are, #1, that the acting can be a bit amateur, I'm not sure if the actors did that on purpose to make them seem more real, or if they just were like that, but there's a few times, especially early on, that the acting isn't the greatest. However it's NOTHING that can't be overlooked and shouldn't hurt the experience. #2, if you get motion sickness easily, this might not be a good movie for you, I for one had no problems, but my fiancée, whom also loved the movie, had to look away a couple of times. I think the way they filmed it was awesome and added to the realism factor, but be ready to watch an entire movie through a hand-held camera. Other than that I can find no faults, I'm usually pretty picky and hard on movies but this was hands down the most realistic, intense movie I have ever seen. It feels weird describing a movie about a giant monster as realistic, but it is, you really feel like you are right there. There is a part of the movie that you could call gross, anybody who has seen it probably knows what I'm talking about, and when it happened my stomach actually churned. I have seen Hostel, Turistas, and many other movies that push the gross out factor and never even blinked. But I felt so strongly that what I was watching was real and that I was there, that when I saw what happened to this character, I actually felt sick to my stomach, and the craziest part is that technically, you don't actually even see what happens. Also, you DO see the monster, I don't know what people are complaining about, they don't put it in a well lit room and let you walk around it, but you see enough to get an idea of it, any more and I think it would have had less of an impact the times you do get a glimpse of it. In closing, this was one of the most amazing movies I have ever seen, and I have a wide range of movies I think are excellent, from 12 Angry Men, to The Life of David Gale, to The Matrix, I give any movie a chance and this one DID NOT disappoint. I feel bad for the people that don't or didn't enjoy this movie and wanted a typical Hollywood destruction/monster movie, or were not angry that the movie didn't tell them more. This movie is a hands down must see and you have to see it in theaters to fully enjoy it, be ready for a very realistic, very intense, and very vague movie.

title: A great theater experience!
review:
This is a great movie going experience. the only down side is the shaky cam, but this movie was incredible!

The monster was better than I thought it would be. The shots were intense, and perfectly executed.

The acting isn't great, but honestly I felt like I was watching a video of a bunch of my friends. People that are hating on the acting are probably over 40 and can't identify with that generation because the dialogue is almost spot on to todays 20 somethings to 30 somethings.

The ending - is by far the best part. I could go on and on, but this is a must see on the BIG screen. Don't look at it like a movie, but as an experience!!!

title: Its everything you wouldn't expect
review:
I have never commented on a movie on IMDb. I have been a fan of the site for years and I have been thoroughly influenced by movies my entire life. Growing up I have seen a lot of good movies, and a lot of crap. Cloverfield was the first movie that even made me comment. Not because it was the greatest movie ever made, which I won't lie and say it was, but it was worth every day I waited since I first saw the teaser trailer earlier in the summer. Knowing nothing about this movie is what makes it worth seeing. There's none of "Ohh I saw that in the trailer" crap. Every reaction seemed realistic and every emotion seemed real. Not because they were the best actor, even though they weren't nearly as bad as I would have though, but because you didn't know them. Real life isn't filled with good actor. Listen to people complain and they sound pretty stupid.

The filming did shake, but there is no steady cam in the real world. Go watch a home video and tell me Uncle Johnny is a grade A cameraman, you can't. You don't really learn to much about the characters, but that is because you have only been drawn into their lives for a few hours. There is no year gap where you can see them grow as people. You see them at their worst, at their barest level of fear.

So before you read a review on how bad the movie was go watch it and decide for yourself. I'm not saying you have to agree with me, but don't miss out on a very interesting movie experience by being afraid of what other people say.

title: One of the best original movies in a long time!
review:
Getting to work at a movie theater has its perks: Getting to watch movies before they are released, and not paying for them.

I have to say that getting to see this movie for free was awesome, and after watching it, I would've gladly paid for a ticket. Reason? This movie is original. It's not your typical monster movie with a bunch of gory killings. This movie actually had a good plot. A monster attacks a city and the story is told from a person's point of view. Nothing else.

After the first real showing of this movie, I had to clean it. As I was holding the door for everyone, I couldn't believe my ears. People actually hated it! I could not understand how. I loved it! After talking with a bunch of people, they said that they were angry with the ending, and lack of history about the monster. I then explained that this movie was from one person's point of view (the camera). It only showed what was in front of it. I then explained that the ending was necessary. How else could it end? People are taking this movie too personal. New York has always been a city for movie destruction. King Kong, Godzilla, even foreign films. All monster movies. All from New York. Everyone knows what New York looks like. This movie has nothing to do with 9/11 and I really doubt the filmmakers were trying to remind you of it.

I have realized that most of the people that are complaining about this movie are older folks. They do not like that the camera shakes, and they do not like the lack of story. However, these are the things that made this film work. If this movie told the history of the monster, or what happened afterwards, it wouldn't have worked Plain and simple.

This was a simple movie about a monster that attacks a city.

title: Something new that was not worth doing.
review: I don't understand why everyone has to do something new.. Guess what, everything worth doing has been done. This is new, but not worth doing. I would explain it as boring with lots of motion sickness.. I thought that the idea of the movie was good, and I would not mind a little POV camera thrown in, but use some of the professional footage with lots of editing and color correction. The grainy footage with not cuts does not do it for me. (these cuts went on forever and felt like home movies). I really like JJ Abrams for all his TV shows (Lost, Alias, etc), but I think he made a mistake here. I do not want to pay $12.50 to watch someone else's home movies.. Save your money.

title: "Cloverfield" better than expected.
review:
The beginning of the movie is pretty much what we all saw from the trailers on TV, everything else, you NEED to see for yourself. First, I will start off with the negatives. My first complaint was the story didn't have much time to develop, characters didn't have enough space for us to really understand them and who they are and what they do, but the rest of the movie makes up for that. There's Rob, who is headed to Japan, Hud, a guy who is "documenting" the party but unknowingly he is going to be the eye of the movie itself. The idea of this was truly exhilarating! Another thing, I realized more than once there were times where everyone in the entire theater had to tilt their heads to certain scenes, this became a little stressful and uneasy at times as I heard a lot of people complain and yell "come on!". Yes, the shaky camera does add realism to the movie but with a huge consequence. As a movie watcher, I find it aggravating to have to focus on the motion picture with my undivided attention, I had to squint a lot, to really see what the movie makers want you to see. This became tiresome a few times during the movie.

Positives: The story development was a B at best, it was nothing we have never seen or experienced before but we don't know why these creatures are here but they are, and they are winning in a battle against mankind but in the midst of all the horror, Rob, one of the main characters, goes on a self-journey to find the one he loves. This was the stories strong point, in my opinion. The man behind the camera, "Hud" adds humor and a few laughs during scary moments, which lightened up the mood a little bit and later in the movie, you start to really care for Hud and Rob, you get attached to these two men as they are best friends. The action was, without a doubt, the most intense in your face, thunderous, godlike and most realistic action scenes EVER to grace a motion picture. The fact that the movie really has no musical score also heightens the realism of the film. Midway through the movie, you start to realize, this does not seem like a movie, it seems like we are all watching an educational, horrific piece of evidence, a historical and tragic event that took place in time, and the world got to see the results through a camcorder on Friday, January 18th, 2008.

It's real, it's sick, it's gruesome, it's epic, its laugh out loud, this movie got my heart pumping more than any other movie I have ever laid eyes on.

It's so good, that I'm going to see it again in its 2nd weekend with a lot of friends because they need to experience it. Maybe if I can watch the movie from a straight angle, not in the very first row of the theater, this film would be 10 out of 10!

title: Incredible, unique and, yes, "intense"
review:
I feel a little weird giving this 10 stars, but I'm going to throw it out there, if only because it is completely unlike anything I've ever seen in my life. I've heard that said about many films before, and it's terribly cliché. I use that wording here because, for the first time, it's actually true.

Another cliché I've encountered when reading about this film is that it is "intense." I kind of laughed it off when reading reviews and hype leading up to the release, because I never seem able to lose myself enough within the imaginary world of a film to actually find it intense. After all is said and done, a movie is just a movie, and I've always understood that. With Cloverfield, (another cliché, coming up) I actually felt like I was there. As soon as that first explosion went off, I was there, and it was scary as hell.

The only problem I have with this film is the first 10 minutes or so, in which the acting and interaction between characters seems a bit fake and forced, but the rest of the film will wipe that from your memory. Other than that, just make sure to suspend disbelief, because some pretty preposterous things happen throughout the course of the film. To me, the probability of these events didn't matter as much as the overall spectacle and sensation that the film achieved.

I came into this film just expecting to see an entertaining, so-bad-it's funny film along the lines of a Godzilla movie, since I've been enjoying Godzilla films since my childhood. I've always thought the "giant monster" genre was something that was impossible to make scary or believable, because it's so inherently laughable. Watching this movie in the theatre scared the hell out of me. And movies never scare me.

Go see this in the theatre. It is a one-of-a-kind experience.

title: Marks the Beginning of an Emerging Genre
review:
I had high expectations going into this movie. I had seen the teaser trailer last summer and the flaming head of the Statue of Liberty crashing into the street blew me away - its sure to become the most iconic part of the movie. It wasn't until it re-emerged a few months later - title included - that I started getting really excited. Finally, now that I've seen it, I can honestly say...wow.

The movie actually begins before the events of the monster attack. We are introduced to Robert Hawkins and Beth Mclntyre about a month earlier. We then cut to the farewell party made famous by the teaser trailer. The reason for this is made clear when it is revealed that Hud - the cameraman for most of the movie and also the token comic-relief - is taping over a day Robert and Beth spent together. In fact, Hud stops recording at various points during the movie, giving you glimpses into the day Beth holds so close to her heart. The farewell party also does more than to just introduce the characters - I spent those first minutes of the movie on edge, knowing that everything was going to go to hell soon but having no idea when.

When it finally does hit the fan, you are thrown right into it. As you follow Robert, Hud, and a couple of others through the streets of Manhattan to escape the monster and find Beth, they do not catch a single break. From the first explosion until you crash into the ending, you'll always see them fighting, struggling, and running for their lives.

This constant feeling of danger is complimented by a wide variety of set pieces. As you progress through the movie, you'll watch as they escape a collapsing bridge; traverse a pitch-dark subway tunnel; scale a lopsided apartment building; and many more moments where you're always wondering what is going to happen next, and sometimes being surprised when you think you do.

In the end, I have nothing bad to say about this movie. Sure, the entire thing is shot with a handy-cam and the footage is sometimes shaky - but such is the draw of a movie that hasn't invoked such a sense of reality to something so fictitious since the Blair Witch Project. My only complaint is that these are the only two movies in what should be a well-rounded genre by now.

title: If Blair Witch Made You The Least Bit Motion Sick, Don't Even Dream About Seeing This One
review: This movie could have been really good had the camera not been so jerky. It was 10 times worse than the Bourne trilogy and a little worse than the blair witch project. My girlfriend and I had to walk out halway through, luckily I was able to read about the ending on wikipedia. Wait until it comes out on rental, it may not be so bad on a normal sized home TV. Another thing that I did not like is how they spent so long in the opening scenes establishing the characters. You are supposed to feel like you are one of the people at this fun little going away party. It's annonying because it takes up about one third of the movie and its sole purpose is to make you let your guard down. This way when the monster scenes finally come out, it's more shocking and scary. Overall, this was a poorly shot version of I Am Legend/War of the Worlds, save your money.

title: If you think you want to see this movie read this first!!!!!!
review:
First of all, I understand that this movie will appeal to a certain crowd of people. But it will not appeal to most I feel. I gave it a 3 because there are certain parts that are.... well, okay. However, for the most part I just felt bored.

Problem one, the camera. I liked Blair Witch, I liked the bourne movies. People said those movies made them sick with the camera shaking.. I didn't. Even this one didn't nauseate me or give me a headache, but it was overused. Just simply overused. Any idiot can keep a camera more stable than Hud did. Also, even in parts when everybody is sitting still and the camera isn't shaking, the picture is either out of focus or out of frame... come on. Overused.

Problem two, the monster. Missiles, bombs, tanks, all sorts of ammunition expelled on this beast and nothing even phases it... even Godzilla feels pain, really. The sub-monsters that came off of it were cooler in that they were fast and scary and at least defeatable. It was obvious from the closeup of the big one that it has no exoskeleton and actually has what looks like soft spots (gills or lungs) on it's head that move when it breathes.... they weren't even scuffed after all the explosions..hmmm.

Problem three, the story. I saw every single thing coming. OOOh they are going to escape across the bridge, huh.... oh look the monster made the bridge fall down.... Rob's girlfriend is trapped in her apartment with a piece of rebar through her chest for 45 minutes.... instead of escaping I'm sure they'll go back after her in her apartment building that didn't 'quite' fall all the way over but happened to lean against an adjacent building so that you could climb out a window, blah, blah, blah, give me a break.. I'm sure she's fine and once they pick her up off the rebar she'll be able to run with the best of them.... Oh wait, that's what happens.. then everybody dies... real original. The monster seems to only want to stay in New York where thousands of troops are trying to kill it rather than crossing over to Jersey or going back to sea... oh, and the troops, wow! Thousands of troops with tanks and other heavy equipment are in the middle of Manhattan within minutes with the Brooklyn Bridge down and certain gridlock at every other entrance/exit to the island... I found myself extremely bored watching everything happen exactly as I thought it would. Even the last 3 surviving a helicopter crash while the 2 military personnel in the chopper died.. of course they lived... the movie's not over yet. And as others have said, the first 15 or so minutes at the party is absolute drivel.... waste of space.

I'll give it this, I liked the lack of music leaving you able to pick up on some of the same sounds the characters hear. I DO like the filming style, it does bring you into the situation, yet over used in this film greatly. Picking not so famous actors so that it seems like it could be anybody, and a pretty good job of keeping the details of the monster secret so that you are always looking forward to seeing it. I DO like that it doesn't give you all the answers.... but that kind of movie has to at least be entertaining or full of surprises... The people here that say it scared them or surprised them must have the mentality of five year olds. The theatre I saw it in had about 100 people in it and after the film was over EVERYBODY was laughing and saying what a horrible movie it was..

...is that how you want to spend your hard earned money??

title: Yep...it works....
review: I just saw the midnight showing of Cloverfield, and overall I thought that approach worked very well. From the beginning I felt like I was there and apart of these people's world's which then get's very fun and even scary when they become attacked. When I first saw the preview I thought the whole idea of the movie being filmed in a digital camera point of view would just annoy me and take a way from the enjoyment of the movie, but actually it was on the complete opposite. Some of the cuts and editing worked fantastic given us that frantic feeling. I also liked the fact that they got mostly unknowns to play the parts. I thought that added to the effect of realism by letting the audience believe that they were there living in these people's worlds and lived up to the approach the director wanted, because had an A-list actor been casted it would have taken the audience out of their world, and we would have thought, "oh there's Brad Pitt," and it just would have taken away from what the director was trying to do. With that the camera does get a little annoying at times, and I felt I may have lost some valuable information because it was frantic and I couldn't quite understand what was being said. Some questions, without giving anything away,of why some specific things occurred I felt weren't all that clear. Another problem some people might have is the ending. But the more that I think about it, I think the way it ended was appropriate to the approach and style of the movie leaving us with many questions, as it would it if this type of thing like this really happened. I also felt it was a bit short, but at the same time sweet. So overall I think this was a good idea and worked in so many areas, and at some points leaves the audience feeling what the characters in the movie are feeling. I felt like I was there and enjoyed it. But really you're just going to have to see it to judge for yourself because I have a feeling this will have a lot of mixed reviews.

title: You may be surprised at how much this film doesn't suck.
review:
Most of us know that 99% of the films released between January to mid April pretty much suck, it's been Hollywood's dumping ground for years. This film may just change that and may lead the way to better films being released this time of year. (yah right)

If you like the horror genre and of course Godzilla monster movies then you should have a blast with this one. The unique angle to this film is how the story unfolds, through the lens of one very lucky camcorder (because obviously it survived).

The first 25 minutes of the movie unfold slowly but help us get to know the characters through small snippets of reality recorded (and over recorded) onto the camera - in a fashion pretty much how we all use camcorders - candidly, sporadically, erroneously and spontaneously .

This may try your patience but look at it as the ride to the top of a roller coaster, enjoy the pretty people and get to know them. This will help to make what comes next even more entertaining and suspenseful.

The script does a good job of escalating the horror and for the most part it feels real, as much as one might expect given the circumstances.

Three suggestions for seeing this film, - see it in the theater (don't wait for it to come out on DVD) - see it in as big an audience as you can for the group reaction - avoid seeing any spoilers that show you the actual monster. I say this NOT because the monster is surprisingly original, it's just that the less you know what to expect the better the suspense. During the film you get caught up in the discovery of 'it' and in the small doses one might in real life.

Bonus extra suggestion, sit as far back in the theater as you can - at least that helps me to deal with all the hand held footage.

##2ND VIEWING UPDATE: After the first viewing I had the oddest experience in that I kept expecting to turn on the news to get an update on how things were in NYC, very much like post 9/11, 'it' had left that much of a resonance in my head.

So, I went to see it again with a bunch of friends and found the movie to be even better. I was able to pick up on many of the little details that I missed the first time. For me, this is a film that improves the more you see it.

3rd Viewing notes:(yes I've seen it 3 times now) In the previous two viewings I didn't stay for the credits. The music is AWESOME, and there is a geek tease at the very end. The very last bit of audio, but you have to record it and reverse it to hear what is said. (and that's all I'll say about that).

*********************************** Technical Spoiler section ***********************************

The Monster  Not a great design (my opinion) and kind of a cliché style - I can see why it was kept a secret. At times it reminded me of Violator, other times like the Rancor Monster from Star Wars. (ewww what if Violator and Rancor mated???) I'm sure it's real hard to come up with genuinely original looking monster these days. Frankly a large crab would have been as effective. :)

The smaller Monsters  looked pretty much like the bug monsters from Star Ship Troopers, again not original but still fun to have attacking people.

The star of the film, the Camera (and this comment is VERY petty): The film was shot on a tape based camera (the film presents itself as a single tape recording) 80 minutes is too long as most camcorders by default are set in SP mode giving you 60 minutes tops. It could have been set to LP mode (about 95 minutes) but it's not likely.

Oh and for you American Godzilla fans there is one shot in this that should come across as sort of an homage.

##2ND VIEWING UPDATE: The film opening said it was found on an SD card / camera. SD video is recorded in individual files with each start and stop of the camera, plus the actors refer to the tape a number of times. This is another petty technical over site, BTW.

##3rd viewing note: At the end, you find yourself looking out at the ocean, keep a close watch just to the left of the boat near the shoreline. Something falls from the sky and splashes into the water. No smoke trail.

Also - the reversed audio at the end of the credits sounds like Rob saying "It's still alive".

title: First Camera Perspective
review:
Unless there was a lot of clover in the fields of Central Park where some of the story of Cloverfield takes place, I'm not sure of the significance of the title here.

Director Matt Reeves had the interesting idea of filming this movie in the first camera perspective. The film is the recorded viewpoint of a video camera and whomever is holding it at the time. Just about every one of those Fifties Science Fiction films takes it from the viewpoint of the people who will eventually slay the monster or defeat the aliens, whatever. You see masses of folks running in panic from whatever the threat is.

What we've got in Cloverfield is a group of ordinary 20 somethings having a party. When some kind of alien invasion hits New York City. Then the group of them take off in understandable panic in search of safety. The film is about that quest for safety.

No name players of any kind are used here and to be sure that does give the audience a good identification. They're not a terribly interesting bunch though, I'm not sure if I really cared whether they made it or not.

Cloverfield is an interesting, but not terribly entertaining science fiction film.

title: Bad idea
review: The camera work is done from the point of view of one of the characters. If you get motion sickness...DO NOT WATCH.....and if you're squeamish....DO NOT WATCH. And the ending was horrible. It was like they couldn't think of a creative way to finish the movies so it just stops. Overall, not a very good movie at all. There are so many better things they could have done with what they had. The special effects, especially on the buildings are the only saving grace of the entire movie. It was a disappointment and not worth the gas and money I paid to see the movie. It might would be a better movie if you could watch it in you're own home on a smaller screen, but watching it on the big screen was too much like you were in the movie and the jerkiness of the camera was irritating and made me sick to my stomach. There were several other complaints of this nature when I spoke to others who had watched the movie.

title: I want my money back, complete waist of time.
review: This was a fine example of advertising winning one for the movie. The advertisements were WAY better than the actual movie. This was nothing more than another Blair Witch Project, with the big bad thing being shown instead of being a mystery through the whole movie. This was nothing original, new, innovative or exciting. I about went to sleep through the bad acting of the character build ups. I was bored to tears through the monster attacks. The droning of the cast as they meandered across the Brooklyn Bridge was unrealistic and insulting. The military showing up artillery tracks leading the way after fifteen minutes of the monster showing up is well NOT GOING TO HAPPEN. Note: 9-11 it took the army almost a solid day to make it to the towers. Another thing this movie has shown to me that the word "dude" can be used every 30 seconds and almost be as sickening as the movement of the camera. So I am to believe that the whole movie, length of the home video document, is to be 85minutes? Again lets poke holes in that one. Party roughly started at 10PM, Main character shows up at 1130PM-12AM... Monster strikes at about 1 maybe 2AM.. so the battery on the camera lasted 8 hours till sunrise while using Nightvision, and a light and filming being slammed around dropped and thrown. Hmm... again I want this camera cause it must be made by the Unubtainium Corp, in Never Never Land. There were so many bad parts in this movie most of the audience actually boo'ed at the end of it, and I wasn't the only one to demand my money back. JJ Abrams has lost ALL respect from me, and I doubt I will go and see the Startrek movie because of his name being on it. The only thing I gave him a 2 for was because of the advertising campaign. Every time I think about this movie it makes me madder that I waisted 13 bucks to see it. Its almost like wanting chocolate and eating a turd.

title: don't waste your money or your time
review: Cloverfield was like a bad mixture of the Blair Witch Project and the Godzilla remake. Sad part is, both of those movies, which are not great movies, are much better than Cloverfield. Between the obvious product placements, the unlikelihood that anyone would actually carry around a video camera during all this "chaos", and the first 30 minutes of torture you must endure to get to any action, I thought my head would explode. Nothing original, as others have mentioned. Only a lot of other ideas combined into one bad experience. I'm mad at myself for being talked into seeing this fiasco. Watch the trailer. It's better than the entire movie and you'll save yourself money and a headache. AWFUL!

title: A dark, depressing movie; some will enjoy, others will be disturbed.
review:
The monster movie genre is as old as cinema yet in almost every film from Godzilla to King Kong the star of the movies are the monsters themselves with the humans often viewed as the antagonists or cause of the monster's rampage.

Cloverfield is a whole different ball game. The movie is filmed entirely through a hand camera; if The Blair Witch project made you nauseas, this movie will do the same. The beginning starts off slowly as we get to know some characters, all of which happen to be generic rich teenagers who have their own little back stories filled with love interests and sexual encounters. Eventually, they hear a roar, witness an explosion, and the movie kicks off in full force.

Before seeing the movie, get this out of your head right now: this is not a traditional destroy-the-city-flick. This movie is about survival. Very little is explained, the monster's origins are kept in the dark, you hardly see the creature for more than a couple of seconds, and the film doesn't hold your hand in any way. Cloverfield is a roller coaster ride of suspense and thrills. While some may draw comparisons between the destruction of Manhattan to that of 9/11, the fact remains that the film's focus is on the plight and survival of the humans involved.

If you're looking for a tale about how a group of plucky youths overcome their fears and defeat an ancient god-like creature, then you'll be sorely disappointed. Cloverfield is dark and tragic while bordering on depressing. There is no hope. There is no bright light at the end of the tunnel. There is only death, destruction, and carnage. There are no morals or lessons-to-be-learned about preserving the environment or the fallacy of mankind. Cloverfield is more akin to a film about natural selection where the strong live and the weak die.

If you don't like tragedies, stay far away. If you're in the mood for a wild action flick with an engrossing atmosphere and dark images then you'll leave the theater very satisfied.

title: Worst Movie I've seen in years!
review:
Several things wrong with this movie: 1. Due to the "reality" slant the camera work made me motion sick. All shot hand-held.

2. No plot. It basically shows a monster (of unknown origin) destroying parts of Manhattan. It starts out as a going-away party, then frantic running and screaming in the street, an aborted evacuation that ends in a helicopter crash and then the movie suddenly ends. No explanation to anything. So, what is the purpose of this movie? It was not entertaining.

3. Length. The movie is only about 90 minutes or so and as stated above, there's 50 minutes of action and no story.

title: Cloverfield Warning!!!
review: A horrible Movie, it was dreadful, awful, terrible, shockingly bad, appalling, a horrifying waste of money, a horrific display of people having a bad time at the movies, horrendous film, grisly, ghastly and gruesome. It was distressing and distressful, traumatic, upsetting, shocking, disturbingly painful to sit through. An experience that will haunt my memories and nightmares forever. It was an appalling, heinous and vile, unspeakable, nightmarish, spine-chilling, blood- curdling; loathsome, monstrous, abhorrent, hateful, hellish, execrable, abominable, atrocious, sickening, foul waste of my life and an insult to movies and movie goers everywhere!!! Please for your sake and the sake of your hard earned money, don't ever go see Cloverfiled. It was really, really, bad.

title: Gojira & Blair Witch Project mated. Their retarded son is named:Cloverfield!
review:
First and foremost, even though there is a sign posted up in every cinema: DO NOT WATCH THIS MOVIE IF YOU SUFFER FROM MOTION SICKNESS!!! The guy next to me threw up and missed my shoes by an inch.

Well, in film school they teach us to always start a review with the positive aspects of a movie, so here goes:

The film sets are amazing, the camera work is quite authentic and the movie is based on a nice idea...uh,...uh,...that's it I guess.

This movie suffers from to many flaws to be considered good. I simply cannot explain to myself how this piece of work can receive a 7.9. I guess a smart marketing campaign does suffice as a substitute for a good plot. Actually I just named it: This movie has no plot! But even that could be forgiven as there are tons of movies without a plot that still have something to them. The most annoying part about this piece of work is the fact that the characters are simply aggravating! As they pass away during the course of the movie, all one can think of is: Meh. I couldn't care less. No sympathy. The motivation for their stupendously foolish way of action is just too unrealistic. And yes, I know that this is not supposed to be a drama so character development is not a priority. But this?!? There's porn with smarter characters out there! I left the movie feeling as if this movie was simply made to take the mickey out of the audience. I really wanted the wasted one and a half hours of my life back. To make matters worse there is no sense to the whole thing whatsoever. It feels like one of those typical "come watch the sequel for answers"-movies.

As I could go on like this forever, let me just finish my rant by saying this: If you liked "Cloverfield", good for you. I also have some crappy movies I love. But that's the point: I know that they are crappy movies! So please enjoy this film if you will, but stop acting like it was really good!

title: Cloverfield
review: This was Blair Witch film technique meets Godzilla Story! It was entertaining as long as you were brain dead.....cheesy at best! I was shocked at the good reviews I read on here. I suspect most are afraid to admit they wasted good time and money to see an over hyped movie. I also think they want to make sure everyone else gets taken by this movie as they did! But its only an opinion but it will make a great cult movie and am confident will not receive any awards! Felt like I was back in high school watching Film Class Projects in auditorium. But sure will make a lot of money for a low budget film. I have to get into the film business....lol

title: Great Film. Separates intelligent moviegoers from the less educated
review:
I have to laugh at the negative comments especially the ones that discuss "shaky camera" work. The movie was excellent and entertaining. It's not for everyone but the ones who get it are lucky to enjoy this film. The moviegoers that despise this post comments that completely shows their overall ignorance on going against the grain film-making. Bravo to J.J. Abrams for revealing to all of us which people enjoy lazy, standard film-making and which ones enjoy something that challenges society's conditioning to accept the mundane.

The film is dedicated to the camera's point of view and the visual effects and directing is top notch.

title: Do not waste 1.5 hours of your life
review:
OK first let me preface this with the fact that I am a big movie buff and I do actually enjoy all different genre's of movies.

What a colossal disappointment this one was. The acting was crap and unbelievable. the characters were morons. The creature was cool looking but not enough of him. The camcorder technique is not new not even by a long shot. It has been done time and time again....in fact it was done with Blair Witch. More notably it was done with one of the most critically acclaimed foreign movies of all time.... El Mariachi.

So the movie is purely an idiotic gimmick. DO NOT GO SEE THIS MOVIE if you are looking to be entertained or looking to see a monster movie. It is an hour and a half of my life I will never get back. Don't even wait for DVD not even if someone else rents it. This movie is atrocious. I can not believe that the master mind behind Alias and LOST had something to do with it. It does not live up to the hype and it is not worthy of even being considered for any awards other than the crap stain award.

title: OMG this movie blows
review: OK, my cousin and I have been catching the trailer for this for a few weeks. It never really showed a lot, but looked like a good movie considering we hardly ever find a movie we don't like. This movie is shot though the lens of a camcorder and the guy behind the camera has a motor mouth. It kinda had a Blair Witch Project feel to it. It never reveals enough about the monster or what happened to the woman that got bit. The ending(if you can call it an ending) left us all with too many unanswered questions(I say all meaning everyone in the theater, as quite a few folks loudly commented on the ending). I don't know what to tell everyone other than if you go in with high hopes I do believe you will be disappointed.

title: I'll Document
review:
Greetings again from the darkness. Have been trying to find something good to say about the film and all I can come up with is that it's unconventional. I am a fan of unconventional, but prefer it mixed with a dose of substance. This is nothing more than a bunch of second tier TV actors running around being filmed in the dark by some hand held cameras. Blair Witch Project blended with Godzilla on September 11 just as the War of the Worlds begins.

The only suspense here is whether anyone in your audience will barf from motion sickness. OK, it is loud. And unconventional. Oh, another positive ... there are no opening credits and no need to stick around for the closing credits. The best of the actors is Lizzy Caplan, who gives her best (but not good enough) Zooey Deschanel impersonation.

Oh, and there is a monster who changes shapes and experiences no apparent side effects from the mightiest military weapons. That is unconventional. Director Matt Reeves ("Felicity" is his main claim) doesn't give us too many real shots of the monster, which is probably a good thing.

Pretty sure most of this was filmed on a sound stage and I assume there were numerous camera operators ... one's arms would get awfully tired jiggling a camera around non-stop. Not sure who the target audience is since we never really get a chance to know any characters, but I will say the film is unconventional ... and lacking substance.

title: Why the tricks of talent shouldn't be used by the untalented
review: I went to Cloverfield on opening night (as, I imagine, most of the rest of the reviewers here did). I was unsure of what to expect, but I thought that at least it would be worth eight dollars to satisfy my curiosity. I had forgotten that it would also take up two hours of my life, which is the part I want refunded. The attempts at verisimilitude via the hand-cam were, in a nutshell, ridiculous. The movie was a B-movie with a C-movie script and cinematography but A-movie advertising. Instead of breaking new ground and becoming the next Leone or Wenders, Abrams even went so far as to deny the viewer a decently entertaining film. The plot was predictable and clichéd, without any real attempts at creativity.

title: Very bad Movie. It is OK until the End. worst ending ever.
review: This movie is OK from the beginning until right before the ending. It does not explain anything, it end like nothing and it leaves you blanked out. You spend 75 minutes sitting down watching this movie, then it ends and you don't even know what happened, you feel like you just wasted 1 hour of your life. Directors concentrate too much on making the movie real, but they don't know that the ending is what makes the movie. JJ Abrams, this is for you You really messed up with this ending. I love almost every movie but this one was pretty bad like on the bottom of the list. Next Time you make a movie, contact me and I will tell you if it's worth putting it on theaters. Get some suggestions on how an ending should be.

title: Dizzy and Confusing.
review: I saw Cloverfield in my film class. I can truly say that this is a movie that I took no enjoyment in seeing. I guess it is a unique idea to have the entire film be filmed from the point of view of someone with a video camera but for me it just got dizzy and bad. I did not like that concept at all, other people may but I hated that point of view and really it made it hard to tell what was going on. The monster in the film was OK, but nothing special. The characters in the film were boring and not interesting. I understand that they all were having a party or something, but the story just seemed rushed or something. BUt overall one of the worst films that I have ever seen. I do not recommend this film.

title: Absolute CRAP!
review:
If you like the 'scare me, scare me some more, what are we scared about?' genre of Lost and Sci-Fi's Ghosts series, then you'll probably like this.

But I found it to be 'absolute crap'! 99% of the movie is shot with a hand-held video camera (gives you an upset stomach just watching it).

The plot is ludicrous, the actors need to go back to acting school, the director shot, and Paramount chastised for even putting such crap on the market!

1.5 out of 10.

I wouldn't even waste a dollar renting it at RedBox!

title: worst film since Hunters Crossing
review:
Could not find 1000 words to describe how bad this film is. At least we took it out on video and did not need to travel to see it. The producers, director and cast could be shot and it would make a better movie.

Awful

bad

rubbish please put warning notices on films by this group so people know not to bother.

sadly they will continue to produce this kind of Blair Witch rubbish which worked once and should be left alone in future

title: Godzilla vrs Mothra much better
review:
Absolutely rubbish. Terrible camera work, plot sequence, character development, action. Worst Sci Fi movie I have seen in many years although the recent Aliens Vrs Predator gives this one competition but at least in that one, you don't get dizzy from the camera work.

I give great marks to the marketing department that hyped this stinker of a movie. They fooled a lot of people.

The main characters feelings for his beloved aren't credible. You really don't care who dies in this movie. Actually towards the end I found myself routing for the monster to just devour them all and end the film.

title: A Poor Excuse for a Movie
review:
I can't think of anything more silly than the thousands of 10 scores for this only halfway decent Blair Witch wannabee -- except it might be studio generated feed. Studios have paid for positive reviews for decades, surely the internet hasn't changed that.

Longing for Richard Carlson in "It Came From Outer Space" or even Dakota Fanning in "War of the Worlds" instead we get another of those hand-held camera things wherein the filmmakers are incapable of making a real movie, with real suspense, and rely 100% on cheap, stupid tricks. There isn't a trace of suspense or horror because the director has no clue how that's done.

From the makers of ABC's "LOST" -- in my opinion the best TV series in decades -- we expected a first rate movie. Well, this ain't it.

title: Blair Witch meets Godzilla!!!
review:
I'm not going to waste much time on this review, as I didn't waste much time on this film, (watching most the later half in high speed, just to get to the ending). My summary above says it all.

The problem with this film is the over used, bad gimmick of the cam-corder gag to try and make things "more suspenseful". The only place this gag worked was the only good part in "Signs". That scene was chilling and looked so real, but it was just a glimpse, not the whole running time of the film.

Maybe the film would have been better if the main characters all didn't make such dumb decisions, and the intent of the people to "document" this happening...just dumb, drop the camera and run.

It may have worked better if the movie had started out this way, then went into traditional film...I just got sick of it. Sorry I didn't buy into the hype, much like Blair Witch I was just left feeling cheated, and like I waisted my time.

title: Finally a blockbuster not ruined by CGI
review:
I watch Cloverfield last night after months of hype. I rarely get impressed anymore by CGI and feel director's often ruin films by relying on it too much. But I couldn't help but be impressed with this.

At the start I was a little concerned with the Blair witch project style filming. At times it can send you dizzy, but after awhile you get used to it and it really does make the movie stand out from all the other disaster blockbusters. You feel as if you are there with them making it feel less like a Hollywood production i.e more realistic. Really clever and risky idea but it definitely pays off.

Overall a really good film that kept me hooked till the very end. Cant wait for the sequel!

title: Don't bother
review:
The story behind this movie is very very very shallow, and the character development was very bad too, which is very surprising from the maker of lost.. who knows the art of keeping an audience hanging on story alone.

The sense of mystery is well kept.. but not rewarded... there is a big sense of anticipation which builds during the movie, because the shots reveal very little of what is really happening, due to the shaky cam.

Because of this the viewer wants to get closer to the story, touch the mystery, but non of this actually takes place and the end of the movie is highly anti climatic.

If you are thinking of watching this movie, don't. It is for the monkey-brained.. go watch "war of the worlds" instead, in comparison it is a master-piece with a genius end twist.

And yes calling war of the words a genius master-piece in comparison to this movie really does say a lot.

title: Not a good movie....but a great video camera.
review: I think this movie will not last in our memories for a long time.Even the director tried to show the human side on the characters,there is not a good story,its just an awesome camera that could resist everything.I do love science fiction movies like Alien,Predator,Star Wars,etc,but this one will not be in my favorites.Also,I agree about the beginning of this movie being too slow.There were a lot of people at the theater who had that feeling.There was not an interesting story for the audience in order to get involved,and if you like to check every detail on any movie,this one show a error in the size of the monster when this one attacks the city and then when it is attacking the guy who was carrying the camera in the last scene of the movie,the size did not match at all.I am not an expert in movies but I do respect the people who did like the movie.I did not like it for the lack of a good story.

title: Cloverfield - an interesting name?
review: After waiting for several weeks for Cloverfield, I must say that I was disappointed. There were several moments of suspense, yes, where I was at the edge of my seat, but overall, I found that there was too many loose ends. Where did the monster come from? Was it from outer space or a lab experiment gone wrong in a place called Cloverfield? Where did the offspring originate from? Did the ending of the movie allude to a 2nd part(I hope not)?. This movie reminded me of a home movie that someone tried to make. I became dizzy and disoriented with all the camera shaking going on. I also agree with one of the other writers on this board it did look like the footage from 9/11. This movie studio could have tightened up the story lines a lot better. With these improvements it could have possible reached the same level of success or close to it as independence day.

title: A unique approach to a classic genre...
review:
So, here I am, the day after seeing Cloverfield on opening night, having been able to "sleep on it" before expressing my views. So, here it goes...

I knew from the get-go that Cloverfield would be shot through the viewpoint of a camcorder, following a bunch of young adults around NYC as they attempt to survive a monster attack. Right away you can see where this could go terribly wrong, as I did, but nonetheless I reserved judgement until the movie spoke for itself. And did it ever.

In short, this is a very good movie, especially for a monster film. I honestly think this blows the 1998 American "Godzilla" movie out of the water. Why do I feel this way? For five reasons:

1. The movie's unique point of view (first-person via camera) and the video quality of said camera gives a very "realistic" look to the whole thing, like something you'd expect to upload and watch on YouTube. And just like would happen, the camera shakes back and froth, jumps up and down, and cuts in-and-out multiple times. Yes, this could get very annoying, but fortunately I think the movie captivates you enough that you really don't mind it so much in the long run.

2. The characters are interesting and believable. I must admit, the first twenty minutes of the movie, mostly shot during the going-away party, is not my cup of tea when it comes to settings and people, and I may have thought to myself at one point "anytime the monster wants to show, please do," but really it did good at giving us a feel for who these people are and where they're coming from. Hence, you come to either love or hate or just find annoying the people we end up following, just as you would in real life.

3. The monster was very interesting in design and though not the best looking beastie I've ever laid eyes on, I have to give him thumbs up for presenting us with an unconventional creature to rip apart the Big Apple. What especially works here is that we see very little of it, that we don't know what it is, nor where it came from, nor why it's attacking. That might sound frustrating, but think of all the cheesy plot lines the writers avoided by literally dumping us into the middle of a monster rampage: no long drawn out scientific explanation as to its origin and motives ("it's a product of nuclear testing and has chosen New York as a nest for its eggs"); it just IS.

4. The "gore" factor, though very limited, I thought left a powerful impression. I only recall three real "gore" scenes; shoots of wounded and dead in mall, girl explodes, and another girl impaled by rod. All are very brief and mostly "off screen" but the execution of them and the mood you're in by the time they arrive really adds to the horror and mystery of just how this creature operates. (Does it implant a parasite into a human host, ala Alien?)

5. The music. Wait... what music? Exactly! My favorite aspect of any movie is often the soundtrack. But alas! No music is to be found gracing this motion picture! But it works; never during the movie do we expect to hear any sort of soundtrack kick in and heighten the mood. Everything plays off very realistically. But even so, I must mention the end credits, for during them an actual orchestral piece composed as the monster's theme does play. And it's FANTASTIC! This composer--Michael Giacchino--never ceases to blow my mind away. His theme, entitled "ROAR!" takes you back to the classic 50s monster/alien B-movies and Japanese kaiju eiga--in fact, I think it'd do swell in a real (Japanese) Godzilla film! I give two big thumbs way up to this guy! Do yourself a favor and sit through all the credits--it's almost wroth the ticket price alone!

On a side note, I must mention that throughout the movie at various points my mind recalled all-too-clear images of 9/11; falling skyscrapers, cities and people covered in smoke, ash and dust, pieces of paper flying and falling through the air, buildings half crumbling full of the dead and dying, utter confusion and panic as the driving emotion... I also thought to myself: was this perhaps how the Japanese felt while watching the original Godzilla movie back in 1954? I don't consider such similarities to be a negative thing. True, such reminders may prove unpleasant for some, but they add two imporntant factors to the film: first, because we all "experienced" 9/11 we all feel that we can "relate" to it, or at least re-visit those past emotions; this brings you right into the film and gives it more realism. Second, for those same reasons, it helps to pass off an unbelievable idea as real by putting the impossible into real-life scenerios. And--as in the case of the first Godzilla movie--a third point stands out; it drives home the message and allogory of "monster=nuclear bomb/terrorist". However, I get the impression that Cloverfield wasn't meant to be a political statement, as Godzilla was, so this third point may be ignored.

So, in conclusion, I must admit that Cloverfield is not perfect. But it is different. It does not entertain. But it does exhaust you. It does not fall gently on your ears. But it will shake you up. The point is, if you're wanting to see a movie like King Kong, then go see King Kong, because you won't find it here.

title: A must see!
review:
You must see this movie! ....For those who want to know.....

Cloverfield is a code that a military gave to the tape they found. Some think J.J. named it Cloverfield since his Production company is on Cloverfield street! Some argue that Cloverfield means, that the tape was found in an area on Central Park which had clovers. Many see some connection to his long series, Lost.

You won't be disappointed. I was very impressed with the acting abilities of a bunch of no-namers.

This movie will grab you in its jaws, toss you around like a chew toy for an unstoppable 85 minutes (yes, it's a short  but oh so sweet  flick) and still leave you panting for more.

It's gonna be difficult to top this movie this year!

title: Cloverfield RULES!
review: I just saw Cloverfield and it is ONE of the BEST films that I have EVER seen...The action is great as it keeps you on the edge of your seat from start to finish..The suspense over the monster is also great as it keeps you wondering exactly what is attacking the city and killing the people...WAY TO GO JJ ABRAMS...KEEP UP THE AWESOME WORK..Definitely worth the money to see since all the showings at the theater where I saw were sold out or close to sell outs...Probably one of the best monster/thriller movies I have ever seen...I think the marketing campaign paid off for the movie and was one of the best marketing campaigns for a movie ever!!!

title: will there be a cloverfield 2 ? i think so
review:
I'll keep this quick cuz i don't want to give anything away from the movie. i personally loved this movie, the only one bad thing that can be said about it; is that it can cause motion sickness lol. the whole movie was filmed in a personal cam format, that can get annoying to some people but i think was done to add to the suspense of not knowing what it is. the less you see the more that is left to the imagination.

I want to let everyone know to go into this movie with an open mind, i don't think any big budget movie has ever been filmed like this and it definitely pushes the norm of the movies we are used to. just like J.J. abrams "lost" this movie will keep u guessing even after its over, and who knows maybe we will see a cloverfield 2. at the end of the credits there is a quick comment made that sounds like "what now", but if played backwards says "its still alive" but who knows.

link to credit track backwards can be found on IMDb's message board, tell me what you think

title: Horror made differently, works out well in the end
review: I do believe this is one of those movies you either love or hate. For me, it was a breath of fresh air. It was realistic in a way unexpected for a horror/sci-fi flick. It must have been a combination of the first person camera view, along with the acting, which I found to be way above average, since the actors made their fight for survival seem real. You were in for the ride, right besides the protagonists; and what a ride it was. I won't go into any details because the purpose of this review is to make more people go see it and I wouldn't want to spoil anything for them. When all hell broke loose, I felt absolutely submerged in the action, almost like playing a really realistic first person shooter. This movie certainly brought something new to a somewhat aging genre. It's not even about the monsters and people getting killed, it is about changing your point of view and showing you how things can be done differently and still work out in the end, to bring you an emotional thrill ride. Having in mind the budget, I really don't know how they made it work this well, this gem of a movie is up there with the best of them. To sum it up, this movie is great and I thoroughly enjoyed watching it.

title: May cause headaches and motion sickness
review:
Okay, first off I respect the fact that this movie is not trying to be your run of the mill monster movie.

That being said there is absolutely nothing original about this movie. It's Godzilla meets a ground zero documentary. The only parallel I would draw between Colverfeild and Blair-Witch would be the the motion sickness I began to experience 5 minutes into the movie.

Yes, there were a few sequence like the street fire fight between the military and monster or the army medical tent that were good but they are very short and few and far between.
