*** Alright, I usually don't do this when I review something. But Cloverfield is a movie that really needs spoilers to be understood when reviewed. Minor spoilers should help in deciding whether or not you should see the movie. ***

The first thing you need to know, is that the movie has a very shaky camera (although the visuals are VERY impressive). If you absolutely CANNOT stand shaky camera filming (which gets only gets really shaky when the monster comes around and causes havoc), don't bother watching it. My friends kept ranting about it, however I truly believe people exaggerate on that. I quickly got used to Cloverfield's shaky camera and believe me, Cloverfield wouldn't work without the first person view, or at least the effects would be less intense if it were in a third person perspective.

The second thing you need to know is, again, you're watching this from an ORDINARY EVERYDAY AVERAGE person's perspective. Don't expect Tom Cruise or Matt Damon as a character to save the day and raid the hell out of a gigantic monster. This is J.J. Abrams's vision of a monster movie and it really isn't your average monster (which isn't necessarily a bad thing). Not everything in the movie is explained, because again, these are normal people, they're not the governments or doctors who quickly studies on the creature to figure out what exactly is going on.

The third thing you need to know is, the movie starts out pretty slowly, but nothing too harsh to be honest. I believe you can bare 20 minutes of character development, which is actually a good thing, because those 20 minutes actually made me care about the characters. Besides, after those 20 minutes, the movie becomes an intense joyride.

So I conclude, after months anticipation, the movie was filled with intense moments, had pretty solid acting (nothing felt forced or machine-like) and has a monster that SHOULD be an iconic monster for America (the monster looks seriously awesome).

title: A movie technology masterpiece; a unique experience for the audience
review:
Anyone considering oneself a regular moviegoer should experience this. I have chosen my word deliberately, for this is indeed an EXPERIENCE not to be missed. A regular moviegoer who has not seen "The Blair witch project" would at least be well aware of it. I understand that it is really filmed with a hand-held camera. But don't be fool by "Cloverfield". This one is high tech stuff that impersonates a hand-held camera, but doing it so successfully that it deserves to be called a movie technology masterpiece.

The entire movie is supposed to be a camcorder "documentation" recovered from "what used to be known" as Central Park after a major disaster ravished Manhattan. The two people who shot the film (one for the first 80 minutes and other the last 5 minutes) are dead. What the audience experience is the first hand POV of four (plus one more at the end) people's ordeal during a devastating attack of New York City by a monster creature the origin of which is never explained (nor is that really necessary). There is nothing that you have not seen before if you are a regular moviegoer who has watched the "Aliens" and "Jurassic Park" series. "Cloverfield" simply repackages all the familiar images that you have seen in these movies. The beauty is in the way it has been done, and this has to be, as I said, experienced first hand, something that no amount of IMDb user comments or film critic reviews can substitute.

Other comments you would definitely come across if you have followed written material about this movie are the obvious post-911 psychological complex and the love story aspect. But in the end, the lure of this movie is in the unique experience that no other movie has ever given you.

title: Blow me away
review:
Cloverfield was beyond my expectations. I expected it this film to be good, but not really good.

The most common thing that fans didn't like is the shaky camera. The camera move quite a bit, but that really didn't bother me. If you have "motion sickness" or whatever they call it, DON'T see the movie.

What bother me was that the movie was kind of short. Other than that, it was all good.

One of the best things that the movie has, is the monster. It's huge, ugly, creepy, and original. I think this monster is totally cooler than Godzilla. The offspring of the monster were cool too. The sound that they make was kind of creepy and suspenseful. *Watch out the tunnel scene*.

Now, the story was very controversial. A lot of people thought the movie wasn't really a monster flick. Here is what I think. The movie is about party-goers giving a surprise party to Rob(Michael Stahl-David), who is leaving New York the next day for a vice-president job in Japan. But then, a monster comes out of nowhere and ends up screwing their party. Then the flick focus more on Rob and his friends reaching Beth(Rob's girl), who is trapped in her apartment when the monster hit. But I still thought the monster got good screen time in the movie.

Overall, Cloverfield is an entertaining intense thriller that will blow you away.

title: I think....
review:
I didn't care about the hand-held camera stuff. The story, was... OK. The acting was quite.. good. The plot was... interesting.

What disappointed me the most about the movie was the monster!!! What the ?? I had seen this drawing of the Cloverfield monster (Spectacular, creepy, impressive whale-thing with bugs all over it), then I was told it was a fake, but then I assumed the real monster would be even more impressive, given the dimensions of the destruction (skycrapers falling, explosions, the noise, etc.).

Instead, we are treated to this anorexic version of the Harry Potter troll!! only thing missing was the log in his hand.

So when you see this effeminate monster strutting its Naomi Campbell legs all over Manhattan, with a head made of poop, you think again... can this flaming monster cause so much destruction? It didn't even look big enough.

That was my pet peeve with the movie.

title: This movie just feels and looks fantastic. (some spoilers)
review:
I'm about to do something i haven't done in a long time. A movie review. As i sit here, eating my buffalo wings, i will review what could quite possible be the most innovative, creative, different, awesome movie i have ever seen. I apologize in advance for any spoilers.

Everything in this movie, in between the beginning and ending, was done perfectly. More perfectly than i could even think of... i honestly cant think of a flaw (besides the fast camera, but that's more of the viewers eyes if they can take it) within the body of the movie. I didn't like the beginning or ending, but i know they were needed, there was no way they could have gotten away with leaving those parts out.. Also, the movie just felt short to me.. like the fun was over quickly. But time flies when you're having fun Cliché phrases aside, I will say, if this movie wasn't filmed the way it was. Like..with normal studio camera angle shots. This movie would not be as good. The source of this movie's greatness is with the style. Take away the creativity and the "oddness" of the film, then you just have, a new years opener of an OK action oriented film.

The point of view makes everything realistic..like what it would be like if this situation really happened to an unsuspecting group of friends. Don't think when you watch this movie... about stuff like "where the heck is the monster from?" "What is it?" ... yes, there are a lot of unanswered questions. But think that this movie was made in the POV of this small group.. they know nothing of what is going on. It saves us the dissatisfaction of dramatic irony. if we knew who, what, when, where, and why, it would take away from....everything. That's my opinion... If you're one of those who wanna be smart and know everything.. look online for all the speculation and theories. This phenomenon has been around for a year online. We were'nt supposed to know anything. It wasn't till a short time before the release that they decided to keep the name "Cloverfield". That was just a code name for the film in its production..

The characters are great.. none of them are popular and scene stealing, they are all on the same level. That means they all have an equal chance of getting killed. I wont spoil this but i'll hint... "I don't feel so good"*KASPLAT* oh man, that was my favorite part.

And the action... spectacular. A major part of the film.. and we see it all. Unlike the Blair Witch which was filmed a similar way... and was nothing but darkness and screaming and major sucking. This movie just feels and looks fantastic.

It is a Classic A lot of people won't understand this movie. Everyone I saw it with didn't like it...(Toni (my friend)even lied and said she did, and later on took it back, calling it "crap") that's OK.. Lately I've liked a lot of movies everyone else didn't. And disliked a lot of movies everyone did *cough* Juno *coughwasgay* I give this movie a 9 out of 10.

I'm gonna stop here because i'm getting the keyboard all... messy and icky

title: Absolutely brilliant!
review: Going into this film I had already looked at reviews on IMDb and saw it had received surprisingly high ratings. To be honest I went into this movie with low expectations. I saw the preview and thought that it would be entertaining but the first person camera style would be too distracting from the actual movie. DEAD WRONG! The filming, however shaky, puts you in the movie. Halfway into the movie I had to remind myself that I was in a theater and not being ravaged by a horrible monster in New York. And after I heard that there was something at the end of the credits I had to go back to the theater and watch it a second time. Although I already knew what was going to happen next, I still found myself right alongside with the main characters in the movie. Last year, I saw at least 60 movies and I don't remember coming out of a movie as satisfied as I did with this one. I highly recommend this movie to everyone.

title: Take some Airborne and deal with it.
review:
This movie was done JUST FINE for the style they worked with.

What saddens me is nobody has a good excuse for why this was a bad movie, I see these things, mainly.

1. Style vs. Plot Explanation Take this into account if you don't get anything else from this review. It's done in first person style, so we only know as much as the kids know, whatever it is they are doing. It happens in a matter of a few hours, and I dunno about you, but all monster movies take a day or so after the initial attack to learn how it all started. Also, if you remember correctly, they had a discussion in the subway tunnels where hub suggested it could have been hibernating in the ocean for thousands of years without our knowledge. The truth of this we won't know.

2. Style vs. Reality Get a friggin grip. They couldn't win here. If they did the movie EXACTLY like a cheap digicam would be, EVERYONE would complain of the horrid video quality, the terrible sound, and the constant shaking (which i will get to shortly). Of COURSE they used an amazing camera to make this film. Of COURSE they stopped shaking the camera to see something cool. Who would go see a movie in Stereo? Who would go see a movie that's heavily pixelated? Who would go see a movie with almost indistinguishable text? NOBODY.

3. Motion Sickness You guys are the biggest sissies ever. What, do you have to vomit when you ride a bike, too?

The camera shaking wasn't nearly as bad as one of the fight scenes in Bourne Supremacy, and honestly, the theatre I went to was packed and no one complained about motion sickness, the theatre my friend went to was packed and no one complained, and none of my friends or their friends got sick either.

Take some Airborne or something next time and suck it up you pansies.

As for the film and my opinion of it.

The film was great with what they worked with. Granted the first 10 or 15 minutes were boring and served no purpose other than to show that the main character loved a girl and couldn't exactly tell her.

Once the "earthquake" (which I might add made me laugh, considering that no earthquake makes an enormous booming sound like that) hits, we're thrust into panic, AS WE SHOULD BE. The kids all run outside to see what's going on, then things blow up and debris goes flying and it's lots of mayhem. We learn that this guy is starting to get scared for the girl he loves and needs to get a hold of her, though the need to isn't so great until the Brooklyn Bridge deal, then he freaks out because he doesn't want her dieing without being certain she know he loves her.

THIS, FOR ALL YOU THICK HEADED MOVIE NOOBS, IS THE PLOT.

Simple as it may be, that's what it is. He is in a panic, his adrenaline is rushing, he is not thinking clearly; as no human being would be doing in that situation. They have their little adventure through New York, getting attacked and still remaining in the dark about what's attacking them. They go to get the girl against all odds, and it is when they pull her off the bar (WHICH DID NOT PIERCE HER HEART NO DUH) that the character has a clear sense of thought. They immediately go for safety.

The end of the movie happens, and it's very simple. Everyone is screwed, period. End of story, have fun with it.

I liked it, they dealt with it well, and even though the plot was simple, all monster movies have a simple plot. This was a monster movie, a complex plot would've ruined it.

Good work guys, next time you should actually enjoy the movie instead of grabbing your clipboards and analyzing every instant of it to see how perfect it is.

title: Fantastic and Refreshing
review:
This film was truly epic. The pacing at the beginning was slow, granted. But after that, the whole film was a roller-coaster adrenaline rush. The effects were well done, the characters lifelike and realistic. When the helicopter goes down and you hear Hud praying to Jesus and god and whoever else happens to be listening, you think "this is exactly what I would be doing" The movie isn't trying to glorify anything, the heroes don't do anything too terribly stupid, or find a way, singlehandedly, to destroy the earth. Instead, they're just trying to survive. This movie was everything that the Matthew Broderick version of Godzilla and War of the Worlds SHOULD have been (Namely, massive amounts of destruction, and no Matthew Broderick or Tom Cruise) The "Gimmick" of having the entire film shot as if it had merely been shot on a home camera, was, in my opinion, pretty awesome. It made me feel queasy sometimes, but the overall effect was definitely worth it, by all means.

People who disliked this movie just didn't get it, or something. I don't fully understand their complaints. The action and pacing were excellent, and the characters were great. I only hope that there is... I hesitate to say a sequel, because those are rarely good. But, I hope there's another connected film. It seems like the start of a very promising franchise, akin to Alien.

title: Incredibly immersive and nearly flawless
review: Well, I thought it was pretty terrific. The characters were likable enough to make me root for them and believable enough that I felt completely absorbed in the action. You won't find any outstanding performances, but they were solid enough and never took me out of the movie - which probably couldn't have happened anyway. The way it was filmed, while making the film incredibly intense and immersive, also allowed for the story to not center on the monster, and I found that really refreshing. Even still, the monster, when seen, is a terrifying beast, mostly due to the impressive effects, and I really loved that you never really found out what it was. This film wasn't about the monster. I thought the end dragged out the inevitable too long, and it got kind of ridiculous when Hud was attacked, but other than that, this is as thrilling a movie as you're likely to find.

title: Great balance between a monster movie and a love story - IT DOES NOT DISAPPOINT
review:
Or maybe this is what the perfect love story look like ? The story is told from a very interesting, unique, point of view. Instead of the usual, chase the monster, find its nest and weakness, and kill it with a gazillion bombs, this movie finds a new way to explore a horrible (yet familiar through all previous movies) event. The film itself focus more on how ordinary lives are affected by an attack on Manhattan, instead of filming a bunch of superhumans who can always find a way out of a tight spot and escape unharmed. It makes everything seem so real.

Matt Reeves & JJ Abrams did everything absolutely right. I love the subplot of what happened between Beth and Robby. Flashbacks in the movie made everything seem so human and reminds the audience of more normal times,when the only thing that matter was love, and each other.

In the end, in the midst of all the destruction, that's all there is left.

title: Cloverfield was amazing! One of the best movies I've ever seen
review: Some people may have not liked this movie due to the abrupt ending and camera shot. Personally i enjoyed the camera work in cloverfield it made it seem very realistic. The seen in the tunnel where hud put on night vision was great. The ending had to take place where it did or else it would have drag on and the movie would have lost interest. Also surprisingly this movie had some hilarious scenes. By far Cloverfield is deserves 4 stars! they also a had some great camera work in the scene when they are on the roof and you down on the monster/alien fighting the army. If i were Rob i would have just left beth thinking she is already dead and head down to safety off of Manhattan.

title: Amazing...
review:
When I first saw the teaser trailer for "Cloverfield" whilst watching "Transformers", I was blown away. The movie looked awesome, but I didn't know what it was. Now, it's much later, in January. I have seen the movie last night and I guess it lived up to the hype and it did much more.

First of all, nearly every aspect of "Cloverfield" was perfect. The weird camera style was reminiscent of "The Blair Witch Project", but the camera style worked much, much better than anything "Blair Witch" could dish out. The camera style helped me feel much closer to the characters and it helped me feel like I was right there next to Hud (the guy filming the movie), running and screaming. The movie was very emotional, and I felt what Rob and Lily were going through when Jason perished. I felt Hud's sorrow when Marlena died her shitty death. I could totally feel Rob's determination to get into Beth's building to save her. I believe that "Cloverfield" would have been a worse movie had the camcorder not been used to film it.

For those of you that are wondering what the monster is, I'll tell you. It sure as hell blew me away when I saw it on the big screen. It looks like as if the Brumac (from "Gears of War"), a slug, an Ultralisk (from "StarCraft"), a praying mantis, and Godzilla had a baby. And the result is a terrifying piece of work that can only be called original.

The movie overall, was amazing. The intense action really kept me on the edge of my seat and Hud's comic quips provided a sense of laughter. The movie was emotional, a great addition to such an action-packed movie. Yes, the movie was more or less a love story, what with Rob going back to the middle of the city to get Beth. However, the movie mixed elements of destruction, action, romance and Godzilla to really create the great movie it is. The government opening ("multiple sightings of case designate 'cloverfield' camera found in u.s. area 447, area formerly known as 'central park'") made the movie feel like a top-secret government document. It's too sad that basically everyone is dead, but "Cloverfield 2" is possible since the monster is PRESUMED DEAD. But if the government did kill the big monster, did they kill all of the little ones? Did someone else film the event, creating a new perspective of the disaster? Wink, wink.

title: Intensly Interesting and "Wicked Sweet"
review:
I went to see Cloverfield, not really knowing what to expect, knowing that there were commercials from the point of a first person camera yet not expecting to have the whole movie through that aspect. And yet, it worked. The music was replaced with the shaking and rattling, the fear and the turmoil created around them. It was the camera's story as the old tape behind the one being film told the past without ever having to have the characters directly re-tell or explain in detail what occurred. The character development in this movie was stupendous, every character feels as though they could be "that friend you have", or someone you can really, honestly relate to. What makes this film so great is not only the camera angles and the unknown veil of what may be happening and what actually occurred, but it is the fact that if it had happened then this is how it would be, this is how we would act.

There is even some sarcastic comedy but everything is completely suitable for the situaution and seems so natural to each character's personality. The ending was perfect, it left me curious, engaged, upset and even somewhat frustrated, however, not to spoil it, that is what a good movie SHOULD be doing.

It was created, different and interesting, I was listening intently, completely obsessing over finding out what was going on, and creating theories along with the characters, and like them, I never found out.

title: not great but not terrible
review: I think the movie cloverfield caught our eyes due to the secretive parts of it. However it reminded me of The Blair Witch Project with its advertising and how the movie was made. The sound effects in the movie were almost identical to Godzilla when the monster was around. The first half hour of movie was pretty slow with some funny commentary. The monster should of been kept secret but they showed pretty much the whole thing in later scenes of the movie. Also the monster had smaller attacking monsters which were only a small nuisance to attack the people when they were on the run from the larger creature. Throughout the movie which is a camcorder filmed attack of NYC the effects were pretty cheap looking but the sounds were amazing. Acting was poor in some scenes but I believe they were acting like they were not acting which is very noticeable with poor actors. The monster was never explained and who was viewing the tape found was not explained except that it was military. Ending left me wondering what happened despite total destruction of NYC and the main characters. Also unexplained scene with girl who was bitten by little monsters that just left everyone confused and curious but it was not explained again. Basically I would call Cloverfield a mystery from the trailer till the end of the movie. Nothing was explained and nothing was revealed the viewers like myself just have to fill in all the unknowns and try to think if we are right. Overall I gave the movie a 3 out of 10. It kept me interested for about an hour and then I was waiting for it to be over. Thats pretty sad for a movie 1 and a half hours long. Good try but after seeing the Ironman and Hellboy 2 previews to hype me up the movie let me down in the end. Rent don't buy!

title: Greatly Over-hyped
review: I was so excited to see this movie because it just seemed like it couldn't be bad...I was wrong. Some people will really enjoy this movie just for the awesome visuals it has in the movie (Statue of Liberty's Head flying, Buildings leaning on others, etc.). However, if you go into this movie looking for it to have some resolve or even a somewhat happy ending, then you will be greatly disappointed as I was. The acting wasn't bad, but it wasn't great either. The hand-held camera shaking did get a little annoying at times where I found myself wishing they'd stop just so I didn't feel sick. I think it was a great attempt to make something that could have been truly amazing, but it fell way short of the expectations that I had for this movie. There were only about a dozen people in the theater I was in, but when it was over there wasn't one person who seemed happy about the ending, I heard many "you have to be kidding me" or "you really know how to pick the crappy movies." I would only recommend this movie to someone that is a realist and wants to see what it would really be like if a monster did attack, but not to anyone looking for a "true" ending or any answers to anything that is happening. I'm sure they are just setting it up for a sequel but hopefully they leave out the hand held camera's next time.

title: Simplistic but effective!!!!!!!!!
review:
Let me first start off by saying that I'm a huge fan of LOST, and I did want to see this movie because of J.J. Abrams. With that being said, this movie was in no comparison to that of LOST!!!! The movie got right into it!!!!!! The first 20 minutes sets up a little bit of background on the very few number of characters that were in this film. The last 60 minutes of the movie is about their will to survive this chaos that is going on in New York City. I thought the movie could have used a little bit more of a story line. I think the writers should have tied into the plot that the main character(who was leaving the Country because of a promotion) had something to do with what was going on in the city. He could have maybe worked with the government, and they knew something horrible might be coming. But, they chose(the writers) to just stick with a simple script. Cut and dry. There is something attacking the city that came from the Hudson River!!!!!!!!!!

Whatever the thing(monster) was, it could be described as a hybrid dinosaur with a very long tail, tentacles like an alien, four legs like an elephant, a head that could turn on a 360 degree angle, 25 stories tall, strong as hell, a host for parasite spiders to drop from it, & overall just a big mean wrecking machine!!!!!!! I think it was left up to you to figure out what this thing was!!!!!

The action and special effects sequences in this movie were done very well I thought. It looked believable for a movie that was done on a fairly low budget(30 million dollars I believe).

I would love to see a prequel or a sequel to this movie, but I doubt very seriously they will retell this movie in any kind of way.

All in all, I think this movie is very satisfying. I will say that this movie reminded me a lot of The Mist(Stephen King's short story). The creatures looked a lot alike in both movies. Both had one huge creature and both had smaller creatures coming from the host. I'm glad I went to see it. Keep your eyes on the last few seconds of the movie. A lot of people I know that have seen it have said they show something crashing into the Hudson River on the videotape with Robert & Beth at Coney Island..........................

title: Terrible.
review: I don't know what movie that other people saw. But 'Cloverfield' was a joke. Is it a good sign when your suspense or horror movie has people laughing in the theaters? And there are no jokes at all. I wish someone would pay me millions of dollars to combine 'The Blair Witch Project' and scenes that look like 9/11 re-enactments. No spoiler here but you do get to see 'Cloverfield'. That is not what people were laughing at, but the movie was a rip-off. I should have seen Juno instead of this Godzilla remake. Movies is very short. After watching it today i called my brother to let him know don't waste your time or money on this. Not the worst movie I have ever seen but a total disappointment.

title: Things to do before watching THIS movie
review:
First of all, the movie is great. Great acting, Great Action, Great Effects. the monster is a little bit mediocre for my liking but its still very unique. This movie however was highly shaky on its cinematography, therefore it gave me a massive headache after watching it. The use of a handy-cam perspective was well effective on the interaction between the movie and it's audience, which i really liked. the conclusion was a bit of a downer, however its still forgivable.

After watching this movie in Australia's biggest cinema screen, I must advise you, that you must sit at the very back of the cinema, as far as possible, if you sit too close to the screen you will get a headache. Also have an open mind about the movie, don't eat while watching the movie, remember that the story is about the people escaping not about the monster, and finally, bring your favourite headache remedy for afterwards.

title: Disorientating, annoying, clumsy and very non-scary
review:
Disorientating, annoying, clumsy and very non-scary.

I realise that it's all 1st person view, through the lens of a handy-cam, but FFS, a 5 year old could hold a camera steadier. They tried too hard to constantly remind us that it's through a cam-corder what we're seeing, D'uh! We knew that before bothering to watch it. How many of you have filmed parties or nights out or kids playing etc ...? and in the midst of chaos and commotion didn't you manage to keep the camera steady enough so that anyone who'd bother to watch what you filmed didn't want to vomit from your dizzy camera work!?

Very disappointing IMO, after all that hype. I knew it was going to be a bit of a mesh between Blair witch and Godzilla, I just didn't think it would be SUCH a mix of both, and not in a good way either. I also knew that I'd hate every character in it and I'd be wishing them all to die horribly, just from the teasers released late last year. I hoped there'd be at least one likable character, and that the whole handy-cam thing would at least be realistic, as in, anyone can point and film with one without it turning upside down, sideways and going out of focus every 5mins.

They could have done so much better with this idea

title: Bloody awful--and I actually liked Blair Witch
review:
I won't bother repeating all of the other well-written bad reviews (a lot better than the movie). Basically, this is the first movie I've wanted to walk out on in probably 10 years.

Acting-nonexistent. Script-painfully slow...agonizing in fact, I can't believe for a movie this short how long it felt. I'm assuming some of the seemingly pointless parts of the movie are to allow the audience to "bond" with the characters. Uh, no, didn't happen. Rarely does a horror/monster movie make me silently cheer every time one of the incessantly whiny characters gets knocked off.

I'm not angry about the marketing nor do I feel ripped off, I'm just very disappointed in this movie which sucks in so many fantastic ways. Don't save your money, go spend it on some bad food-you'll enjoy it much more.

title: a piece of crap! waste of money and time!
review: This is the worst film that i've ever seen! I never wrote and posted comments on anything but i felt that i really have to on this one!This film really sucks.I wonder why this film has a very high rating when in fact all of the people that was on the cinema with us was disgusted with this trash!The acting was the worst,it's really irritating actually!The character's reaction was very very cheesy, I want to choke the writer of this film. I want my money back!Pls save your time from watching this nonsense crap! Whoever would enjoy this manure is out of their mind.I am so upset with this film and the people that made money out of us movie goers.

title: Movie enjoyment turned roller-coaster!
review: I wondered why at 15 minutes before screen time, my party of three sat alone in the theater. Later, 4 sets of people turned up! The groans at the conclusion of this "movie attempt" conveyed the discontent at a director that was high on the need to try something that really wasn't different and is not a norm in movie production for a reason, it doesn't work or maybe so for You Tube. Can we all just be happy with the Blair Witch Project and leave it at that. Sadly, this could have been a great movie; the story line contained all the necessary elements to capture the audience such as romance, a diverse cast, NEW YORK as a setting, and awesome special effects. The right director could have made this an awesome experience instead of an attempt to not get nauseated from the continuous moving camera. This "let's make it realistic" attempt was a huge failure and only left me warning others to "Do not waste the money." We are not in high school so leave taking risks to the Casinos and do not gamble with the reels.

title: This movie is very,very bad !!!!!!! Don't watch it !!!!
review: This movie sucks something awful. It's really really bad. The handy cam work thing is so off putting it made me want to walk out ( and several people did )I mean check on the AVP - requiem threads because one of the main complaints was that the movie was dark dark you couldn't see anything.Well guess what the camera work in this jumps about so much i couldn't see anything !!!!! I can get past the bad acting, storyline etc 'cos its a monster movie so what do you expect but this film is just really bad home movie remake of Godzilla. Maybe i'm missing something because i don't understand why this film is rated so highly Don't waste your time or money watching this junk.

title: The camera ruins everything
review:
Warning! This may contain spoiler!! So, why can't the camera just stick for one second and that I can hear the sound a lot lot more better than the one that we usually heard from our very own handy-cam? The script is without doubt the best yet but the camera was like having a roller coaster ride (remember transformers? The camera circling and I just wonder since when that audience have become robots?). This ain't Blair witch and surely.. if u've been attack by a giant monster or let say an ultraman, would U carry Ur camera along? I mean for what? For viewers to see how U die? Haha.. I don't like the camera's angle at all, it means I HATE it and I will not going to watch this movie if they make a sequel, unless there's a mix between a hand+ache camera with a static ones.. Alrite then n uhm watch it and U'll understand but don't say that I didn't warn ya!!! he he..

P/s; the reason why people went to cinemas is because of the fact that people wants an entertainment. I did mentioned that I vomit.. so do you believe that I enjoy watching it? That's the reason why I'm giving 1 out of ten. Because I vomit!!!

title: this movie is gay
review: okay this movie was about some people who went through an attack on in NYC. the monster was never really revealed in the movie. it was just about as good as snakes on a plane aside from the part where the guy gets eaten by the snake. it had bad drama like the Blair witch project and then ended terribly. i am glad that i bought a $5 DVD off a Chinese person on the subway. it spared my friends the entertainment of going to the movies. the only thing that was good was the bottle of southern comfort! this movie started out like a cheap skin movie from the eighties and then all of a sudden something blew up and the statue of liberty head flew by and everyone was drunk and people died. it was honestly a pretty terrible movie watched by several people who couldn't wait for it to end

title: Worst movie ever
review: OK so I feel like I wasted my money. The beginning of the movie was totally irrelevant, and then when they finally get to the monster, its the worst cg monster I've ever seen. I'm not even sure what it's supposed to be. Then half the time you can't see whats going on because the guy holding the camera has it pointed at the ground; then the shots you do see make you extremely nauseous. I had to close my eyes the last half of the movie and I never get motion sick. Trust me the ending was completely stupid, and anti-climactic (which I can't spell) It's the second worst movie I've ever seen, and I've seen a lot of movies, so do yourselves a favor and save your money.

title: wow!!
review:
I was honestly in awe the whole time. Never have I watched a movie for a full hour with my jaw dropped i couldn't believe it.

The movie seems SO real that halfway through i totally forgot it was fake. The way they film it and the way the characters die just makes it even more real because unlike other huge Hollywood budget films the filmmakers don't care how big the actor is they just kill them and then after there death is pretty much not talked about. Which makes it real because how many people would scream and cry for 3 minutes when a giant monster is attacking the city? You would want to save your lives and others.

The only reason i gave it 9/10 and not 10/10 was because i really wanted to know what the hell the monster was and i wish we just had a really good body shot of it but at the end we get a extreme closeup of it which is so scary.I hope they make something after the film to kind of give origins as to what it was something like a year later type video about how they found out what it is and where it came from.

Overall a GREAT film and i highly recommend people to go see it if there having doubts,one of my top favorites. Totally worth the hype and wait.

p.s- make sure to see it in a theater with amazing sound,its makes it so much better!!

title: Cloverfield Sublime
review: Cloverfield does exactly what I hoped it would do, and that is focusing on character development and keeping the frame of reference centered around them. Abrams appreciates a good monster flick, and he nods to those films, certainly. However, the PoV is what did it for me, because there wasn't the typical Hollywood brouhaha that answers every questions and sees everythingthere was no bottle feeding the audience, handing them all the details, because who actually wants to THINK when they go to the movies? The characters were scared and confused, and thus, so was I. Cloverfield, like the pilot episode of TV's Lost, places us right in the middle of conflict and then the pace keeps moving. What seemed to make the audience angry at my showing (other than the crazy camera movements) was when the PoV ended, so did the film. For me, that was wonderful. There was no Hollywood closure, and that allows me to make assumptions, keep questioning and thinking. Although, the last scene of the film, the video from Coney Island, did show a falling object in the upper right corner, this was approximately one month before the attack. I assume that the falling object was the creature hurling into the ocean, but then again, I can only make assumptions (and that's what I love about Abrams' approach--put audiences in the middle of an experience and don't give them time to question it). I absolutely adore this film.

title: First-person action? Awesome!
review:
I watched this movie with three friends: one of them hated it, and the other two said it was average while I thought it was just awesome. The whole uniqueness of the movie lies in its first-person perspective which is either a total turnoff or an incredible experience. It was the latter for me and I have absolutely fallen in love with this technique. You actually feel like you're in the action and participating with the characters. I've probably never gotten this involved with a movie before. I was literally gripping my seat through its entirety. The style can be compared to a driving video game. Some people prefer to play with the perspective behind the car so that they can admire the cars/scenery and have more awareness of the surroundings. Others choose to play in first-person mode which emphasizes the speed of the car and generally provides an experience closer to that of the driver.

Many people complain about the constant camera shaking making them uncomfortable. I have major motion sickness, but I got through and felt only slightly disoriented at parts. The rest of you should be fine.

This is definitely one of those movies that you have to watch in the movie theater. The big screen and speakers allow for a truly immersive experience, so go out and watch it. At least see if you like it or not. Then you'll know whether to avoid these kind of movies in the future.

title: Revolutionary, exciting, but a little disappointing
review:
I must begin by saying that, in my opinion, J.J. Abrams set out to revolutionize the action movie, which I guarantee he did. With the idea of the shaky camera already making headway, Abrams film will definitely start a new generation of hand-held camera films. In that respect, the film was very well done: while the camcorder was crazy, it wasn't so discombobulated that it became distracting, and the effect made me feel like I was really in the movie. I also highly recommend that you watch this movie in theatres, as I promise the effect is great. Plus, on a T.V. screen, I have the feeling that it might look more like a home movie than like a (somewhat) frightening action movie.

I appreciated the willingness to kill off characters (I always get annoyed with those death and destruction movies where everyone dies EXCEPT the main characters) and was often surprised by the humour of the cameraman. It was also a unique twist that I only rarely saw the cameraman, despite the fact that he was the main character.

However, I was rather disappointed on one fact: total lack of closure. While I do appreciate open-ended movies, this didn't address the one main issue I feel many people anticipate an answer to: what the hell was that thing? Was it an alien? Was there one or several (though you never see more than one at a time, there's no certainty that this is the only one)? Was it a Godzilla remake with a twist? Was it a government experiment? Was it a surprise to the government, or did they know it was coming? Did anyone know anything? Did anyone ever find out anything? I would have been okay with just a little idea, a hint, a musing; anything! I have been trying to guess what this creature was since I saw the preview this summer. Friends and I would have heated debates about it. And not only did Abrams never give an answer, he never even gave a hint. I almost felt like Abrams himself didn't know what would have been a satisfying explanation, and ended it before he would ever have to explain it.

Overall, unique, riveting, and well worthwhile; but I apologize to anyone who went hoping to discover what the monster was.
