As I came out, I could see all of the other audience completely lost thinking about the movie as if it was still grabbed their attention!

This one will be remembered for a long long time!

Highly recommended!

title: "Sometimes you have to hold on to the ones you care about"
review:
OK so having anticipated this movie for quite some time I just got back from a screening of it.

It was funny. I was pumping myself up for it for a while, then as a sat there in the cinema i thought, wow, in 90 minutes this will all be over...will this be worth it? Overall though the answer to that question is yes. Yes there is a set up of 20 minutes or so...doesn't matter guys! It is necessary to gain some connection to the characters, so lets not complain about that.

The part where the monster first hits interrupts a conversation between Rob ("Im like your main dude") and his bro Jason -which, by the way, has very relevant dialogue to set the tone for the rest of the movie, so pay attention.

Because, as been mentioned in another review, this is a step up from a monster movie; that is to say, when something terrible is happening, how would you react, what would you do for the ones you love? With the immediate threat, we get answers to these questions from our main characters.

To quote a poster at the Rotten Tomato forums "If life as you know it is ending, the world around you is crumbling, you are probably going to reach out for the ones you love." I loved this movie, and i hope you reach out for it.

OK, too cheesy end to a review, just see this movie! PS: There has been a lot of talk over motion sickness- i was fine with it, however the person i saw it with got a little nauseous, so be careful.

title: almost a crime
review:
This is almost a crime to make such a movie !!! i got headache by shaking camera... so annoyed.
this movie has 7 IMDB rating ? i mean seriously ?

title: Worst
review: This Is Worst Movie ever,Camera to shaking worst plot,and more worst storie

title: This film is overratted
review: Shaky camera from beggining to end will make you puke. And..., whats going on? Whats the destination of this film? 4 teenager doing ridiculous mission,? Saving 1 (nowhere but miracoulusly found) person but let other friend or theirself die?

title: One of my best picks for monster movies.
review:
Can't believe the negativity from some of the reviews. This by far took me by surprise. It wasn't one of your cliché movies with the scientist, hero, villain trying to stop people from killing it, or a president with the goofy patriotic hero music.

This was by far the most exciting movie that took an event in life and showed how monstrous it was. It wasn't about killing a monster or how it really evolved, but how something so terrifying can interrupt our daily life. I like that it started with people going about there lives and how self involved they where only to have all of that change in moment. And the movie sticks with that idea and that is what I liked about it. It did not go off on tangents. It didn't have stupid people who know everything and think they can stop the monster. I liked the challenges these kids had to endure to get from point A to B. The acting is what I thought made the movie. It wasn't some silly muscle actors pretending to be gung-ho. I hate the fact that everyone keeps referring to BWP because of the cinematography. It was nothing like that movie. I CHALLENGE ANYONE TO HOLD A CAMERA STRAIT IN A MOMENT LIKE THAT. NOT GOING TO HAPPEN. Also, I like the end and we see where the monster came from. A product of space, time and gamma rays. I believe.

title: Cloverfield
review: Cashing in on the successful "found footage" format, seen in successful low-budget movies like The Blair Witch Project, and Paranormal Activity, this ambitious bigger budget film does it to make a disaster movie, produced by J.J. Abrams (Lost, Super 8, Star Trek, Star Wars), directed by Matt Reeves (Let Me In, Dawn of the Planet of the Apes). Basically, the footage seen is recovered by the United States Department of Defense in the area "formerly known as Central Park", for a case titled "Cloverfield". It is footage captured by a group of friends across New York City and Coney Island, with clips from a former recording seen is parts throughout. Rob Hawkins (Michael Stahl-David) is leaving the city to travel to Japan for a new job, so his brother Jason (Mike Vogel) and Jason's girlfriend Lily Ford (Jessica Lucas) have thrown a farewell party. Their friend Hudson 'Hud' Platt (T.J. Miller) films testimonials for Rob during the party, while Rob's ex-girlfriend Elizabeth 'Beth' McIntyre (Odette Annable) shows up with a new man. Rob and Beth have an argument, during which a supposed earthquake strikes, and a brief citywide power outage occurs. Suddenly, many loud noises are heard, and explosions are seen from a distance. When the partygoers leave the building, the severed head of the Statue of Liberty is hurled into the street in front of them. Then an enormous creature is seen several blocks away collapsing the Woolworth Building. Later, during the city's evacuation, the Brooklyn Bridge is destroyed by the creature's tail, killing Jason and several other people. News reports show the army troops and vehicles attacking the monster. Smaller "parasite" creatures fall off its body and attack nearby pedestrians and soldiers. Going against the crowd, Rob, Hud escape the subway, Lily, and another partygoer, Marlena (Lizzy Caplan), venture into Midtown Manhattan to rescue Beth. They get caught in a battle between the creature and the Army National Guard and run into the subway, soon attacked by several of the parasitic creatures. Marlena is bitten, but the four escape and find a command centre and field hospital. Marlena bleeds from her eyes in reaction to the bite. She is dragged into a tent, where she appears to explode. Rob, intending to save Beth, persuades one of the military leaders to let him go. The man then tells Rob when the last evacuation helicopter will depart before the military executes its plan to destroy Manhattan hoping to kill the monster. The group manage to climb the building opposite to enter the apartment building leaning next to it, and they find Beth impaled on exposed rebar. The four make their way to the evacuation site at Grand Central Terminal, where they encounter the creature once again. Lily is rushed into a departing Marine Corps helicopter and escapes. Moments later, Rob, Beth, and Hud are taken away in a second helicopter and witness the creature being bombed. The bombing causes the creature to fall, but it lunges at the group's helicopter, causing it to crash into Central Park. On the crashed helicopter's radio, the group are warned that a second bombing will commence in fifteen minutes. The three friends regain consciousness and flee; Hud retrieves the camera when the creature suddenly appears and kills him. Sirens blare and the bombing starts, Rob and Beth grab the camera and take shelter under an arch. Rob and Beth take turns to leave their last testimony of the day's events. The bridge crumbles, and the camera is knocked out of Rob's hand and buried under rubble. Rob and Beth proclaim their love for each other just before another bomb goes off, with both screaming while the monster roars. Also starring Margot Farley as Jenn, Theo Rossi as Antonio, Brian Klugman as Charlie, Kelvin Yu as Clark, and Ben Feldman as Travis. The performances are average, the special effects are reasonable, and the camera is often shaky, but these faults aside, you can get into it and enjoy things going crash and bang. I originally thought that this film was either naff or silly, but I'm glad I watched it again and gave it a second, it is an interesting enough alternative to the typical monster movie, a watchable science-fiction action thriller. Worth watching!

title: How bad is bad? Watch this and find out
review:
There are two things going for this movie: first, it's shot so darkly (with a hand-held camera), you can't see much the stupid antics of the characters in this so-called story. And, second, it ends after seventy-one excruciatingly boring minutes. And, not a minute too soon...

If you're into excessive use of CGI and special effects, then by all means see it.

If you're looking for a rip-off from maybe a dozen other movies e.g. The Thing (1982), The Blair Witch Project (1999), Predator (1987), Alien (1979), Godzilla (1998), King Kong (1933, 1976, 2005) etc etc, then, by all means do go and see it.

As a metaphor for the tragedy of 9/11, however, it just stinks. Shame on the whole production cast for making this piece of trash.

On the other hand, I give it points for those special effects, the CGI (albeit excessive) and the frenetic editing (which is still often annoying). And, I give the (forgettable) actors a point for having the moxie to actually appear in this pile o'sh**t.

Not recommended for (real) kids or serious movie-goers.

And, look, if you want a much better non-stop action/terror flick, using hand-held camera, see REC(2007) – but, only the Spanish version.

title: Waste of time
review:
I watched this film only because of the users high comments, I thought since it didn't really appeal to me I'd wait for the video release. After much procrastinating I finally decided to rent it.

Well personally I should of never rented it or watched it, I'm sorry but the movement of the camera and the person was was asked to film was totally unbelievable and truly irritating. I can't believe the guy can be that stupid also why would someone who has somewhat of intelligence befriend someone who is a nut job. That it self makes the film even worse! The whole film could of been made much more realistic, I don't know about you... but if an alien is destroying an entire city why would you risk your life to save someone who might not be alive anymore? The film was truly a disappointment and I should of stopped watching it within the first 10 minutes

title: The good and the bad
review: Cloverfield was a pretty good movie all and all. Besides the hundreds of point of view shots and the camera bouncing around every five seconds it was a pretty good movie. I thought that it was very clever and smart the way they made this movie. Despite me not being a fan of the camera shots and the way they did the camera work you might be a fan. I just thought that the beginning was boring and the ending was bad. The actors did a great job for the roles they had to play. I also thought that some of the messages and themes aimed toward this movie were great. I also loved what the characters did for each other in this movie. So in conclusion if you like bouncing cameras, and big monsters then i recommend this movie for you.

title: First movie that I've to leave the cinema half way through!
review: I've watch so many movies, good & bad... The worst movie that I remembered is that I only fell asleep half way through but this one, Regretted to say, I've to leave the cinema half way through!. I thought is my own perception.. but is not... In fact, some of the people in the cinema quit half way through because we can't stand 'the way that the movie presented', we suffers - headache, feel like vomiting, dizzy... Some complaining inside the cinema.. Some just shut/cover their eye and sleep.. However, the story is good! a little bit boring at the beginning but I just not use to the way it presented. Perhaps, if the movie is less boring at the beginning-to cut some of unnecessary boring conversation in the party! and a bit stable, I mean the person who hold the video cam, will make the movie perfect!

title: Thank God for destroying Manhattan
review:
Contains spoilers. The worst acting and most illogical film I have ever seen. Plot holes are so big you could drive a semi through them!! Blair witch retards will love this film. A bunch of rich spoiled asses that all deserve to die which is the best part of the movie. THEY ALL DIE(there is a God) I wouldn't recommend this movie to my worst enemy. Viewing it should be used as a form of torture!! Thank God that it was the worst place in the USA that got destroyed, Manhattan!!

People took way too long in dying and the only sad part is some good people got killed that should have lived. But at least all the asses died.

title: nooooo, ah no no no no no!!!!!
review: Not good, not good, appaulingly annoying camera, which even when you are shown what is happening just frustrates you, not for a minute could i suspend my disbelief, if anything just made me laugh and snigger at the 'best' bits. Ps why must all these disaster movies happen in new york? This film probably has a marmite affect - either love it or hate it - if, and only IF you could suspend total disbelief for a moment and hold down the laughter, then and only then could this failed attempt of a film be passable, no expense was sparred on this film most of which appeared to be filmed in Spielberg's office corridors with the lights off!

title: The biggest load of rubbish
review:
If I could give this negative stars I would. This has to be the worst film I have ever seen. After 85 minutes of threatening to walkout I left with a headache, 10 poorer and in a bad mood. It just goes to show you if you have a big enough marketing budget you can sell any piece of sh1te.

If you want to gage the audiences reaction watch the last episode of season 4 of Entourage. That episode sums up the entire film.

This film should be found in the 5 straight to DVD bin in your local supermarket. A 5 year old could have wrote the script. Save your money and add 85 minutes to your life. .

title: Totally over-hyped
review:
Well, the idea for the movie is really cool..... Handycam.....there are moments which really give you the thrills, e.g. the subway scene. But as such, if it supposed to be a docu-style movie, it doesn't make sense that Hudson has the cam running the whole time. Come on, I want to see you guys climbing over a roof to another and holding on to the cam and filming the whole sequence...If you people think that's realistic...And on the other hand, as soon as action starts the camera is shaking, so you really don't always know what's going on....

And the monster...it's cool. But I would have likes to see it more in details...the shots and the movements plus the shaking handy cam, don't really get across how big and fearsome this creature is... Anyway....check it out...interesting style, but fails along the way.....

title: Very Exciting!
review:
I recommend seeing this without knowing anything *except* that it is filmed POV Camcorder style like the Blair Witch Project. I sat in the back row and was fine, so you can stop reading now before you ruin it for yourself.

I thought this movie was extremely exciting, well acted, and very scary. Some of the scenes were so cleverly set up that I found myself grinning unintentionally.

I think that there are allusions to 9/11 and that they are absolutely necessary: after all, we have experienced 9/11 and we know exactly what it looks like when there is a disaster. This film captured that feeling. It brought back my own memories of that morning, trying to get out of Washington D.C. under the impression that we were being bombed, panic and false information everywhere. I don't think it was exploitive.

If you liked the escape scene in the most recent War of the Worlds where the aliens attack for the first time, you will love this. It's the intensity of that scene drawn out over an hour and a half.

I think we need more films like this which are willing to take risks.

title: Meh
review: Not worth seeing. It builds up a lot and never really delivers. This movie is the prime example of why you can never trust hype. Some people might state that the camera work was excellently done and that the storyline was great but don't listen to that jargon because this movie was lame. It had all the workings of a great title but I found myself actually trying to make myself like this movie and trust me that doesn't happen often. It's predictable and leaves you feeling like you've wasted an hour and a half of your life. The ending is very anti-climatic and the love story which is the only other plot this movie has is lackluster and leaves you wanting more. Do yourself a favor and don't see this movie. Watch Godzilla, Alien, or Blair Witch because they were way better and that's not even saying much.

title: Not for everyone
review: First off, I am not going to spoil anything in this review. I gave this movie a 1/10 because that's what I think it deserves. This was one of the worst movies I have ever seen. There are many scenes in this movie that are unexplained and the characters motives are very poor. The entire movie is filmed in first person with a shaky camera. The special effects are pretty good quality, but there's no point in having a movie full of special effects if the storyline is poor. I did not notice any parts of the movie that explained where the "monster" came from or why the monster was attacking. Neither did any part of the movie explain what would happen to the monster's victims if it had attacked or infected them. I would recommend this movie to anyone who does not like to analyze movies and people who like trillers.

title: Cloverfield (2008) ***1/2
review:
You'd never know it by its generic title, but this is actually one of the finest films about a giant monster destroying a big city ever made. The entire "movie" is captured on someone's camcorder a la THE BLAIR WITCH PROJECT (and recovered, we learn at the start of the film, from "what was once Central Park"), as a secured government document of the tragic events which a small group of twenty-somethings experienced first-hand. What begins as a harmless home video party at a club in New York City abruptly turns into a long night of mass destruction and decimation, as some type of unexplained creature devastates Manhattan. This is not so much a movie about the creature as it is an intense and downright unnerving POV exercise that puts us as viewers into the chaos. Some scenes play very much like that fateful day of 9/11/01, and any person who witnessed that paralyzing event of buildings collapsing and smoke and debris gushing down the avenues will likely be revisiting the visuals in their minds.

I've heard people complaining of nausea and dizziness over the filming technique, but the camcorder craziness didn't bother me as I knew what the movie was trying to do and I just went with it. The special effects here are outstanding, and the monster is never shown all that much to ruin the illusion. I'd also call CLOVERFIELD one of the more genuinely scary monster movies I've seen in a dog's age. You really feel like you're a part of the destruction and it seems very realistic. Would I go so far as to predict future "classic" status for this film? Not sure. I do think the tendency by the general public these days is to move on to the next popular movie, and nothing retains a hold on viewers today like cinema giants used to, when life was simpler and perhaps offered not nearly as numerous entertainment options. But it's still what I'd consider a great monster movie. I'd also advise fans who want to see it NOT to wait for video; this needs to be seen on the big screen with thundering sound effects for best impact. ***1/2 out of ****

title: Fresh idea! Heart-stopper, creates real panic!
review:
*** SPOILERS! ***

The beauty of this flick is that it bridges the gap between trendy "reality" entertainment and classic sci-fi. If you take exception to silly plot machinations or suffer from a heart condition or seizures, then steer clear. But if you are like me -- able to suspend disbelief, easily entertained, and a CGI addict -- then this is a MUST SEE!!!

Start with a surprise going-away party for Rob (the lead character who got a job offer in Japan) with maybe forty well-dressed yuppie-types and all the typical social drama/humor. Hud, Rob's befuddled best friend, is asked to video-tape goodbye wishes from the guests. When Beth, a hot, recent one-nighter of Rob's, shows up with a guy, Hud gets Rob's emotional crash on film. Rob had wanted more from Beth, but had held off due to his imminent departure. Rob forces a smile, then goes off by himself to sulk. Beth leaves. With Hud secretly recording, Rob's friends try talking sense into him outside on the fire escape, when -- BOOM!!!

Out of nowhere there is an "earthquake", which sends the men scrambling to the roof to see what happened. Suddenly there is a huge explosion a few streets away which rains flaming debris down on their building. The guests run screaming down the stairs and outside. Amid ominous, thundering roars and impact tremors -- and the Statue of Liberty's rolling head -- scattering people are still shouting "What's happening?" No view of the source yet, as the handy-cam is flailing aimlessly. Hud then tries to get some footage, and he catches a fleeting shot of a giant leg stepping between buildings. He tries to tell everyone what he saw, but everyone is too stunned to listen. From the party, only Rob, his brother Jason, Hud, and two female friends are able to regroup. From here on out, it's all chaos, noise, and terror -- in a documentary format.

With the streets all blocked, the masses try to get out of the city on foot. Meanwhile, the unidentified enemy (still unseen by the audience) is apparently destroying NYC. Eventually, the group gathers around a TV in a local gadget shop, and are appalled to see CNN's sketchy live footage through smoke and flames of a giant creature crushing buildings, as thousands of dog-sized, spider-like creatures rain down from it and pounce savagely on people. The group is torn away from the TV by sudden machine-gun fire, scrambling Army tanks, and RPG's whizzing by overhead.

Rob gets a cell phone call from Beth, saying she is trapped in her building and can't move. Rob wants to try to rescue her. The group decides to stay together and they attempt to cross the Brooklyn Bridge on foot, but the creature slashes it in half (which Hud gets partial footage of), killing hundreds, including Jason. The group has no choice but to go back and try to use the dark subway tunnels, which they find are crawling with rats fleeing from the spider-things. In a terrifying night-vision sequence, one of the women is bitten badly while beating a creature off Hud. When the group escapes the tunnels and finds themselves in a military field command post, they ask the soldiers for answers. The unidentifiable creature is winning. The government will be nuking NYC within hours. The group is given directions to a chopper evacuation site. Suddenly, the bitten girl says she doesn't feel well, starts bleeding from her eyes, and then basically explodes, apparently from the weird toxins in the bite she got. The survivors push on towards Beth.

In the ensuing sequence, we get our first decent view of the creature, sort of half lizard, half monkey, with beady eyes, savage claws, and huge fangs. It may have extra limbs or tentacles, but that aspect is unclear, as the handy-cam is always shaky and the glimpses are very short. (Brilliant fake cinematography!) Beth's building is found precariously leaning over against an adjacent building. Rob knows she is on the 39th floor. They climb the stairs of the adjacent building and cross over to the roof of Beth's building, then they are able to crawl down and locate her, unconscious, cell phone still in hand. She is pinned through the shoulder by a piece of protruding rebar. They tear her loose and carry her down, fighting off more spider-things.

They reach the military helicopter lift site by dawn. They get on choppers, apparently saved. Beth, Rob, and Hud get on one, the remaining girl from the party gets on another (I think hers gets out OK). Rob's chopper has to fly by the monster, and Hud films it clearly for the first time, cheering as bombs hit it. But it decides it wants some chopper for breakfast and it suddenly turns and clips them. They scream through a frantic, spinning free-fall and crash, but they survive and crawl for cover. That's when the camera looks straight up as the monster spots Hud and says hello in person. It looms in and chomps him. Supposedly bitten into pieces, we lose Hud. The monster moves on and the camera falls back to earth. Rob grabs it to give his final testimony in case the film is ever found. Amid giant roars and the sound of jet bombers, he and Beth crawl under a foot bridge in Central Park. Rob states his name, Beth states her name. They start crying. Explosions, getting closer. The camera drops to the ground, pointing at nothing. We hear Rob tell Beth he loves her. She tells him she loves him. Then there is a final huge explosion and the film immediately cuts to a previously-recorded day at an amusement park with Rob and Beth out on their only date. They tell the camera they are having a great day.

End.

title: Wonderous, suspenseful, just amazing movie
review:
First of all -=SPOILERS=- This movie is the best I have ever seen and probably, after thinking about it, will be my favorite movie. I was just blown away by all of it. Not one part of the movie are you left bored, and that part that you may feel get dragged on have some funny comment given to you by Hud, the character who holds the camera. I have seen this movie 3 times. The acting in this movie is wonderful. To me, acting is like make up. You have to use the best of it to make people realize there isn't any. Saying this I mean that you do not think people are acting. You feel like you are actually with the group of people, as one of them. Especially with the point of view coming from the camera. The entire movie, from the time Hud receive the camera, I felt like I was the person with the camera. This is the only movie to actually make me forget I am seeing a movie, its that powerful. The character detail is so deep, you feel like you actually know the characters. I was HEARTBROKEN (trying not to reveal a big scene) during the scene of what happened to Marlena at the Medical station. For some reason I felt like I actually knew her and that a good friend had the same fate. That is what a good movie should do to you and it is what Cloverfield does. This is not only a monster moving but also a Romance, Mystery, Action, Survival, Comedy, Sci-fi, and a Thriller.

The only thing with this movie, which is the reason it does not get a 10, is that to fully understand what happens, you have to do a lot of research in the viral marketing. The whole deal with Slusho plays a huge role into this.

Other than that the movie is absolutely perfect. I can't wait to get it on DVD and force showing it to friends who haven't seen it. The only reason why I could understand someone not liking this movie is that some people do not like a jiggly camera and might get motion sickness but that majority of people do not have this problem. To me that just added to the suspense, making you feel like you are at the party, in the streets, in the tunnels, and eventually under the bridge. I would much rather prefer this than a third person point of view like most movies.

Go Watch it, and don't feel bad if you have questions at the end, I know I did. The worst thing about this movie is that it ends.

title: Shaking the camera does not make a good movie
review: Fromt he director's point of view, they thought it would be awesome to make a movie with extreme camera shaking and make it like a home video. If you are a Blair Witch fan, you would love it and rated it a 10. The movie is 1 hr 24 mins. 30 mins of it is about the party and relationship breakup. It really has no beginning no ending. It leaves a bad taste in your mouth. Everything is distorted and confused. It definitely will not win for best pictures. However, it can easily be a "B" rated movie. The maker of "Clover Field" wants us to think it's about the monsters but I think they are trying to depict 911. If you don't get motion sickness, you will surely want to demand your money back at the end.

title: A New Era of Film
review: Every once in a while a new film re-writes the way we make movies. Cloverfield simply grabs you by the shirt and takes you on a ride!!! It's as if you are a part of the action! By incorporating the cameraman into the plot, each angle is creatively tied into his character. We see emotions and feelings portrayed in the way scenes are choreographed. Other films have tried to use this cinematography element and failed. Cloverfield is the first film to pull it off. With Cloverfield, it's as if Indy has finally arrived at the box office. It's all made possible by the cutting edge technology of the 21st century. With the hand-held HD camera, the next wave of action films is coming. It's about time! We are more than ready...

title: Can there be a bigger let down
review: This film had two things working for it, it's marketing strategy and its review ratings. With images of NYC under attack by something mysterious the trailers are successful in building suspense. Reviews everywhere said the movie was great and blah blah so i went to watch it with my friends.Once you start watching though, the first thing that you realize is that the monster in the movie (which was supposed to be the main attraction)is pretty average looking. Nothing new. Next you start to realize that this movie has absolutely no plot, no beginning, no climax and no end. Then you realize how the movie is so unrealistic when the protagnist and his friends survive a crash, extremely unrealistic. This was by far the biggest let down of a movie that i have ever seen. A movie with no plot and unrealistic events and an ordinary monster, well that's all i have to say about it. I wouldn't even watch this movie again even if i was paid to watch it.

title: Please don't waste your money or your time on Cloverfield.
review: I repeat: Please DO NOT waste your money or your time on this idiotic movie. The hand-held camera gave one of my companions motion sickness and he had to leave the theater for a period of time so he wouldn't throw up. The plot can be summed up as thus: Monster attacks. People die. Sure, there's some soap-operaish chatter about how Rob and Beth slept together and they're so "in love" and Rob is going to Japan and(OMG!) Beth brought some other guy to his going-away party...but honestly, I couldn't care any less about the characters.When Rob's brother Jason died, I felt only the slightest "Oh, I guess that's sad."I found the utter implausibility of some of the events to be just stupid. For example, Beth gets practically impaled on a pole in her apartment and she "can't move." But when Rob and company finally rescue her, she is able to both kiss Rob and run across Manhattan? In what realm of possibility does that even make sense? The special effects are cheesy. (I laughed at the sound the smaller monsters made.) I wasn't scared in the slightest of the big monster. I kept praying for the movie to be over and wishing I could have the $8 back that I was robbed of. Finally, it was over and I was thrilled that I would no longer be feeling a headache on account of the "groundbreaking" and "original" hand-held camera work. The "Blair Witch Project" did it first...and someone could make a similar movie in their backyard andpost it on YouTube.So don't waste your money or your life watching "Cloverfield." That's 74 minutes of your life you'll never get back.

title: Bad Robot? Bad movie is more like it
review:
Maybe they should have just shot it with a real low-end video camera (or at least made the quality appear as such) and released it to Youtube and let people watch it in sections. Most of the acting in the film was one notch above the typical soap opera. So I couldn't care less for most of the characters. Someone should splice this with The Russian Ark, which was also filmed w/1 camera, and post it on Youtube. At least RA had cool costumes and scenery.

This film should've been done as a typical monster flick. Much of what the characters did was typical for the genre anyway. Maybe the sequel will be done that way.

title: Horrible movie and a waste of time....!!
review: This is by far one of the worst movies i've ever seen. I though it had a good story at first, but then everything went to hell after the first ten minutes. The acting was good, special effects were great, but the movie just sucked. I really didn't plan to pay for a 90 minute dizzy effect, but I also wasn't about to leave the theater 9 bucks in the drain. Now on the the beast! The monster looked like it was half chicken half brontosaurus and really disappointed me in comparison to Godzilla. Godzilla had so much fear the whole Japanese race was scared by him. This movie was supposed to give Americans its own monster, but instead it gave us some reject dyslexic retarded monster. What can I say besides the face I was really disappointed and will never recommend this movie to anyone. I would rather sit back and watch "The Hulk" starring Eric Bana 1,000 times in a row. Anyways my money is wasted along w/ my time....This movie ranks in my 20 worst movies ever to be seen.......

title: Cloverfield
review: I loved this movie! It had everything going for it, from funny lines "I can't stop imagining how creepy it will be if a homeless guy just came around the corner lit on fire."-Hud, while in the tunnels. I especially liked how the movie was a "1st person" movie. I think people either are going to love it, or are going to hate it. I LOVED IT! Can't wait until it comes out on sale. I too liked how you you actually feel like you are running with the characters and how you don't know what is going to happen next. I think my favorite part was when the main four(Rob, Lily, Hud, and Marlaina)are running looking for beth, and all of a sudden the monster appears, and then the army comes firing away at it. Tanks, and all. That scene was pretty awesome. If your over the age of 35, or easily motion sickness, I HIGHLY recommend that you DON'T see the video.

title: A big screen experience not to be missed.
review:
I saw Cloverfield on the night of 1-18-08, as no other timing would have seemed appropriate. The trailers got me excited for what was to come (both the movies they were for, and the movie that was listed on my ticket), the feature surpassed my high expectations, and I left the theater a content guy.

Unfortunately, I felt like I was in the minority. Four days later, it seems everything I hear is about how the camera shook too much, it was too short, nothing was explained, etc. Some of that, I'll voice my opinion on later. In my opinion, Cloverfield succeeded in delivering a slightly-compelling story, gripping visuals, and intense sequences that kept the viewer's eyes glued the screen (despite the alleged motion-sickness-inducing Queasy-Cam work).

For those who only know of the movie being about a monster attacking Manhattan, here's a more detailed run-down: A young man has a heated encounter with an ex at his surprise going-away party. She leaves. People have fun. Party disrupted by monster attacking city. Screaming and running ensue. The young man and his closest friends flee for their lives, while trying to meet up with the ex-girlfriend who left earlier in the night. All of which is witnessed through the lens of the hand-held video camera that was recording good-byes.

The filming style, I think, was very effective in immersing the viewer in the experience. The acting got the job done. The CGI was convincing enough. The monster's appearance, to my surprise, didn't disappoint.

Addressing the complaints from other opinionated folk, that I mentioned above: Camera too shaky? You try framing a shot while being scared enough to pee your grown-up pants. How did he hold onto the camera the whole time? (I've heard such a comment) It had a strap. Long battery life? He turned it on and off throughout the course of the 75-85 minutes. Nothing explained (such as why the monster is there)? We only know what the main characters know. "Scientists" and the military people were too busy doing their jobs to explain to some random twenty-somethings what they thought was going on. Also, the ending was perfectly fine, if you figured out what happened.

Last year, my favorite movie was I Am Legend (just barely besting Bourne Ultimatum and Superbad); midway through January, I think I enjoyed Cloverfield more than I did the Will Smith film. This year is off to a good start, you think? (Or maybe I just have bad tastes...)

title: great film
review:
even though it is a retread of your typical monster movie, it breathes new life into the genre. the best way to describe the film is that it is genuine. you never feel cheated and find yourself rooting for some of the characters (I generally find the main characters are stupid and hope they die). it was chilling to watch the events unfold on a home video recorder a la "Blair Witch." This genre has seen 2 solid entries as of late (the other being "Host"). I would love to see more filmmakers take a similar approach with their films. I'm tired of cookie-cutter films where everything is predictable. The originality of the approach sets it apart from the Japanese monster flicks. I could go on, but wanted to keep it brief and make sure I voiced my approval on a brilliant film (I even jumped several times). The most telling part of my movie going experience was how my wife reacted. I made her go and she seemed totally disinterested in the whole thing and told me to "wake her up" when it's over. First 15 minutes I thought she'd fall asleep for sure, but then the action begun and she was hooked. Midway through the film she brought he feet up and knees to her chin, hugging her legs. I would have started busting up, but the scene was genuinely scary. (You'll know it when you see it). She loved it. But the best part about the movie? No Tyler Perry!! Which is more than I can say for J.J. Abram's "Star Trek."

Go check out this movie, it's great.

title: Cloverfield=Awesome
review: First of all Cloverfield was everything I'd expected it to be and more. Non stop action and a lot of destruction. Some people say there is no substance to the movie but it's not supposed to b/c it's about someone filming their friends going away party then a monster suddenly attacking new york and there isn't supposed to be any substance in a movie like that. Anyways the monster looked awesome. It really felt like I was watching recovered footage of the attack and the friends' last hours of survival. I loved it so much I saw it twice, 2 days in a row. To those who wondered why they decided to rename central park Cloverfield. And why they called the movie Cloverfield was b/c it's either the name of the street JJ Abrams lives or lived on I can't remember. anyways if you haven't seen Cloverfield then see it you will not be disappointed.

title: Long over due!
review: Although I did become nauseous with the camera-work, I accepted it for what it was supposed to be, amateur footage of an incident that comes out of the blue one evening. I am glad that the director had the guts to stick with the format in spite of the dizzying effects it has on the viewers. I have long dreamed of a monster movie that would capture a realistic public reaction rather than the heroic calm that every other movie seems to be packaged with. This movie was CHAOS!!! Beautiful chaos. The only part that I felt lost me a bit was when this gigantic beast took the time to ponder the single individual (the cameraman friend) at the end before he mangles him... I mean, COMMON!!! He has a whole city to terrorize, why suddenly was he captivated by this single individual? Other than that, I thought the movie was stellar and so Im giving it a ten based on BALLS alone.

title: The video camera is my favorite inanimate object in movie history that could almost be a character.
review:
It all started when I watched Transformers (2007), which I just happened to watch on opening day, July 3. Before the feature started, we were privileged with a unique trailer of a movie that contained a video-taped party that turned into a video-taped monster disaster. This trailer only ended with a caption that said "From producer J.J. Abrams" and a caption that said "1-18-08." The monster wasn't revealed, and the title wasn't revealed. My first reaction was "Okay," like I didn't know what that was all about, or like I didn't know whether or not it was a real movie at all. Later, after watching Transformers, I thought again about the strange trailer, and thought positive thoughts about what the movie could be. I first saw the trailer to Transformers about a full year before seeing it, and a big blockbuster movie like that would basically only be showing trailers to movies that also would be big blockbusters. So this unusual "1-18-08" movie must be pretty big despite the release date in January, which is usually a month for "stupid" movies. Because of a partial premise that we didn't know exactly what the monster was, or whether or not we've seen this monster before, the movie did get a bunch of anticipation from trailer fans, which I think I'll say I belonged to.

The release came, I decided to remain positive about it, and I saw it opening day at midnight. And the cinematic experience I experienced was very unique and original. Like the promotions suggested, it is a documentation of a monster disaster following a going-away party for a friend, all taken from the perspective of a single hand-held video camera. The plot is intense, and I liked the idea quite a bit. And because the entire movie is taken from the camera's view, we get things that we don't get in movies very often. Behind The Ring from LotR (which does have a will of its own), the video camera is my favorite character in movie history that can be argued whether or not it's a character as it is an inanimate object.

The story is: First, the story of friends who decide to videotape a going-away party for a friend Rob Hawkins. The monster attacks, and these friends attempt to survive. Second, the story of the government as they find the camera at the end, mark the beginning of the tape with "Multiple sightings of case designate 'Cloverfield' Camera retrieved at incident site U.S. 447 Area formerly known as Central Park," and the government uses it for government and/or history purposes. Third, and most of all what I want to emphasize, is the story of the camera, from the beginning of the tape to the end. More than the story of the victims, whose characters we come to appreciate and hope for their survival, more even than the story of the monster, whose neither origins nor fate is entirely explained, it's the story of the camera. We only see the middle of the story of the monster, we see the beginning and middle of the story of the victims, and just with that, the movie isn't quite enough to appreciate. But the story of the camera has a beginning, middle, and end. And the story of that is more than enough of what we need to enjoy the movie.

Because this is nothing more or less than the story of the camera, from the camera's documentation, no music is scored. The credits after the camera's story, which document how this became a fictional story with the intent to entertain movie fans in theaters, is the only place in the entire movie that has music attached. And the music there is quite fun. When the credits for the songs came, I was surprised that there were many songs credited, which I guess were entirely used during the beginning party scene. I almost impatiently waited for the end credit music score to be credited. There was a big space in the credits between the other songs and the end credit music. It was called "Roar! (Cloverfield Overture)" by Michael Giacchino, who I have previously appreciated for the music for The Incredibles. When that credit came up, I clapped madly. I loved the music, and I probably loved the credits just as much as I loved the rest of the movie.

This movie is fun, it proves that there is originality left in the world, and we come to love everyone in the movie, the friends, the monster, and the camera.

8/10

title: Is that what I think it is?
review: o.k. guys , I know what I saw and it was a terrible monster. What the heck were they thinking. The film is interesting and I would like to have seen that American version of Godzilla in similar style. This monster is repulsive penis monster? Freakin big ol penis, complete with nut sack and crabs?!? So evident in the aerial shot some dude doing the crab walk through New York, waving his VD infested penis about, peppering the city with crabs.. esh!! I was so offended I had to pay for the torture twice, Haa Haa Haa Haa. Regarding the end, well it's better then expected. Then at the very end it sounds like to guy says they all have it? They all got it?...Some obscure reference to his VD or crabs... So what happened to the creative talents of Rob Bottin, Carl Fullerton? Phil's talents are superb but why the penis? Whynot giant squid with a whale tail or something invisible?..Crabs? Well good luck at the awards shows..

title: You get what you put into it.
review:
Cloverfield was a brilliant film in my opinion.

I came in knowing these following key-points:

-It was shot with a hand-held camera-which could lead to motion sickness. -It has a slow beginning. But the beginning was necessary to build character development and to let you see the different personalities of the main group of victims before they were thrust into the disaster. -The ending was abrupt

People who are complaining about the motion sickness can be justified. But it wasn't bothersome to me at all. One way of BEATING THE MOTION SICKNESS is envisioning a point at the center of the screen and just focusing on that point instead of following every direction the camera flails around to. This will allow you to digest the scenes without moving your eyes constantly (which leads to the motion sickness).

The ending was perfect. It wasn't a Hollywood ending, which is why it was good. It seems like the main characters die but, do they? The end credits give you an impression that they may still be alive and gives room for a sequel.

I thought it was a gripping film overall and leaves you attached to the characters. The sounds and action sequences really made you feel like you were right behind the camera lense.

Don't be warded off by the poor comments that other people are giving and please see this film.

It is way better than the other sci-fi films released this year that have failed to deliver ("I Am Legend" for one).

Of course there are some holes in the plot that are left unanswered but it was shot from a hand-held people! It was from the perspective of 1, yes count it, 1, hand-held video camera. It wouldn't be the same if they explained every last detail of what was going on.

When September 11th happened, people weren't asking around and going on the internet trying to find out what was attacking their city, they were running for their damn lives, they didn't care if it was terrorists or a giant monster!

So please,

see this film.

Don't see it if you have an extremely weak stomach.

See it if you like rollercoasters because this movie takes you on a wild ride.

9/10, most fun I've had in a theater in a LONG while.

title: boe_dye sez... actually secret agent j sez.... it's blair witch goes to N.Y
review:
So here's the deal; had i walked into this film not know that it was going to be documentary style, running around with lots of weird and wacky camera angles, sporadic monsters, and lots of hight pitched screaming, i probably would have been somewhat upset.

However, i did walk into knowing all of this to boot, so there it is.

I think the best way to describe this, and the most fairest observation about this, is that people who love it, are going to love the exact same things that the people who hated it, hated.

Personally, i will never spend money to see another pseudo-documentary style film like this, because i don't care for the open ended story telling. i thought that it was far too annoying to enjoyable. although what was done, was done extremely well, what was done was done in a style that i just don't like.

The scenes were very well played, and the footage was pretty good for what it was. my biggest complaint however was the character "hud" who acted more like a 15 year old with a camera. too many stupid comments, too much idiotic chatter, and not enough substance. sure, he was supposed to be the stereotypical doofus who was given the camera because it amused his simple character, but i think that it was over played after the whole "he and she slept together" bit.

The monsters were done well, and i liked how the kept the cloverfield monster a mystery so to speak towards the end, but at the same time, i felt that they could have used just a smidgen more intelligence when it came to evading the monster as they escaped in the choppa.

And yes, they do most certainly have to "get to a choppa"...

The ending was a bit of a disappointment for me, as i felt it was unnecessary, and really made the film pointless. They go to all this trouble avoiding the blasted thing, only to make a very predictable escape that parallels the monster path of destruction.

Why they thought that a monster that could toss the statue of liberty's head half way across manhattan would not be able to jump a couple of hundred feet in the air from a standstill is beyond me, but hey, there it is...

In the end, i and my wife, were both somewhat nauseous. she liked it, but then again she also likes me too, which goes to show where her tastes are at. my best friend, the man known as secret agent j liked it, but then again still lovingly referred to it as blair witch goes to N.Y.

Those who say that it is nothing like blair witch really need to get a clue, cause it was almost exactly like blair witch, only with more running, screaming, and eye candy...

... and no stupid man standing in the basement of a cabin looking all... stupid...

I had to be fair and give it five stars. 5 cause, and again, what it did, it did really well, but i just didn't like what it did...

... although the star trek teaser gave me chills... >8^P

title: Cloverfield's flaws never subtract from its strengths.
review:
Many excited filmgoers have been waiting for it and here it finally is, in all its glory. Cloverfield in the beginning was a simple trailer that showed an explosion, panic, and the Statue of Liberty's decapitated head lying in the streets of New York. This lone trailer invoked so much mystery into the movie since all it showed at the end was the name J.J. Abrams (TV series Lost) and the release date 1-18-08, which will now go down in monster-movie fan history as a famous date. After all the mystery, guesses, clues, photos, and intrigue, finally a second trailer was released. People were now even more excited claiming they saw the monster run in between two buildings in one shot, or they saw the monster's face as a bridge collapsed. But nobody was sure of what they saw in the trailers and press, which was a result of the brilliant viral marketing scheme of the film. Nobody had any idea what to expect, or what the monster looked like until they saw the film. All answers were answered and mysteries de-mystified on the infamous opening day of Cloverfield 1-18-08.

Cloverfield is filmed completely home-movie like with main character named Hud holding the camcorder the whole entire time. The movie begins with a going-away party for a young guy named Rob (Michael Stahl-David) who is leaving for Japan for a job as vice president at a company. As Hud (T.J. Miller) walks around interviewing people, a sudden earthquake-like interruption occurs. Everyone goes out onto the roof and sees a gigantic explosion occur. Everyone wanders out onto the street only to learn that some kind of giant monstrous entity is attacking New York. Total mayhem ensues in the city as Rob, Hud, and a few other friends such as Rob's brother Jason (Mike Vogel) and Marlena (Lizzy Caplan), try to escape from the city. (Of course they bring the camcorder along for a home movie like none other.)

At 84 minutes Cloverfield is a short movie, but runs with frenetic and tense energy the whole time. Once the monster plot kicked in, I never felt any boredom for one moment and was constantly excited to see what was going to happen next. The character development felt shoddy but to me that only adds to the realism of what's going on. This is not like a normal film where everything is shot sequentially and time is added to developing the characters. The audience does not know these characters any more than whoever (Probably the Army) found the camcorder. Did you really expect Hud to go up and ask everyone their life story before the attack, I guess that's a no.

Many have complained that the home movie style of the film induced motion sickness, or caused them to throw up. I personally didn't get sick or feel sick at all, and neither did the two friends I saw it with. The camera angles in the movie at certain points are still and firm, and at other points shaking all over the place, and dipping up and down and every which way and that. This camera style is one of the key ingredients added for the realistic residue of the movie. But I guess I agree, Cloverfield should be labeled "WARNING: This Film May Cause One to Puke."

Now to the big excitement of Cloverfield that is the monster. We never really gain a good view of the monster in its full detailed form. There is pretty much always a building or smoke blocking part of it, or maybe the camera angle dips which happens a lot during this film. But that nevers detracts from my fascination with the unknown creature. One fact that angered some audiences was that we are never get an explanation of what the monster is, where it came from, why it's so destructive and mean, or what its goal is if it has one. To me that is the beauty of Cloverfield. I have had enough of horror-thriller flicks like Cloverfield that always spoonfeed to filmgoers all the dirty details of what everything means. The imagination can think up far more brilliant theories and details than the film itself can. Once the mystery is explained, there goes the mystery. The monster in Cloverfield was enormous, vicious, destructive, and intriguing. I'm also very glad that it's something original and not Godzilla.

The flaws are there of course, so here's what I and others found. The camera seems to be very high tech, I've never heard of a camera that's battery can last vast hours, and also survive a few huge drops without even a cracked lense. Another problem I found is that there aren't more buildings that were knocked down by the creature. We see the statue of Liberty's head thrown down a street, and also a huge skyscraper fall to the ground, but not many others are torn down. Another issue is why are there no dead bodies littering the streets? With all that's going on there should have been a few bodies scattered about. Also why is everyone on foot, did they forget their car keys? I think the instinct would be get in a car to get away from a monster attacking a city, but I guess a nice pair of Cross-Trainers solves that problem. One last issue is that the lady characters are running very fast in high heels, now I'm a guy but I don't think that'd be happening.

Cloverfield has flaws just like any other movie. But the suspense and heart-pounding excitement, and unexpected scares, are what got me. I give Cloverfield a 3 out of 4. It is the prescription to cure any fanboy's fever.

title: WARNING: Post-movie sickness!
review: The movie started off with a party, which was all like a home-made video. Heaps of shaking occurred, and half way through the movie, we realized that the movie is going to be like that. The movie made me sick at the end by the dizzy-ness that the uncontrollable shaking camera gave me. The camera was moving so much. I know, I know, the movies SUPPOSED to be like that, but it just gave me a really sick feeling while watching the movie. Overall, the movie was alright. The story line was alright, the fact that it was a home-made sorta movie was okay, and the effects and set was Excellent! I just didn't like the feeling I experienced after I watched the movie. The movie left us still wondering what that CREATURE was ! Is it an alien, is it an ugly re-make of Gozilla, or is it just some weird creature? No-one knows, but it was ugly. I have a gut feeling that it is going to continue on onto another movie. In conclusion, this was a GREAT movie, if it just didn't make me feel sick.

title: Cloverfield amazed me
review:
OK, so I went to go see Cloverfield last night, to be honest I didn't think it would impress me this much...I was wrong.

The movie was astonishingly good. The special effects were amazingly well done. Great story, there are a few scenes where it feels as if it is just dragging on but then something happens that snags your attention. It keeps you on the edge of your seat the whole time, the monster looked awesome. But i felt they showed it too much. I wish they would have saved it all up until the end of the movie to show the whole monster, but i think they made it work.

Anyways, make time to see this movie.

title: Simply Superb!
review:
Before going to see Cloverfield, I had heard many different reviews of its quality, ranging from "the worst movie ever" to "simply incredible." After having seen it, I must say that I fall in with the latter of those two groups. The movie is great in all aspects. It's fast paced and leaves you on the edge of your seat for the entire ride, yet manages to do so without exhausting you. The handicam style filming adds great depth to the story and makes the experience so much more visceral. The characters are also well developed, and the actors do a fantastic job.

The only reason I could see why people wouldn't like this movie is because it's not a generic Hollywood film. This movie is innovative and isn't afraid to break some of the conventions most blockbusters follow today. The ending is fantastic, although atypical for a movie of this sort. I wouldn't spoil it, but let's just say that if you're willing to open your mind to new experiences, you'll love it.

All in all this movie is probably one of the best action/disaster movies ever made. With a great cast, great crew, and an amazing story, this film is miles ahead of the pack.

title: Highly Unusual Film!!!
review:
Back in the fall of 2007 when I first saw the trailer for CLOVERFIELD I was very intrigued. The trailer was high tension. I was itching to see this movie.

I WAS NOT DISAPPOINTED!!! I truly love this movie. Seen it three times!!! It was made to look like a video retrieved from what was once Central Park here in NYC. The movie starts with the U.S. Government blurb and logo. Its apparent that the footage was being viewed secretly by top military brass and members of our government. This the video begins. Its lighthearted and in many places funny before the attack. Its about one of the main character's Bon Voyage party and some of the insanity that takes place during the party. The there is the great explosion and insuring "attack" upon Manhattan. This is not a monster I've seen before which makes this extremely satisfying. Monster is NOT a reptile.

I understand the original title of the film was going to be PARASITE. I see why. WOW!!! But the military designation is even better.

Congratulations to Matt Reeves and JJ Abrams for bring us a highly original film.

title: Cloverfield, Felt Somewhat Real
review:
Cloverfield was filmed in a unique way. The style of the camera was in a document first person form where the viewers (us at the theater) are able to see the film in the perspective of a character who is holding the camera and recording the action as if the events were to be happening in real life. The story focuses on a group of people whom are trying to survive as a monster begins destroying NYC. The whole view is through one camera, the 25 million dollar budget was well done on the special FX, Sound and Graphics which made the film feel real. The plot is stunning yet makes you feel at times that there could have been more towards it. At times the camera movement swayed too fast and made you look away from the screen for a short time. A lot of people loved the climax and were confused by the ending, therefore the film didn't balance out entirely to the expectations. This movie compares to other hit movies such as Godzilla, Day after tomorrow, War of the worlds and even the Blair Witch Project. The actors deserve credit and so does the film.

Many people were disappointed because they didn't understand that once the camera shuts or turns off during the film, the whole movie turns off too. This appeals at the end. If you didn't enjoy the films it compares to then maybe you should wait until it becomes available for rent. Though Altogether IMO this is a good film to check out in 08.

title: Whoa, this movie rocked my world.
review:
I sat up way in front just to get totally immersed in the movie, like I usually do. But, this time, whoa, I was sweating the entire movie, it was that good. I don't think I've felt this way about any movie my entire life. Not any movie. Just the way this was filmed the rawness of it,as if you're really looking at it from a "reality" point-0f-view, not like big Hollywood type movies where you have to suspend disbelief. This movie was awesome. Good work director and writer, JJ. Abrams, Matt Reeves, and Drew Goddard, Thank you, this is entertainment the way it's supposed to be. Whew... that was awesome ! Please, Please,..make sequel. perhaps it starts with Military in need of clues as they watch the ending of the Video. Then you can get into something really big budget with cool effects and regular Hollywood camera fare, since the semi-documentary is over.

Sheesh, I don't know, but a sequel is paramount.

title: Made me SICK!!
review: I can't give this movie a rating because i couldn't last longer than 30 minutes in the theater...and 20 of those i had my eyes covered. In my opinion at this stage anyway i have to give thumbs down to the attempt at artistic merrit. It's been almost 12 hours since i left the theater, and i still feel the lingering effects of motion sickness. I did make it through Blair WItch years ago without incident....Cloverfield went over the top with its hand-held camera effect, and it completely ruined the movie, and my day for me. I hope that the 6 or 7 other people that left before me, and who knows how many after me, were able to do something with the rest of their day...i spent mine curled up on the couch doped up on gravol

title: One of the best monster movies to ever hit the screen.
review: I had been following the movie since July when I went into the midnight showing on Friday. I was worried this movie wouldn't live up to its hype, but it did indeed. I went and saw this movie for my 2nd time today. The movie is just so amazing with sounds, visuals, and its mystery that is going to leave fans talking long after they've seen the movie. It's one of the most different monster movies i've ever seen not really focusing all the attention on the monster and more on the characters of the film. I loved J.J's work and we may be looking at a squeal. I guess time well tell what's in store for Cloverfield fans. My advice see this in theaters in will never be the same at home.

title: The Monster Movie: this time it's personal.
review:
Spielberg got us partway there with War of the Worlds (a huge missed opportunity to outdo the original). These guys -- Abrams and Reeves -- get us all the way there. 'There' is what it might feel like to be in the way of something big and angry and strange in New York city.

I rate this movie a 9 because it is nothing if not effective. The unknown actors are credible, the atmosphere is credible, and the scares are credible. All three are hard to sustain, especially considering the premise of this movie.

The way we all are blindsided and bewildered by events that jar us -- the way we lack the 'God's eye' perspective usually offered in such films; the way life-altering events seem to come out of nowhere... all are captured in a uniquely powerful way here.

Someone called this the first monster movie for the MySpace generation, and I can't argue with that. But I'm way beyond that generation, and I thought this was a breakthrough. Don't wait for rental, see it on the big screen.

title: Good Movie
review: This film could be reduced to a cross between The Blair Witch Project and Godzilla, but it rises above such amateur labels. This is a good flick based off of original cinematic methods, but addressing coherent and pertinent subject matter. The cinematography was good (as far as the genre goes). There were certain parts that I would advise anyone who is in any way sensitive to 9/11 to avoid. That is a big minus of this film: it is a great story, but the setting is... somewhat unsettling. The film makers could have used Chicago or L.A. as a setting and avoided the distraction. This distraction is onmniscient throughout the film. Nevertheless, I liked the film. There was a flow in the concept and the storyline.

title: Better than people give it credit for...
review:
I really don't like big-monster movies other than as fodder for MST3K. And this isn't so much about the monster itself as it is what the monster does. People somehow are missing that, partly because so many movies are just about the monster and some stereotype characters.

But this is different.

And it resonated with me because I understood what the film symbolized. Everyone's trying to evoke Sept. 11 and it's about that, but not the way people think. We're looking at 9-11 through the eyes of 7+ years of memory.

Think back to that horrific day when you had no idea what was happening and you just felt like an ant being fried on the sidewalk by some evil kid with a magnifying glass and you were helpless and unprepared and incapable of comprehending what was happening.

THAT is what Cloverfield is about. In the end, you have no idea what that thing was or where it came from and you doubt you'll ever know the truth...

...just like so many things in life. And when you come right down to it, disaster movies and their ilk, to me, are not about how cool the special effects and action are, but how it takes that feeling of being side-swiped by life and magnifies it so out of proportion that you don't feel so bad about it anymore by comparison when your car breaks down or you lose your job.

Sure, that sucks, but at least I'm not watching my friends get hit by flaming wreckage from some sort of towering colossal beast while everyone screams and runs.

I give it 8 out of 10. Flawed but then, so are the events in life.

And if there was a real giant monster attack, you can believe it would occur like this.

title: READ THIS before deciding NOT to see the Movie!!!
review: First off, I am an easy going movie patron. I pay the price of admission to escape for a while and to be entertained. Thats it, plain and simple. I do not expect every movie to shake the world and be an Academy Award winner. I just expect it to be somewhat interesting and intriguing. With all of that said, I will tell you that the only thing you should pay attention to in the negative comments are the warnings about dizziness from the shaky camera effect. When the film first started it did take a little while to get used to, but you DO get used to it (most people anyway). It appears that some people prefer to have standard cookie-cutter movies spoon-fed to them, which is unfortunate. A lot of movies can be compared to an Amusement Park Ride. Either you sit down, suspend disbelief and go along with it or you look at all the gears on the ride, complain about the way the characters are constructed, and completely remove yourself from the experience. Honestly, when you go to Disneyland, do you allow yourself to enjoy 'Its A Small World' & 'Pirates of the Caribbean' or do you complain about the flaws in craftsmanship? This is the same thing. Its a Popcorn Movie with monsters, presented in a unique way. And you know what??? It's done really well if you allow yourself to enjoy it.

title: Go see this movie
review:
I went and saw this movie last night and I loved it. When it comes out on DVD I am buying it....

First of all the whole camcorder thing was perfect, it was a new way of filming and I thought it made the movie intense, and realistic. But I do agree that some people might get dizzy or sick watching it, but I didn't and absolutely loved it. Also the monster does not disappoint, it was perfect

Plus u saw plenty of the monster in the movie, so the mysterious monster is finally revealed.

So go see this movie, I can already tell that it is one of the best movies of 08.

title: Intense Moments of Total Fear!
review: I totally loved this flick! Sure the video is choppy, but it usually is when shot from a hand-held video cam. This was so realistic, I felt like I was there with the group. Total mayhem like that would happen if this were a real event. I didn't feel the 'motion sickness' many of the reviewers speak of at all. The ending is abrupt and I found myself really wanting more as I left the theater. The next best thing Abrams and Reeves could do is collaborate on a sequel which would be shot in the normal sense for a film - with a more complete storyline which would explain the origins of the creature and its lively deadly 'offlings'...This film is brilliant in all the pre-marketing and even in the choice of filming for this type of perspective. I was totally involved with all the characters. I will definitely watch it again when it comes on DVD.

title: Cloverfield is unique
review:
First, I really need to say is: if you have any motion sickness or are pregnant and suffer from severe to moderate nausea, this movie is not for you.

The storyline was good, the monster was unique and very cool. The camera action was not! I have never been so motion sick during a movie for a long time. It was hard on the eyes and the constant moving was painful. Looking away didn't even help. Most of the people that I could see from my seat were either looking away or playing with their cell phones.

The intro to the movie was good until it got redundant. There are some parts you don't need to see or hear about. You're watching a movie of gore and blood, no one needs to see romance. I also did not like how they used the romance to the point where the main characters risked their lives to rescue someone who was possibly dead or dying. I just wish that they had used a rolling camera with a team, not some guy relating the problems to you. I did not find him funny and only laughed once.

I was also annoyed with the Brooklyn Bridge part. It was very dumb. Who heads out into a open, hanging part? Obviously the creature will notice and end that.

They should have ended it with Hud being picked up by the monster. You got to see the creature, and that should have been it. I did enjoy that you barely saw the monster or it's offspring, only when they were attacked. These people also hid in the most obvious of places. If that was me, I would have ran and never looked back. Nor would I head into the center of the chaos.

Again, good storyline, bad filming. Next time, use a better camera.

title: Not quite a movie, more of a ride. An awesome, hugely immersive ride. But be sure to watch it in theaters, it won't be the same on DVD.
review:
Cloverfield is a lot like a simulator ride with elements of a movie. It still is one of the scariest experiences in a theater I ever had.

The whole movie is shot like a homemade camcorder movie, and this is implemented perfectly. This isn't like the Bourne movies, where the camera loses it just when the action is getting good. The filming is much more realistic, and the cameraman's hand shakes a lot more, but it steadies itself when looking at important things, like the monster. The camera-work is so realistic it will put you right in the middle of all the action. This is probably the scariest part of the movie, because you think you're there. Way more immersive than any simulator ride I've ever been on. Never leaving the camera's point of view makes it an experience not unlike Half-Life.

The movie takes a while to get off, and spends some time introducing you to the characters. This is time well spent, as the backstory plays a big part later on. Also, you'll come to like the characters as you try to survive the ordeal together. The action starts at the perfect time, and rarely lets up after that. The dialogue is very believable (or believable enough, considering the situation), and never pulls you out of the immersion.

Overall, Cloverfield is definitely a movie I would recommend for anyone who wants to get their heart pounding for 80 minutes non-stop. I strongly urge you to watch it in theaters as it is an important part of the experience. The sound makes the theater rumble as debris hits the ground. The 50 foot screen makes you feel like you're seeing it with your own eyes. If you can see it in IMAX, even better. But don't wait for it to come out on DVD, because no matter how big your TV, it won't be the same.

title: Good movie, but take motion sickness meds before!
review: I have been looking forward to this movie ever since I saw an unnamed trailer online a long time ago. It did not disappoint, but it did make me feel "car sick" from almost the very beginning and one of the people in my group actually threw up in the bathroom at the end of the movie. Although it made me feel queasy, it did not take away from the experience too much, actually made it more real. If you are not prone to motion sickness, you will be fine, but I tolerated the Blair Witch and Bourne Identity movies just fine, so do not use those experiences to compare, because this one made me sick immediately, but it was mild and I still enjoyed the film greatly. It is funny, suspenseful, and gives you plenty of shots of the thing attacking New York, which is not Hilary Clinton, as one moviegoer shouted at the beginning of the movie- one of the reminders why going to the theater often can enhance the experience. So if you do not mind a shaky camera, and not having all the questions answered and just want to enjoy a different thrill type of movie, then go see it. If the shaky camera and unanswered questions will bother you, then you might want to pass, or wait until video when you can have a bucket nearby! 8/10! Addendum- I feel strongly that I should add, after having read other comments, that again, know what you are going to see. If you lived through 9/11 in New York, you may want to skip this if you are prone to post-traumatic stress, as the destruction of New York may bring that back to you. And, if you know you are prone to getting sick, then seriously, go to the store and get some over the counter medications! The warnings are out there people, heed them if you are vulnerable, rather than go then say it is a terrible movie!

title: The movie was very cool!
review:
I just saw the movie yesterday and it was really cool. I might add that I had no problem with what is characterized as "motion sickness". Maybe at the beginning it was a little, but by the time the party is happening, you are in the movie and the motion is much less. The acting was pretty good ( if you are concerned of it). If one word could characterize the acting, it would be "normal" What I mean is that it was really good. The effects were pretty cool too. the ending was very different than the other movies, but I liked it. SPOILER ALERT....................................................... About the ending, be careful to notice the splash in the right hand corner at the ending sequence in which Rob ad Beth are in Coney Island. The monster actually came from space about a month before the footage of the attack. END OF SPOILER......................................................

One recommendation: Do not go to the theater with "perfectionist" expectations. You will ruin the movie for yourself. Just go, relax, sit quietly,clear your mind,and enjoy. I really enjoyed it.

title: Cloverfield... Wow...
review:
This movie is genius.

Instead of being from the perspective of a omnipresent camera which tends to stay 50 miles away, this is from the perspective of the people running through the city in terror from the monster.

What an amazing movie. I don't want to give anything away. Just realize two things when you go in: Yes, you will be dizzy during the first 5-10 minutes (then the camera steadies out) and realize that the whole movie is from a camcorder video.

You will leave the theater feeling like you just experienced a giant monster attacking the city. You will leave the theater having seen amazing, ridiculous things. I absolutely loved this movie. Those who didn't were the ones who didn't know what to expect.

title: Best Documentary Ever
review:
Cloverfield=amazing!!! I know a lot of people don't like it, but I really don't understand why. It's in the form of a documentary from a group of young adults, trying to figure out what the heck just happened. They're trying to survive and save the people they love.

Yeah, the camera is shaky and it's hard to follow sometimes, but that's what makes it so good. The documentary point of view puts you in the middle on NYC and one of the survivors trying to find refuge.

Throughout the entire movie, I felt like I was there and running myself. I was physically exhausted afterward because I was so into the movie that I was tensed up because of the suspense.

If you love an action and suspense movie, go see Cloverfield. You won't be disappointed.

title: An excellent work of cinematic art.
review: Cloverfield, brought to us by the geniuses behind Lost, is a very different movie by normal standards. It follows a group of friends as they try to survive an attack by a gigantic monster and its little gremlin minions. The entire story is told through the group's hand-held digital camera, which makes for a very interesting twist on the storytelling. The creators were also very clever in adding flashbacks with this style of cinematography and storytelling. I personally didn't find the movie to be as terrifying as the MPAA rating suggests (violence, terror, and disturbing images) but it definitely had it's moments. The disturbing images part was right on target though. And the scale of the movie created by the digital camera-style filming definitely makes you feel as though you are actually there. There were a couple of moments, especially toward the end that made my eyes open wide and think, "Oh, crap." All in all, I really enjoyed Cloverfield. 8 out of 10.

title: An interesting half of a movie
review:
I saw this movie opening night in Australia and had no clue what to expect.

First point - the "home video" concept is interesting and gives the movie a nice feel, but I wish they could have at least kept the video still and level for at least a portion of the film. Even when there was no action going on, the camera was always off-center, angled, or shaking. My girlfriend and I regularly had to look away from the screen just to keep from getting motion sick. The lack of any video stabilization was unnecessary and over-the-top.

Second point - The characters, albeit fairly well-developed, are just plain stupid.
