The movie makes an attempt to portray the characters as courageous, but the panic-driven story line became very tiresome and predictable. Then again... there wouldn't have been much of a story if the characters made rational decisions.

Third point - unsatisfying movie. Although you get to see what's causing all of the destruction, there is absolutely no closure. You are left to wonder how the story ends, and by the end of the film I really didn't care if a single one of the main characters survived because I felt they all deserved whatever came to them for taking such ridiculous risks.

All in all - not worth my $15 except for the great previews for the upcoming action flicks Jumper and Iron Man.

title: Must See in Theatres
review:
Going into Cloverfield i had much the same expectations i had for snakes on a plane... this is going to suck. Much to my surprise i received a mind blowing visual experience that kept me glued to the screen. The beginning of the movie does an excellent job of developing the main characters and really helping you empathize with them and even put yourself into the story. Then the action hits you extremely quickly and doesn't let go until the ending credits roll.

I know a lot of people complained about the camera bouncing around too much. I for one did not find the camera style to be distracting i actually found it to be more immersing. The story and shooting brought something real to an event of complete fantasy, were at some points you felt it was almost believable.

While Cloverfield may not be for everyone if you are a hardcore movie goer, like myself, and love a great story, this is the film for you. If just looking at the tilt a whirl at your local county fair makes you queezy, then i would recommend you go see another film. In the end this film shattered my expectation and i think its one of the best films I've seen in the past year or so.

title: Believe the hype...but don't expect too much....
review:
When I walked out of this film I have two emotions: happiness and disappointment. I was happy because I got the film I wanted: a monster movie that didn't explain everything, but had enough for me to understand what the hell was going on. The main problem with Godzilla(98) is that it force-fed the audience what the monster is or where it came from. This movie leaves it up to your imagination, and I'm glad it did. I'm disappointed the film felt too short for a monster movie and too long for a love story. As much I appreciated an actual attempt at story, it distracted what was basically 65 minutes of monster madness( and 5 minutes of light humor). Though, if it wasn't for this love story, the movie would've been the length of a TV show.

Basically, the characters( no matter how annoying they were sometimes) were well acted, the monster looked pretty awesome( I think JJ Abrams need to thank the Half Life creators for some inspiration ) and it ended the way I wanted to end ( even though it could've been better).

So I say go see this film, u wouldn't regret it. Just don't come in expecting this to be the greatest movie ever made. It's just a great way to spend a Saturday night with your friends. Oh and word of advice: don't watch this film at least in the first 5-10 rows.....u will get motion sickness from the shaky cam.

title: Possibly the greatest movie ever...
review: Before you read this review let me just say I've been waiting a very long time for this movie. Ever since the mysterious trailer featured in Transformers, I have been completely psyched for the release of this movie and did some research online. This is everything how I pictured it and more. I enjoyed every single second of this movie. It sure kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire movie. Throughout this movie you will laugh, cry, and say "I can't believe that just happened!" and leave you wondering what will happen next. They did an AMAZING job with the camera in first person, and easily would not be the same without it. There are many questions you will ask yourself after you see the movie, and leaving you wanting to see it again as I definitely will. Some parts there was so much happening in the environment it was hard to tell what was going on, which is what makes this movie unique though. I will not tell any spoilers at all, but I was very mad when I heard people say "What! That movie sucked!" at the end. Before you do the same if you see the movie, just remember the intensity of every second of this movie. I will be disappointed if this doesn't make the Top 250 because it most definitely deserves the title. This is I think one of the best movies I've ever seen and the most adrenalin rushing experience I've ever seen in the cinema. I HIGHLY recommend this movie to anyone! I can't think of anyone who wouldn't enjoy this movie.

title: very,very strange
review:
OK....well I first saw the trailer for this movie right before Transformers....and I thought it would be very interesting.This movie, just like Godzilla; would actually both be decent movies if the stars of the movie were indeed the monsters attacking new york.

However just like in Godzilla it is drenched down with sappy whining 20 somethings that are either in love or wanna be in love with each other.The way this movie was shot;from the view of a character I thought was a mistake....I understand the beginning...for the testimonials and all....but the whole movie.....basically ruined it for me.I know this was supposed to be kinda blair witch-esquire;but way would any movie really wanna accomplish that....did they see that movie??...wasn't exactly...Good.If the movie was shot like all other movies and kinda more or less focused the emphasis on the monster itself and perhaps a little insight of why it was in Manhattan....where it came from....I think it could of been half way decent.....

title: Definitely Lives Up to the Hype.
review: After months of media hype, the J.J. Abrams-produced "Cloverfield" finally hit theaters, and the movie definitely delivers. "Cloverfield" is, without a doubt, the best monster flick yet made! I won't go into details about the plot, but it is very intense, exciting, and quite scary at times, with good performances from a terrific cast. The use of a P.O.V. style of film-making makes this film all the more believable. I won't go into detail about the main monster, except to say that it is fantastic! The only spoiler I have is this: along with the main monster, there are also hundreds of little creatures, and they are terrifying to behold as well! This film definitely puts "Godzilla" to shame. This is a terrific film that fans of sci-fi, horror, and monster films will want to see! One of the best ever made! Grade: A+

title: Cling to the character relationships.. and hold on for a good ride :)
review:
The relationships formed at the beginning between the characters really does carry the film through the 80 or 90 so minutes, if and only if you are drawn into these relations.

It so happens I was, I connected with the characters and laughed with the amusing comments that were made at times. So it was no surprise that I was very interested in seeing how the movie concluded.

In general, the first thing i'd touch on is the acting as these are not big names, we don't expect to see Denzel Washington like performances. And on that, to be honest these generally unknown actors do suit these roles much better then a famous actor would. The acting is convincing enough.

The camera work is a main focal point as most would know or heard of, but it is done a heck of a lot better then The Blair Witch. The people behind Cloverfield did their homework and took advantage of the Blair Witch's downfalls in this department no doubt.

There are instances in the movie where you may question why the camera is still rolling, but as I see it, this is common in these such films.

Summing up, this film is rewarding if you are able to cling to the characters at the beginning of the film. If you don't by the time all the crazy stuff starts happening. You most likely wont enjoy it.

Overall i give it a 7/10, I don't really want to write specifically why it loses 3 points as i will spoil some things, but they are due to unrealistic events occurring in a movie that is using realistic camera work.

title: Be prepared for Excedrin headache #29!
review: The film is shown in a retrospective with the camera work reminiscent of the Blair Witch project. That's O.K. The premise of the initial news of some form of catastrophe in the city of New York and eventual "encounter: with the beast/alien was well done. however, some of the acting was immature, silly and adolescent at best. Not to spoil the plot, some of the behavior of the main characters was juvenile and the dialogue was 2nd grader level. We are drawn into characters that are the most naive and stupid I have watched in a movie. The characters as a whole are barely nelievable and cartoonish. When confronted with a catastrophe of this nature, normal thinking people run AWAY from the scene of ground zero, not towards it. the film's second half seems to be some type of virtual reality game. Enough said. I prognosticate this film will not do well in the box office once people find out. I will definitively will not be anticipating to buy the video. The move is entertaining in parts but misses the mark by about a few hundred meters. The camera work eventually felt as if the viewer will be having a seizure at any minute. Wheww!

title: "Lost" Potential
review:
After months of anticipation, I have to say I was somewhat disappointed in this film. While I felt the concept was a great idea, the story was well thought, the execution was just lacking.

First off, they went WAY overboard with the hand-held camera feel. I spent half the film having to try and not focus on the screen to keep the dizziness at bay. Perhaps had they just shown and opening shot from the camera menu that showed "Steady Cam On" or something like that, they could have filmed a bit less motion blur. This unfortunately kept me distracted through much of the film.

The performances were generally pretty decent, but there was something lacking. I never felt any anxiety, or anticipation, or fear, or sadness, or pretty much any emotion. As a person who likes to get swept up in the story, I was very much aware that I was watching a movie.

I plan on giving this another chance when it hits video, but for now I would say it was a great idea that unfortunately wasn't pulled off.

title: Cloverfield Exceeded Expectations
review: I went into this film thinking about all the hype and being worried about it not living up to it but to me Cloverfield definitely did and exceeded the expectations I had. I have always liked the idea of our own Godzilla or something like that and Cloverfield did a great job of giving it to us. Honestly I was pretty freaked out by the whole idea of a giant monster just destroying everything and this didn't help. Although the first person camera view has been done before I think Cloverfield just made it better, it personalized this genre of movies. The special effects were amazing and the acting made it seem real. All of the characters are easy to relate to. I say this may be one of the best of the year to me. Everyone should go see this film.

title: Bottom line: amazing.
review:
There is nothing i can say that could express the excitement i felt while watching this movie. Although many monster story movies end up being a huge disappointment, this movie will change that forever. Clover field was not just about some crazy insane humanity hating monster, but about the emotion. I loved it, phenomenal, outstanding, greatest effing movie ever. It had everything a good movie needs:I laughed, I cried, I laughed til i cried, i was in shock, i was scared, i was excited and anxious. I feel that the whole "blair witch" type filming really made the movie, along with the dry-humor given through "Hud". All in all it was a great movie, props to everyone who helped create it. I will see it again, many times, before it leaves theaters.

GO SEE IT.

title: Visceral, action-packed, and original.
review:
I really enjoyed this film. I thought it was very original in the way that it was filmed from a first person perspective, and the ending was very bold for an expensive American film. Like most people I had high expectations for this movie and it mostly lived up to them. The special effects were very good and it clearly relied on evoking images of 911.

I don't have much to say that hasn't already been said but I'd just like to make some comments about the monster. While I thought the monster was pretty good (and scary), it could have been better. Obviously the makers of this film were aiming for maximum realism and so the monster could have been more "believable" by for example not giving it humanoid features. Since it is supposed to have come from outer space how can it have a humanoid face with recognizable facial expressions. For that to be so it would have to have descended from the evolutionary ancestors of mankind. Also another point of realism, how can the US military fire so much ordinance at the monster (destroying much of the city) and still not kill it? Absurd! The film makers captured a very realistic and immersing feeling and they did the right thing by not showing much of the creature until the end since it is much more effective when only partially and briefly glimpsed in the midst of the action, thus maintaining its mystery.

The characters were hard to sympathize with I think. They were just twenty-something yuppies living in New York and I find it hard to believe that they would go out of their way and risk life and limb to document the events portrayed in Cloverfield. Perhaps they should have been scientists or journalists, that would have been more believable.

If you are thinking of seeing this film you should definitely go see it in the cinema and not wait for it to come out on DVD since it is a visceral experience needing a big screen and powerful surround sound system to be truly appreciated and will not be half as good on a small screen. Also, be warned that because it is filmed in "queasy-cam" style it may make you feel nauseous on the big screen.

title: You'll Either Love it or Hate It - I Loved It
review:
NO SPOILERS!

I just got back from the midnight screening and I have to tell you how awesome I thought Cloverfield was. It is not surprising to see how many people are already bashing this movie. What is surprising though is why they are. People keep on complaining about the camera work and the way the movie ends. Let me ask those people this: What did you expect? It was pretty clear since the beginning that this movie was being filmed on a Handy-cam. So why expect still shots and Academy Award winning cinematography? I think the reason why people are giving this so much crap is because they were annoyed by all the buzz and just decided to lash out against the movie itself. I'm not saying that's the case with all of you guys, but I know there are those people out there that are like that.

If you haven't seen the movie yet, let me just give you some tips before you do. Don't go in expecting a typical monster movie with a beginning, middle, and end. Abrams and Reeves set out to redefine the monster movie genre and that is exactly what they do. They made this movie very unique, managing to stay away from a lot of the pitfalls and clichés that always manage to sneak into the other monster flicks.

I may just be the only person who enjoyed the camera work. Seeing it from the point of view of the people who went through it made it even more incredible and realistic. I hardly get scarred or jump in a movie, but this one definitely will cause a few jumps! However, if the whole shaky camera thing is not your cup of tea, then you have been warned (although you don't really need a warning). I did not find it distracting or nauseating like some people will say (overreacting of course), but I can understand how there are those of you out there who will not like it.

Secondly, be prepared to find that there is actually a human element involved in this film. The characters are so realistic it's hard to remember that they are just actors; they do such a great job of keeping the film going when they aren't running for their lives. Basically, the main character Rob is trying to find the girl he loves throughout this entire attack, going against the common sense of getting the hell out of there! And lastly, do not expect to have all your questions answered. I'm gonna try and not spoil anything here so I'll just say this: whatever the hell that monster is or where it came from is up in the air at this point.

Some of you may not like the ending. I found it fitting and strangely satisfying. Although, why people think there will be a sequel is beyond me.

Cloverfield is a very entertaining movie that manages to keep you on the edge of your seat most of the time and has a surprising amount of humor from cameraman Hud. The graphics are very well done, the monsters are refreshingly new and original, and overall the film kept me entertained. IT IS NOT FOR EVERYONE, but if this sounds like something you will like then see it! 8/10

title: A Great Monster Movie
review: For those who think that this is suppose to be the cliché, "Blaire Witch meets Godzilla" clash, you are are completely and utterly misled. This is a very good POV film and needs to be treated as something of it's own kind. People need not compare it to other films, but rather compare other future films to it, because it's style will probably be mimicked. This is a very realistic film, as realistic as it can be at least. It has its moments but you are mostly left believing these are real emotions the actors are displaying. The biggest problem that I saw some members of the audience having was that they were being nauseated by the camera's wild motion. Folks, if you know you can't handle things like that, this isn't the movie for you. As for the hype, hype will always ruin every movie if you listen to the guy that always hates the movies that have it built up. If you go in there because you have a personal interest to see what it is suppose to be about, and it seems interesting and innovative to you, see it. If you are seeing it because everyone is talking up a storm about it and have no real clue what to think yourself, wait till it comes out on DVD. It is a great theater experience. Even the greatest home entertainment system and the most comfortable couch on the planet couldn't do it justice like the true silver screen does. See it if you like monster movies and aren't afraid of camera motions nauseating / disorienting you. I went in expecting a mildly entertaining thriller, and came out having seen a very interesting and intense monster flick that deserves to be held as unique and brand new. (Ps: I have never watched any of JJ Abrams productions)

title: What a horror film should be...
review:
****************CONTAINS MINOR SPOILERS*********************************

Minutes ago, I finished seeing the midnight premiere of Cloverfield at the Uptown Theatre in Washington, DC. If anything, I had low expectations going in. I found myself pleasantly surprised by an elegant horror film.

All too often, horror films suffer from three basic faults. First, horror films tend to devolve into morality tales or popularity contests in which unlikeable and/or morally flawed characters die and usually do so in horrible ways. Second, horror films tend to reveal too much of the monster, by either showing the monster in full detail or by revealing too many facts about the creature. Third, although it is not necessary that all major characters die, uplifting endings tend to reduce the full impact of a horror film. Cloverfield's effectiveness lies in its ability to clear each of these hurdles.

First, Cloverfield avoids being a morality tale or popularity contest by presenting us with a set of characters with whom the audience can relate and who show, overall, positive or at least understandable character traits. Although the characters have slightly different personalities, no one is written to be clearly more or less likable than anyone else. There are times, however, when we question the wisdom or morality of certain characters' actions. For instance, the audience would probably question both the morality and wisdom of one character whose decision to film this incident in undeterred by the destruction surrounding him or even the deaths of some of his friends. Further, the audience is left wondering how moral it is to search for one person in NY city (which forms the underlying premise for the film) thereby endangering the lives of everyone else in the group (a kind of 'Saving Private Ryan' problem). Although these characters make decisions that are questionable or even downright stupid at times, the characters acknowledge the risks that they're taking and behave in ways that someone may conceivably behave in a high stress situation. Further, the resolve of the character filming the incident and of the character who spurs the group forward looking for a woman who may already be dead (not to mention the loyalty of his friends who agree to go with him) further makes us like and even root for the characters.

Second, although we see a lot of the monster, we tend to see parts of the creature in low light situations or in between buildings. When we finally do see the creature in daylight, the sun is to the creature's back, creating a halo effect that obscures the details of the creature's face (this was done rather effectively with the aliens in M. Night Shyamalan's 'Signs'). Further, we are left knowing very little about the monster and its origins. Ultimately, fear is based on ignorance, and since you leave the theater with more questions than answers about the monster in Cloverfield, the monster remains terrifying. For an alternate example, consider the creatures from the ALIEN films. These aliens are scary for a time. Once you know where they come from, how they mature, and that they are essentially social insects, however, every film afterward feels like a National Geographic special about the predatory behaviors of the Man-Eating Parasitic Xenomorph of LV-426. They're not scary- just interesting at best. If Cloverfield has sequels, this monster will inevitably suffer the same fate. But for now, the monster's mystery keeps it scary.

Finally, horror films are essentially multi-million dollar ghost stories. Ghost stories are most effective when either (a) the monster wins (b) there is a threat that the monster will return or (c) there is an ominous sense that the creature was not fully understood and a graver fate awaits the characters. I will not spoil the ending by telling you whether Cloverfield conforms to (a), (b), or (c), but, I will say that, in regards to the ending, Cloverfield takes a page from 'The Birds' and 'Night of the Living Dead' in that the fate of the characters, the monster, or even mankind are left to some extent uncertain.

I am giving Cloverfield an 8/10 because it manages to be a great horror film not by offering something new but by borrowing from classics. Elements of 'The Birds,' 'Night of the Living Dead,' and, of course, 'The Blair Witch Project' are fundamental to the film's success. Indeed, I am surprised that no one made a film like this soon after 'The Blair Witch Project' because that film's success makes a film like this a foregone successor.

title: More than what was expected.....
review:
First and foremost I have to say I really enjoyed this movie. I spent a great deal of effort avoiding any speculative discussion about the nature of the movie prior to my viewing (and I've been excited about it since the first preview in Transformers!) in order to avoid any feelings one way or another. I went in completely neutral, but left in awe.

I have been reading some of the reviews and thought I would add my two cents. I personally think this a "love it or hate it" movie for the most part. This is, unfortunately, due largely to the way it was filmed which is actually what was most enjoyable for me. Don't get me wrong now, all the running did make me dizzy, maybe even a little nauseous, but it was nothing someone who's watched a few home movies can't handle. The handy-cam point of view adds so much excitement and suspense to the movie though. It really feels like you're there, right in the action with everyone else. You become lost and confused, nervous and anxious, and you truly feel how small and desperate everyone is. There are moments in the film that just literally sucked me right into the streets of New York, military all around fighting the good fight, running for my life with my heart beating out of my chest!

Now I do have to admit this is not your typical movie. There is no real "development" so-to-speak. After all, you follow the same group of people with the same camera the whole film. You can only learn as much as they can, which isn't much. But, that really isn't what the movie is about. If you go in expecting there to be some Hollywood ending to the movie you are not going to be happy. Some people say there is no ending, but I assure you there is. You have to accept what is offered. So if you can stomach the camera (really not that bad) and take the movie for what it is (a guy with a handy-cam in the midst of a disaster) I'm confident you will thoroughly enjoy every minute.

title: So you've never been to Coney Island?
review:
"What is Cloverfield?" We've been hearing it for almost 6 months now-although "What is 1-18-08?" was first said till it gained it's titled- but regardless we all wanted to know what Cloverfield was. Today we found out. Sorta.

Cloverfield is the codename given to an incident that occurred in New York city. It's footage recovered from a hand-held camera find in the aftermath of this incident. Its the lives of Rob and his friends as they experience first hand what occurred. It's our gateway to experience what they went through. Its utter brilliance.

It begins a bit like Deathproof, you know that movie that played after Planet Terror in Grind House, the one that not many people stayed to see. Slow conversation, a build up of character, boring blah blah blah BOOM.

Panic and Chaos ensues. Headless statue of liberty, dust, debris and more panic and chaos ensues. So what? Somewhere between all this, however, is a story of one mans journey to find the love of his life. Midway across the city. (One of the major downfalls of this movie. SOOO Cliché!!) But at the same time we're treated to snippets of what this creature looks like, and that it spawns other little demons. So through this first person look we find love of life, run for safety and then end up.... with a awesome shot of creature and then nothing. (Not necessarily, but i don't want to ruin the "ending.") Okay so yes it never really ends. The story of Rob and his friends does, it comes to a complete close, but we never really find out where the creature originated from, (although we are given theories by the funny cameraman, Hud. And who knows, perhaps one of his theories were, but we never find out.) Or what happens after the incident either. It just ends. And some of you might say thats dumb, and I agree but at the same time makes the movie that much more interesting. Why? Let's say a month from now we get a book, or a website, or some other form of 411 giving. An account of what occurred after wards. Wouldn't you go out and buy this book, or visit that website to get the lowdown? We know the tape was found, and we know someone find the tape. So whose to say that the spiffy marketing campaign the movie had, wasn't replicated by the film to, this time promote say-such book. I can't guarantee there will be more but I'm confident there will be. And we're all going to chew it up to learn it all.

So why did I give it a 9? Well, first of all it didn't get a 10 for the clicheness of our hero and for the simple matter that I don't want more later, but now. Aside from that. This movie delivers. It's got a bit of comedy, even when the creature is but a foot away. And it's got a hell of a lot of suspense. It's got terror, as in, "Oh sh!t, I pooped my pants." and it's got some sad moments that makes you want to cry, (not my, chick I went with.) But most of all suspense. (The climbing of the building to find Beth, the roof top scenes that was brilliant.) I just can't wait till tomorrow to see it again, and Sunday to see it once more. And, although the first 15-20 minutes are good for the first viewing, it's get a tad boring. But I do recommend watching it for character development the first time around.

As for the camera and those "users" giving the movie one star based on the nausea they acquired throughout the movie, I didn't experience it. Yes the camera shakes but and we do see some floor, but thats only like 2 minutes combined in the 2 hour movie, (although the ending does show the floor a lot, there is no movement.) It's absurd to give a movie a one star rating just cause it got you dizzy. Reading those reviews I see no mention about the plot or the monster leading me to believe the movie wasn't even seen.

Also, leaving the movie theater a lot of whispers could be heard saying, "Thats it?" I just chuckled to myself and said "It is J.J Abrams." However, even if the movie did have an actual tell-all ending, I think they would of found something else to complain about.

Again, just watch the movie for the movie is like a ride you've never experienced before. You can compare it to the first time you rode a roller-coaster. It begins slow, comes down fast, takes some turns, makes a loop, drops a couple of times and then abruptly ends. You may become sick but your still left wanting more. But there isn't, there's an hour wait for a 60 second ride. And once it's done you have to stand in line and wait some more for the next attraction to experience some more.

title: A Nutshell Review: Cloverfield
review:
OMIGAWD! OMIGAWD! RUN! OMIGAWD! HELP! GET THE HELL OUT! OMIGAWD!

You'd be expecting to hear a lot of that, but not to fret, the rest of this review is spoiler free, guaranteed! So we've weathered a six month wait since the teaser trailer premiered with Michael Bay's Transformers (and draws some parallels, more on that later), and set the net buzzing with its many viral marketing sites appearing online, some red herrings, some dangling treats for those who can't wait to guess just what the movie will be titled (well, just Cloverfield), and speculate on how the creature, if it was one, would look like.

In recent history, Hollywood had tried this stunt before. Remember the Godzilla of 1998? Audiences were teased with a tail here, a roar there, and the filmmakers pretty much had the monster kept under tight wraps. Until it opened, and because it failed to live up to its hype, and didn't meet everyone's expectations of how the good old Japanese lizard would look like and behave, it tanked at the box office. Now, Cloverfield adopted similar strategies in having us hear a roar, and to witness its destructive powers, without a visual clue of what it looked like. Did it deliver?

Strangely enough, in my opinion, yes. Don't get me wrong, as I was leaning toward, and close to committing the cardinal sin of loathing a movie prior to experiencing it for myself first hand. I was apprehensive about watching something that perpetually couldn't keep still, and yet its technique adopted in presenting the movie worked perfectly. Like Blair Witch Project, we witness a series of events as unfolded through the lens of a hand-held consumer camera. In doing so, we forgo watching the movie from a third person perspective, and get plunged head on to first person instead. In this age of reality television, exclusive news scoops, youtube voyeurism, this shakycam technique works in putting us there where the action is, watching things unfold, raw.

Imagine, just if, a big unknown were to happen. You push and probe, and frankly, get scared, wondering what to do next, worry about your loved ones, and probably would just follow the masses. Cloverfield took a simple, tried and tested story about a monster invasion in the scale of Godzilla's, and played with us - what if we were caught in the same situation with the monster pounding everything in sight - what would we do? We take pictures for our blogs. Then run.

I would put my neck out even to say that there is no grounds of comparison between Cloverfield, and one of my recent monster movie favourite The Host, simply because it's like comparing apples and oranges. The latter decided to show all very early in the movie, and had a strong focus and emphasis on the family of characters. Here, we don't feel much for the yuppies, we somehow become one of them, the videocam being our eyes and ears. And the creature, while we don't see it in full glory clearly, makes it all the more menacing. It plays on actual fear - we catch a glimpse, then quickly run away - and I thought it made the 1998 Godzilla look like a pussy with so much unexplained, that this uncertainty breeds and grows within you.

But of course there will be some quick to dismiss this along the lines similar to those who dislike Transformers on the grounds that there isn't enough screen time for what mattered to them - "we're here to see robots/monsters, so give us the robots/monsters!" As mentioned, there are nice moments where we sneak a peek at the rampaging creature, but there will be those whose appetite remain insatiate. Bear in mind though the point here is to experience what it would be like if you're stuck in a similar situation yourself (wonder why this wasn't available in IMAX format), rather than watching in God mode, the narrative unfold in extended Starship Troopers style. And similar to Transformers, Odette Yustman is your new Megan Fox, except that she goes back to being the classic damsel.

Cloverfield, if it makes enough money at the box office, leaves plenty of room with multiple doors wide open to possibilities of spin offs, prequels, sequels, and probably even a television series, animated or live action, or through any other visual medium. You can essentially repeat the same premise, but from different points of view - trust me, there are enough - and can probably build an entire community of creative work just around this one simple flint to sustain a campfire.

OMIGAWD!

title: Overhyped
review:
With years of hype, Cloverfield was swathed in mystery, with several name changes (even the first trailer released did not have the title attached) and only brief glimpses of the main monster shown before the films release. The film is a science fiction thriller, focusing on the rampage of a monster through New York and was aiming to replace King Kong as the so-called Godzilla of America. Of course, nothing is ever as good as it seems. Clovefield turned out to be a polarizing movie, at best a daring experiment and at worst poorly written and migraine-inducing.

Cloverfield begins in NYC, at a party thrown for one of the characters. The first 15 minutes is boring drama. The 20 something characters aren't memorable at all, but at least most of them aren't overwhelmingly annoying. The most critical point of this exposition is to introduce the audience to the found footage style the movie is in. The movie is supposedly film recovered by the government after the actual interesting part of the movie takes place, but we'll get to that in a bit. The party is being documented by one of the kids, which turned out to be the excuse the director used to explain the entire movie being from the viewpoint of a shaky camcorder. It's an interesting decision, and makes the brief appearances of the monster (unofficially called Clover) more impactful as well as helping the audience to be immersed with the characters. However the shaky view could be nauseating for some viewers, and can cause the film to be a little confusing at times.

After fleeing the party when the monster begins its attack, the party group is split and the rest of the movie is spent by the main party searching for first a brother, and then a past love interest. At this point believability of the characters actions. No sane person would rush towards a large monster they don't understand, or would the military allow several civilians to leave instead of evacuating. The most bizarre point in the movie is when a woman is pulled off rebar, and is apparently fine just minutes later. With a script reworking and some better casting, the film could've been a lot more enjoyable. The only truly gripping moment of the movie in when in the final moments of the film, the only two surviving characters profess their love for each other, as bombs explode around them and the monster roars. The camcorder then skips to an earlier time when the two were on a date, and the film ends on a bittersweet note.

J. J. Abrams (via his influence from Bad Robot Productions) intended Cloverfield to be America's Godzilla, and with a bit of magic it could've been. The film was held back by a lack of emotionally relatable characters, and wasn't quite interesting enough to rely on shock value. The unanswered questions posed in the film makes you think about after it is over. Clocking in around an hour and a half, Cloverfield is not a particularly long film if you don't enjoy it. If you did enjoy it, there's a chance you'll be frustrated with how great of a film it could've been. Overall, I would not consider Cloverfield to be a bad film, just a large missed opportunity.

title: Ok... Would have been better if...
review: I really wanted this film to tie into Lost. That was the main reason it had my interest. The concept of a bunch of yuppies running from a monster lost my interest pretty quickly. But it would have been really cool if it was a Dharma thing...

title: I think it was a bit alright.
review: An exciting lost, found, film footage movie, that was a fresh injection to the 'Monsters from outta space, coming to get you' genre. Some tight, solid set pieces and with the suitable chaos that would follow such a catastrophic invasion. Not really feeling why so many have scored it a 1 but there you go.

title: Epic!
review: Most tense, epic, and thrilling found footage film you'll come across. Though if you found Blair Witch too shakey, this may be too much for you.

title: Over-rated, bad acting and no plot
review:
There's been some time I haven't seen a worse acting. The plot is so full of mistakes and inconsistent and incoherent that it seems written by a child on the school break.
Waste of time

title: the authenticity and impression are perfect
review: Some of the intense motion pictures are really dizzy, but the authenticity and impression are perfect, and the actors are very natural in the camera. What does the plot say? Run desperately to save people, and then be penetrated by steel bars as well as nothing?

title: Bad camera, and boring at the start, but became good after
review: The camera was really bad i wanted the camera to be steady, i dont want the camera to be moving, and honestly this movie was kinda boring at the start, but it became good after so yeah...the CGI is good for 2008 and the acting here is pretty good

title: If you're able to get past the shaky cam, it's really good.
review: I never saw the movie until just recently, since Netflix was kind enough to put it on, but I was really impressed with this movie. The beginning is a little slow, but as soon as the chaos hits I found myself at the edge of my seat the whole time to the end. You could actually feel what the characters were feeling throughout the movie. Scared, confused, all of it

title: Smart
review:
'Cloverfield' is a smart and engaging found-footage monster horror that will keep its viewers on edge.
The team of director Matt Reeves, producer J.J. Abrams and writer Drew Goddard create a great horror flick that is surprisingly unpredictable and one of the tensest films I have seen in a while. The well-thought out pacing enables it's viewers to know just enough about the main characters to care about them, so when the action starts you're actually hoping that the characters will make it. Character establishment is an important aspect of any film, particular horrors because the audience needs to have some sort of attachment to it's characters in order for them to actually enjoy the movie because you have people you want to root for. From the very moment that the terror begins, it essentially doesn't stop, resulting in that edge-of-your-seat feeling that we all love. The fact that the entire film is done in an amateur manner, through a shaky camcorder, helps the viewer immerse into the film and it adds a sense of reality. Therefore, when the scares come, they are nothing short of frightening. However, this film did have a few flaws as some scenes seemed rather far-fetched, particularly at the end, which broke the sense of realism. There was also some predictability, but it was balanced with a few moments that were surprising.

title: Cloverfield review.
review: When I first heard of this movie, I was skeptical because I wasn't a big fan of Paranormal Activity and I haven't seen the Blair Witch Project. I watched it and I loved it, but I did started to have a bit of dizziness 20 minutes into the movie. The reason I love this movie is because It's extremely realistic and the acting doesn't even look like acting and it's everyday people just doing their everyday life things and then all of a sudden, they are the victims of a giant creature and just like they, the audience have no idea about this thing and what it is. The special effects are amazing and the dialogue is very ordinary and normal. My favorite part is when the guy holding the camera sees the monster for the first time and it looks extremely huge in size. Cloverfield, Paranormal Activity, The Blair Witch Project, and any other found footage are the type of movies that you either "love or you hate". I love this movie, but I can 100 percent sympathies with you if you get motion sickness, because my brother Gerard got motion sickness and hated the movie. Another thing I was taken by surprise that a reference to 9/11 was used when the Statue of Liberty's head fell into the city and the dust of clouds came. It's very offensive that they referenced to that. That's the only problem I have with this movie. Go see Cloverfield, but bring some Dramamine when you go and see for yourself. This is my opinion.

title: Waste of time
review:
I've watched a good deal of bad movies, hell, I make it a habit of watching them, yet I always end up finding entertainment value on them.

I couldn't find a single redeeming factor about this movie. It just feels like a pure waste in all aspects. The footage style is atrocious. I could bear with it if the story and the ending had any redeeming value. I'd rather watch paint dry if I knew this movie was this bad.

How it managed to get a 7/10 rating is beyond me, but who cares. A polished turd is still a turd.

title: Worst movie ever!
review:
Hey Rob Hey Rob Hey Rob Hey Rob Hey Rob, Rob Rob Roooobbbbb

If I hear those words again, I'm going to smash my T.V. "Hey Rob" was yelled more times than I can count. The acting in this movie was pathetic, with all the heavy breathing and every scene being predictable. There was absolutely no creativity in any part of the movie. Even the C.G.I was unbelievable. This movie makes my top ten list of the worst movies ever made. If you have not watched this movie, Please don't waste your time.

title: No More Found Footage!
review: I'm not democrat or republican. But I'll vote for any party that promises to outlaw found footage movies. I'll dig up my uncle Louie and have him vote too if they also promise to outlaw shaky cam.

title: Excellent Monster Flick
review:
I give this movie 8 stars just for the main creature. Coming from someone that is a big monster movie fan, this is a great monster and the little spidery things that come off of the larger creature are indisputably terrifying (almost more so than the larger creature), not to mention that you explode if you're bitten by them (which is super cool).

The downside of this movie is that none of the human characters are all that likable. None of them are very relatable and the movie fails to make you care about any of them or their concerns. So, while the whole movie depends on the crew trekking into hostile territory to save someone, the emotional weight is never there.

title: LIke Most Films About Survival, It Does a Decent Job
review: There are so many plot holes that it's hard to feel positively about this film. Still, it had a modicum of suspense and characters that we sort of cared for. The protagonist leads his peers on what should have been a hopeless venture. As a monster is attacking Manhattan, he manages to get to an apartment building, go into a building next door, and cross over to rescue his girlfriend. The possibility of any of this is beyond belief. Sad as he feels over his poor girlfriend's plight, he isn't going to rescue her. Oops! I spoke way too soon. Why are these monsters so set on knocking down skyscrapers? Are they hungry? Why would the idiot continue to film when everyone is running for their lives. But if you don't want to think too much, it will entertain you pretty well.

title: Before Found Footage Movies Got Out Of Hand
review: Cloverfield takes the Godzilla formula but with the found footage style. Director Matt Reeves and Drew Goddard took something that should have been terrible, but gave it enough style and substance to make it a fun and entertaining thriller. You don't go to these films for Oscar worthy acting or ideas. You go to these films to shove popcorn in your face and have a fun time. That's why it deserves a 9 out of 10, because as a standard monster thriller, it is a well above average movie. The action is intense and not lazily filmed, you are never bored, and thanks to the Cabin in the Woods writer/director, has some humor in it as well. This is not a horror film, which some think it is. The acting is good enough to not take you out of the movie immersion. This is an excellent rental.

title: A total thrill ride...after those first 15 minutes
review:
I almost gave up on this because the first 15 minutes are super annoying. Watching a bunch of young New Yorkers at a going away party through the shaky, jarring point of view of a hand-held video camera. Thankfully I stuck with it though because after those first 15 minutes, when the sh*t hits the fan, look out!

Cloverfield then becomes a total thrill ride as we follow 5 of those partygoers (documentary style) through the city as a giant monster descends on New York. You really feel like you're in it with them due to the unique imagery, reminding me at times of some of the post 911 shots seen on TV. Anyways I ended up getting quite wrapped up in this.

The story is pretty good, nothing too original but because of how its been filmed it feels unique as the army descends, N.Y is evacuated and one of the characters attempts the carnage to rescue his girlfriend.

I loved how the monster isn't fully seen for quite a while (in a 'Jaws' sort of way) this made it much scarier. "did you see that?" "what the hell was that?" I think a lot of the dialogue was probably unscripted here too. I also liked the ending which is left...vague, with lots of questions, so that you're asking yourself "And then what happened?" Would love to see a sequel to this. 5/31/14

title: Why can't a disaster movie ever have REAL people?!
review: Don't know why, but never saw Cloverfield until the other night, and didn't really know what the movie was about. Just saw a 77 Rotten T rating on Direct TV and taped it. To say this is one of the worst film I've even sat through is an understatement! Yes, it completely rips off The Blair Witch, who is now a 500 foot monster in New York City. I'm mind-boggled how anyone with any sense could find this movie even the slightest bit entertaining.??? It drags on in the beginning with "Hud" (TJ Miller) who is given a hand-held video recorder to film comments about some friends who are preparing for marriage. BORING. Of course the camera wiggles and goes in and out of focus to the point of migraine. BTW, how did Miller ever get an acting job. You only hear his voice through 99% of the movie, and that's annoying enough! So the monster FINALLY shows up and people do what they always do in Hollywood movies.... The exact opposite of reality. If you see a 500 ft monster destroying NYC and a friend wants to go straight towards it, to save his girlfriend who is injured, you're not going to follow. More like, "You are crazy, and if you go it's on your own, idiot!" Oh, and when your buddy holding the camera continuously films your friends getting killed cause "people will need to see this," instead of turning the damn thing off and helping, you're probably going to kill or seriously injure him. It was so stupid!!! You also know that, like in Blair Witch, they are all going to die and the camera will capture it. Took me 5 min to figure that one out. Oh yeah, the guy actually does get to his injured girlfriend. Yeah, she's got a piece of rebar sticking out through her chest from the building she was in falling over. She's not dead. Nope, she is very much alive, and is then violently pulled of the rebar, and then continues to run around, seemingly unhurt, the rest of the film. Of course, only until she's killed in the last scene... A "7" score on IMDb??? Is this for real, or is this as science fiction as the characters in this awful movie. Oh, there's a sequel coming. Wow!

title: Movie makers never learn...,
review: It seems as though too many wannabe sci-fi/horror movie makers have not realized that the "Apocalyptic-Giant-Monster-Attack + Lots-of-Little-Creepy-Monsters + Shaky-Camera-First-Person-View + Dark-Tunnels-and-Hallways + Screw-It-Let's-Nuke-The-Site-From-Orbit-It's-The-Only-Way-To-Be-Sure" equation has been overdone, and they should have learned from the Godzilla '98 travesty. The giant monster had the _potential_ to be really cool, but despite the myriad conceptual drawings (that leaked their way onto the Internet), the powers-that-be opted to go with a Godzilla/Marauder/Arachnid hybrid that was creepy without being truly terrifying. The spider-like "ticks" that seemed to steal their movements and appearance from "Pitch Black" and "Starship Troopers" monsters held little appeal other than a way of saying "Boo!" during quiet moments in the movie. If you are prone to motion sickness, don't plan on enjoying your popcorn in the theater, as the first-person shaky-camera footage throughout the movie (as in, the ENTIRE movie) will ruin your intestinal fortitude. After looking at the 8 out of 10 clover-field received on IMDb, I was fairly excited about seeing the flick. However about halfway through the movie I realized that there really wasn't any plot.. Not even any main characters.. My 8 year old cousin could have produced a better movie! The entire movie consisted of a couple of friends trying to get away from this giant clover-field spider (Which is actually a type of spider) If I could have thought of the typical monster movie taking over the city and destroying everything this would have definitely fit the mold! An would have fallen far short of my expectations.. 3 out of 10 is a generous rating for the movie as I don't even think it should receive a star! Don't WASTE YOUR MONEY OR TIME

title: Brilliant.
review:
When the first indescribably spontaneous trailer for 'Cloverfield' previewed, Abrams and co. effectively threw the absorbent mystery net over the viewers. Releasing the brilliantly teasing two minute trailer of a ravaged national sculpture being tossed through NYC and supporting text other than 'Produced by J.J Abrams' - no movie title. Terrorist movie? Monster movie? Disaster movie? What we acquired about J.J's style from 'Lost' was that there were no limitations. This movie was spectacularly marketed. The opening character meet and greet serves a comfortable introduction to the characters who endure the mystery J.J has in store for them. Deciding on a slightly less recognisable cast really allowed the interest in the characters to flourish, with no John Mcclane's or James Bond's to assure us they'll get the girl and save the world. 'Cloverfield' is boldly portrayed, tensely gripping and since its release in 2008 has been a monster movie unrivaled (arguably until Abrams returned with 'Super 8' in 2011).

8/10.

title: I Don't Know Why It's Happening.....
review:
"I don't know why it's happening". In hindsight this quote is a potent embodiment of Cloverfield, its raw emotive core which sees its central characters be driven by their emotions through thick and thin in a night which forever changes the course of history.

Starting off in an ordinary fashion we witness the trials and tribulations of Robert as he prepares to bid farewell to friends, family and his true love Beth. Although this sequence is nothing spectacular and could easily fit into a sappy rom – com, it has an underlying sense of dread and lingering at the events to come. Seeing this love drama unfold forms a humanity which makes them relatable to us which was exactly the move Cloverfield had to make before hitting us forthright with the traumatic horror that ensues.

The major player here is the cinematography, its point of view vision which we're confined to so that we become immersed into the devastating chaos that the survivors finds themselves in. Being restricted to a point of view vision means there's no escape for us, we're not in control of what we see forcing us into the horrific psychological ride which consumes every character a la The Blair Witch Project. Cloverfield defiantly would not have fully realised its havoc - filled atmosphere and tension if the cinematography had expanded.

Cloverfield's cinematography is only a percentage of the immense psychological roller-coaster we venture on. Shock deaths, immediate changes to situations and honest accounts of individual feelings, Cloverfield does not shy away from raw emotion. In watching Robert having to tell his Mother of his younger brother's death is a culmination, his whole emotional barrier crumbling down at the stark realisation of his world being devastatingly altered hits us simultaneously.

Credit also has to be given to Cloverfield's familiar urban New York setting, the hustle and bustle of modern life suddenly hauled to a standstill where everything the characters come across causes us to feel overwhelmed with senses of profound astonishment. Particularly when the surviving members of the group randomly come across a white horse and cart causally making its own way across now deserted streets, only in such a stunning journey of pandemonium and brutal violence would witnessing a white horse and cart become a disturbing absurdity. This along with the mystery surrounding the invading monster only serves up more horrifyingly astonished scenes.

Running up to only the seventy minute mark, Cloverfield uses its short time frame perfectly with terrifying tension and jittering suspense playing with us psychologically constantly making us wonder, why is it all happening?

title: Excellent American Monster Movie
review: Cloverfield is an engaging, intense and thrilling ride that takes about ten minutes to introduce our characters and set up the relationships between them before kicking off the chaos and never letting up throughout the remainder of the film. I was blown away by the effectiveness of shooting this story from the first person perspective. What could have been a typical monster movie is upgraded in intensity by making the viewer feel as if they are going through the same situations that the characters are. And by giving us likable characters that we care about also goes a long way to invest the viewers in the story. The story itself is fairly simple, but it works well enough for the purpose of the movie, which is paced at a near break neck speed. The writing is well done, giving us a few clever moments and a few moments of levity, largely provided by T.J. Miller as Hud, who gives nearly his entire performance off camera. The effects are the real star of this movie bringing the monster and a destruction ravaged Manhattan to life. Strongly recommended for anyone who is a genre fan, a first person perspective film fan, or anyone looking for a hell of a ride.

title: The events that happened to a group of people while they enjoyed in a party.
review:
Generally, I can't say that I like this film. Of course some part of it enjoyed me but not all part of it excite me. Firsly I want to talk about the good side of this film.

The most influencing topic in this film is the friendship among the characters. They didn't leave one another and supported themselves no matter what happened to them. They show us that to keep together helps us get rid of all bad things. So I like this part of the film.

I was also affected the man who taped the events. The reason why I affected me is that although he had a lot of bad things, he didn't give up and keeped taping. He was sample of determination. He was also ambitious and he didn't set a value on realizing his purposes. He breathed his last when he ran after his purposes. So the film recommends us to follow our dreams at any rate.

And now it is time to talk about bad sides of the film. There are a lot of monsters in it. And because I don't like unrealistic events and creatures, I didn't take enough pleasure. The monsters in this film don't seem to be like real. They are too imaginary and realizing them is not successful.

title: 'Believe the hype'.
review:
When I first saw Cloverfield, or when I first bought it, I wasn't sure what to expect, I knew that the entire film was shot as if it was from one of the character's camcorders, but I wasn't sure if I was going to enjoy dislike this style. I loved it. One of the most compelling things about this movie was the fact that you didn't get to see the 'thing' that was attacking New York City, for about half of the movie, this really kept you on the edge of your seat.

I'm sorry if I have confused a bit already, not explaining what the movie is about so I'll just start off now, Cloverfield is about a 'thing', as I said early that attack New York our main characters being a few friends that were having a 'Farewell Party' for their friend was leaving to Japan the following day, obviously things didn't turn out for our friend as he had planned. Now moving onto the budget of this film, it is an astonishing 25M, the last time I saw a film this action packed and well realist (effects wise), was probably never, maybe The Matrix or District 9 (I saw District 9 before Cloverfield), although even then Cloverfield feels more real despite having a lower budget.

Now don't get me wrong I would probably list The Matrix and District 9 higher on my favorite movies of all time, but I can say this, Cloverfield is a revolutionary, exiting new film that made a lot of money from a film made out of nothing.

9/10.

title: not wasting time
review:
First of all normally i am not interested in action movies.But this was the first time i was excited about one action movie.Recording styles,acting,sound effects are really professional.The effects are great and realistic thanks to the hand –held camera. Before this film i hadn't watched any film which is shot with hand-held camera. I am really impressted by hand-held camera. It feels me as if i was into the film. So it makes this film more enjoyable and fluent. Except in the party which is given at the beginning of the film there are not any music but my thought this is better because it makes this film more realistic.actors and actresses are not well known but they acts really cool.

As a result that movie is not wasting time,it is a good experience. .

title: Interesting but ultimately unsatisfying
review:
Take the hand-held camera gimmick of The Blair Witch Project and marry it to a standard monster-destroys-city flick and you've got Cloverfield. It's an interesting way to tell a monster movie, seen closely through the eyes of a small, bland group of friends caught up in the disaster, yet while I found it interesting it never really pulled me in, and the ending did not make me happy.

You can't talking about this movie without talking about Blair Witch, mainly because Blair Witch took the same gimmick and got so much more out of it. Even though that earlier movie had a fraction of the budget, it used the device so much more effectively; compare the final talking to the camera scenes from both films and tell me Cloverfield's is even a tenth as effective.

It is also less convincing as a premise. The guy with the camera is oddly devoted to documenting the event, to the point where he will stand back and film when he should be helping. In the real world, one of his friends would have grabbed the camera and threw it against a wall. Because of the way it's done, you never forget that this is just a clever device. Blair Witch was more convincing because the camera was the whole point and you were dealing with someone who would think in those terms.

Still, it does have it's good points. Because we see everything from one point of view, we get information in bits and pieces and never get anything like a real explanation of what's going on. There are individually effective scenes. The cameraman is vaguely likable, although everyone else is pretty forgettable.

Ultimately though, the hand-held single view camera is not an effective way to film action or horror scenes, the story and characters fail to be interesting, and the ending is very disappointing. It's interesting enough to watch, but it could have been so much better.

title: Stylish and definitely effective, if flawed.
review:
Cloverfield is at first glance not the kind of film I'd bother to review. Numerous reviews here comment on the hype around its release, and there is a definite 'love it or hate it' feel to things. Still, clearly weighted towards the 'love it' camp.

As we all know, the 'clever' conceit is that this is a discovered DV tape covering the experiences of an apocalypse-like event in Manhattan. The DV tape thing, I thought, worked well enough. You get the interesting temporal tool of the main footage being recorded over existing video, so we see snippets of a previous day in which the main character has formed a romantic bond with the girl he eventually goes back to save. It takes a moment to get a feel for this disjointed exposition, but it works.

For all this of course it tends towards fairly 'realist' acting, and the main performers are capable, if given little to work with. There are some convincingly shocking moments. Comparisons to the laughably stupid Blair Witch Project simply don't stand up. In addition, this benefits from the nice faculty of serious, big-scale visual effects being coupled with the hand-held, 'camcorder' footage. This undermines disbelief very well.

Unfortunately, suspension of disbelief pretty much ends there. The monsters in the film are far too conventional and familiar, and, frankly, are much too visible. It would have been much better seeing much more of the effect of their presence, and much less of them, especially the big daddy monster. In addition, there are countless holes in the plot, or certainly in the behaviour of the protagonists. If you're going for 'super-realism' in your disaster movie, then you've got to be a bit realistic about people's actions and motivations. This wasn't. Fair enough, the main character might (maybe) go back to rescue his girlfriend from her damaged building. But no way would the broadly uninvolved others come along with him into the jaws of death, and certainly they wouldn't bother going around filming all of it. Then again, these days, perhaps that bit is fair enough! In any case, what it gained in stylistic, visual realism, it lost in the lack of narrative credibility. A shame, really. Could have been really good.

Still, an enjoyable enough, if slightly pointless hour-and-a-half of film, with some nice and pretty well achieved aesthetic ideas. Not quite the genre-shattering event it maybe could have been, but certainly worth seeing for an entertaining Friday evening in.

title: It's like Godzilla, Blair Witch, and Road Trip meet 911 but instead of being horrific it's funny.
review:
Didn't pay much money for the film, so I don't feel cheated. On the whole I think Cloverfield is an innovation in filming style but that style needs a lot of work and the director needs a lot more practice. Style-wise, I thought I would find the camera nauseating and a turnoff going into it, but surprisingly I got used to it fast and it quickly blended into the background of the experience. The film definitely held my attention which is interesting considering there was no soundtrack for most of its length.

Story-wise, it was fun to watch but if it was supposed to be "thrilling" or "scary" it wasn't. I laughed at the various deaths which, while not frightening, were entertaining. The plot is fool of holes (which I won't go into here since so many other reviewers have) and the characters act like idiots but I found their actions quite believable since there are a lot of idiots in this world and many people probably would do, or try to do, what they did. Imagine people with the forethought, wisdom, and maturity of your typical college buddy movie spliced into Godzilla. The acting wasn't great but it was good enough.

title: Much WORSE the second time
review:
I saw this opening night in theaters in 2008. I watched it for the first time tonight, nearly three years later.

Really what I wanted to comment about is how far CGI has come in these short three years. Watching Cloverfield tonight, it struck me how mediocre the CGI in this movie actually is in 2011 standards. The scenes of the monster wrecking NYC look awful. A few of the closeups of the monster later in the movie have held up fairly well, but overall, what awed me then, doesn't fly nowadays. It's pretty amazing.

Also, tonight I realized how AWFUL the acting is. Some of the worst in recent memory. I felt like killing HUD the camera man long before the monster did.

Cloverfield 2 is due out summer 2012. We'll see.

title: A very rare and unique monster film
review:
After reading many reviews from this film I decided to check it out. I wasn't all that interesting in the film when it came out back in 2008, so I finally decided to watch it, and I thought it was pretty good. Cloverfield is a unique monster film because of the filming method (its all by a hand-held camera). Its engaging and very entertaining. At first it gets somewhat distracting and annoying then you eventually get used to it. And I thought it actually worked- it made the audience feel as if they were actually there with the group of people seeing the monster attack. Cloverfield has some good thrills, many of them are from jump scenes with the monsters (not too scary and unexpected). The film was pretty interesting but it could have been better had they focused more on the monster. The movie is pretty short. The first 20 mins takes place at a party then the film takes off when the friends notice a monster from outside. Most of the main cast end up dying and since its being filmed by a hand-held camera, you don't see how brutal the death's are- it happens pretty quick.

The characters were alright, not really that likable but not that bad. I think they should have done more development on them to have made the film better. Cloverfield is definitely better than that garbage Skyline- which gets compared to because of its recent monster/alien type films. Watching Cloverfield, you could tell that Skyline borrowed many scenes from the film. I think Cloverfield could have been better had they made the film about 20 minutes longer. The actual film ended around the 73rd minute (73.45). This film is definitely not for everyone. Many complaints are from the camera but to watch a film like this you need to have an open mind, and take it for what it is.

title: Post-catastrophic Scientific Thriller (The Cloverfield effect)
review:
I watched this movie with my friend in the town theater back in 2008. We didn't know that the film was made to be hand-held viewing for the audience. So, kinda felt dizzy a bit. Anyway, We enjoyed it and I think it's really a haste movie, intense enough and quite spectacular. The Clover monster is quite unique. I recently bought this DVD and I watched it again at home. Well, I can tell the feeling is quite different when I watched it at home (don't feel dizzy at all). Anyway, both experiences are really cool! Besides, there are some mysteries awaiting to be unleashed in the DVD, which we would probably unnoticed before when we watched it in the theater. So, quite interesting to know that these mysteries can be found......

I think even two years now since the release of Cloverfield, the Cloverfield effect is still saturating around us and I really can't stop thinking about Cloverfield 2 (the prequel or sequel of Cloverfield?), undoubtedly there would be a even lot more expectations and fantasies from all the fans who love Cloverfield.

title: Monsters in real life
review:
Wow, this movie blew me away. All those that rate it low complain about the shaky camera, the missing information about the monster and the sudden ending.

And all I could think was: This is probably what it would be like if a monster actually showed up at your doorstep. You would have little or no information about it, you would try to escape but with no real master plan, authorities would suddenly appear out of nowhere and they would know more about the monster and the situation than you, and they would not trouble to keep you informed. Eventually you will get caught by the monster, and you will die a horrific death.

There are no heroes, there are no losers and winners, and there is no real ending... pretty much like in real life.

Besides that monsters aren't likely to appear, the only thing that seemed unreal to me was that Hud kept recording once the panic started. But i guess that 60 minutes of static noise from a lost camera would be pushing it :-)

But hey, if you only like movies that are predictable and with happy endings and heroes, this is not for you. This movie challenges you.

title: Blairwitch Meets Godzilla Meets War of the Worlds
review: Most simply put, this movie is a combination of Blair Witch, War of the Worlds and Godzilla. It begins with the familiar concept (which is starting to become cliché) that the following events actually happened and video tapes were discovered. Then the audience start to watch the video tapes which are shot in the hand-held camera style (again, Blair Witch style). New York city is under attack but we don't get to see the attackers, this unknown element does bring some suspense to the story. Then we discover *spoiler* that it is a gigantic creature (kind of like Godzilla) from outer space that is attacking the city. That, in a nutshell, sums up the movie. Even though I didn't get bored and watched until the end, I don't think the movie offers anything original other than bringing good ideas from the past movies into one plot. Special effects look more impressive on film shot with hand-held camera style. This is the best part of the movie. Story is very basic and like I said nothing new about it. The movie deserves a rating between 6-6.5 .

title: Not A Bad Effort
review:
Frequently compared with 'Blair Witch' as an amateur's movie legacy of terror at ground-zero, 'Cloverfield' comes with a much bigger budget. The scenario spiralling out of control presented from the uninformed 'everyman' perspective rather than that of the more traditional 'expert' was also attempted by Spielberg in his rather hammy, over-the-top borathon remake of 'War Of The Worlds'. Well; Cloverfield is considerably better.

The problem - for me, at least - is the lengthy scene-setting preamble. We are treated to a tiresome, hedonistic party of young people, getting highly sexed and pretty drunk, quibbling about their shallow little lives. On and on it goes, with the wobbly hand-cam making for a dizzying sensation. Can there ever be anything more boring than movies of other peoples' parties? For me, it was almost a turn-off.

However; for those who stay the course, when things liven-up, they are worth your patience. The wobbly-cam comes into its own. There are some truly excellent scenes of disaster, panic and general chaos, that I would have liked to have dwelt on for a little longer; a great deal of imagination and no little money must have gone into their creation. In the dark, the CGI joins are seldom evident. The main monster is enigmatic and imperfectly seen, which really works better than full-frontal. Late in the movie we do briefly come face-to-face with it in the park as it devours our cameraman, and I found the revelation disappointing - a bit of an anti-climax.

As well as the biggie, there's any number of small dog-sized terrors like shrimps or insects that are fast-movie and vicious. So it's not just a case of hiding in a doorway till the 'Godzilla' thing has blundered past.

There are plenty of taut little shocks. The set pieces - what can be seen of them - seem excellent.

But despite all of the positive technical issues, I come back to the old bugaboo: STORY. It's something that happens to people you are induced to care about. And once again; I wasn't persuaded to give a toss about any of the characters. They are the sort of shallow young brats that inhabit every gore-fest. Freddy Kruger's been dispatching them for years. You'll find 'em in 'Saw', 'Hostel', 'Wolf Creek' - where not? In fact I don't believe I saw a single character above the age of thirty-five. A better mix and more interesting relationships as well as more clearly defined and less stereotypic characters would have been a big plus, and this is where 2 of my stars were lost.

As a comparison, I found all of the characters in 'Pitch Black' rather fun, each had something to say, and I was sorry when the got axed.

Still; it's got plenty going for it in the effects, sets, and suspense department that are well worth a watch. There's just this rather unfortunate hole where STORY should have been. Some survived, some died. I think the monsters got killed. That's it.

title: was this a cheaper film to make ?
review: I had really looked forward to watching "Cloverfield" but had not expected it to be shown so quickly and on Channel Four in the UK. Having resisted the temptation to leave it early I persevered. Did we need to have the over long camcorder farewells to our hero leaving for Japan without any idea as to why as none of those interviewed left sufficient of a favourable impression that I cared at all who lived or who died or who was saved and ended with the impression that this fuzzy strategy stuck the Director with this approach for most of the film at the end of which I felt no resolution and still wondering whether it was made on a shoestring budget but probably wasn't ?

title: Motion sickness with a twist
review:
After coming out from seeing this movie me and a friend had a small debate about whether there would ever be a newly invented stylized genre of film, and if not will films always be pigeonholed in the same exhausted genres we constantly see rehashed now? I kept asking myself "in a hundred years will audiences still be watching updated versions on the same old concepts?" I was always taught, "don't mess with genre" and in today's market this regrettably holds true....

Obviously Cloverfield is a "updated version" in a classic film genre; the monster movie. Also obvious is how this bothers me, mostly because of the hype that was built around this film, or rather the viral marketing campaign that sent fanboys everywhere racing to their online message boards in nerdy excitement. Producer J.J Abrams sent the Internet in a tizzy (yeah I said tizzy) with clever viral marketing tactics, never hinting on what the film was actually about until the ominous teaser poster with a decapitated Statue of Liberty entitled "1.18.08." With this much mystery-laden buildup a big payoff was certainly expected, yet behind all of this hype was just another variation of yes, a monster movie. Now at this point you're either thinking I'm being cynical or I just have high expectations, but you'd be right because yeah, I am and I do.

See I was really rooting Cloverfield wouldn't just be another monster movie, that it be more clever, something no one has ever seen before. But maybe I'm just gonna have to just accept the fact that genre films will live a lot longer than I ever will and I should just get over it.... but not today friend, because, in fact, there really wasn't anything clever about this film at all, its basically Godzilla meets Blair Witch Project. The convention of telling the story in first person perspective through a shaky consumer camera was built for and attends to the iGeneration, and although commendable is still a cheap trick. However (and this is big however) under the guise of this marketing ploy, there is a really good film. The way the film's writer Drew Goddard establishes the lead characters in the first act is really involving, and I did actually kinda care for their outcome when the monster (eventually) attacks Manhattan.

As good as the movie's cinema verite style is there is still a lot of questionable motivation throughout the film (They all go back to where the monster is, really?) and you also really have to use your suspension of disbelief to believe some of the um, logistics (the handicam has night vision, a built in light, can record over an hour and a half of footage, and can survive a 100 foot drop?) But forgoing all my negativity (as you should), this film ultimately achieves its goal of allowing the audience to experience first hand what the characters are experiencing. And even if it's in a hackneyed monster movie genre, as a native New Yorker I was at the edge of my seat, eating up every second of it, call me cliché.

title: Big monster, cool CGI, terrible plot..
review:
First of all, it's not scary. A monster 30 stories tall destroying Manhattan is supposed to be a scary deal. But "Cloverfield" sidesteps that challenge and opts for an easier way out. It makes it look cool. You'll watch this movie, go home, have dinner, go to sleep, wake up the next morning and go to work, and before you know, a whole lifetime will pass without your thinking about it for once. While watching, you might (might, j-u-s-t might) enjoy it, but there's nothing in this movie that you'll take home with you. Least of all a good scare.

The story? Have you seen "Godzilla"? That's pretty much it. Huge monster comes out of the ocean and into Manhattan (oh no, not Manhattan again!), and goes on a building-tumbling rampage. Meanwhile, the military tries to bring it down with everything they've got (of course, to no avail). Throw into this your protagonists, who are caught in middle and are trying to escape, and there you have it! The use of shaky cams, however, brings a new perspective into films like these. Starting from the path-breaking "Blair Witch Project" to the recent "Rec", shaky cams have been used to create a sense of reality in movies, and thus, to intensify scares.
