Basically the style of the film was fascinatingly cool, the innovation created is a piece of eye-catching flick from the moment you start to watch the film. Although I believe some where vexed with the fashion of the movie, but they sure do doesn't know how to appreciate an impressively imaginative film. Primarily I have no complete idea of what would be the central cause of the stories major conflict, it was indeed exciting and makes you sit still on your couch and expect the unexpected. But to be honest, I thought of it as a frequent bunch of maturely adult friendship story that focuses on their self issues and try to narrowly solve a relationship coma, and then suddenly an outbreak of unexplainable war-like-fare boomed out of the blue causing awe and panic all over Manhattan. Later, however we come to understand the causes and main point of the story, thus I sparingly conceive what the tag line says "something has found us", then a huge monster appear in a blur from devastated store's tvs stormed by petty thieves out for their own egotistical interests.

Then the impact from our faces? Trepidation and astonishment, as is. Then the story goes on, its not boring and I would admit I appreciated so much the film from its skin and core. Deserves a ten.

title: Something for Steven to see ...
review:
I rarely ever login to comment on movies but for this particular one, I just had too.

I was very disappointed with Spielberg's war of the worlds and never thought i'd see a movie about aliens attacking a major city again but Cloverfield has changed my mind. It has just the right amount of humans, aliens, military and those little things that eat humans...just right.

The best part about the movie is that it's not cryptic at all like War of the worlds was. When I sit down to watch a movie I don't want my mind racing with questions, I just want to relax and watch a good feature and Cloverfield provides just that.

title: CLOVERFIELD is easily a monster movie legend.
review: If you haven't seen this movie yet I very strongly advise that you do. Do whatever you to. Rent it, buy it, whatever. I promise you you won't regret it. This movie delivers everything an action movie, a monster movie, and a suspense movie can possibly give and more. You get a strong dose of all 3 and you are left begging for more. I was on the edge of my seat the entire time. There is no way you will finish this one without an adrenaline rush. The acting is great, the effects are great, the monster is awesome. If death, carnage and, mayhem is what you want that's what you get. J.J. Abrams and Matt Reeves spare you no sympathy in this movie. I knew it would be great because I'm a big fan of LOST. Now I can't wait for the sequel. I hope Abrams and Reeves return. No one will do it quite like them, No One.

title: Adrenalin rush!!!!
review: My first thought after seeing this film was "wow fu... Godzilla"! This movie is something special, the filming was much more different than we use to watch,so it take us in the film, it is like we were there, like all that is happening to us, and the story is flawless. For most of the movie you don't even see that monster that is attacking Manhattan, but that was the idea of the film, i think, that is why everything is so trilling, your trying hard in every frame of the film to see that monster but you can only see some parts, and that was brilliant from the director of the movie, and for change there are some unknown actors there as main characters. I would recommend this movie for everyone to see, i liked it so much, i mean it was adrenalin rush in whole 80 min. of the film!!!

title: waste of time
review: I do not know how this film got such a high rating it is a terrible film. The acting is over done a bunch of weeping saps that put there self's in that position. The main character Rob how he could endanger his friends at his own needs is shockingly selfish, the biggest coward in film history. Pointless story poor characterisation no point to telling this story after watching it I felt cheated oh why did I not turn off earlier? Why god oh why? I can not think of one redeeming feature about this s$*%, do not believe the hype, do not watch this drivel do not waste your money or time learn from my mistake people avoid it, it will only reduce your IQ.

title: phewwww
review:
My first impression was a high-budget "Blair Witch" type movie. It was shot entirely with a hand-held camera.I found it incredibly dull on first viewing. I then read many reviews which raved about it so I decided to pay more attention on a second viewing.

The first few seconds tell us that this movie was recovered by the government in Central Park. We then go into 18 minutes of bad photography and inane dialog at a Manhattan party. At about 19 minutes there is an explosion and people start running around. The hand-held keeps on running. The rest of the movie is basically panic, people running around, screaming, more inane dialog (much of which is hard to understand because of ambient noises,) Monster movie? NOT. It might as well be an attack by a foreign power or a bunch of crazies.

Is this a realistic depiction of what it might be like in Manahattan during an attack? Yes. Does that make it a good movie? No.

A good movie requires a blending of many elements - Screen writing, acting, directing, cinematography. A good script should have a few basic elements such as meaningful dialog, plot, character development. This movie falls way short on all these factors.

If you liked the art films of the 60's you might like this. Otherwise don't waste your time

title: A sub-mediocre 4 for a sub-mediocre film.
review:
Think Blair-Witch meets Godzilla, with a substantial amount of Manhattan sightseeing.

A thoroughly predictable rampaging monster sci-fi. It should have been good what with good character development, acceptable acting, and all the money so obviously spent on effects and extras. Unfortunately it was let down due to the appallingly formulaic, and apparently deliberate unoriginality of writing.

After about the first fifteen minutes I was beginning to wonder if they'd run the wrong film. Add that first fifteen minutes to the last ten minutes given over to the credits, then the majority of the film seemingly devoted to walking around Manhattan, and you have the idea.

Oh yes, and did I mention that in the opening credits they let us know everyone dies? Only watch this if you have absolutely no desire to think, or simply can't be bothered to take a nap.

title: It's been a long time...
review: but finally, here's a movie that actually gave me some moments of genuine fright. You know, like when you see Alien and the monster comes out of the stomach, or like some scene in The Hills Have Eyes that I've half forgotten. The hand-held camera used throughout the film helps, of course, and indeed much better than in, for instance, The Blair Witch Project (which was a laugh, honestly). The plot isn't much to say anything about; four young persons run through Manhattan (to help a friend) after a monster has attacked ditto, the army tries to bomb the monster to smithereens, but to no avail. It's the acting and directing of the film that makes it so good. You actually don't see the monster in so many scenes, but when you do, it's from the victims', the humans' point of view. That's nice! Some scenes are sure to stay in your mind for some time; the horse-carriage without a driver, the little creeps in the subway, the head of the Statue of Liberty laying in the street. And also, as a bonus, no-one ever utters the words: - Is it a terror-attack? The non-Hollywood ending opens for a sequel, of course. But why not?

title: A Big Disappointment
review: Given that this was produced by JJ Abrams, I was expected a high level of production values. However, I found it like a 1950s B-movie. A very poor script, which seemed to be "Oh My God, Oh My God" ad nauseum, or, at least ad boredom. The acting abilities of the cast were amateurish, at best, and the cast will probably be like a group of characters in an X-Files episode. They'll never be seen again, apart from the pretty younger females who'll probably be seen in a few teen TV programs, or straight-to-video movies, probably with less and less clothes as the films get poorer, with lower and lower budgets. Every expense seemed to have been spared on the special effects to stop viewers getting a good view of the monster. This is a bad thing in a monster movie, JJ. Why 2 stars? I thought that Marlena was very attractive. Otherwise it would have been 1.

title: Rubbish
review: I do agree with the last comment about the acting, it was very good and the visual effects were good. But the movie was the worst one I have ever seen, too much of it was shot with the hand held camcorder, My wife and I were bored stiff with this movie. Don't waist you your money on it. I have to right ten lines of text for this to be put in the comments about the movie but I think I have said enough is enough is enough, the movie's crap and that's it. So the rest of this comment will be unreadable just so I can speak my mind about Cloverfield. I would not wish this movie on anyone, if you fancy watching it, rent it and you will be disappointed with it.

title: Sad State of Affairs
review:
Its a sad state of affairs when outstanding movies get 6.x ratings and a completely non-original (see Blair Witch Project) idea with a nothing script currently has close to an 8 rating.

Continuous tension and relief is the repeated pattern of this movie. Any first year film student could easily make a movie as compelling as this one.

If all you are looking for in a movie is bad acting, a nothing story, poor special effects and a complete robbery of other peoples original ideas then this film might be for you. If you have half-a-brain and enjoy seeing a story actually develop then don't even bother

title: this film is in top 5 sci-fi horror ever made
review:
First if you want to watch this movie'and to experience it you have to be alone and its have to be dark ...

I saw this movie last night and i still think about it,the sound effects was real thing, like i was in that movie all the time, and i was scared, real scared and hopeless because i cant find the way to escape from all that madness and destruction around me.I could smelled that creatures around...

And after movie i just could say what are we gonna to do if something like that happens in real life, everything is possible, we are not alone in universe ...

You can see how this movie influence on me :)...

title: Very poor, bad camera, no entertainment .. JOKE
review:
I don't usually comment, but this was a movie really worth commenting. Well, I must admit that I was looking forward to seeing this sooo much. I couldn't wait - seriously. I was seeing all the trailers and previews through past few weeks and finally I watched this movie yesterday. 1) 75mins - JOKE 2) "shaken" camera - JOKE 3) stupid and predictable plot - JOKE 4) copy of Blairwitch, Starship troopers, Mist and Aliens - JOKE

Actually this movie ends right at the moment I was expecting it to begin! Seariously, I was like: "f**k! Is that really IT?? Thats all?? C'mon guys, nooo! This cant be happening ...

Please, don't waste your money. Blow your 9USD elsewhere, OK?

title: Almost unparalleled in the genre
review:
I first reviewed this film back in 2008 and decided to update my review nearly a decade later because I STILL watch this film regularly. It is without a doubt my favourite monster movie of all time.

I am a bit of a monster movie fanatic and will watch just about anything in the genre. I'm an especially huge fan of Godzilla (with the exception of the awful 1998 version) and I wince a bit to say I enjoy Cloverfield more than Godzilla, but I have no choice but to acknowledge that it is superior in its ability to completely suck you in and keep you invested in what's happening on screen.

The storyline the film is built around is a bit cliché but it works well as a backdrop to the disaster that is unfolding. It creates some decently believable motivations for the characters and while I wouldn't be very moved by it as a romantic story in any other context, I think it serves its purpose well here.

I think the reason this film works so well is that it focuses on the experience of being inside a monster attack, rather than focusing on all the logistics and militaristic drama of battling one from the outside. This makes the film much more gripping and psychologically tense than other films of the genre.

I tend toward motion sickness and the shaky camera thing bothered me a bit when I first watched it in the theatre but viewing it at home I've not had any ill effects.

I have seen this film a minimum of 25 times, and I know I'll watch it many times more. If you haven't seen it before I recommend checking it out.

title: monster-less garbage
review: Call me crazy but I think that a monster movie should have a monster in it! Why do I feel like I'm the only one who believes this. This movie was like a porno without sex. Characters in monster movies are meant to be fodder. The only thing you are meant to care about is how they die. This movie was an insult to monster movie fans everywhere. I like sex in my pornos, action in my action movies, blood and guts in my horror movies and MONSTERS IN MY DAMN MONSTER MOVIES! Take your complex characters and their dumb ass relationships and stick them in a Julia Roberts flick. I'll take mindless entertainment over this character driven drama crap any day.

title: Now that is a monster movie
review:
I haven't enjoyed a movie so much in ages. No, it isn't the greatest movie of all time, but it's one of the best of its kind I've ever seen. So the hand-held POV isn't wholly original, who cares? It works. And works so well.

What is striking about this is it actually ends up being moving. Too many of these films make it (a) easy to spot the order in which characters will die and (b) make you start wishing they would all die horribly. This isn't so predictable. And by the end of this, partly because of the intimacy of the viewer's involvement in the action and partly because this is refreshingly thin on stereotypes, you end up caring about them.

A thoroughly good watch, some genuine jump-in-the-seat moments, enough cleverness and allusions for the movie geeks amongst us and just plain enjoyable, which is rare enough in any year.

title: Interesting, But Not Memorable
review:
Cloverfield is unique in the sense that the entire film is supposedly filmed by the actors. This makes it interesting because it makes the film seem very real. Also, for a hand-held camera, the special effects were notable. However the cons outweigh the pros by far. The entire movie can be summed up in these words: "Look, big, mysterious, scary monster; lets all run for our lives!" Their is no plot, subplot, or other, the characters are as shallow as the movie's concept and the theme is tired and redundant.

If anyone does wish to see it regardless, go ahead, but it is not a movie that stands out particularly. You can watch "Blair Witch Project", "Spider-man" and "The Incredible Hulk" and see the same kind of action (and scenarios) as here. The dialog was interesting, the acting even I can say I liked, but the story is empty, devoid of any true depth and very predictable.

NOTE: The writer also seemed to enjoy being as exceedingly blasphemous and showered the script with enough Oh My Gods and "Jesus Christ's" to save a nation.

In all 3 out of 10 is the most I can give for this attempt at entertainment. Even the monster is void of any depth; no details on what exactly it is where it came from. Let me stop commenting before I drop the rating down to a 2. Truthfully, the manner in which it was filmed is unique, the acting is nice, and the "scary moments" are intense, but "Cloverfield" is shallow and lacking in the entertainment sector of movie making.

  • F.N. Bessing


PS: The name "Cloverfield" has nothing to do at all with the movie.

title: Cloverfield: Clever Movie , Fantastic Movie!
review:
Three months ago when I saw the movie trailer and the advertising for the movie I knew that this movie will be "The movie of the year". And now I know I was one million percent right! The element that made the movie so good is the Hand-Held Camera that used to film the movie.

Some people say that the movie is bad because there is no camera that can film 9 hours continuously and that "hud" (the camera-man) film all the interesting scenes although he did not know what is going to happen.. I say that the movie is almost 84 minutes what means that the camera didn't film everything , and I think that the camera-man did everything right and the movie that he filmed make sense because , he began filming in the party when the attack begins and then he filmed on the streets , in the tunnel and also when saving Beth , what I'm trying to say is that the progression of the movie is good and make sense , and not like some people who think that Hud was like knowing the future and that's wrong. Another thing that bothers me that people attack the quality of the camera , like there is no hand-Held camera that can film with so great quality , but in my opinion there might be , and also nobody told us that the movie was filmed in 2008 , maybe it was filmed in 2011 and the cameras will be more advanced!

I have watched hundreds of movies in my life , but like this movie I never saw!! Because it's really outstanding. So I advice every person who didn't see the movie yet to buy a ticket and enjoy 84 minutes of extraordinary Thriller.

title: Headache
review:
If you saw the trailer already you saw it all -- shaking camera and a lot of "oh my god". Unfortunately that does not make a great film.

It is like cheap version of Godzilla (which was disaster), a bit of Alien feeling and Blair Witch Project (I believe, because I didn't see it) -- hand-camera artsy-style.

Surprisingly, this movie gets only high rates, well, then, good for producers. If you want to save your money, shake your head a lot, scream, and bang it from time to time against the wall.

Overall, it is a pity, because I would like to see some new great sci-fi thriller, but unfortunately every attempt is bad clone of something. I hope we won't see Cloverfield 2.

title: Not nearly as good as trailer hyped it up to be
review:
So lets just get this part out of the way; Cloverfield is most likely the most well advertised movie I've seen in the past few years. The teaser trailer shows two awesome clips; a distant building being blown apart accompanied by large chunks flying past the camerman, and the Statue of Liberty's head tumbling through the streets of manhattan. Now for those of you who viewed the trailer, you'll notice that in between these scenes, you see about 4 ridiculously quickly cut shots of people running down a stairwell. Guess What? That wasn't done just for the trailer... its actually one continuous scene in the movie.

Thats just one example of the irritating Blair Project-Rip Off of a movie that Cloverfield is. While the 1999 horror movie used the first person camera perspective as a way to trick the viewers to thinking that the movie was an actual documentary, Cloverfield uses this to make sure the audience gets the blurriest, and quickest shots possible of the limited amount of special effects in the movie. And as if that wasn't irritating enough, the camera man is retarded. I could most likely tape my digital camera to the top of my dogs ass while forcing him to run on my treadmill for a piece of steak and STILL get a better shot than the moron who recorded this movie. *end rant* Okay, with that out of the way lets focus on the movie's plot.

Oh wait... there isn't one. You see the other reason why I hate this movie so much is the fact that it scored a 7.8 on this website while Godzilla scored a 4.6. Because that makes a lot of sense. Okay sure, Godzilla may have had its issues with a couple of actors, and maybe all of the fans complained about him not breathing fire, but at least it had a plot.

Cloverfield opens up with a good 25 minutes of absolute irrelevant crap. The writers attempted to have some character development, but it never really works, or for that case matters in a movie with such ordinary boring characters. Have you ever gone over a girlfriend or boyfriends house and got stuck watching one of their god awful home movies? Well thats what this is... a really bad, boring home movie.

As far as the special effects go, they work... although theirs never anything really special about them, as most of the time the creature is covered in smoke, or so dark that you can't even see any texture on its skin etc. They aren't bad but theirs so few of them due to the ridiculous budget constraints, and that just sucks in a movie with such an epic scope.

The best part about this movie was its 85 minute run time... because when it ended, I got the hell out of that theater.

For the love of god, save your money 3/10

title: We've never seen a movie like this before
review:
Does this movie have any meaning? Although some may disagree, I think we could really say a few words about it... While Godzilla had an ecological message and criticized the experiences with nuclear power, I believe this one is a metaphor of the unpredictable world where we live, when from a moment to another the thousands of people may die in an airplane crash, in a tower hit by an airplane, etc, etc... These are new times, when with certain technology in the hands of the crazy people that will always exist in the world, thousands of people may face a horrible death in seconds.

Unless you were previously informed that the movie is about a monster, the first scene in the top of the roof makes you remember 9/11, which is by the way also quoted in the movie. This is quite intentional, since we see an explosion in the building and the same building collapsing in the next scene screened in the street. The monster is only introduced after some minutes, and surprisingly I could well accept as something that could really happen, since everything looked so realistic in the movie. On the other hand, this monster is quite different from others, like Godzilla, Hulk or King Kong. This one is more powerful and does not have a soul. Its purpose is basically to unstoppably kill, destroy and eat things and people like if there was no tomorrow. Where does it come from? Why is he doing this? Well, I really appreciate that the director has cut those stupid explanations such as that it was a dormant monster in the depths of the ocean, or that it has visited earth inside a big spaceship coming from other planet, or crap like that. As the trooper says near the end of the movie, "we don't know what it is, but it is winning". We could not listen to such a vague and at the same time so disturbing statement if one of those stupid explanations were given. We just need to know that this monster is there and it is damned as hell. Sometimes explaining these types of films turn them more simple and less scary... If this was a thriller maybe the rules were others, but this is a disaster and scary movie, and here sometimes it is better not to give details.

I would say that the movie is essentially an experience. Until now, I only remember the amateurish "blair witch project", certain scenes of John Cameron's "strange days" and an interesting episode of X-Files exploring the concept of the movie being entirelly filmed in a hand-held. I agree that we should not abuse of this method... But I won't also claim that this is not art; I really believe it is, but the way of filming should be adapted to the theme and only in these tense and scary movies there are reasons to film this way, without slow motions, background music, cheap exhibitions of special effects...

I have seen lots of people criticizing the characters but I think they are perfect here. I am also glad that the director has not chosen famous actors; it would not be so scary if we saw leonardo di caprio trying to rescue the girl... This really adds more reality to the movie. I think that the dialogues of the characters are also purposefully casual and sometimes stupid, since usually people will not say grandiose statements in a situation like this; they will most likely talk in monossylabes... In sum, we get the feeling that we are really there living the moment. And, without less importance, we have incredible fun watching this movie!

title: Disappointing
review: It gives fresh action throughout the hole film... the camera movements gives a feeling that u are "in" the film and it creates suspension...there is always something happening throughout the whole film....the bad thing is , that the actors are very artificial but the end is very disappointing and sad as it leaves many questions .... SPOILER: You should watch till after the credits , there's a short audio scene that u can hear which is very interesting ... especially when u hear it in reverse... so all in all you should spare your time and money and not watch this film Because of fu**** line rule I have to write some more crap lines here... man I don't want to write a roman just a little film comment so what the fu*** ??? Is that here lol...ah finally...

title: Not Very Good
review:
To be honest, It is not very good. It reminds me the movie REC. But Recwere original and this one is not. Shortly I could say you can watch it, but just don't expect a lot. Acting and the rest are moderate. I think it is an ordinary Hollywood movie. In my opinion, American cinema is in a big depression and they cannot produce original scenarios instead they reproduce Asian or European movies or simply take the ideas from international independent movies. And they make high budget movies with stolen ideas. This one is one of those reproduction movies. And even introducing high tech. effects and expensive tools to the movies is not enough.

I like the hand camera in the movie maybe this was the only successful thing. But again problem with hand camera is that it is bit professional and when there is an action scene cameraman does not stop. I found it not realistic.

title: Amazing!
review:
The movie was really breathtaking!

I loved it! The special effects were extraordinary! I just got blown out of my seat. The thing is this looked just like an ordinary day. That could happen to any of us. The good thing is that this isn't a movie where u need to watch very closely and keep things in the forehead to understand it!

Well I just want to recommend it to all of u guys out there who love breathtaking effects and like a little kick in their movies... Just see it before it comes out...

Regardz, K

title: The Blair Monster Project
review:
After reading several good reviews of this film, I figured I'd go and check it out. I'm still not quite sure what to make of this one.

The film centers around a group of teenagers caught up in a dangerous situation in New York. The mysterious ongoing destruction about the teens forces them to try and make a run for it - head for the hills.

The photography and plot line of this movie is not unlike the Blair Witch Project - in fact it is nearly exactly the same: frightened teens caught up in something spooky try to escape and someone finds the shaky film documenting the events at some later point. Except this film takes place in a city and the mysterious events are a bit more Hollywood than BWP.

I was really quite unnerved during the first 30 minutes of the film in which next to nothing happens. We get introduced to characters that are really nothing more than their clothes and a name tag. We do learn that they can all run and scream real well, though.

If you liked the BWP you'll probably like this, too. It's not a bad film action film, per se. If you're over 15, you'd do better to find something else.

title: Just plain terrible
review:
If you enjoy your health, and dislike throwing up when you expect a thrill at the movies, avoid this movie at all costs. I probably wouldn't have minded this movie if it hadn't been shot from the bystander's point of view. I admit, this had some excellent thrills to it, and I always love films about gigantic and destructive monsters, but it was filmed like the Blair witch project. It's almost as if they wanted to take a wonderful idea and ruin it. I felt so physically ill that I kept my eyes closed for five minutes of it so that I could control the migraine that this useless piece of crap gave me. It almost felt like the director was trying to insult the general public.

Goal well met, jerk.

And now they're planning a sequel. Dear God, have mercy on us, we DO NOT deserve trash like this in our cinema. Don't let the absurd rating of 7.8/10 fool you, this movie should be ranked on the Bottom 100 list.

title: Such a waste of time
review: This movie was such a waste of time. Seriously, don't go see it and don't buy it or rent the DVD when it comes out. For almost an hour and a half you see a shaky image that films almost everything but what's of interest. And it's not feasible either, I mean. when a monster's chasing you you don't run holding your camera up and filming everyone around, you run like hell before you get killed. It's just stupid. The idea was great, but it was badly put into practice - such a waste of potential. I prefer classical camera angles, where you can actually see what's happening. And also, the ending sucks, although I'm not going to spoil it for you. Please take my advice and don't go see it; you'd be better off renting Godzilla, although it's like 10 years old, compared to this one it's brilliant. Maybe a sequel would be more interesting.

title: Made in Taiwan
review: Cloverfield is an interesting movie, for several reasons, the biggest of course being the Cinematography. It's a little heavy and slow for the first 20-25 minutes, but then the mystery starts to spread among the main characters. What it is? Is it bird? Is it plain? NO! It is a cheap and spider look-a-like monster, Godzilla's cousin who was beaten with a hanger as child. A big nasty and apparently very angry on humans? Althoughs unanswered questions contributes well to story, and for audience as well, making us feel totally clueless of the situation. Again Manhattan is the playground of another paranoia monster, only this time is could use some Botox and be run through a Commodore 64 to get a better and more realistic look. It is a real mood killer when you see a destroyed in flames (nice!) New York from the top of a skyscraper, and then the monster is as scary as Super Mario. See it for a different experience.

title: Could have been better, not worth the wait
review:
OK, i have been waiting since last year, since transformers came out, and i have been psyched about this film, researching everything to the last detail, hoping this film would be the "greatest film ever"

i was in the movie theater, and it seemed as if, as soon as i sat down it ended, it was extremely short, this movie would have been perfect if maybe it was , longer then 5 minutes, if it was more, real time, then i would have loved it, but i sat up and said i hated it, it was an OK film and it depends on the person watching it,

i really hope the sequel is better then this one,

however the monster is pretty kick-ass

title: "Great special effects" does not equal "great movie"
review: OK, so you think you are going to see some "realistic" great movie...and in reality it was a real disappointment! 25% of the of the movie was an introduction of superficial background, nothing to interestingly funny, or even mattered in a movie like this. Then we get to the action: a few good parts, great special effects, but the cameraman, although realistic, is NOT picking up the ACTION! He is looking at the ground and at everything BUT the aliens. Lastly, the characters have to be some of the most emotional and stupid people on the planet! When it comes to survival you have to get back to the basics: food, water, shelter, and of course, PROTECTION (in the form of weapons or some sort). These fools didn't do as much as pick up a stick let alone find some guns. In conclusion, if you like realism, stupidity, and a bad plot, then THIS is your movie. If you are someone that wants something 'special' when watching a flick, stay AWAY from this one.

title: War of the worlds meets Blair Witch Project
review:
You are looking at a "War of the Worlds" setting with some unknown Force/Creature/Whatever attacking humanity (or just Manhattan in this case). The Whole movie looks like it was filmed from a hand-held camera by people caught in the incident. Even without no background-music during the whole movie it still manages to build up a dense atmosphere since the viewer is (as he experiences the events through the eyes of a small group of people - or their camera) left with almost no information whatsoever. There is no scene in which the viewer for instance gets a good look at what is wreaking havoc in Manhattan, which again contributes to the atmosphere.

The down side is that at the point, the movie ended, I found myself expecting a "second half" of the movie. ("Was this really it?").

title: worst movie ever
review: i can not understand, why this movie gets nearly 8/10 points at IMDb. i suppose the producers voted for their own movie. do not waste time and money on this crap. plot, actors, monster, camera --> LAME. I am supposed to fill 10 lines with critics about this movie, but it is so boring and bad that i really have problems to write something about it. it even is a waste of time to think about it afterwords but i really want to spare you that awful film. the comparison with other movies is a defamation. hats off to the commercial foreplay off this movie. they really got me. and i am very sorry for it. bad worse cloverfield. 1 out of 10 is really sugarcoated voting.

title: Watchable, but not as scary or immersive as it could be.
review:
On paper, cloverfield is a great idea: A giant monster invasion movie shown entirely from the perspective of hand held camera has potential for all sorts of coolness. However, while cloverfeild has some good things going for it, it doesn't quite live up to that potential.

The problem with cloverfield is that it feels a little too Hollywood- its supposed to show the action in a documentary style, but thanks to some teen soap style drama and unnecessary character development, that sense of realism and immersion that horror mockumentaries need to evoke to draw you in, isn't always there. Thats not to say that the film is bad- the film is definitely scary in places. There is a serious sense of dread and panic in scenes when the crowds are fleeing from the monster and news footage of monster attacks are chilling and shocking to watch.

Cloverfeilds biggest problem is the very thing thats most integral to the movie: the camera. I understand that the bad, sickness inducing, extremely shaky camera work is supposed to add to the realism but it makes the film difficult and at times, frustrating to watch. Even the micro budget Blair witch project had better and more realistic camera work and that film didn't have a CG monster to show off.

Cloverfield is a unique take on the 'monster attacks new york' theme that the American remake of godzilla tried to do 10 years ago and its good for a few scares, but its not as as effective as it should be.

title: Just above decent
review: If you get nauseous from watching a shaky camera, you are probably either a grandmother, a small child, or a pregnant mother. Get over it people. Just because someone tried a different angle and view with their movie-making doesn't mean you have to be a bunch of whiners. "I got sick, it was terrible, wah wah." This movie was different and semi-original, and the second someone uses the first person angle the uneducated yell out a resounding "Rip off!". I never said this movie was great, but it most definitely is not a 1. I think I have family videos that I could rate higher than that. I think Cloverfield is a good movie that kept me on the edge of my seat all the way. YES IT WAS A BIT SHAKY AT TIMES, BUT I DIDN'T CRY OR THROW UP. 7/10 just above decent. Good plot, good character development, and a new approach.

title: just another post 9/11 disaster movie.
review: Oh.... dear. The only two words which can actually describe this excuse for a movie. I went to watch it after seeing the teaser trailers a few times, and because a few of my mates had told me it was awesome. However, the trailer is just about the whole movie. Nothing happens (aside from the little mini "aliens"... which look VERY familiar...) that I didn't already know from the trailer. And the dialogue??? The oh-so-cheesy all American look at me I'm the best dialogue? the two worst lines out of any movie have to go to Cloverfield - "Are you still filming?" "Yeah, people are gonna want to know... you know... how it all went down" And then, in a false macho accent "So lets make this clear. We either die here, die in the tunnel or die on the surface" I've seen better dialogue and production values in the Teletubbies!!! The themes are exactly the same as EVERY other action movie since 9/11. They even do a fairly sick parody of the infamous video of the rubble flying down the street and people taking cover in the buildings. Totally disappointed with this movie, but then its JJ Abrams. He seems to be the MASTER of overrated rubbish.

title: This movie made me sick... really
review:
Cloverfield was hyped to be America's answer to Godzilla. Didn't live up to its promise.

I came in with a very open mind but left with a huge migraine.

The actors were wonderful but the characters were pretty flat... stereotypical and sometimes their motivations were stupid... I mean what kind of person would sacrifice the lives of his friends just to go after a girl??? It was hard for me to buy into a lot of the premises of the film.

The jerky camera movement, ala Blair Witch Project, was a bit on the heavy side and i had migraines halfway through the film and rushed to throw up after it ended.

So I'd recommend this movie only if you want to torture yourself and want to have an excuse to not go to work/school after.

title: Skip it or wait for DVD if you must
review:
It is a waste of money and time. This thing with the camcorder was not entertaining to watch...and that's why I go to the movies...to be entertained not tortured by jerky camcorder shooting. You don't get a sense of who the characters are or care if they get eaten by the monster...which by the way looks like they borrowed it from my kids' toy box. These guys need to go to film school or go back if you actually ever went. This guy, Matt Reeves, needs to stick with doing TV. I will never see anything he does without first checking it out...there's talk of a sequel...unbelievable! Well that's the beauty of this country, people make stupid movies and people without sense keep going to see them...

The guy two rows behind me summed it all up when the movie ended, "THAT'S IT?"

title: Believe the hype
review: Now I'm not going to say that this movie is for everyone, because it isn't, but I was amazed by it nonetheless. It has to be the best movie I have ever seen at the cinema yet. The graphics are stunning, and make it look so real and harrowing. The movie pulls you in, making it seem like you're actually there experiencing this with these people. The actors did a great job of making me feel for their characters and not wanting any of them to be killed off. I went into this movie expecting a good thriller, but I got more than I bargained for. This is not the sort of movie that anyone under the age of fifteen years old should see. It's quite gross in parts but even in other parts it is disturbing, watching everyone running for their lives from this huge monster. It really was very frightening, especially the ending, which disturbed me to no end, but I won't spoil anything for you. It may not be for everyone, but you should definitely check it out anyway. You'll either love it or hate it. I for one was mesmerised by it, and I don't care what anyone else thinks, because I loved it. Don't be swayed by the bad reviews, see it for yourself and see what you think.

title: Amazing!
review:
I'm going to answer some questions..

People who are commenting this are so annoying. Seriously stop whining and pay attention to the movie. No one understands why the movie ends so suddenly. If you actually pay attention you hear the military say that they are going to blow up Central Park if the 'monster' doesn't die soon. Then, while they are under the bridge, you hear the sirens meaning that the bomb or whatever is about to go off. Then, the movie ends. Clearly they both died. If the bomb killed the monster, I'm pretty sure if would kill them too. And it is a little hand held camera so if they both died, who's going to take over? No one, hence the quick ending. Moving on...

I liked the hand-held camera. It made me feel as though I were in that situation. Yes the first 15 minutes may cause motion sickness but you get over it after a while.

Also, people are saying that the first 15 minutes or so are pointless and boring. I thought it was great because you get to know the characters. It's basically the only time you have to get to know them because the rest of the movie is spent running from the monster. Not much time for socializing and getting to know them. Also, what kind of a movie starts with the monster attack as soon as it starts?

Marlena's 'unexplained' death: If you pay attention when they first get caught by the military and borough into that mini hospital thing, the camera focuses on a stretcher going by with a body that has basically the entire ribcage and gut eaten. Then they find out that Marlena has been bitten and the military and nurses freak out. When you get bitten by the spider-things, it basically releases eggs into the wound. Which lead to growing spiders inside your body. Then they take her into the tarp and you see the shadow of her exploding basically from the spiders.

And as for the "Where did the monster come from?". At the end it shows him and Beth on the ferris wheel (a clip from a while back that was recorded over). If you look closely in the background, you'll see something falling from the sky into the water. Hmmm...what could that mysterious object be? The monster of course! I thought the movie was amazing. Definitely worth the $10. It was the best movie I've seen in theaters.

title: ruined by a moaning women.. another good sci fi ruined.
review:
I gave this film a five.. why? well very good plot and fliming, keeping the viewer gripped throughout the film.. sadly another fine sci fi ruined by a moaning burbling women.. why do they insist of having women in good sci fi films when all they do is cry and irritate the viewer. its beyond me. I cant stand a women crying and moaning, looking and staring into their hands when there is a frikin monster around the corner??? in real life you are more likely to be silent in fear and concentrated on the situation.. get rid of the women, and its a good film.

However this film is original in that it expands on the blair witch first hand approach with good effects and CGI. Maybe a glimpse of why the event happened may have been good to tie up the story possibly at the beginning or end.. but its not as bad as "no country for old men" as a plot dropper, at least this film has a plot and story you can follow to the end.

title: An excellent piece of cinema (no spoilers)
review:
For those who kept an eye on the publicity / viral campaign for Cloverfield (aka Slusho / Clover / Cheese / 1.18.08 / Milk), you'd be forgiven for expecting a film that doesn't live up to the hype. Well, Cloverfield squashes the hype.

An excellent all out monster movie, director Matt Reeves brings you a package of horror, action, drama, suspense, and a little bit of sublime comic relief every now and then.

Set in New York, the basic story (for the uninitiated few) involves a huge monster attacking the city, and gate crashing Rob's (Michael Stahl-David) leaving party. Before long, a small group of survivors take off across the big, wrecked apple in order to save Rob's potential girlfriend, Beth (Odette Yustman). Sounds daft, and may niggle at you for a moment, but you probably won't care ten seconds later.

The film starts well, setting up the characters with quite a while before the mayhem begins. For a film that is all through the lens of one impromptu cameraman, Hud (TJ Miller) - H.U.D, geddit? - the complexity of the characters by the end is quite something.

Cloverfield looks the part, too. The main attraction here is obviously the crumbling city, the various buildings meeting their demise (most people by now have seen the Statue of Liberty's severed head). Also, don't worry; without saying too much, the monster looks the part. Oh yes it does.

A film involving the destruction of NYC is obviously going to bring up some queries of subtext, specifically about 9/11. Reeves and producer JJ Abrams are quite aware of this, and give you the subtext if you want it. There's also denotes of Katrina and Iraq, again, if you want there to be. But hell, this is a monster movie, so you can choose to ignore this and just enjoy the ride.

This is also a movie that wears its influences on its sleeve. Apart from the obvious monster movie look, you can also see Independence Day, War of the Worlds and Escape from New York in there. In one delightful scene which uses the camera's night vision abilities, we get an homage to / rip-off from The Descent. Plus, players of shooter epic Half Life 2 will see some familiar things there too.

Seeing as it's all through one camera, there's no non diegetic music, either. The absence of cinematic effects such as this makes Cloverfield a scarily authentic experience, with believable characters and a not-too-unbelievable plot.

With few, if any, real flaws, this makes Cloverfield a fantastic cinematic experience. This is the type of film you compare to the likes of Jurassic Park, or the aforementioned Independence Day. Do not wait for the DVD; this is something that must be witnessed on the big screen.

* * * * *

title: Totally underestimated!!!
review:
I think I understand why this movie is so underestimated. It is clear that we have not seen a truly re-invention in a long time and many viewers doesn't know how to react. And the thing is, all the main good reviews and press notice that this film has received are not for nothing. All the praises have been given by people, I mean critics, who actually knows a lot about cinema and storytelling, characters development, etc.

I am not saying this is a sort of citizen Kane, just referring to the fact that the form, the way this movie has been made, may distract from the substance and the value this piece has as a drama.

Marlena, for instance, is a great character, and it totally shows a lot of work in his creation and performance.

I think this film should be called "Cleverfield", because it is not just a success regarding marketing campaign (the filmmakers actually create a parallel universe), but also as an entertaining film.

It impressed me, and not because of "the monster". It simply took me by surprise in a good way.

title: An excellent film.
review:
First things first, the movie does not reveal all the information to the viewer in the film. Either you need to watch the movie closely in order to derive some of what is going on, or you need to surf the internet. That's right, you heard me; the movie uses something called "Viral Marketing," which is when you find out a whole bunch of information about the plot over the internet.

Now for the movie itself.

Many people complain that the camera wouldn't stop moving; well, it's supposed to be a hand held camera the whole time, so it wouldn't make sense for the camera to stay still if it was hand-held, would it? And many people rate the movie down because it made them sick. Look, even if it makes you sick, that doesn't mean it's a bad movie. It just means you get motion sickness. Live with it.

And it very much had a plot, if anyone is curious. It's actually incredibly deep, but like I said, you need to do some research to fully understand the plot - which is quite in depth.

My overall rating: Very good, tense monster movie, but obviously not for everyone.

title: A cut above most monster movies (spoilers)
review:
Let's face it. Most monster movies are rubbish. Even the original King Kong leaves me cold, featuring as it does bland characters and atrocious dialogue. But wait, it features a massive ape tearing stuff apart. Isn't that, like, totally awesome, dude? No, not really.

So does Cloverfield buck the trend of the rubbish monster movie? Well, it does and it doesn't. I mean, the characters here are amazingly bland. I cared for them not one bit. And the dialogue is serviceable at best. It's basically, 'Let's run!' or 'We've got to go back and find Beth!' But because of the film's central gimmick, the fact that it's supposedly shot on someone's digital camera, it ends up being a lot of fun.

The fun that's to be had in the movie is from the tension that is generated by the way the movie is filmed  one camera, no music; the sound design is the score. An example is an excellent little sequence in a subway tunnel. It's dark and we can hardly see. Yet we can hear something  the main monster sheds little monsters, so we know these little bastards are pursuing the characters. And so their reveal via one of the characters turning on the night vision on his camera delivers a bigger jolt that it ordinarily would.

And the use of the single camera makes ordinary scenes of death and destruction far more expressionistic. We see bits and pieces but we rarely get to see the full monty. Which in the case of a monster movie is actually a good thing  Godzilla and King Kong wreaking havoc is so ludicrous when viewed from a safe distance that it usually elicits yawns and laughs. So the single camera helps ground the film  to ensure that it doesn't become one massive flight of fancy.

However, I just wish that the filmmakers had the balls to go all the way with the concept. I was perfectly happy only seeing pieces of the monster. But at the end we get the grand reveal. Yep, it's not good. To picture the monster just imagine a massive frog-like mouse that has ape-like arms and which seems to have mated with an old man somewhere along the line. In all its glory, it looks terrible. It really takes you out of the film.

And I also got fed up with the numerous endings. Oh, the helicopter's crashed and they're all dead? Okay, that's pretty brave: a bleak ending. Oh, no, they survived. And here comes the monster and he's killed one of the main characters. Okay, another decent ending: the cameraman is dead and the rest will lose their lives too. But no, someone else has picked up the camera and the film's still going. Rather than end with a bang, the film ends with a splutter.

But to be honest, the film doesn't start much better, either. The first twenty minutes or so revolve around a party where we get introduced to the main characters. And what a dull lot they are  lots of bland late twenty-somethings. There's not one bit of fat anywhere. Not one ugly face. But there's also no personality. Indeed, the charisma void is so chronic that I had no idea who had perished  someone called Jason dies and I was left scratching my head. And then later I found out that it was the hero's brother who is quite prominent in the party sequence. Oh, okay.

But once the destruction starts there are some very enjoyable sequences. There's a great bit where we see devastation in the distance and then the head of the Statue of Liberty comes bouncing off buildings before resting in the middle of the street. Finally we have a monster movie that isn't up in the skyscrapers, watching from the heavens.

I also liked the street battle the characters get caught up in. For a brief moment it becomes like a war movie  the cameraman hiding behind a car as the army tries to take down its enemy. And there was something grimly enjoyable about the moment where one of the main characters, who's been bitten by the little monsters the big monster sheds, is taken to a medical tent and we see the silhouette of her head exploding. The film is surprisingly violent in places.

But although the action is superbly done and the central gimmick works a treat, it's still very traditional at heart. The main character is in love with a girl he's been friends with for years. And because he's leaving to go to Japan, they kind of have a fling. So you're watching a guy go back into hell to rescue the woman he loves. Now this isn't a film where you feel like there's a deep emotional bond between the characters, so the central story is a bit of an eye-roller. Okay, you love this girl. Okay, you've spent a blissful morning in bed and you had a lovely day at Coney Island. But please could the pair of you just be a bit more than pretty. Please.

But as it stands, the film's good entertainment. The action is well choreographed and the single camera works superbly. But it still can't transcend the monster movie limitations. It's still basically a bunch of idiots running away from a silly creature. Plus instead of a bunch of morons in top hats fleeing from an ape, we now have morons in khakis filming everything with their mobile phones. Yes, when the apocalypse happens it will be scored to a cacophony of obnoxious ringtones.

title: Better Than Expected
review:
Given that i am not the biggest J.J Abrams fan, i headed into this with some reservations. However, i am pleased to say that 'Cloverfield' is a great success for the monster movie genre in the 21st century. By playing on the current western fear of terrorism, the film presents the kind of fear that the cinema goer can invest in, in 2008. The film also boasts some strong performances from its cast of relative unknowns, who, because of their anonymity, also add another layer of reality to the film. Having said this i feel that the films biggest success, is the use of only the camcorder footage captured by the group, which in many parts of the film greatly adds to its atmosphere and intensity, in particular in the subway scene. Despite its many strong points i feel there were two problems with the film, which hampered it slightly as an experience: Firstly, i feel that the monster itself did not quite live up to its hype, which i suppose is not surprising given, the films promotional push prior to its release. Secondly; I feel the film suffers from what i like to call return of the king syndrome with respect to the ending, as it feels that the filmmakers couldn't quite decide what they wanted to do, so they packed everything in at the cost of the films coherence.

However, despite these issues, 'Cloverfield' is great, daring, and genuinely scary popcorn cinema, and a very strong addition to the monster movie cannon.

Rob Yeomans

title: It's like Marmite
review: You either love it, or hate it. I thought it was amazing. Brilliant special effects; so much so my jaw actually dropped, plus the camera angles and shots made you feel like you were actually witnessing a real event. I was enthralled from the very beginning. The storyline itself is well thought-out, and it doesn't disappoint when you find out what actually is doing the damage to New York. There's even slight bits of comedy which had the whole audience laughing. The ending is only bad if you need your movie story lines spoon-fed to you. Personally I think everyone should see this movie. If you don't like it then there's really something wrong.

title: A revitalising experience
review:
First and foremost what I liked about Cloverfield was the hand held home movie camera filming style, which as far as I know has not been utilised before in a monster movie. This is what ultimately makes Cloverfield a unique experience and a unique film. I believe that if it was not for the amateur movie making style this film would have never been made because Godzilla, King Kong among other monster flicks have already been created on large budgets, so for anyone that complains about the shaky camera movement and the fact that it is extremely fast at times you have to remember that this movie would have no merit as a film if it was not for the amateur filming style. The Blair Witch project was the first mainstream film I recollect that attempted this style because it does create a more visceral atmosphere and as time passes, and we as humanity are subjected to more and more violence, such as the news that is always displaying negative material we become more immune to being scared, surprised and frightened. All you have to do is compare the violence in movies today compared to the earlier days and it has increased dramatically. Special effects and visual effects have been incorporated into films to give us filmmakers the opportunity to broaden our imagination to what can be adapted for screen, but to generally scare people, especially older people it is becoming harder all the time that is why film crosses over into the documentary style genre to try and reflect reality. I think Cloverfield was a good idea because it does reflect reality (obviously minus the monsters) ultimately making it more scary, thanks to the amateur film/documentary style.

The fact that terrorism is prevalent in society today and peoples psyches is another reason why Cloverfield is a power film and made for this era to reflect a first person experience of what it would be like in the midst of a major attack and the affect it has on people. Films generally are the most successful when they have an impact on people by incorporating present issues and fears. The story is so simplistic and obvious for those of you expecting a complex plot, but sometimes it is the simplist stories that are the best and Cloverfield works, but again coming back to the filming style which makes it fresh and worth making. Cloverfield also relies on the hidden enemy method to create fear. The less that you see the more your imagination can run free usually making the experience more frightening, just watch Jaws for example. I believe the film/documentary style is the way forward to create generally more scary films or if 3D cinema becomes the mainstream then that will be the way forward. Imagine watching a film like Jaws in 3D. We need fresh experiences in cinema for new eras as technology grows and I believe that Cloverfield is a good example, although if I might add a very obvious one in my eyes.

title: Not a masterpiece, but still a breathe of fresh air
review:
It seems that most people who rate this movie badly went into it expecting a special effects extravaganza, chockablock with wide shots of the monster causing mayhem. If that's what you're looking for, go rent "War of the Worlds" or any of the dozens and dozens of the other disaster/monster movies that have already done it.

While no masterpiece, this movie takes a novel approach to the genre, fully commits to it, and in my opinion, pulls it off very well.

The 9/11 allegory is relatively bland and unimpressive, until the second-to-last scene (the final scene in the story's chronological line). Its raw authenticity is extremely powerful, and for me, ended up raising the whole picture's impact and value considerably.

title: Very well done, Great entertainment.
review:
"Cloverfield" is just a downright entertaining movie. It's got suspense, good humor and cool looking action scenes. The shaky camera wasn't even bad, it added to the overall effect.

Rob is going away for his new job, and a large group of friends throw him a going away party. Unfortunately, the party must end abruptly when a giant grasshopper looking monster begins destroying the city. The cameraman for most of the movie is the comic relief best friend character Hud, and him being the cameraman works very well. Some intense scenes needed a bit of comic relief, and he worked just fine. The action scenes are usually shaky, but they still look great. Because the first 20 minutes of the film are used to introduce the characters and their backgrounds, the audience can actually relate to these likable group of young adults.

It's a very entertaining flick. See it in the theaters for the amazing sound effects.

My rating: *** out of ****. 74 mins. PG-13 for violence.

title: Good monster movie, but... (contains plot reveals)
review:
At a leaving party for Rob, who's heading to Japan, explosions are heard in the city. Going out onto the street, the head of The Statue Of Liberty crashes down and in the distance a glimpse of a creature is seen. Rob and some friends heads into the chaos to find Beth, who he's in love with, as she's trapped and hurt in the city. all the while recording everything on digital camera.....

The actors are mainly unknown, which is a good thing as it keeps you wondering who will survive, and how many as the monster and the military battle it out on the streets. The script is okay, but most of the lines are of the 'OH MY GOD' variety or screaming at some points. The actors do enough to convince with their performances being scared and on occasion funny.

The start of the movie, during the party is long enough to introduce the characters and how they relate to each other. This of course, means that when the destruction occurs you do care who is going to live or die.

The director Matt Reeves does well not only in keeping the story moving, but also in the decision to only show glimpses of the monster. This makes it more frightening. There are a couple of moments from a story point of view where the director has obviously set up a scare to happen, but on the whole it's done well

The appearance of the monster is never explained, which is good. Most movies of this nature, such as Godzilla tend to explain the origin on the monster, but here it simply shows up and chaos reigns! The effects are impressive. The scenes of devastation in New York are stunning, and the creature effects are pretty good, both the huge creature, and also it's 'offspring'.

There are some good shocks through-out the movie, the stand-out scene being a tunnel attack from the 'offspring'.

But.... there are flaws.

The story is very similar (guy looking for girl in a city in chaos) to an 80's movie Miracle Mile, right down to the downbeat ending.

The idea of the movie being showing from the point of view from video being recorded isn't new. Movies such as The Blair Witch Project and Diary Of The Dead have used the same point of view, but to be fair the footage shot is impressive.

The movie is only around 90 minutes long. As a result, things are kept tight, and also believable with regard to the battery of the camera. A longer movie, might have had battery problems with the cameras!!

As a monster movie it's great. Does it live up to it's hype? Not quite. But it's still worth seeing.

title: Don't Listen to The Small Minded, This Movie is Great.
review: I was very anxious to see the film, not only because the concept of a Monster attack on New York, but the fact that they kept the monster a mystery until the film came out for release and the fact that it was shot in the eyes of people trying to survive, if it were to be a big budget film like Godzilla, which sucked, then I would have passed. Now the movie does start out a little slow, but if you pay attention to the characters, you can tell who will live and who won't, and to see that they are real people, not heroes. Now if you are some sap where you want every detail given to you like you are some robot and have no taste for a real film, then you should stay home and leave the rest of us to enjoy the movie. I mean if you know your an a##-hole, why rub it in our faces. But back to the movie, I felt the camera work was the best part, and you can't even compare this to Blair Witch, it gave the movie a more realistic feeling and it stayed away from the same old story line where we have a solution for everything. In reality people, if a monster did attack us, we would be fuc%@^ Just like in the movie. Now the look of the monster was the best choice for a because it was different, scary, and had no background story, so it made it more intense. Now for the ending, perfect, just how it should have ended. So don't expect to see a Disney B.S. ending where everyone sings and is happy, it's a monster movie, that ending doesn't exist. I highly recommend the film to the people who really get movies, not the ones who like Meet the Spartans. It's a great film, very original for a known concept, and will leave you with a new idea of what film making is turning into, not the same old crap.

title: Enjoyable ride
review:
It's too flippant and easy to call this Godzilla meets The Blair Witch Project. Cloverfield deserves better than that.

What it is in reality is a tense, highly enjoyable ride that (with a reasonably short runtime) never outstays its welcome. It's able to convey a tangible sense of menace that other mainstream Hollywood disaster films like ID4, the Godzilla remake and the remake of War of the Worlds couldn't, and does it without having to resort to laying on the gore.

Those who have trouble with shaky camera work and need everything in the plot tied up in a nice neat little bow need not apply to see Cloverfield. If you do, I'm sure you'll be annoyed by the films "conclusion". It feels and plays like found documentary footage so it lacks the normal structure (like Blair Witch), which is exactly the intent.

I had high hopes for this film and was completely satisfied by its end.

title: Blair Witch Godzilla Style
review:
Cloverfield (2008)

*** (out of 4)

The Blair Witch Project meets a Godzilla type movie in this action film that has NYC being ripped apart by some unknown monster. Okay, this film has some really great moments but the screenplay really left me cold. I understand the whole gimmick of having a hand held camera capture all the action but the screenplay gives us four rather bland characters and none of them are more interesting than the actual monster and destruction of the city. Even though the film runs under 80-minutes I found myself getting bored whenever the film focused on the characters but thankfully there's still plenty of action to keep things going. I hate CGI but the effects are used very good here with some really great scenes of the city being destroyed. The ending with the monster on a full rampage while coming under attack was very thrilling and I also enjoyed how the film ended but the very ending was a little frustrating but perhaps this will be cleared up in the upcoming sequel. The performances were okay but the screenplay really didn't give them much good dialogue and the love story was just downright stupid.

title: Fantastic, a must see!
review:
So i set of with my mates to see cloverfield today, i have been hyping about this film for ages and knowing that the Americans got it two weeks before hand made me cry. So, anyway we get in the cinema mixed opinions on how the movie will be. When it ends i ask my friends what they thought of it.

Me: Absouloutly epic, a must see! Prentice: Brilliant, fantastic CGI innovative filming. Jack: Lived up to the hype, the little ones are scary! Toby: FLAMING HOBOS! Pheobe: Great. Sean: An averagely average movie.

So in all 90% of us thought it was epic.

title: cloverfield
review: this movie was so horrible that it makes me want to go back in time to find my grandfather. so i can kick him in his balls till they pop to insure that i will never see this movie. the constant camera movement had many people ill, including me and i wanted to vomit with rage. the small creatures that come of the monster seem like a rip off from some other movie i can't quite recall. Abraham's had no chance to live up to the hype of the marketing for this polished turd of a movie, especially with the very small amount of the monster that is seen. And the websites that kept you entertain for about 2 minutes till you get bored. i would have rather force feed my face into a garbage disposal. i want my money and my time back.

title: Cloverfield sucked
review: OK first off the camera work sucked. I mean who's idea was it to make a movie where the entire movie was on a camcorder... Everyone I was with felt sick for most of the movie due to the extremely shaky camera. Thendon't get me started on the ending, I am not going to give it away, but lets just say it left a lot to be desired. I really think the movie would have been awesome if it were made into a normal movie with better camera work (normal), and actually give an end to the story, but the way it is I would not even recommend watching this movie if it was free. Also, if you can't handle shaky videos (like home videos) don't go see this movie because it will give you a headache, or maybe even make you sick to your stomach.

title: a bunch of idiots running around and filming them self and think there good a lot of bull that is me done
review: what a crock of s**t don't watch it u be so disappointed u want believe plus the most stupid as endings i ever seen u don't really see the monsters its like bulls**t Blair witch all over again rubbish i would not wast my money people at the pictures u will ask for ur money back lol i sort this is good like hell a pile of cack the best bits are advertised on TV and thats about it so boring and it takes a long time to kick in and when u think yeah here we go finally and then it just goes more down hill because this monsters from what u can see are crap all u see is shadows no monsters really one of the worst film i ever seen so Lady's don't be frightened nothing to be frightened of i would let my 8 year old son watch it thats how frightening i thing it is crap

title: Fun, Fun, Fun!
review:
Wow! Thoroughly enjoyable! I've been reading a lot of comments from viewers who didn't like it. Most of them complain about the hand-held camera aspect. Many others complain that it didn't have every aspect of the story laid out with surgical precision, leaving no room for the imagination. Boo-whah! The first 15-20 minutes allowed us to get to know the characters. The rest was just go-go-go and is what you'd expect from a first-person experience. They didn't linger on the creature, but just their own experience while it was happening.

This is a movie that depends on the intelligence of the viewer to let their own mind fill in the blanks - the beginning and end of the story. I feel sorry for those who need to have everything handed to them on a plate.

So what if the characters do stupid things...isn't that part of the news everyday?

title: Give a 3 year old a camcorder and this is what you end up with...
review: There is very little I can say good about this movie. During the entire thing, I was waiting for it to start but, alas, it never did. While the "first person" perspective was a novel idea it did not translate well to the big screen in my opinion. WAY too much camera movement - if you have any kind of motion sickness stay away from this movie! There were a few good scenes I suppose, but as soon as I started to get interested it was "cut to new scene while camera bounces around like it's being shot by an epileptic having a seizure". Character development was horrible; I didn't empathize with any character in the movie (if someone would have put a bullet in all the main character's heads within the first 30 minutes maybe I could have empathized with that), and was pleading for them to die before continuing to assault me with their overacting and annoying "self awareness". Bottom line for me, this movie sucked - and if you did an exit poll of the people in the theater that day I believe you would have got a 99% thumbs down....the main theme of conversation walking out was "WTF was that piece of s*#t!"

title: My Kids could have made a better movie.
review: The trailers were the best part of this movie. It takes too long to get into anything of interest, then the camera never stops moving. This film is made for the gamer's who like the first person shooter. I do give them some credit for the monster, but it doesn't get enough screen time. To much Love Story and not enough story telling. The plot has to many holes and the characters just don't draw you in. I didn't feel sorry for any of them during their journey. I think the writers went on strike before this movie was completed. The storyline was too unbelievable and the military would not allow a small group back into a war zone. Don't waste your money!!! You can wait to rent this one.

title: This film was horrible
review: This was the worst "movie" I have ever seen. Who wants to sit an watch an amateur video shaking and moving around never actually stopping to let you view anything. This movie made me literally want to barf. This was the worst "movie" I have ever seen. Who wants to sit an watch an amateur video shaking and moving around never actually stopping to let you view anything. This movie made me literally want to barf. This was the worst "movie" I have ever seen. Who wants to sit an watch an amateur video shaking and moving around never actually stopping to let you view anything. This movie made me literally want to barf. This was the worst "movie" I have ever seen. Who wants to sit an watch an amateur video shaking and moving around never actually stopping to let you view anything. This movie made me literally want to barf. And the movie was only about one hour. More like a documentary.

title: Let's be honest - entertaining, not plausible
review:
I decided to write this a full 24 hours after watching the film because it usually takes me that long to come to a critical decision. If I had written this immediately after viewing the film, I would have written that it was a great movie. I never once was bored, the explosions were nice, I was satisfied because I got to see the monster and I was even more satisfied that the film never told where the monster came from. I do think audiences are sometimes better off using their imaginations because nothing is ever as creative or terrible than something you make up for yourself. People leaving the theater were complaining because they felt they hadn't been told enough. Not me - I had fun. I expected total trash. Maybe the fact that it was so much better than I anticipated lead me to overrate the film.

Yes, I was never scared. It was action-filled, but predictably so. I knew the bridge would be torn down. I told my husband that as soon as they directed everyone to the bridge. I knew they would see rats running in the tunnel and why as soon as they went into the subway. This film is not a horror film. It is an action film. At least, I do not think the intention was to scare the audience, but rather, keep them involved in the action. Predictablity is par for the course in action films.

However, I was disappointed that the film was not more realistic in some ways. I fully expected that girl to change her shoes in the department store - I would have. It would have taken the military longer to get there. I am no expert on weapons, but the monster looked soft-skinned, still, nothing hurt it. Come on, I don't believe it. A more realistic situation would be trying to escape while waiting for the military to get there with tanks and whatever else. But other things were unrealistic as well. The three people who survived the copter crash weren't strapped in as far as I could tell. If the camera's auto focus had problems in one part, why not in any other part? But, hey this camera did much that mine won't. I don't think mine would have made it after falling from the monster's mouth, let alone the crash or even some of the falls. I didn't mind the camera jumping, but the little break-ins from what was supposed to originally be on the tape were overused. Finally, the whole "Hold on to someone you love. That's what's important - love" stuff is a little too obvious. Other movies have made far more serious statements about society in far less obvious ways. Like Romero or Takashi Miike (spelling?).

I enjoyed myself. It wasn't a bad movie, but it wasn't "groundbreaking" or "unique." I certainly did not "make my entire life" as some have claimed here. I am glad I was talked into seeing it.

title: Simply doesn't live up to the hype.
review:
Since the untitled teaser trailer was released with Transformers in July, hype and mystery have been on this movie like flies on crap. Sad to say, Cloverfield doesn't live up to it.

The biggest hook this movie has is "What does the monster look like?" I won't spoil it, so don't worry. You DO get one clear shot of the monster near the end of the movie; the rest of the time it's bits and pieces. For the first 10-15 minutes of the movie or so there is no attack. It is a going away party for Rob, the main character.

Which brings me to the camera. I was expecting it to be used for the party, not for the ENTIRE movie. When the camera isn't focused on the monster, I felt sick looking at the screen. It feels a little too realistic most of the time. However, the special effects and sound are spectacular.

I would've given this a higher rating, but the camera, overall forgettable characters and terrible ending bring this to a somewhat generous 7/10.

title: Not very thrilling, but it was awesome.
review:
This movie mainly focuses on the people, and not on the monster itself, unlike other monster-related movies, which somehow focuses on how 'great' or how 'cool' the monster is. Be real. When a monster comes, do you know why it came? Do you think that the monster is 'cool'? Would you return all the way back for someone you really really love? Or would you just run? Would you even bother showing the world what really happened?

I really liked the way they ended the movie. It was real and it makes sense. In the first place, who would survive a hammerhead? Unless God protects you, otherwise. NO!

The entire movie was shot in a hand-held camera style. I'm amazed by the production. It didn't make me dizzy, and i was pretty nervous all the way till at home. Even now, as i'm typing this review. I would want to know how they make the movie.

I'm kind of hoping there will be a sequel or something.

title: Now For A Real Review
review: Alas we wait in eager anticipation for the movie to start. No Opening soundtrack. We're alert from a mix of visuals from different elements from recorded video. Intro: we meet various 20 something's at a surprise party. Next Scene: Monster Attacks & 20 Somethings kak themselves. The movie is good....not great. We witness a dark time from the eyes of an everyday group of social butterfly's. The exception is that we see a change of survival instinct from everyone involved. This creature has no interest in one person nor 1000. Its interest or background is not known. What is known is that these few survivors should've, could've taken the first route out of Manhattan. They Don't. This is the Alien of the 20th Century. We are only being introduced to the beast. Running and being scared is just natural. The following movie will provide more info in regards to "its Bacground" however the interest will remain with the surviving characters. Turn this into a movie of equals. Produce it from different perspectives, Survivor, Saviour etc. Enjoy the movie. Its better than the hype

title: A Movie Fueled By Viral Hype That DOESN'T Disappoint!
review:
