So what has months of internet hype and viral marketing given us? Apparently, a pretty damn good movie by most people's standards. "Cloverfield" is the lovechild of a bunch of guys who got bored with writing and directing TV and decided to try their hand at a film. And it paid off, big time.

As is evident from the trailers, "Cloverfield" is the story of a group of six friends trying to escape Manhattan during an attack from an unknown monster. All of this seems utterly familiar from any other monster movie, but the thing that makes it original is the Blair Witch-esquire storytelling from the point of view of a handicam. The film starts out by showing a series of screens, followed by the text "SD Memory Card from the camera retrieved from US Site-???, area formerly known as Central Park". We are then introduced to Rob and Beth, two of the main characters. They are seen laying together in bed, planning out their day, just like you'd see in any home movie. The rough cuts fit well, as it shifts from that day to another where Rob is planning on leaving for Japan for a job. The camera is now in the hands of Jason, Rob's brother, as he and his girlfriend Lilly, Rob's best friend Hud, and a few others prepare for Rob's going away party. It all fits the bill of being a home movie very nicely, until the monster attacks. Hud, the cameraman, decides to document the night to let everyone know "how it all went down". From there, we are introduced to the sometimes nausea-inducing shaky camera movements.

But you cannot fault Reeves for doing what he did: the camera is very shaky and during a few scenes almost unbearable, but it never breaks the illusion that we are watching a first-hand account of what is going on. Frequent turning on and off of the camera give the film a seamless quality. Hud, the resident idiot, also filmed over the tape that Rob used to film his lovely date at Coney Island with Beth - so when Hud turns the camera off improperly, we are given a few brief moments of the tape he recorded over, helping us to understand Rob and Beth's relationship.

The idea is nothing short of genius. I seem to keep reading people chastising the film for being overdone or unoriginal, but all I can see is originality and a fresh idea. It's Blair Witch meets Godzilla. But it's done with style, heart, and a surprising amount of substance. The cast, which is comprised of mostly no-name television actors, pulls off a collaboratively believable performance. Every actor in the film helps sustain the illusion that this is real footage from the night, and that they are being completely natural on-camera.

"Cloverfield" avoids many easily ensnaring pitfalls and clichÃ©s. The film takes a few minutes to warm up, but then it launches into an hour-long, bloody, terrifying, no-holds-barred rampage where no character or set piece is safe from the destruction. Ignore the naysayers - "Cloverfield" is an adrenaline rush with thought and characters. Finally, I've seen a Hollywood Hype-Machine that was worth all the hype, especially considering the brainless, mind melting action poo piles that they've been throwing at us the past few years. Abrams also dishes out to the hardcore fans of the film, dropping little hidden tidbits of clues and hints, and rewards the diligent seekers by putting in hidden secrets only the truest of nerds would be able to find. It's films like these that make me embrace my nerdiness.

Great film, and a great way to start out 2008.

title: Insane, tense, intimate, and compelling. A must see.
review:
I thought going into this film that the hand-held camera would be just a gimmick but it actually turns out to be highly effective at creating a sense of intimacy in the early sequences and shear terror in the latter.

It doesn't compare to Blair Witch even though everyone will make that comparison. There are long awesome sequences that show incredible visuals but also give a sense of realism because the camera really does feel hand held.

I was blown away, you will be, too.

N

title: Incredible and thrilling BUT NOT for the weak of heart or those easily frightened by horror movies.
review:
PLEASE NOTE: This film is EXTREMELY intense. There are a lot of sudden terrifying moments and shocking turns throughout with borderline rated R violence, terror and gore. This movie, particularly near the end absolutely terrified my poor wife who swears she will never go to the movie with me again after this (and "I am Legend" a few weeks ago)

I just got back from the midnight premiere of Cloverfield at my local theater (Yes, I got the free camera, no I haven't used it yet). My wife and I went as today was my 30th birthday and I have been looking forward to this film ever since the first trailers. I really thoroughly enjoyed the film and thought the "shaky-cam" approach was particularly appropriate for the story being told, though my wife had a hard time with it due to the erratic motion made by the camera holder in most scenes and I noticed a few other people getting a bid queasy from it.

Again, if you like thrilling, shocking and intense thrill rides, this is it. SPOILERS POTENTIALLY BELOW THIS LINE: --------------------------------------------------------------- I don't see this as spoilers, but if you are exceptionally worried about being spoiled on the basic layout of the film, please be advised of it in the paragraph below:

This film features a group of friends who get caught up in by some sort of unknown attack on New York and the entire film is solely from the perspective of the person holding the camera who basically is partly trying to document the horrific events unfolding and partly just holding onto it as an anchor to his own sanity in the situation. Scary stuff at times, but beautifully executed. Also, make sure to stick around through the credits and you will hear an audio only tack on to the end of the film that is important (in my opinion) to resolving a plot thread.

I'm ready to see a sequel/follow-up now!!! (?)

title: Excellent, Take the Movie for What it is!
review: Cloverfield brings a whole new take on the dying monster genre of films. First off take the movie for what it is. It is a home-movie type filming style that represents the YouTube generation being obsessed with capturing everything on video. Thus, naturally questions that people had prior to the movie could not be realistically answered as the movie's plot or story is simply being in the midst of a giant monster attack in New York City. We know as an audience as little as the main characters do about what is happening which is a good thing that fits the story. The movie can not spoon feed us every answer to all our questions, because that is not the point of the movie. The point of the movie is not to tell us the origin of this monster and why it is attacking the city. The main characters our likable enough to carry you through this experience. The main character in a sense is you or Hud (guy filming event) experiencing this giant monster rip apart the city. Let's be honest there is plot loop holes and some unreal situations, such as Hud filming this event and not putting down the camera, but it is a movie! Overall this movie utilizes an effective hand held filming style that has not been done since Blair Witch, which brings a shockingly realistic feel to the movie reminiscent of 9/11 images. Take the movie for what it is, an experience that will still leave questions, but nonetheless an excellent frightening tale of a group of New Yorkers being attacked by a 4 legged-dinosaur like monster whom unleashes all his rage on the city reviving the giant monster genre.

title: Very Good and Thankfully not too Long.
review: The reason I say thankfully not too long is that the hand-held cam is so headache inducing that it almost isn't worth having. But, without it the movie would lose what makes it so cool. Looking at the visuals like this really made it seem like it all was being destroyed. The best scenes are seen in the previews but they really are amazing to behold. It makes it all the more terrifying that it's happening in New York and it seems like another terrorist attack at first. The chaos is very cool when it is about, the running around, while necessary, very hard to keep watching. The monster is what it is. It's pretty cool I guess, but you really never get a great enough look to tell. To me it looked kinda like a oceanic praying mantis. There are some really well done intense scenes and pretty serious shocks. I really enjoyed the film and do recommend it. However, if the shaky hand-held cam makes you sick, you might want to avoid this one.

title: A fresh idea executed well
review:
Well, this is my first review, so go easy on me.

I had my doubts about this movie, I don't know the director or any of the actors, it only has 30 million dollar budget and no real synopsis. Have to say, this is the first movie I went and watch driven by hype only, and in some ways I think it did live up to its hype.

The good parts: Let's face it, we go to watch this movie to see a giant monster wrecks Manhattan, so I wouldn't go too far about the plot. The movie is about a rescue and escape, and that's all I'm going to say about it. It's a decent plot that drives the movie, at times it can be pretty stupid but the actors did well for this kind of movie.

So they promised us a giant monster. Many of us, me included, thought that due to its small budget, it will only appear briefly at the end of the movie. Well turns out this is not the case, the monster appeared early and often in the first 30 minutes, albeit only glimpses of it, around 40 minutes into the movie, we get to see it face-to-face. It's early appearance was satisfying considering all the hype and mystery about the monster's appearance. But most importantly, in the third act, we get to see the monster as a whole, and how did the filmmaker executed this with such a small budget? I'm a 3D animator myself, so I know quality special effects when I see one, for a 30 million dollar movie (if this is true), the special effects look proper and very well made. This can be attributed to the whole movie taking place in the dark and most of the special effects shot are always full of movements and quite short, with an exception for a single one: the statue of liberty's head scene, it actually looks quite cheap, fortunately when it comes to the scary stuffs, this movie done all-right.

The bad part: The origin of the monster is not quite explained thoroughly even until the end of the movie. This is, because the entire movie is told from a first person perspective of the protagonists. This way the whole movie is constrained only to its protagonists fight for rescue and survival, so, no subplot about a scientist with answers like in other monster movies. The origin however is explained only by a single split second scene at the end, blink and you'll miss it.

Overall, I enjoyed the movie, but just like "I am Legend", i feel that the third act kinda collapsed. The concept's quite fresh, Hollywood has not many giant monster movies and after the disastrous attempt on adapting Godzilla in 1998, thanks to J.J. Abrams for producing this movie. I would like to see more of this franchise, too many questions are still unanswered, maybe a sequel with a bigger budget and a different narrative. But for now, this is a very good start.

title: Did Hollywood just do a cool film???
review:
If you like having everything explained to you, tedious backstories, and all loose ends tied up in a no brainer so you won't have to use your imagination, don't go see this movie.

If you like cheesy Hollywood music scores telling you when to be frightened, when to be sad, or happy, don't go see this movie.

However if you want a visceral, original, immersive experience and are prepared to take this film as the monster film it is (albeit done in an original and interesting way) then you'll love it.

It was like an amusement park ride. loud, tense, INtense, and not exactly Shakespeare.

And for once the characters (mostly) made believable decisions, and were believably scared, freaked out, and ran like hell screaming most of the time. As i damn well would too.

Different, original, and a whole lotta fun.

title: A Decent Film
review:
Like many of you, I was intrigued by this film when I first saw the teaser come out with Transformers. Then, between the initial teaser and the film's release, the hype for this film built up higher and higher. Days before the release of the movie, I began to worry that Cloverfield wouldn't live up to its hype, so I went into the cinema with mixed feelings. However, after watching it, I was not disappointed at all.

The basic story of Cloverfield is that there is a group of 5 people trying to evacuate Manhattan because of a monster attack. While there are some people who would disagree with me, I say that the one of the best parts of the film is the lack of a background story for the monster. All we know is that it most likely came from the ocean, and decided to attack.

Whilst this movie is not really a perfect film, I was entertained throughout it. My only complaint about Cloverfield was that the camera was too shaky. Unfortunately for me, I sat in the front row of my cinema, and felt slightly sick when the movie ended.

Overally, I thoroughly enjoyed this film. 8/10

title: My View of Cloverfield After Seeing the Debut,(SPOILERS INSIDE)
review: Great Movie Overall 8/10, great scenes and decent acting, but the Blair Witch Project point of view, kind of gets old, very quickly, This could be my 2 cents, where i like long pan shots and close ups where i can see in detail, but it does add to the action, in each scene and the point of view of the monster etc. And at first, I thought it was the sequel to Godzilla, but changed very quickly after seeing the close up of the Monster.... It was a great movie till the ending, which really disappointed me and as i walked out of the cinema at the end, i was hoping there to be a sequel, cause this would have intrigued me to see the next one, but was sadly disappointed to find out NO SEQUEL!!! AHHHH! I found that the plot was quite good, but for those die hard sci-fi fans it has the action and CGI of the best, But it doesn't reveal the nature and origin of this Monster/Alien, Which i found Upsetting. Would have liked to seen a little more concentration on alien background, but the action was great, Its just one of those movies which is perfect till the ending, Where it looks like they ran out of Money, And you feel that there should be some closure. I do recommend seeing it, Great Action Flick for All, As its in the point of view of an everyday bystander, as you feel you could walk into that persons shoes and imagine the choices and feelings you would experience, which is great.

title: Quite gripping and much better than I thought
review:
I live in Thailand and caught the first show today. After all the hype I was pleasantly surprised. The story starts a bit slow, but the monster attack began before I got bored. The shaky camera work puts you in the middle of the action. Other than "The Blair Witch Project", to which this has been compared, the characters are sympathetic enough to make the story compelling. There's so much action that the movie seems to be much longer than the actual running time.

The monster design is fine, if not completely original, with flailing, spider- or crab-like legs. The "face" reminded me a little of Ray Harryhausen's Ymir. The beast has only one clear close-up shot near the end of the movie, but its massive body is glimpsed several times before. It looks very impressive. The small offspring or parasite monsters are barely glimpsed, but they are vicious.

No explanation is given about the monster's origin. The camera-bearing protagonists are all killed - no Hollywood ending for this movie.

Altogether a solid entertainment with a big potential for sequels. Also one of the best uses of surround sound ever.

title: Cloverfield!!!
review:
So Cloverfield is a different type of monster movie. You get quite a bit of quick shots of the monster that eventually gives you an overall idea of what it looks like. aside from the looks for the creature you don't get much info on it at all.. Like what it is, where it came from, how long it's been here? They do explain why its in New York and what it wants.

There actually presentation of the movies also is hurt by the fact The Blair Witch Project looked steady compared to this stomach churner. The movie keep looked into like a vise tho and made me feel like i was along for the ride. I also feel i want more! i want to know what happened after the movie ended, why is the movie named Cloverfield, will there be a sequel? i have to know!!

My favorite part of the movie tho is at the very end when you realize that Rob and the monsters fates are tied together long before the attack. I almost missed it but at end there is a scene with the camera overlooking the sea and i think you can see the alien creature splash down in the ocean!! i was impressed.

P.S. The Star Trek trailer got me so pumped!!

title: Pretty Darn Decent
review:
One thing I have to commend Abrams on is his marketing. If I had known anything about this movie before I went and saw it today it would've lessened the impact greatly as you literally spend half the movie trying to piece the monster together out of hurried camera shots until finally everything is revealed. Thats not to say EVERYTHING is revealed. In fact, nothing is revealed except what the monster looks like, how bad ass it is and how screwed humans are. So don't expect any investigation into why the monster's in New York, why it got there etc etc...

The presentation is aesthetically pleasing, at times dizzying, but nothing groundbreaking. It manages to carry an otherwise stereotypical storyline all the way to the finish in fantastic flair.

Cloverfield's faithfulness to the handicam style is really what makes and breaks the film as while it provides a more personal and realistic experience, nothing goes beyond the boundaries of the camera so don't expect any answers whatsoever.

The storyline is where Cloverfield falters, as it is essentially 1997's Godzilla shot from a handicam - a pretty sturdy one at that - so nothing revolutionary and it will not be replacing my Evil Dead collection somewhere near the top of my DVD pile.

Cloverfield blatantly lauds style over substance and it is pretty much exactly what would happen if anybody picked up a camera and started recording during a giant monster invasion. It makes for an entertaining cinematic roller coaster but nothing truly great.

Has Abrams and Reeves created America's own Godzilla? No, probably not. Gozilla is timeless and fairly simple in design, the Cloverfield monster is too complex and awkward, original nonetheless but I'd pick Godzilla in a fight.

title: Your an idiot if you like this garbage.
review: This movie gave me the biggest headache ever. I felt like throwing up. I didn't know if it was because of the motion sickness, or just the movie itself. What was the deal with this film? Why was it made? The creators should burn in hell. I just wasted 2 hours of my life watching this. OK i think i spent enough lines bashing this film, i have no choice IMDb wont let me post it if the comment is too short. Alright never mind im not done yet. To all the idiots who actually like these retarded fairy tales, get a !@$#$ life. If i could only puke one time in my entire life, id like it to be on everybody who gave this movie a good rating. Your all stupid.

title: I have to say, I am extremely impressed
review:
I didn't want to see Cloverfield when I saw the trailer, it looked like another Blair Witch Project, it was going to get all our hopes up and then when it played, it would disappoint. But when my friend saw the film, she said that it was interesting and worth a look. So I went ahead and saw the film today and I was very impressed with the story. Even though the camera work made me a little nauseous, from where the story was told from made it all more real. It was interesting to see the film from the character's point of view and not only that, it looked so real and really scared the heck out of me. I was thinking how weird it was though that someone would record the whole thing, but in today's world, unfortunately, we have those people who think they are automatically professional documentations. This film was a mix of the 1950's sci-fi and Blair Witch that was actually scary.

A group of friends are having a celebration for a their friend, Rob, who is going away to Japan. In the middle of the party, Rob and a girl friend of his, Beth have a fight and she leaves. While a friend, Hud, is filming the party, a huge crash happens in the middle of Manhattan, they go outside and see the Statue of Liberty's head in the middle of the street and see something like Godzilla destroying the city. As the group makes a run for it, Rob hears a voice mail on his cell from Beth that she's trapped, he, his brother's girlfriend, Lily, Hud with the camera, and Marlena go to get her, but end up getting attacked by little creatures. But when three survive, they continue on to save Beth, but time is running out before Manhattan is truly gone.

Cloverfield is a good film because it's different than any other horror film we have seen for a while. Believe me, it's a thousand times better than the Blair Witch Project, this has truly scary and intense moments that will leave you breathless and make you feel like you're right there with the group just wishing to get out of there. Strangely, there is a love story in here that was actually touching, Rob is so determined to get to Beth and he risks his life big time, even though there's a possibility she's already dead, so it added some terrific emotion to the story. Cloverfield is a great horror film, I was very impressed and I highly recommend it.

8/10

title: Horrible Pretentious Movie
review: I wanted to like the movie, the people who edited the trailers should be given an award for making this film look actually interesting. The movie technically begins, but doesn't take of after close to 20 minutes of hipster types talking useless banter, trying to create some sort of depth to a shallow script. Many people have complained about the camera movements, I however found this to be a perk, added some interest to a bland film. Cloverfield tried desperately to paint three love stories in the backdrop of the monster chaos in NYC, this however it did abysmally. The film would have been better served had they focused more on action, and less on character development, when the films running time is short enough as it is, and having used almost 2/3 of the running time trying to set up the opening "party scene they did not use their screen time wisely. The cast as an ensemble left much to be desired, especially the leads. It seemed as if JJ Abrams plucked a few hopefulls from a college acting course and threw them in front of a green screen. All in all, if you do watch the movie, be prepared to wait and wait for the movie to take of, and then be prepared for an ending thats nothing short of ludicrous. Save your time, effort, and money and instead treat yourself to a movie actually worth watching.

title: Best Monster Movie Ever
review:
When I saw the preview for Cloverfield, I was very excited. The hype was contagious. I had huge expectations for this movie and that made me wary because like most movies that have the kind of hype Cloverfield does, expectations turn into disappointments. It happens a little too often.

But within the first 2 minutes of the movie I knew my expectations were about to be lived up to, in fact they blown away.

This is by far the most entertaining monster movie ever made. I've never enjoyed one so thoroughly. The first person camera is extremely effective and it truly made me feel like I was one of the characters. I appreciated that they used more unknown actors. The characters were equal, thanks to no major actor stealing the show.The monster itself is effectively menacing and the small monsters that drop off of the large monster are used so well to deliver the scariest parts, yet are not over used. The camera work may make weak stomached folks queasy, but it truly adds to the chaos and fear that any person in that situation would experience.

I think a majority of the movie was unscripted, which if true gives the air of panic and true fear with genuine feel. I loved the fact that it didn't go down the Stephen Spielberg route, needing 20 mins of needless dialog to spoon feed the story to the movie going masses. It makes you wonder before, during and after just where this monster came from, and why its so indestructible.I cannot stress enough that people should and need to see this movie. It is movie going at its finest, its passionate, intense and terrifying.

Cloverfield is one of those defining movies that will hopefully reanimate a genre that has long been played out, predictable and boring. The movie is at its best on the big screen, it might not have the same effect on DVD.

A cinematic experience not to be missed and finally a monster movie worth the movie ticket.

title: Go ahead and see it, you will be entertained.
review: As with most monster movies, the monster in this movie is awesome enough to outshine bad writing, bad camera work, and a bad plot. The monster, in fact, is so awesome that I would recommend seeing this movie just for the grainy, fleeting glimpses you get of it. It's been said that the monster is based on H.P. Lovecraft's Mythos, and I can definitely see the connection there, although there's no direct connection to any of Lovecraft's monsters specifically. Several scenes are directly ripped off from Blair Witch, and if you had any problems with that movie (like I did) you will have the same problems with this movie. Given the unrealistic reactions of the main characters and the totally unbelievable elements of this movie, there are still enough explosions and destruction to keep things moving. It would be nice to have more story revolving the monster, but I'm sure that's coming in the sequel.

title: Great Movie
review:
I just saw this movie an hour ago in Australia.

The movie itself is very original with a great story to it made better with it being shot through hand held camera.

The monster itself you actually only see twice in it's whole but even then it is quite hard to take in all the details of it, while the rest of the movie you see bits and pieces of it. It isn't explained were it came from or why. It also seems to reproduce what seems like some spider monkeys with several legs and the head of a piranha while displaying different characteristics to the actual big creature it self.

The main characters were very good and it was made a lot better by not being big name holly wood stars. Also at the end of the movie you aren't really told if one of the main characters actually escaped in the helicopter. It does take a while to get into the movie before it does come extremely intense and you really want to know what happens next or if it has ended, as there were several times in the movie when you think it is over but it isn't.

Overall J.J. Abrams has done a great job with this however seeing how he doesn't explain everything that is a let down but that is what he usually does but that doesn't stop me from seeing it again tomorrow.

title: worse movie
review: This is the worse movie I've seen in years. Aside from the dizziness and headache it caused me,the story is soooooooo unrealistic. How could somebody be so stupid to carry a camera in a situation where your life is at stake and still have time to have its lens focused on their face. They're not some war journalist for crying out loud. Everybody were moving out of the city and here is this guy going the opposite direction along with his friends who were also not using brains..The monster should have eaten them in the first few minutes of the movie so that we could go on with the story.He and his friends almost got eaten and yet still went out to look for his girlfriend. I should have stayed at home and not spent my money on this piece of crap. Watching cartoons would have been much fun than this. No wonder the theater was not packed with viewers. Spread the word---This is one lousy movie

title: Bring aspirin and plenty of it.
review: My recommendation, save your money and wait till it's released on video, but if you do go, bring aspirin and plenty of it. While I'm sitting there trying to watch the film and feeling my head spin, I happen to notice that some of the people were getting up and walking out on the movie and they never came back. I stayed till the end, hoping it was going to get better, I was sadly wrong. I was not alone in my feelings either all of the remaining people were booing the screen as the credits rolled on. I even heard a couple of people saying that they wanted their money back. Alright, alright I'm not saying that the movie was all bad, I think that the idea behind it was a very good, interesting idea, the movie I feel just needed a little more control and lots more on character depth and feel. The monster, I feel like it was really nothing new or special about it. They probably would have done better if they had just stuck Godzilla or the Staypufft Marshmellow Man in there as the big bad creature instead.

title: Cloverfield: The Explanation
review: I already wrote a review the night I saw this movie, but I need to change what I wrote because I just went through and read a whole bunch of reviews that were complete sh*t. Let me start by saying I have never seen such a huge bunch of weak stomachs in my life. Some of you said a lot of people ran out of the theater sick. Where do you live? Lameville? I sat through this entire movie, as did the rest of the people in the theater I was in, and not a single person left feeling sick at all. If you are running away from a giant monster you are not going to have a steady-cam, so what did you expect? Next, this movie didn't have all the answers because it was shown just as it was supposedly "recovered" from the scene of the attack. People experiencing the attack are going to be less bothered about finding answers than they are about getting the hell away from the giant, 300-foot tall monster attacking them. If you want an answer to where it came from, watch the very last scene closely and look behind the characters at the background of the frame, that gives you mondo clue to where the thing came from, so don't say they didn't give you anything. As for no character development? I don't know what movie you were watching, but Cloverfield has ten times more character development than 80% of the movies Hollywood turns out nowadays. What do you think the entire beginning 15 minutes was all about? Oh, and the "Why are those 15 minutes even there?" this is supposed to be a real videotape meaning that the characters in the movie didn't go out expecting to videotape a monster attack, they were expecting to videotape a going-away party. Someone else said there was no plot. I'm going to try not to spoil anything, but the plot was that there's a giant monster attacking Manhattan island and 5 people are trying to survive the attack while documenting it. Also, they discover that someone the main character cares about is in trouble, so they go to help her! How is that not a plot? Write a comment when you actually know what you're talking about.

title: Why all the grumbling?
review:
I know a lot of people have been whining about certain aspects of this movie ie; the shaky-cam, the ending, the beginning... I see all of those complaints as being reasonable but why it is being touted as "garbage" by people is beyond me. I don't recall the trailers telling people It will move you....A Masterpiece.....Oscar Contender. No this was a balls to the walls MONSTER MOVIE, the only way I can explain it is as a theme park ride. If Universal Studios had this thing I would be there right now. Who cares about the creatures origins? This wasn't about introducing us to the next Godzilla, it was about throwing us into a crazy situation and letting us feel the hysteria felt by the characters. I personally wish more Hollywood blockbusters were like this, I mean the plots to those are usually just thrown together to pad the running time anyways, at least this movie gave you something you haven't seen before. Besides a few thousand unlucky souls in NY none of us have experienced this amount of pandemonium in our lives. Maybe not everyones cup of tea, but it was a rush to sit through.

Personally my only complaint is the beginning, I know they wanted to set up and easy to relate to situation for us. But these characters were not real and the things they said and did were not real. The "Guy Talk" about Beth was ridiculous, I don't ever recall my friends actually talking to me like I was in a Real World episode. So its funny that the only thing resembling a story is what bugged a good chunk of us. This is because we wanted a thrill ride, and we got one, it just took about 15 minutes longer to get there than we wanted. But when it did it kicked my a**. Also there were a number of people talking behind me about the shaky-cam "do you want to leave? I told you it was like this, so stupid" They stuck it out for about 15 minutes and then the first attack came and their a**es never left their seats. Neither will yours, unless you have some nervous tick that makes you hate movies well things aren't spelled out to you. I mean honestly, would it make the movie better if they were like: OMG thats a Gidransaurus!!! It was thought to be extinct in the Jurassic Period only to resurface because of chemical waste from earth pollution! I think that may ruin it.

Anyone who got past the lack of back story in Children of Men and saw what a great movie that was(though Children of Men is in a totally different league), will see what I saw in Cloverfield. Thrill ride from Hell....New York.

title: The Most Brilliant Adrenaline Ride In Movie History (Minimal Spoilers)
review: This movie was crafted from the victims point of view and shot home video style to portray REALITY.JJ is a genius.He has completely succeeded in making the audience experience the TERROR FIRST HAND.It started out slow and natural and took a sudden devastating turn that should catch the unsuspecting audience totally off guard. The movie may be a little 'nauseating' for some because of the home video style shooting but by the time the suspense sets in the giddyness would be totally forgotten!Im quite disappointed to see that there are some ppl who gave the movie a one-star out of 10. You people don't know how to appreciate a move from the "raw" point of view "- this move was created specially to take the audience through a very very realistic ride, so why are you people judging the story line and other 'Petty little elements' like that-ppl should not be so critical and learn to watch a movie with an open mind. ANYHOW for those interested PLEASE DO NOT MISS THIS MOVIE...A MUST WATCH A Sin if you don't catch this.

title: Very frightening movie
review:
I agree with your comments. I thought the POV camera really intensified everything that was going on, even if I thought the actors were a little lame. But after a while I noticed that I didn't think of them as actors any more- I thought of them as real people.

THIS is how Blair Witch failed- while I enjoyed the concept of Blair Witch, I always felt that it failed to achieve its goal of really frightening people. Instead, it was a very long and poorly shot film that circumvented the scary stuff for as long as possible, finally starting to get into some weird things by the time the movie was over. Cloverfield trims the "fat" off a sturdy plot line, goes for the jugular, and really puts you in the characters' high-heeled shoes.

This movie will stick with you for a while. I do recommend it.

title: A Simple Yet Entertaining Monster Movie
review:
So i went to see "Cloverfield" yesterday and i know a lot of you are dying to see it. So i decided to write a review about it.

The story of "Cloverfield" is simple. A bunch of people are hanging out and minding their own business when the city is attacked by a huge creature and they have to try to make it out of the situation alive. Its your basic monster movie plot and there's nothing really special or different about the plot to make it anything more than your basic monster movie plot. The characters are all fairly shallow. The only ones who have any real sort of depth are the Rob and Beth characters but they aren't much deeper than the rest of the cast. Any actor aiming for an Oscar are likely not going to get a nomination for these roles. Not because they're bad actors but because there's not much to work with when it comes to these characters.

Speaking of the acting, everyone did what they could with these characters. There aren't any breakthrough performances here but at the same time there aren't any terrible performances either. It's all pretty average. In fact, most of the acting consisted of running and screaming and the occasional fall now and then. But the parts when they weren't running and screaming were pretty convincing so props to the cast there.

The special effects were undeniably good with this film. The visuals of the tore up and broken New York city were pretty beautiful as ironic as the sounds. The most impressive visuals, in my opinion, were the statue of liberty's head when it came crashing down into the streets. Watching that scene in the commercials is great and all but you really have to see that on the big screen to get the full effect of it. To put it simply, this movie had some really great special effects. Not as great as the special effects of "Transformers" but then again i doubt that anything in the next few years will be able to top that movie in the special effects department.

Anyway. The one big complaint that i have against this movie is the way it was made. Don't get me wrong. The concept of the film and how it is shown through a hand held camera was a brilliant idea but that was the very reason the made this movie extremely hard for me to watch. The camera was really shaky, especially during the scenes where the camera man was running. Halfway through the movie I had to tilt my head back and take deep breaths and i had to continue this every few minutes so i was watching a lot of the second half of the movie through the corner of my eye. I usually don't get motion sickness but this movie really had my stomach turning.

The bottom line is that if you can get past the shaky camera you'll have yourself a simple yet entertaining monster movie. But if you're looking for something that will make you "feel" things this is not the movie for you. As long as you don't look too far into "Cloverfield" and just take it for what it is i'm pretty sure you'll enjoy it. And you might want to bring a barf bag just in case.

My Overall Rating: 7 out of 10

title: For all who say it sucks, you missed the point
review:
First of all, commend the actors for such long cut scenes, imagine how difficult a movie must be when after 5 minutes of shooting ( with a camera intended to move all over the place)on one scene someone skrews up a line and you have to start over. Second, of course the camera is everywhere, your supposed to get the feel your in the chaotic setting.

There's no explanations, because the main characters don't know. thats the point, your not supposed to know whats going on, you cant pretend like you weren't into this movie, the movie is great and it delivers an experience and not the same tired cliques. ( except of course giant monster attacking new york city)

Its the answerless, suspenseful, scary chaos that one would expect if this were an actual situation. Spoiler - Take for example when they rush the girl who gets bitten into quarantine. Instead of doing a resident evil style explanation as to what happens when your bitten, they just keep the movie going because guess what? The characters the movie is focused on don't know. Hud's camera is all over the place because hes being pushed around while hes trying to find out whats going on. Get it? Your there! your trying to figure out what the hell is going on just like the character!

title: Cloverfield: Must See
review:
I saw a midnight screening of Cloverfield last night and I must say....I was highly impressed....I first found out about the movie early last year when Spider Man hit the theaters with Cloverfield as a preview....I was intrigued since that time. I was worried that after so much hype and anticipation I would be let down by the actual film itself, but to my surprise, I enjoyed it very much.

It's basically a fictional documentary about a group of young people in New York City when a mysterious creature (monster) surfaces and begins destroying Manhattan. This is what you see in the previews, but underlying the surface, the film has some comedy, intense action, suspense, a love story and more. Basically, it actually had a plot. The movie is more about the characters and their story, than the monster itself. You won't be disappointed though because you WILL see the monster and it's not just a brief glimpse...or teaser as I call them.

The only draw back to the movie is the cinematography. The film is recorded in a first hand person point of view. In close comparison to the way "The Blair witch Project" was filmed. You're seeing what is going on as if you were behind the camera. Although it can get a little bumpy at times...you never really think about it because you are so entranced with the film and the character themselves. Don't let this deter you. The film had an unpredictable ending that left me wanting a little more but closed the movie enough to satisfy my curiosity. With a good story line and everything that I have mentioned above I would Highly Recommend this flick as a must see. Make sure to let me know what you think when you do!! :D aniel

title: Words can't express how awesome it was, but I'll try anyways
review:
If you aren't already a little curious about this movie, you've been living under a rock since Transformers came out. We've all seen the trailers, we all know the tag lines, hell we even knew the damn release date before we knew the name of the movie.

Like most, the idea of seeing the Statue of Liberty decapitated in a trailer very much made me want to know what the hell 1-18-08 was. Then the title came out, followed by one of the most ingenious viral marketing campaigns ever. Bottom line, whether or not you wanted to see it, you knew what Cloverfield was.

The trailers hit. At my particular showing, you got a trailer for Step Up 2, some MMA movie that looked God awful, and a teaser for the new Star Trek film (also being produced by J.J. Abrams). Bad start I must admit, as I don't like Star Trek and all of the rest of the films were things I'd never see, even for free.

Then the film started. The whole opening and character development was to be honest rather weak. You're given sorted little details about people and then they flip the script so you feel bad for the main character Rob (played AWESOMELY by Michael Stahl-David) cause this chick he is in love with is totally with another guy and blah blah blah. Like I said, a little boring. 20 minutes in though, the actual attack begins. From then on this movie is edge of your seat.

I won't give away much of the plot (everyone should already know what it's about), only critique it. The character development was pretty bad at first, but while you watch these kids through the eyes of a video camera (the whole film is shot via hand held camera a la The Blair Witch Project)you actually really get into it. The plot itself is pretty basic and doesn't require you to really engage the script to understand what is going on. Go into this flick prepared to focus on visuals.

Visually, even with the flaws that come with a hand held camera (meaning if you get motion sickness this might really suck for you) the visuals were unbelievable (in a good way). In the trailer, when you see the head of the Statue of Liberty get hurled across the screen, you really don't think much of it; in the film however, this scene will give you chills. It's important to note that while the monster has very little on screen time, the path of destruction it leaves is enough to scare the hell out of you. The images in this film FEEL one-hundred percent legit, and that's what made this movie really enjoyable and genuinely terrifying. Director Matt Reeves did an amazing job capturing a city that is in utter chaos. The special effects in this movie are mainly limited to explosions and such and looked dramatically realistic as well, big plus for a film nowadays where it has become the norm to have the CGI not look all that great. The team really nailed every aspect of the visual, I can't stress that enough.

As far as the sound department goes, they must have had a hard time doing this film. Where many movies rely on a score or soundtrack to build tension, this film had to rely simply on the sounds made by the actual monster, explosions, and people, and they did a fantastic job. One of the this most horror films lack nowadays are awesomely put together sound fx, which make the movies fall flat. When you hear the roar of the monster, you're freaking out, so you know they did their job damn well.

The acting for the most part was nothing to write home about. In fact, you don't really pay much attention to whether the acting is good or bad simply because you are so caught up in the visual. As mentioned before, the main character you will focus on is Rob, and to his credit Michael Stahl-David did a great job portraying emotion on screen (which is to be expected as he has done theatre in the past).

To write a review of this film won't do it any justice, it's just something you have to see for yourself as the devastation can not be put into words. The carnage you witness on the screen will no doubt make up for the lack of screen time the monster actually has, but when you finally do see the monster in all of its glory (yes, it is glorious) it makes everything well worth it. The only thing I really have left to say is kudos to the crew who worked on this film because you did something that is damn near impossible to do when making a movie about a giant monster attacking a city: you made a film that didn't really at all remind me of Godzilla.

Overall I'd give this film a full 10 stars because it's going to leave you focused entirely on the action and when it's all over, you're going to want to talk about it.

title: Amazing
review:
Cloverfield was always in danger of dying by not being able to live up to it's own hype, but coming from someone who wasn't closely following the viral marketing and waiting with bated breath for any new piece of news on the film, the final product is one of the most impressively engaging films I've seen in a long while.

It's pretty much 4 people going through a torn to pieces New York city whilst a huge creature who's origins are unknown rampages through it. The action is 'documented' through a domestic handy cam, and the rest takes care of itself.

A lot of people are complaining that the story is weak, or there are things not explained, the ending is too abrupt and so on. What these people fail to realise is that this is no conventional film. First of all, you can't really devise a clever, compelling story from the a film that is intended to be viewed as a real life, homemade, handy cam job. (In the context of the story) There is no experienced Director calling the shots, the man behind the camera is not a professional cinematographer, it's a regular person doing their best to capture the madness that has gripped the city. It's from the first person perspective of people caught in this chaos. So if you expect high quality visual storytelling on a level such as the Coen brothers, you really are being naive.

I personally feel that if the origins of the monster and the whole "what happens next" song and dance would have let this film down. The sudden ending keeps with the nature of a real life essence of the thing. You only see and hear what you need to and you can draw whatever conclusions you want after it's over. The final 15-20 minutes you know that an event will occur that will likely end the picture, and when it arrives, that's it. I didn't think the ending was abrupt or annoying at all. An annoyingly abrupt ending would be something like the batteries on the camera running out in the middle a big action sequence. There's none of that here.

If you don't go into this film expecting a simple, fast & loud wild ride then you will be disappointed. But if you do take it for what it is, it'll be one of the cinematic highlights of the year.

title: Better Than I Expected
review: I have to admit that I was pretty hyped going into the movie on Wednesday. I think the cinematography was brilliant. Who wants another monster movie where everything is explained to you while leaving no room for your own interpretation. No one wants another Godzilla. The way this movie was done lets you know a very limited amount of information about the scenario. They don't give the monster a name or explain where it comes from. The only information you know by the end of the movie is what the main characters know. This allows you to feel like you are running around Manhattan with them. Despite the fact that the movie is supposed to be in the view of a person's camcorder the quality is still excellent. The movie is amazing and is definitely not one of the worst movies that will come out this year. A lot of thought was put into the making of this movie and the finished product definitely reflects that. As for the male characters seeming like the same person, you have to keep in mind that there are only three male characters with much time, and majority of the time there are only two. One guy is behind the camera, and only other guy for majority of the movie is the main character. How this is confusing I don't know... The movie is not perfect, but it deserves a 9 or 10 out of 10. Go see it and judge for yourself.

title: Chillingly unique...
review:
At the beginning of 'Cloverfield' you get the feeling that the documentary-like way the film is shot etc will be annoying and get rather tiresome by the end of it's running time. Funnily enough, you ease into it and it soon fades out of your attention. The beginning of the film gives you a look into the characters and does so in quite a different way due to the home video feel. Surprisingly, you slide nicely into the false sense of security the beginning presents. But this eventually dissipates into one of the most frightening, exceptionally well done and thought provoking sci-fi thrillers that we'll probably see this year, or for many years to come.

Though it is not for the jumpy ladies, it definitely is for the lads who take jumpy ladies to films to frighten them into a cuddle. Your pretty much cuddle-guaranteed with 'Cloverfield'. Amazing CG, superb acting, unique feel (doing what Blair Witch failed to do) and you really leave wondering with a slight chill down your spine.

See it.

title: What a thrill ride!
review:
I saw this movie in the premiere last night here in Sydney and oh my god! The first 15min. I had to get used to the camera-work, but after that all hell broke loose. The sound was magnificent and the suspense brilliant. People are complaining about the camera work, but it gave exactly the feeling which I always wanted to have in a movie. The feeling that you are actually experiencing what they have been through.

You don't see to to much of the monster and it did not bother me one bit. Do not watch this movie for the story but for the whole experience.

This movie is definitely a cinema roller-coaster!

title: Cloverfield isn't for everyone, but it's definitely for me.
review: I saw an advanced screening of Cloverfield on the 16th and came away from the movie both entertained and impressed. The movie, as I'm sure you all know, is shot entirely from a hand-held camera pov. Doing this took a lot of guts and I think that ultimately it pays off much more than just an easy on the eyes cookie cutter monster movie. Yes, there ARE sequences where you literally cannot see anything that is happening (specifically when the camera operator is running), but little glimpses of action and excellent use of off camera sound make for an even more effective film in my opinion. If The Bourne Ultimatum made you queasy with its shaky cam, then Cloverfield will send you into convulsions. However, I loved the film, and the realism stuck with me(On my drive home I half expected a monster to leap up and kick down the Sears Tower). Also, this movie has a great sense of humor from the character Hud, who spends most of his time off screen being the camera operator, but often finds opportunities for colorful one liners to lighten the mood. All in all, Cloverfield isn't a perfect movie, but it's definitely entertaining and the best attempt I've ever seen at this kind of film making (Blair Witch sucked!!!).

title: good film
review:
i went to see this film at 4.30pm yesturday with 3 friend, myself and a friend who are both amateur filmmakers with a love for film liked it, to have everything explained and wrapped up in a nice little bundle would've completely ruined the film and I quite like how all the characters die.

My other two friend who are casual film-goers disliked the film, demanding the conventional Hollywood corny ending, where all those still alive find out exactly what happened and the guy gets the girl, they get married and everyones happy.

to do this IMO would ruin the film, it was good because it left you thinking and speculating afterwards.

title: Probably the best movie of 2008 so far (which isn't saying much)
review: I must say that I thoroughly enjoyed this film. The critics are right. it's not for old people. It's for people who can follow a fast-paced story (which is not that complicated), frequent jump cuts and a pretty shaky camera. The beauty in the film is that it's so convincing. From the moment I started watching I was convinced that these were real people. Why? The dialogue is snappy and what you'd expect from people their age. The characters are also persuasively youthful. I would disagree that the pacing and detachment of the film are a hindrance. The quickness with which critical events occur is literally breathtaking. As with what could be believed to be reality, the film doesn't magically slow down to illustrate death. There are no pauses. Things just happen. It's great.

title: Cloverfield: what good movies should do
review:
No spoilers here, just a warning. Cloverfield isn't great in a 'godfather'/'lord of the rings' totally awesome story telling kind-of way. BUT, the idea of movies is to immerse you in another world for a few hours and make you feel something different and forget about your problems. There is no better movie at this than 'Cloverfield.' The first person perspective that Hud's camera gives you leads to a totally intense and personal experience. Rarely does it feel forced and it never fails to offer the requisite monster movie thrills and still have time to allow you to feel empathy for character's in key moments.

I can't remember the last time i forgot i was just watching a movie.

Video gamers will already know the feeling from 'Half Life''Halo' and 'Doom 3' and i couldn't help but think if they used a similar first person perspective on the Doom movie, you would have had a far scarier and involving cinematic experience.

Best of all (and unlike 'Lost' or 'Blair Witch') it is never boring and doesn't wear out its welcome. Just remember to keep breathing.

title: Cloverfield review
review: The entire show was literally hand-held footage. It was very shaky throughout the show. Due to the fact that it's a hand-held footage, the perspective of the whole show was very limited. It's basically from a first person point of view. It's like comparing between watching a football match in a bird eyes' view and a close up replay on a few players, except that it's really shaky and can be pointless sometimes. If you do not like the close up and limited view then this is not a show for you. However, there's suspense throughout the show, and quite some bits of thrills and excitements.Ending was too abrupt though and lots of parts left unexplained. Not a bad movie overall.

title: Cloverfield Don't see
review:
I just saw the movie last night when one of my friends won tickets to see the movie at an early release party. The movie is less than an hour and a half but I was waiting for it to be over by the end of the movie. I enjoyed the way the movie was shot from a perspective of a dude holding a camcorder it made the movie seem to be more realistic and gave the impression that the viewer was seeing the movie first hand.

While I wouldn't not recommend to see this movie in theaters due to the outrageous ticket prices I would wait to see this movie on DVD. The camera style resembled a Blair Witch style which other horror movies should follow because it made the viewer connect with the characters. This style also forces the viewer to only know the same things the characters of the movie know.

In my opinion I would wait to see this movie on DVD but if you want to watch a movie that is shot interestingly and done in an interesting way this movie could be great for you. This could be the type of movie that could spawn a completely different breed of horror movies and this would not be a bad thing by any means.

title: Giant Monster, explosions and a hand held camera = Entertaining stuff!
review:
After the first 5 minutes of motion sickness and flashbacks of the Blair Witch Project I was engrossed with the film. The story follows a small group of people and this change of style is something that has been lacking in movies for a long time. We never see the Army, the President or some reporter. Just a clueless group of young people who have no idea what is happening.

Apart from the jittery camera Cloverfield is fantastically filmed with stunning explosions, lots of screaming and dust flying everywhere. The typical American "is it Terrorists?" line got a laugh in the cinema and the subway and helicopter scenes were fantastic.

I was a little disappointed with the short running time and the ending is very typical from the creator of Lost. Left me wanting more.

title: On your marks, get set, watch something else.
review: A completely idiotic story presented in an utterly unwatchable way.

title: 85 minutes of...
review:
T.J. Miller whispering, saying, yelling 'Rob.'

After a while, I couldn't even hear the rest of the cast talking, just him saying Rob.

title: Decent Sci-Fi/Disaster Film w Great Casting. A Little Slow, But Worth Watching.
Could've been better with conventional camera technique.
review: Just saw this now with my wife at home on a 50 inch tv. Wife got sick and dizzy after about 10 minutes and I stopped the movie. Watched something else and finished the movie by myself sometime later. I understand what they were trying to do here but really? This could've been a great horror/action flick but the handheld camera action made it almost unwatchable. If this happened for real and your life was in danger, would you film it constantly? Nope you'd fight for your life. There's a movie in there, somewhere but they forgot to properly put it on film. Two stars for the effort and blowing 40 million on a shaky mess.

title: A Very Innovative Monster Movie
review:
Cloverfield is a mixed bag. I enjoyed the film, but there are problems that I had and that others might have with the film. Cloverield is another attempt by America to do our own original monster movie. This time they used the found footage format to make it their own. Compared to other American monster movies or monster movies in general, I'd say that this is my second favorite. Though, as I said the film has problems.

With Kong Skull Island being first, I'd say this is my second favorite American giant monster movie. I like this more than most Godzilla movies, and I like Godzilla. I even like it more than Pacific Rim. What makes it good for me is the different approach they took. Instead of focusing on the monster attacking and the military fighting it they focus only on a select group of average people trying to survive, get out of the city, and find out what's going on.

They focus all of it on the civilian point of view of what they're going through and they show the immense destruction and casualties from that angle, which you rarely see in other movies like this. It's supposed to be more real in this is what it would really be like if a giant monster did attack a huge city. Plus it took place entirely at night which evoked a greater sense of despair and atmosphere in the film which added to the realistic angle they were going for.

They also kept the monster mostly in the background or in quick clips until the end which evoked a sense of mystery of what it was or where it came from. The latest Godzilla movie tried something similar but it didn't work. It worked in this film and not that Godzilla movie in 2014 because we already knew what Godzilla was, so keeping him in the shadows the entire movie is pointless, other than to save on the budget. Here it works better because we know nothing of the monster so there's more mystery behind it. Also the character in Cloverfield, while not that great either, were still more interesting than the ones in Godzilla 2014.

One complaint I have is the found footage format. I like that they tried a different approach to making a monster movie, but it did not always work for me. The point was to get a sense of realism and put the viewer right in the action like you're actually with these characters during this major attack. It was trying to be a more real experience.

However, the camera was too shaky and it often did not focus on a shot long enough for the viewer to completely take in what was happening. Though I could buy it in the beginning, as the film went on, I found it hard to believe that they would not drop the camera. It would've been better if it had just been a regular movie revolving around these people trying to survive a monster attack.

Another problem is the characters. I did not find them annoying, but I thought they were bland. I did not find one of them especially interesting. They weren't terrible characters. I got with them enough to be invested in the story and what happens to them, but there's nothing much to them either.

The effects were good. I thought that the design of the monster was cool and looked very original. There was a ton of hype surrounding this film when the teaser first came out. People were wondering what this thing was that was destroying New York City. Some were probably let down by the fact that it was a monster. I did not get into the immense hype this film generated so I was okay with it. This film also had a great atmosphere to it as well.

Overall, I did enjoy this film. However, it is not for everyone. If you can't stand the found footage style or you're not a fan of giant monster flicks, for both, than this isn't for you. If you got into the hype like so many did and wanted something more than just a monster than you'll be disappointed. However, if you just want a fun and slightly more realistic take on a monster movie then check this out. I admit I didn't like this film when I first saw it but it grew on me. Now I actually think it's fairly good despite its faults.

title: Super intense creature feature
review:
A group of young folks find themselves in considerable jeopardy after a vicious giant monster suddenly attacks New York City.

Director Matt Reeves, working from a tight script by Drew Goddard, takes time to develop the characters, grounds the fantastic premise in a believable everyday reality, and generates plenty of nerve-wracking tension. The total absence of a music score and the expert use of a shaky hand-held portable camera give this picture a bracing, riveting, and above all extremely harrowing sense of immediacy and intimacy that basically puts the viewer in the thick of the terrifying action just like the hapless people in the movie; the acute feeling of blind panic and complete chaos is frighteningly well captured. Lizzy Caplan, Jessica Lucas, T.J. Miller, Michael Stahl-David, Mike Vogel, and Odette Annable are all credible as the imperiled protagonists. The scenes of destruction -- the Statue of Liberty's decapitated head rolls down a street, the Brooklyn Bridge gets demolished -- are quite potent and startling. The grim ending also packs a shocking punch. The special effects are convincingly done. An on the money nail biter.

title: Movie was the worst
review: Waste of time movie. Terrible acting , poor camera work, Hard to follow never knew where it heading.

title: Shaking and jerking video, terrible made movie!
review: Shaking and jerking videos, it's a very terrible made movie, it does nothing except cause you to have a headache. I would never watch it again.

title: Watch Godzilla (1998) instead
review: A huge monster terrorizes NYC. The End. Except we're given no backstory as to how the monster came to be like in Godzilla. A monster suddenly appears and the military tries to kill it. As an extra special bonus, the first 15 or 20 minutes of the movie is nothing but 21 year old drama that doesn't further the plot whatsoever. All you need to know is guy #1 is with girl #1 and guy #2 is with girl #2. It doesn't matter that somebody is moving to Japan or somebody likes a different girl. Nothing matters. Think of any horror movie with an "attacker". We know the origin of Freddy, Jason, Michael Meyers, even the piranhas, (as stupid as that movie was). Something doesn't just show up and start killing people randomly (except Jaws, which shouldn't even be mentioned along with this movie). Just because it's shot on a hand held cam doesn't give it any credibility. It's been done before and it doesn't automatically make something creative or revolutionary. I can't say enough bad things about this "movie". It's like a 5 year old wrote a story. Seriously, Anaconda is better!

title: Bad movie. Made for low brainers !
review:
To me its a confirmed fact that if a movie is made with camera held by a movie cast, then the movie has to be a dump one. And this movie is that another example.

I came to see this movie after watchin The Cloverfield Paradox 2018. I thought this would be the prequel, and would be equally interesting.

That's it !

title: What the ****?
review:
I hate the fact they used a bad digital camera. I can't see anything. Not realistic at all. I hard lots of "what the hell is happening!" "oh!" "aaaaaaaaaaa" and so on. No real acting. The storyline is wrong: oh, let's search for my ex-girlfriend while creatures are eating people.

If you want to waste 1h30m, watch this movie! I am very disappointed about this movie,

title: Wanted to shoot myself after watching this!
review: This is honestly one of the worst movie I have ever seen in my life. The movie absolutely have no story line and only features a bunch of stupid teenagers wondering around New York City. The cinematography is soooooo awful that it gave me a major headache after. Just don't even get me started on the acting because I will puke whenever I think about it. Whoever think that this movie is good should have their TV taken away from them till they learn what a good movie should be. I literally lost all my respect in J.J Abrams along with all the other people involved in making this film. This is a warning to avoid this movie at all cost and if you see a Cloverfield DVD you should burn it IMMEDIATELY!

title: Cloverfield
review: Cloverfield 6/10 The opening twenty minutes of the film might hold the dullest scenes in any movie I've seen. The party provides nothing to the movie, no good character development, interesting dialog or purpose. It's a terrible party I'd leave in real life. Getting past those initial scenes and into the bulk of the monster film is well worth the wait. The fact that the monster is never shown right away is a great tease, which builds up the wanting to see more throughout the film. The monster itself looks realistically clammy and the little monster fleas that come off of it are a great little twist into the equation. The destruction scenes by the movie are great and so are the military action effects. The story, dialog, and action scenes improve as the movie goes forth. Although the ending is typical of a giant monster film its filmed well and tops of the hopeless feeling perfectly.

title: Monster movie with all of the destruction and a fresh perspective
review:
I finally watched Cloverfield, which I've been interested in ever since the mysterious trailers came out and impressed my monster-movie-loving-middle-school self years ago...and I wasn't let down. This could have easily turned out to be a lame gimmick flick (and many people will see it as that) with all of the shaky cam and found footage aspects, but I never found those to be a hindrance to my enjoyment of the movie and I even thought that it enhanced the atmosphere and mood of the disaster. After seeing the newest Godzilla movie recently, Cloverfield came along and gave me everything that I thought was wrong about Godzilla 2014. It shows a human perspective and a city dealing with chaos that came out of nowhere. Shocking, chilling, impressive...all shown in a way that reflects a lot of the fears from 9/11 (a lot of the footage reminds me of some scenes from 102 Minutes That Changed America. Instead of focusing on the monster (which I thought could have looked cooler) it focuses on the human reactions in dealing with the problem. BUT, it does have its fair share of monster movie glory. The destruction looks great. Buildings collapsing, explosions, smaller faster monsters, a good amount of gore, screaming citizens, military action...it's all there, just with a unique twist in the form of hand-held camera-work. It's definitely not a great quality movie when considering all of the standards in assessing film, there are flaws. The actors aren't great, the writing is below average, the constant commentary gets a little old. But I'm willing to overlook all of these just because it's a monster movie that I think really captured the initial and following moments of terror in discovering a huge alien creature destroying all of Manhattan. There is also a romantic sideplot added in, which I wasn't too excited about, although I will admit it adds a whole element that adds a personal touch. Annnd although it could have been better, I have no complaints about the ending.

Rating: 9/10 Watch again?: With pleasure

title: What The........
review:
Has everyone gone on drugs? Found Footage sucks everything, and sucked a infinity more times after. None of these movies done this way are never good. I hated them since "The Blair Witch Project". TBWP is or was so over hyped and overrated, its pathetic.

Okay, what really ticked me off was the preview looked great. I did not see it in the theater, which is a plus. I and my mother waited to watch the DVD, which was bad idea. Started all shaky, and we were like "what the crap is this". We continued to watch and still shaky camera. It never stopped once. Holy Mary F***** God and Christ. Could not tell what was going on. Monsters you can't see. Someone talking you can't see.

Characters running from something you can't see. Can you say boring? Yes, I can. This reminded me how much The Blair Witch Project sucked. I am one of the people that thinks the sequel to The Blair Witch Project was better. At least normal camera is done right. This shaky camera crap can be done, just give the camera to an infant and strap them in front of an actor, and you got the same crap. It is stupid.

This is just as annoying as the TV broadcasters putting reality shows on TV. Man nothing is getting done right anymore. No original movies or TV shows anymore. If Cloverfield 2 ever come to a release, I would not go near any theater that has it. I will just wait until its out of the theater, then go see a movie that is heck of a lot better. Stupid Found Footage crap.

title: Don't be fooled by high rating
review:
This is NOT a good movie. It has a terrible plot, awful characters that you couldn't give a toss about, wooden acting of the "scream and run" variety, takes an interminable 30 mins to get going (said 30 mins taken up with incredibly boring scenes from a farewell party for upwardly mobile brats - out of frustration I fast forwarded to the good bits) and has an annoying shaky cam for the entire duration. The camera wielder makes things worse by being whiny and yelling inanely throughout the movie. It was an enormous relief when he finally snuffed it. Nothing in the movie made sense especially not the gang of idiots charging around a city in the middle of an intergalactic war and not taking the many opportunities to get out. And last but not least, the ending. Seriously bad & totally predictable. There were so many plot holes in this thing it resembled swiss cheese. I wont go into them all, I notice some other reviewers have covered some. Suffice to say, there are dozens more of them. Nothing is explained about the sudden arrival of the monster either. No build up to it or context at all. This leaves the whole movie without much of a foundation. There was nothing here that was original, fresh, unexpected or interesting apart from.... THE SPECIAL EFFECTS which were reasonably good. All of my points are for that and that alone. If only this had been more about the monster and less about the use of terrible gimmicky camera and sappy half-baked love plots.

Watch The Host instead, it has heart and soul as well as a brilliant story and awesome effects. Or even The Bay which, tho not as good as The Host, has a far superior plot, engaging characterisations and better acting than Cloverfield. The Bay is so tightly constructed you are pretty much convinced it actually happened. You'd be hard-pressed to find a plot hole & the back story is brilliantly conceived. But more importantly the directors etc had a MILLION TIMES better grasp on how to use the "found footage" concept to it's best advantage to draw the viewer into the "reality" instead of annoying the cr*p out of & alienating them.

title: A great marketing campaign for a great monster flick!
review: After browsing the net for the very best of viral marketing campaigns, I found myself hooked on the back story involving the fake oil company that awoke the monster in this movie, and I just had to view it again and I am so glad I did. If only I had been actively pursuing the campaign before the movie was released! And what a great looking monster, along with the parasites that apparently spawn off of it. The actors do a great job in this of showing how terrifying the entire experience is and the sheer state of shock really flows off of them well. A great monster movie and definitely something I can see myself watching again in the future!

title: Bad movie, bad editing/directing still virgin
review:
This movie was so bad, i think no one deservs to waste time watching horrible movie. It was so bad that i want to find the director and kick him in the nuts between he's legs and then tell him he suck in making movies. After that i would ask, DEMAND my money back to pay for my internet bill because i wasted internet downloading it, thats right i torrented the film so screw u and screw u family.

First of all this movie doesn't deserve the rate it has, and second of all this movie gave me and my family cancer, and I did get HIV and I'm still virgin wtf? This movie was so bad MADE that my friends died without even watching, the sound made them approx suicide.

title: It's not a field trip.
review:
We just discussed this movie on a RPG forum.

Hand-held camera movies are still alive with the Paranormal Activity movies.

Now, back in 2007 some unknown teasers had been spread out on the early days of Youtube.

Two people recorded in a bedroom, and also clips of New York City being attacked by something.

Then in Winter 2008 Cloverfield got released.

The movie got split reviews, but still a Box Office success.

In classic hand-held movie style we follow some people in New York City having a party for a guy that is going to Japan.

But the party is crashed by a giant monster.

The soldiers can't beat the monster.

In September 2001 style we follow people flee from that giant thing destroying the city.

The movie had deserved some Oscars.

If you are having a movie party one weekend go watch this.

10/10

title: Something Has Definitely Found Us..........
review: And once the movie gets rolling, we really wish it hadn't! "Cloverfield" is one of the rare cases in which the movie lives up to the hype. I remember when this was being advertised and how little the movie makers revealed in the trailers. However, for whatever reason, I didn't get to see this brilliant film until now(pretty sad, I know). But luckily I was able to fix all of that just now and can honestly say I'm a better movie lover because of it. Everything starts out innocent and normal enough with a group of friends throwing a surprise going away party for their other friend when IT arrives and as soon as it does, all hell breaks lose. Feel the tension as our heroes try to find a messing a friend while battling the ever growing chaos caused by the destruction of the visitor and the breakdown of all law and order. What is this visitor? Well, let's just say that it isn't looking to make friends, that's for sure! What makes the film stand out above everything else is the chilling realism that the filmmakers are able to incorporate into the movie, from the realistic shaking of the camera to the excellent performances of all the actors involved. The more down to the wire things get, the faster and faster our hearts beat. I wish I could say more but this is really one of those movies where the less you know going in, the better (and more bone chilling) it will be. Find it, watch it, and while you're at it, keep watching the skies!!!!

title: Great monster movie that focuses more on the characters than the monster
review:
Cloverfield exceeds as both a monster flick and a horror movie. It does so by being old-school in its approach and showing restraint. The film is all about the characters placed in this situation, not getting carried away with plot or set pieces or making the film about the monster itself. Atmosphere is more important to establishing the horror for the characters, with them not feeling safe at any time after the party.

A good horror film knows that less is more, and that is a philosophy that Cloverfield nails. You rarely see the monsters face (only three times) and only see it in its entirety once. Instead you get glimpses that allow you imagination to fill in the gaps.

The film's atmosphere is also to its credit, with the constant feeling of insecurity even though our characters don't face direct danger all that frequently, they never once feel safe. The anticipation of something horrific happening is much more powerful than the actual act itself, something that many modern horrors could do with taking into account.
