This has got to be one of the most annoying and disappointing films I have ever watched, particularly in view of the hype that surrounded its release. I had no empathy for any of the characters so I didn't care at all what happened to them. In fact, that's not completely true; there were many times when I wished the characters would just die, so annoying was their non-stop screaming and shouting out to each other. The acting was truly dire, the dialogue non-existent and there was precious little footage of the monster itself throughout the film. The character with the camera, supposedly recording events for posterity, evidently thought it more important to record the inanities of his friends rather than focus on the main event. And these were supposed to be terrified people running for their lives!

An absolute crock of a film - no one can afford to waste 90 minutes of their life watching this abject rubbish, unless perhaps they are in solitary confinement in a maximum security jail with no other option.

title: Now that I've seen it...
review:
Now that I've seen it, I am so happy I didn't go see it in the theaters.

In fact, if anyone paid more than a dollar for this it was too much, I would even feel a little cheated if I had to pay a rental fee, thank the stars a relative works at a video store so I didn't' waste my money at all.

This was done so badly that I may not see anything else from JJ, ever! Any first semester student could have done better on the graphics(CG)that they loosely call a creature here. I really didn't mind the low/no-budget, home-video filming style that was used, but even Blair Witch was done with more style and suspense...lol.

It frightens me to think of him doing a Star Trek film after such a bad outing but I guess I will have to wait for that to hit video now too. I was interested in going to see it but with how poorly this was done I certainly will not.

For all that liked this, everyone is entitled to an opinion and rightly so. I just think that this really belonged on the tail end of and After Dark (8 Films to Die For) release...if at all.

title: Excellent ??? I don't think so
review:
Sorry, if you think this film is excellent, then this is either the first film you've ever watched or you need to get a life - desperately.

Supposedly filmed on a home video camera you get an hour of not being able to see anything properly, including lots of running, walking, more running, shouting and running, lots of views of the pavement (sidewalk), oh, and running. The camera is swinging around wildly so you can't focus on anything, and when it is held steady half of what should be there is missing. In reality, is anyone that bad at operating a video-cam or was he completely oblivious to the concept of the view screen on the digicam ??? Don't tell me it was done deliberately to make the film raw and edgy, I understand that, but because it was so obviously done on purpose it became really annoying. Add to that the moron and his comments from behind the camera, discussing tramps being set on fire in the subway, it was all so formulaic I'm surprised the studio let them get away with it.

Add to that all the things they did that no-one would have done in a real situation and it all adds up to an hour of your life wasted if you watch this film.

title: Questionable story , Awful Photography!
review: Story ends unresolved... Where did it come from, was it defeated? The photography was atrocious, I know it's supposed to be from the point of view of one of the characters, but you can't see most of what's happening. The shaky camera with inadequate light doesn't contribute to the story or feel thereof, it just serves to annoy. Also, where there is color, there isn't much of it. It's a shame, because, if you could see most of the film, that might offset the unresolved storyline, which I could handle. Godzilla (1998), which was put out by Roland Emmerich and Dean Devlin got average reviews and was a similar story of a monster attacking New York City. It was well filmed and the scenes were exciting and easy to see. The color was great and the story showed the origin of the monster, and followed a smooth storyline to the resolution. The special effects were awesome. In my opinion, Cloverfield fell short in every area. The actors were wasted as they were portraying their characters well, but you couldn't see them most of the time. In many scenes , the camera was pointed at the floor and all you saw was the ground blurring by. It may be the intent of the movie, but what a difference it would have made to have filmed it in a similar style to Godzilla. I sure hope film makers get over this shaky camera and poor lighting and color kick they are on. There are some good movies out there, Minority Report, War of the Worlds to mention a couple. If only they weren't distorted by lighting and color manipulation and shaky camera work to set a mood.... an annoying one.

title: CLOVERFIELD (Matt Reeves, 2008) ***
review:
To begin with, I found this to be somewhat better than I had anticipated (though, admittedly, advance reviews had been generally positive). That said, the opening fifteen minutes are quite deadly - (even if the extended party footage helps to flesh out characters and, thus, heighten the later relentless anxiety passages). Thankfully, the teen relationships stuff gets forgotten pretty quickly  but, when they occur, the elegiac intermittent video footage of the happier past gives one a much-needed breather.

This is THE BLAIR WITCH PROJECT (1999) meets THE HOST (2006) or, if you, like a Hollywood monster movie of yore updated for the MTV generation and filtered through with a post-9/11 sensibility. SCREAM (1996), THE BLAIR WITCH PROJECT itself and SAW (2004) are all recent examples of the next big thing in Horror films; and, yet, who today recalls (or even misses) the film-makers of BLAIR WITCH? The director of this one, Matt Reeves, is already 42  and his previous film had been the comedy THE PALLBEARER (1996); in any case, CLOVERFIELD is more renowned for being a J.J. Abrams project (who produced it).

The film is compact (even with its tight 75 minutes duration, barring the typically lengthy closing credits, it stills sags slightly and interest starts to wane towards the end), the title obscure, the monster(s) undefined (the shapeless main creature is creepy and admirably one only gets to have a real good look at it when gobbling up the Hud character! The young cast is variable, anonymous (with the most interesting characters being the misfits  Helena for being a Latina and Hud a geek) and, fashionably, indiscriminately disposed of. As for the cine'-verite' approach, the film-makers' over-reliance on it becomes rather self-defeating: would it be plausible for someone to keep filming this stuff? Besides, while aiding in the immediacy of the destruction and the ensuing panic (with such effective shock sequences as the demolition of the Brooklyn bridge, the tunnel attack and Helena's mysteriously violent and messy death), it never allows the audience a moment for reflection  coming across as a sensation rather than an experience and, given that nothing at all is explained, one isn't any the wiser by the end of it!

In retrospect, it seems obvious that the traumatic 9/11 events has transported the U.S. back to the days of political/nuclear/alien paranoia which, back then, was also transmitted into cinematic terms via any number of sci-fi parables but where it's evident that the film-makers of that time were utmost professionals (in their strict majority) whose mission was to provide thought-provoking entertainment rather than merely computer-generated publicity stunts. At least, it does manage a couple of lingering images: the disembodied head of the Statue Of Liberty tumbling to the ground and an empty horse-carriage eerily wandering by night on a practically deserted city street. Sadly enough, but hardly surprising, a sequel is already in the works; the film, then, is no masterpiece but very well done nonetheless: smart, exciting and highly effective  in essence, what the much-hyped Hollywood remake of GODZILLA (1998) should have been in the first place! In spite of my reservations, I still consider it to be the first must-see movie of 2008 (which I chose not to watch it in the theater for fear of the dizzy camera syndrome proving to be a bit much but, actually, one gets used to it pretty quickly).

title: Excellent movie, draws you into the characters, seems like almost "real" events
review: In my opinion, this movie was excellent. The fact that it played more on realism than on Hollywood crap makes it even better. Now given, the Blair Witch Project was a big stinking disastrous bomb. The realism of that movie was just *puke*. I kinda think it's funny that people are comparing it to that just because it's filmed in a hand-held video camera way. It's nothing like that movie in any way. Most of the bad reviews start "cry cry, the moving camera made me ill, cry cry". I think that fact made it easier to get engrossed into the movie and actually care about the characters. Given the acting wasn't completely perfect. But how can you possibly act exactly as you should without being in that situation. And the references to 9/11, what's the big deal, who cares. It's probably just another ploy of Bush trying to get our minds off his retardedness.... again. Oh, and I loved one of the previous comments that start: "Why do Americans feel the need for stupid, totally unrealistic disaster movies?" Ummmm, we're not the only ones that make these kinda movies. We're just the only ones that make GOOD ones that anyone remembers other than the Godzilla movies (which are fantastic even at their old age btw). All in all, this movie you will either love or hate, doesn't seem to be an in between. I usually only write a review if I feel strongly for a movie. I loved it. The ending was fantastic. Leaves you thinking "wow, that really sucks". Heh, for all we know, if a giant monster attacked New York that's exactly how it would be.

title: Really Good
review:
An amazing movie! Original, full of unknowing segments which can stop your heart out and most of all- done with a lot of thinking and analyzing how a person can react in dangerous situations. It's not just the crazy action scenes where the American soldiers fire at the monster and the guy with the camera is trying to take cover, giving you the chance to experience something that has never been done before in the world of cinema. It gives you the preview of normal daily life with a bunch of people who are throwing a party for their best friend who is going to somewhere and you don't want to loose contact with him. And everything goes on and on, until suddenly the reality strikes you and last but not least, fear is contacting in you in a full circle of madness.

As final words, I don't want to spoil anything for you, I just strongly recommend you this movie, done by a real genius, who knows how, when and where to put his big sack of money. And truly he should be taken as an example of how can you do an amazing job, without wasting cash on something that has been already seen. 9/10

By the way I'm giving 9 out of 10, because there were some parts which i really didn't like- for example the way the monster is showing up . Its true that it can be seen from another side, like who cares, this is the real world, this is really happening, a monster is coming, so i don' t have time to read news or something like that.But, it would have been cooler and more satisfying to have hidden- mini introduction of the terror. Again, this could be a hint, a step for another sequel, and if there is... ooo I'm going to watch it, definitely. :)

title: This movie rocks big time ... best ever ... See it !
review:
Cloverfield is one awesome and very unique movie !! WHAT A RIDE !!! Without a doubt the best and most innovating and thrilling movie for years !! maybe the whole century !!

Beats Everything in this genre (and most others as well) The movie also has a good pace/tempo about it ! Wonderful in every way possible !

Filmed in a genius way (takes a little getting use too) This is not a "typical" Hollywood movie ! it is not following the flow so to speak ! The only downside in the movie is the opening scenes.... they are a bit slow and take a little to much room in the movie! and the ending (but maybe there will be a sequel .. i hope soooo).

And another little downside is that i thought that the movie was a little bit to short... but hey you cant get everything !

I think its a good underlying concept/idea in this movie about the monsters .... represent terrorists and the fight against them but also some points about sep 11 2001 attacks ! In the real world ....... terrorists are monsters so its a good comparison!

The monsters in movie are well made but not very scary but good ! The special effects in this movies is awesome ! The monsters make the movie what it is !! VERY good !

But what really makes the movie special is the actors that portray ordinary people (could have been anyone of us) they make the movie interesting and exciting !!

This movie is a must to see ! And i will get the DVD as soon as i can ! Everybody that will see this movie will love it i can guarantee it !!

I really hope the will be a sequel... because i want more !! Or maybe another one like this one !

And they have made the movie soooooo good that it feels like you are there in the movie and experiencing it yourself!!

And don't compare this movie to The Blair Witch Project because that movie sucked big time and this does not it is the complete opposite/contrast !!

I give this movie a full 10 because it deserves it and it is that gooooood !!

title: most annoying film ever
review: everything about this film annoyed me, from the rather lame plot to the truly awful camera work, some people might think its "trendy" or "genius" to film an entire movie through a camcorder personally i hate it and think its lazy, then there's the characters i'm so glad they were all killed, i was getting really angry as well especially when they were on top of the apartment block and HUD turned and you got a fantastic view of the monster being bombed, but did he keep it there? oh! no! lets turn it back to the pointless other 2 people and film them walking down a slope instead, what would have really made the scene there would have been if the slope had given way and they fell to their deaths at least then they could have ended the film a bit earlier, with all the hype this film got and the rather teasingly good TV trailers it was a huge disappointment so all in all i,m giving this a 2 and believe me that is a generous 2

title: you are the part of movie
review: I see this movie. I love and like Hollywood movies very much especially horror and science fiction. About this movie what can i say? This is the amazing movie story, acting and direction. It's not like any other alien attack movie the actors have no preplanned how will they face the situation and we also.I BET you can not guess what happen next? After watching this movie you will say "this what i am looking for" this movie stay in your heart and brain. About the the actors of this movie they are perfect they all are new to me but they all done a great job. The movie make you stick to your seat. I am waiting for the next part of the Cloverfield. in the last i say go watch this movie if not then you will miss not something but lots of things.

title: Oh no's, its Another One!
review:
I think it is rather funny how everybody I talk to about this movie says it is great, but when asked why...they have NO answer! The best I've gotten so far was a "Well...the monster was awesome!" SO WHAT?! Am I the only sane person alive on this entire rock? Originality: So...what was the deal with the camera? Was that suppose to be original? Im sure other people have already brought this to your attention, but it still seems like they are being ignored. THATS NOT CUTE! The director had to be tripping when he came up with that idea...

Special Effects: decent, though I only got a 2-3 second glimpse of any given rendered scene...

Plot: Whatever plot you may think there is does not exist. Starts off, yay fun party! Blah blah blah, lets make the stereotypical comic relief who happens to be missing half his brain and is incapable of forming complex sentences carry the camera! Oh no, monster! Careful, the obviously mindless monster decided it would be in his best interest to symbolically rip just the head off of the Statue of Liberty and toss it conveniently at our cameraman! Must...rescue......hot babe...(though that outfit is far from attractive...). Lets get everybody killed trying to rescue the already half-dead girl! Oh, while we are doing that...lets make some meaningless, idiotic and heavily lacking sarcastic remarks so the audience can have something else to make fun of us for! Oh no's! The bridge is falling, lets record a little more of my death! Weee! Wait a tick, getting bit by the mini-monsters causes your head to explode?! "Aww man, why did I waist all that time trying to hook up with her? Oh yeah, Im an idiot!" -- Ooo, Im impressed. This girl we found in the toppled over building who happens to have a steel rod through her chest mere inches away from her heart has survived like this for the past...wait, how long did it take for them to get to her? I couldn't tell...OK, we get to the helicopter which seems to have been waiting just for us...don't bother trying to save the brave soldiers risking their life for the last three people left in Manhattan...OK, let the one actor we did pay enough to stay without forcing us to edit them out with a cheezy death escape on the one safe helicopter while we take the obviously doomed second one! On no's! We is going downs! Hey, did you notice that it was night when they left and it was morning when they finally emerged from the obviously fatal helicopter crash? Did it seriously take them 2 hours to get out of the wreckage?! Oh, my favorite part: the monster, which has been wandering around the city 90% of the entire night getting fired on by the better part of the National Guard, which includes every modern and advanced weapon known to man, decides to leave the city EXACTLY when our nomads emerge from the crash and had enough time to pause while running from the Army to give our idiot cameraman a good stare down before feasting on his legs (NOT his head or torso, mind you...gotta save those for later...) and then, for no apparent reason, walks away so that the camera can be picked up by the same guy that thought the camera was a stupid idea to begin with...Brilliant! There is no way I could have come up with that climax! "Since the only entertaining part of the movie we have been making for an hour is done with, lets just finish up with a meaningless ending monologue by our only two characters remaining alive and then kill them. Even better, lets not give them a respectable Death by Monster, oh no. Lets have them explode twice from a human attack that was obviously aimed for the bridge they had taken shelter under... THE END! Lets go have a drink..." PS: If it feels like Im jumping around randomly in the story, it isn't a mistake or lack of time/effort. The movie REALLY is like that...

PPS: Honestly, where did they come up with the name "Cloverfield"?!

title: This *will* leave you speechless
review:
Originally,I didn't see this movie in a theater,because I checked the comments here and they were mostly bad.Its an old habit of mine,but this time,I still decided to watch it,after downloading it from internet,because a friend of mine said it was very original,fresh and thrilling.Expect a lot of spoilers from here on.

First,we have the main characters-someone must have watched many of the classic horror movies from the past 20-30 years.In the first 20 minutes of the movie,we get to know the main characters.These are names you have never heard and will never hear again,so no need to mention them. Friends,a going away party,unspoken love,a moron with a camera and his unsuccessful flirting...The rest of the movie is mostly screaming,a shaking camera,as few as possible moments,actually viewing the antagonist...In the end we don't really care about the characters,I personally enjoyed seeing the narrator die and thats about it.

The visual effects here are satisfactory(there are booms,bangs and big explosions)-much like in any other movie nowadays that relies so heavily on them,the shaky-camera is in no way original,as many people believe,i won't explain why,rather just watch BWP.

Ah,the advertising-this is what made this movie the most successful January release gross of all time.A lot of funds and time have been put in this department and in the end it paid off.Overall praised by critics and grossing in at over 152M$..enough said for the advertising-the boys obviously knew their job well.

The story-as I said its screaming,running,screaming,running,this guy dies,that guy dies,more screaming and running and in the end NOTHING REALLY HAPPENS.I stood for maybe 2 hours reading comments and wondering why the hell did i not waste 90mins on something better like hitting my head against the wall,just trying to find something worth my time in this movie,a reason for all those nice comments...alas my work is complete,take what you will from this comment,but don't waste your time like I did.

title: Sloppy Camera Work But Good
review:
On the eve of his departure for Japan, Rob (Michael Stahl-David) sees his going-away party as an opportunity to confess unresolved feelings and tie up loose ends. His agenda takes an unexpected turn when a jolt shakes the revelers. The crowd quiets down to watch news reports of an earthquake, then rushes to the roof to assess the damage. A fireball explodes on the distant horizon. A power failure follows. Confusion gives way to panic as the partygoers stumble through the blackout and into the streets.

Amid the human screams and one inhuman roar, Rob and his friends must traverse a landscape that has changed, overtaken by something otherworldly, terrifying, monstrous... Cloverfield 6/10

title: I just want to ask one question .. is the director still alive !!
review:
I just want to ask one question .. is the director still alive !! this movie is really bad ... and i will prove it ..

the director want to make a new style and want to let u live this events .all right u do it but u kill any thing else in the movie by made the film by using a camera held on hand .. and this made many flaws in the movie * it killed the special effects in the movie that i admit it was cool .

* it made the whole movie go in one way there isn't any change in the event or time or places u are forced to see the movie from one position.and this is so boring * it doesn't make any sense .in the scene that in the metro tunnel. when the guy still filming and his friends were attacked by monsters * there are many things that i want to watch but OMG the camera is filming the ground . is this to rise the frame rate or what ? * what the hell with this camera it still working after many times of droping and not just this the battry worked two days and half without stoping . this must be a wonder Number 8 after building the Pyramids that is enough about the camera . now lets see the flaws in the movie at all . but before that i want to say that 2 degree from the 3 i gives to the movie .is going to the sound it is good . just to be honest ..

now the flaws ...

title: Best movie ever!
review: I watched the tailor of the movie, I read the reviews, I listened to people that the movie was a waste of time, I listened to people that the movie was crap overall. I never listen to people anyway and since i'm a big fan of the movie "The Blair Witch Project", I simply had to go and see the movie. After sitting through the movie, I would suggest people to either watch the movie in the cinema or if you plan to watch the movie at home, you better have a 50" Screen and a 7.1 Sound System with a lot of bass! This movie kept me thrilled from the moment it started to the moment it ended! I simply sat there, in shock and awe for 5 minutes after the credits were done! It is simply, hands down, the best and I mean THE BEST movie to be ever made! I HIGHLY RECOMMEND it on the BIG SCREEN!!! The Sound is Perfect, The Effects are Perfect, The story is Perfect, I simply cannot find any reason whatsoever to give it a 9!!!! 10 out of 10 for this bad boy!

title: A piece of art
review:
There are films that take your breath away, and this is most definitely one of them. What could have been just another crappy monster movie is instead a piece of art, with incredible realistic performances from a largely unknown cast. The scriptwriter was clearly at the top of his game, the snappy dialogue keeps the plot moving at a good pace, and the set pieces in the film were genius. Never clearly seeing the monster also gave this film an edge and a sense of enigma. It makes a refreshing change not to have the stock goofy scientist, or any of the other stock monster/disaster movie characters, you find out the information as the characters do, which makes it easier to identify with the characters.

J.J.Abrahms made a risky move in shooting this film on hand-held cameras, and thank goodness he did. Contrasting films like the Blair Witch Project, it works brilliantly, and contributes to the success of the movie. The sequence in the subway tunnel for example shows how the camera can build tension and create suspense. That this film works makes me look foreward to Diary Of The Dead, which will be an incredible experience if George A Romero utilises the camera half as well as Cloverfield has. Definitely a must see.

title: in a word - Predictable
review:
First off I would like to thank all the people who gave honest reviews... I should have listened to them... I did like the concept of having the film be from the point of view of an amateur camera man ... unfortunately this film fell way flat.. the characters are so one dimensional it is ridiculous the only scene done well was the subway...

I have seen where people have stated that this was supposed to represent the horror of 9-11 .. again that is a thin statement at best .. I lost some very close friends during 9-11 and to say this captures that horror .. I am offended.

There were absolutely NO surprises for me during the viewing .. to be honest I almost walked out ... I kept saying to myself " it has to get better... everyone said this was thrilling ..." boy was I wrong..

Again I loved the concept however they could have done much better pulling it off .. OH yeah BTW what video camera do you know of that can run for what is supposed to be 7.5 hours without needing a new battery while using both light and night vision .. sorry just ain't happening ...

I would like to see the movie redone in the future .. however done correctly .. maybe flesh out the characters a bit more in their reactions .. and telling us why the bites have the effect they do .. ( natural question when you see that happen to a friend!) gah I did end up getting my money back from the theater and got a free ticket to Sweeny Todd .. NOW THAT WAS A MOVIE WORTH WATCHING

title: Not a bad film, but...
review:
Whilst this film is not exactly bad, I can not say it is particularly good either. The main reason for this I thought that it was full of plot holes and obvious events, as well as making me feel decidedly sea-sick! Part of the film's problem is the fact that it took so long to get going. For a film as short as this the opening party scene seemed to go on for hours, and was the kind of party that I would personally have avoided like the plague! In fact by the time the action actually got going I was already wishing for most of the party goers to 'bite the dust'! When eventually the film did get into its stride the comparisons with 9/11 were so blindly obvious to be quite painful. The falling building, the rubble and dust rolling down the street etc could not have existed before that dreadful day and the subsequent TV coverage. Following on from this the film really became not much more than a chase movie, with a lot of running - and I mean A LOT OF RUNNING! - about, plenty of screams and some really dumb actions by the characters.

The most puzzling part of the film for myself was when the surviving lead characters went into the subway system. Now surely, with New York being attacked in the manor it was, this system would have been heaving with like-minded souls attempting to escape from the happenings on the surface? Yet when they got down there they were the only ones. As for what happens down there, well I would spoil it for those who have not viewed the film yet, but to say they were obvious is like saying Manchester United play in red at home! The few things that save this film from being a complete duffer is the special effects. The monster, which is only slowly revealed, is really quite scary, and the destruction is well done. The action, when it gets going, is fast and furious, and the acting, whilst never being Oscar worthy!, is not bad for a film of this type.

Of course I am sure that there is a whole essay to be written about this film - and others like the recent 'Invasion', 'I am Legend' etc - and the whole post 9/11 scenario, but I will leave that to much more learned minds than my own! Surfice to say that if you are willing to leave your brain at the box office, and can cope with the opening party scene full of horrid little people, then this film offers up a reasonable amount of entertainment.

title: Only two words suit this movie: "thrilling" and "unique".
review:
Cloverfield is unique among it's fellow monster movies, in that it is infinitely more sickening. And I mean sickening in the best possible way. To put it frankly, Cloverfield is brutal. This isn't your cliché "guy in a rubber suit attacks city in campy manner" monster movie. This is something that will leave you shaken, and for various reasons at that.

But first, a word of warning. If you have motion sickness, you might wish to wait for the DVD release. Cloverfield's camera work is designed to emulate a hand-held camera in the possession of a scared young man as realistically as possible. As a result, it's going to be shaky. Very shaky. While it sounds disheartening at first, it helps add to the realism of the disaster portrayed. It is a very effective manner of filming in that it significantly raises the heart rate of the viewer. This style, combined with the non-stop panic and chaos Cloverfield shows, is a brilliant way to portray a monster attack. Cloverfield gives you exactly what you would expect from a real monster attack, or even any disaster, and that is total chaos. And when it comes to portraying total chaos, Cloverfield does it more or less perfectly. This is helped by surprisingly competent acting considering the fact that the cast is full of near-unknown actors. (What did you expect? It's a relatively low budget movie which requires lots of effects because of it's very nature.)

The monster itself is totally original, and very well designed. It looks totally unique, with nothing to compare it to. But I will say that it has probably the best design in monster history. And I won't spoil the movie, but I'll say that it isn't the only thing that's well-designed. The events of the movie are all very memorable, with some that are simply shocking. But don't be fooled, although this is a monster movie, the characters take priority. The monster isn't the only thing the camera records. It also shows the struggle the cast go through and their relationships with one another. The characters are all rather well-done, particularly Hud, the cameraman(and oh-so-subtle pun). Cloverfield is in many ways a very well made film and a great revival of the dying monster genre. Additionally, it provides some commentary and messages amidst the destruction, much like the original Godzilla did well over 50 years ago. I would highly recommend Cloverfield, but do not expect cliché white lab-coat scientist exposition about the monster's origin. the movie shows what people caught up in the havoc would see and know, but if that is really so important, look up the viral marketing which explains more of the overall plot. But Cloverfield is about more than just that-it shows struggle, and panic, and how helpless we are against our own planet.

title: Seriously?
review:
Im giving this film a 1 out of 10 Because there was one good thing about this film ..when it ended

"oh my god, oh my god".... shut up!

The actors were too obviously trying to act normal, and this did not work - because they could not act

There was absolutely no mystery - we knew straight away that there was a monster and there was nothing else to find out

And it looked cheap although they probably spent millions on all the special effects

I want my money back

title: Amazing Experience
review:
I recently went to the movies to see this film before it hit shelfs. I went with the impression that I would be minutely disappointed with the movie because of the style of film, but soon found the first movie that amazed me. Truly.

The movie started abruptly with no credits, which I prefer cause I want to get strait to the movie. Then it set up the characters in a romantic real life comedy sort of way, that in a way made me feel like one of their friends and this was just a memory I was reliving.

Because the movie was written and filmed in such a way that it made these people real and not fictional characters, it became an amazing watch. Everything I or another person would want to witness, feel, do, encounter during an horrific ordeal was show and done. I felt as if I was living this experience with them.

Also, they style of film added to the dramatic suspense and horror of it all. I was immersed into this event and scream out loud every time something happened. I felt as if I was in a virtual 3D movie and when I walked out of the theater I expected to see people running and screaming and some creature tearing up the mall.

So really my first thought and impressions were wrong. The movie would not have been the same without the shaky camera. All around great experience, couldn't ask for a better way to spend my night.

title: The Worst & Most Unprofessional Movie Ever!!!
review:
The worst movie ever! Disgusting!

It made me sick and vomiting, as the focus keeps moving. It was filmed by one of the roles in the film itself, but much worse than a homemade American Funnies Video.

Was it because that there was a shortage of budget so that they could not afford a professional photographer?

Anyway, the effect is the same.

Anyone could be a better photographer than the real one who filmed it.

Do not see it, unless you want to vomit on site!

The worst movie ever! Disgusting!

It made me sick and vomiting, as the focus keeps moving. It was filmed by one of the roles in the film itself, but much worse than a homemade American Funnies Video.

Was it because that there was a shortage of budget so that they could not afford a professional photographer?

Anyway, the effect is the same.

Anyone could be a better photographer than the real one who filmed it.

Do not see it, unless you want to vomit on site!

title: Has a slow start, but afterwards, the action is unstoppable.
review:
I actually went to see Cloverfield with six friends of mine before I shot the footage for my own film for film studies coursework in college. We saw it in a cinema which wasn't really the best one around, but when the film started, and moved slowly into the disequilibrium of the narrative, it didn't feel like I was in a cinema at all, but I was in the movie amongst the other characters and the action.

Cloverfield is one of those films which is most likely going to be one which will be bought as soon as it is released out on DVD so the audio commentary from the directors or producers can be heard so they can reveal any secrets about Clovie, and where the hefty 'fella came from. This is simply because the amount of enigma codes present within this film causes the audience to ask themselves a number of questions, but then forgetting them as another piece of action thrills them into asking even more questions.

I must admit, despite looking forward to seeing Cloverfield, I was a little hesitant about the whole 'shot with a hand-held camera' thing. But I'm glad I saw it because I was pleasantly surprised. You may feel a little sick with the fast camera work, but it's nothing to worry about. Just take note of the warnings which are usually on the counter near where you buy your tickets at the cinema, or when it is out on DVD, look out for anything on the back of the case.

I don't want to reveal too much about this film, but it is certainly not one to be missed. It is full of mystery, suspense, action, and romance. It's hybrid genre makes it unique along with the way the film is shot. I loved it, and so did my friends.

The CGI is awesome, as well, so go check it out! One of the best films of 2008, I'd say.

I Am Legend, eat your heart out. New York has room for one hungry critter, and one critter only.

It's Clovie. ;)

title: A fun 90 mins
review:
I was expecting this movie to be a bit more scary. That's my main gripe. Nothing really bad happens to the characters (on screen) so no real fear is conjured up. It's scary in the same way the movie 'Earthquake' was scary, ie. like a disaster movie, not a horror movie.

This might be your bag but I needed more to make me feel the fear I would have, had I have been in NYC during the onslaught.

The fx are great and I think future monster movies will use more of this first-person approach to drive home realism. The monster is killer.

The acting's *ok* and doesn't really let the film down but is questionable in places of high emotion. Towards the end, I just yearned to watch people get eaten or something.

To sum up: a fun 90 mins but didn't knock my socks off.

title: Rip-roaringly entertaining
review: In this rip-roaring, home-movie styled monster movie a group of teenager partying for the departure of one their closest friends find themselves amid a blaze of destruction when a giant 'thing' starts ripping the city to shreds. One of the unlucky scamps happens to be filming the entire thing, and thus we get a faux-documentary much in the style of a megabucks version of The Blair Witch Project meets Godzilla. Although the shaky camera and choice of the 1st person view may put off some viewers who suffer from motion sickness, Cloverfield for the most part is barnstorming entertainment, fully exploiting the resources available to it. The idea to shoot entirely from some poor sap's camera is not entirely original, dating back to the Italian cannibal movies of the early 80s. But it does make for an interesting take on the monster movie.

title: Wow
review:
Just wow. I didn't have any great expectations when I sat down to watch this, and I was completely blown away. Good plot, good actors and it seemed fairly realistic.

And yes, the monster IS awesome. You won't be disappointed.

They manage to keep the plot together, something I'm not terribly used to when it comes to movies like this. I love how they supply different explanations for what's happening, pretty much leaving it up to the viewer to decide what's going on throughout the movie.

I'd recommend watching this in the cinema by the way, there are a few really nice shots of New York in there. We had a couple of teenagers screaming in the back of the theater when the movie started, and the movie was so good they actually shut up during the whole movie. THAT'S how good it is.

title: over-rated garbage
review: Everyone has their own opinion so i will give mine and everyone i have spoke to about this film, in fact to find anyone who likes this film i had to come on this web-site. it got booed in my local cinema and rightfully so. i had a head-ache watching it, the amateur camera work was pointless and spoiled the film. there was no tension (what they tried to achieve with the amateur camera work) the main thing was that this film was totally BORING!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I only watched it last night and i can honistly say that i cannot name any of the characters names. the acting was poor and the characters were boring. i'm not going to waste anymore time in telling you anymore about this film as its not worth my time its already wasted an hour and a half of my life, either listen to me or not i'm not bothered, some of may like it (dont understand how) but if i save anyone money by putting you off this garbage at least my hour and a half wasn't totally wasted.

title: dumb movie
review: this movie was not very good at all. the movie was short and we don't even know what happened to the monster i was at the edge of the seat waiting to see what would happen to the monster, but unfortunately nothing happened this was a horrible movie. unless their is a sequel coming then it might be worth watchin it again, it was harsh for the critics to say that this movie was better than rambo lol that was very dumb. apparently the critics are in their own dull worlds which they don't probably don't even know how to change a flat tire haha funny stuff. anyways i shouldn't have wasted my money on this movie especially at seven dollars a ticket. i hope there is a sequel because this movie was dumb and a waste of money

title: Blair Witch Project VS Godzilla.
review: Hello, I went to see Cloverfield last Tuesday. I was so excited about the idea of seeing it, the trailer made me eager to see the whole thing for a while. Well let me tell you, I've been badly disappointed. This movie is nothing but a mix between The Blairwitch Project and Godzilla. The camera just keeps shaking and moving around the whole movie, which gave me the same feeling you have in a bad roller coaster ride. At the first fourth of the movie, I was wondering if I could sit there the whole movie without running to the bathroom to throw up because that camera effect made me dizzy and nauseous. Nothing to do with the actual movie and the 'disturbing' scenes (didn't see any, by the way). I badly needed fresh air when I stepped out of there. The monster is a cheap rip off of Godzilla, only a little better computer-made, but still the same thing, same type of story. The start of the movie, that party thing, was way too long. The movie was also too short for the price. Including the trailers, 1 hour 20 minutes? Completely ridiculous. Sincerely, I stepped out of the cinema thinking I had spent some money for nothing, except getting a bad case of nausea. It disappointed me like no other movie did in a long, long time.

title: Blarwitch + No script + Crappy 3D monster = Cloverfield
review:
I had to see this movie because I was late at the cinema to watch the latests Burton movie. I knew that was about a bunch of guys holding a camera while a monster attacks Manhattan. So, I decided to give it a chance.

I must to say that the building destruction, the shooting and the sounds effects were pretty good.

When the movie starts I could see that was about a founded video about the destruction, and I expected a little more explanation about how the monster came in, where it comes from or something else. But no. There is no f***g single clue of anything. It's just about guys trying to rescue a trapped girl crossing between the little monsters that came of from the bigger one. That's it. End of the story.

My recommendation is this: "DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY ON THIS" If you want to, wait for the DVD at least.

title: With Hud's own eyes
review: Starting with the fabled 16th century "chain map" of Florence, Rennaissance draughtsmen would place likenesses of themselves, sketchpad and feather in hand, in the foreground of their cityscapes. These tiny self-portraits act as warrants of authenticity: they had been on site to see their subjects first hand. Similarly, Matt Reeves makes us believe that we witness a monster attack on Manhattan through the lens of a party-goer's hand-held video camera. To authenticate the footage, he has Hudson "Hud" Platt (first-time screen actor T.J. Miller) shoot flashes of his own face at regular intervals, exactly the way the draughtsmen inserted themselves into their designs. The camera tilts and jiggles to suggest Hud is actually filming this as he runs from a very ill-tempered lizard the size of the Chrysler building. But the crystal-clear footage is on 35mm film, not videotape, and of course the jiggling isn't at all like the shakes of "real" hand-held video. But what's real anyway? The whole thing is an illusion, fabricated to corroborate an illusion. This is also how this is different from "The Blair Witch Project", which was actually (mostly) shot on video. "Cloverfield" starts out as a fully-fledged rich kid relationship drama. Until the monster hits town some 20 minutes later, you can't even be sure you're in the right movie. All in all, I think it's pretty clever for a mainstream thriller. Oh, and Lizzy Kaplan is very hot in the part of Hud's love interest, deadpan beauty Marlena Diamond.

title: Mistake on the trivia...
review:
Heads cannot be decapitated, they can be disembodied, bodies, however can be decapitated.

**BEWARE SPOILERS** Hey, I thought this film was worth the ticket price and even worth the popcorn price (which is tough to admit). As in The Blair Witch Project, I found my own imagination to be much scarier than the full view of the monster at the end. I really enjoyed it though and thought it was a great "date movie". Even the reminder at the end not to hold back telling someone you love them roped me in like a sentimental sucker. There were plenty of frenetic moments that were well beyond the threshold of intensity that has my girlfriend (to whom I've been married for 15 years now) holding me close. It was a great night at the movies and was in many ways very modern, but a throwback to old-school drive-in horror that I miss so much. Bring a date.

Rizzo

title: Watch this while it's in cinemas...
review:
I went to watch Cloverfield with low expectations. I expected to watch the film, appreciate the hand-held camera gimmick as far as I could and leave feeling a little nauseous. I was insistent on seeing it in the cinema though, rather than waiting for the DVD release and facing a far inferior experience.

Maybe it was partly due to my own cynicism but I was extremely impressed.

There is much more humour here than I would have imagined. Hud (T.J. Miller) is our socially awkward cameraman and, thanks to him, this movie becomes much more than the typical "giant monster" movie. It might be a British sense of humour that finds it funny but at times I was in hysterics.

The romance at the centre is no longer the generic sort where the good-looking girl is captured by the monster. The personal camera idea works exceptionally well in making everything feel very human and real. At times you do actually feel directly involved in the action and the friendships. When the humour suddenly stops and things 'hit the fan' I was stunned. It all emphasises the way catastrophes aren't anticipated, they just happen when we least expect it and feel safest.

Some people will be annoyed with 'the monster'. I'll say little about it for two reasons - I don't anyone to feel their experience has been ruined and I can't really find that much to say. It's a monster. It does what you expect. It's big and it smashes things.

Obviously the concept of the movie isn't an original one. 'Big bad monster attacks Manhattan' has been done so many times. It's the personal side of the movie that gives it just enough originality. The audience know that whatever they see is through the eyes of a character and that is a comforting thought. There is someone else there, with you.

Some have accused the film-makers of exploiting post-9/11 paranoia. There is an element of that in there but I don't see that as a bad thing. You feel as if you are in the middle of a disaster, rather than watching someone else filming a disaster, which is an interesting feeling.

I don't tend to like the big budget monster movies. The Godzilla remake didn't thrill me. I wasn't remotely interested in the remake of King Kong. This, for me, has a lot more to it.

Sequels are on the cards, I just hope they don't kill off the Cloverfield concept when this film alone works so well.

In the end I wasn't feeling any nausea, just glad that I'd taken a chance on a film I didn't have massive confidence in.

title: Don't waste your money!!!
review:
Don't waste you money seeing this in a full price theater, even a dollar theater is spending too much to see this movie.

To make this as simple as possible, this movie resembles a Retarded version of Godzilla filmed by the crew of the Blair Witch Project. If you enjoy watching an entire movie through someone filming it with a camcorder your set. Not only is the entire show being filmed through someone carrying a camcorder to document what is happening you get all the shaking and moving as they run around like idiots trying to get to safety.

I'm not saying to trust me on this but at least wait to watch it when someone else buys it on DVD so you really don't have to pay for it. I think it cost them about $50 to film this movie...

title: Monstrous Live Action
review:
A not ordinary film, watching "Cloverfield" on its first part feel like I need to sleep then wake when the real film(Some part of same film has a NON-CAM shoot)starts but after some minutes the real action began. As the story goes its either I get myself dizzy or I have to move from my sit because of really thrilling events.

The Movie is like an Indie or an amateur low budget film but what makes "Cloverfield" interesting.its REAL. unlike Godzilla or any other film this makes the audience involve in the film. the tilting camera makes audience feel running and other stuff. even how the characters on the film projects their feelings affects the audiences. as the story comes to an end...you will be on the edge of your sits

title: Best Movie ever
review:
This movie was the best I've seen in a long time. the suspense was great. the action was intense.

it felt so realistic.

the first person point of view added to the greatness. the monster was amazing. the monster was greatly done. it fit the part perfectly. the bulging sacks behind the eyes. the parasites dropping off and if they bit you you exploded. the monster destroyed the Brooklyn bridge and killed Rob's brother and it ripped off the statue of liberty's head. it was so nasty when Marlena died. the parasite bit her shoulder, and when the got to the army base, she started bleeding from the eyes, then the doctors brought her behind a curtain. all you could hear was screaming, then a squelching sound, then a giant blood splatter on the curtain. the best view of the monster was when it got right in the camera, then i think it bit Hud in half. the whole movie was excellent and i would highly recommend it to all ages

title: Cheap Crappy Version of 'War of the Worlds'
review:
This is a great film if you want a big headache watching a cheap, low budget version of 'war of the worlds' Please don't watch this, I only wish I had read some reviews before I went. I ended up really disappointed and walked out because it hurt my eyes so much.

The entire movie is some one carrying a camcorder and never really aims it properly at anything. So basically, you will not see anything, apart from some of the girls chest and it movies quite a lot, giving you eye ache and migrane.

I suppose you could watch it, if you really want, but all you will be doing is paying to use your own imagination, because there is no story line and there definitely is no movie. Your better off staring at the roof of your room, silently (with popcorn and a drink!)

title: GODZILLA For Twenty-Somethings
review:
A giant monster attacks New York City: the idea is at least as old as THE BEAST FROM 20,000 FATHOMS (1953). What distinguishes CLOVERFIELD is its perspective. Stealing THE BLAIR WITCH PROJECT's gimmick, it tells the story exclusively from the point of view of five twenty-somethings armed only with a video camera. Instead of the usual panning shots of thousands of anonymous screaming extras fleeing in panic, which has the effect of distancing the audience from the action, we are right down there in the carnage, underfoot as it were, in danger of getting trampled like the rest.

Unfortunately, this verisimilitude has landed CLOVERFIELD in political hot water. Some people claim it offensively exploits the memory of 9/11 (like a certain former mayor of New York/ex-Presidential candidate). Just to put things in historical perspective, GODZILLA was made in 1954, just nine years after Hiroshima and Nagasaki. (In an early scene, CLOVERFIELD acknowledges its kaiju roots when it is revealed one of the characters is moving to Tokyo to pursue a career.) CLOVERFIELD isn't a classic like GODZILLA, or even as good as THE HOST, another recent giant monster movie that focuses on people. The characters--the heroic guy, the heroic girl, the nerdy guy, the stuck-up girl, the heroic guy's heroic brother--are far too generic to be memorable. On the other hand, it towers over the disappointing 1998 remake of GODZILLA, also set in New York City. CLOVERFIELD is efficient scary entertainment that will hold your attention for its scant 84-minute running time.

title: Terrible movie!
review:
Wow! I thought Blair Witch Project sucked but this movie brings suckiness to a whole new level. First, I am not a fan of the 'Blair Witch' movie where you see the movie from the point of view of the person who is holding the camcorder. As you might expect, the movie shakes A lot. Now I heard from people and on the news that some people vomited and even fainted in the movie theaters because the erratic movie shots made them dizzy. I was not one of them. However, 'Blair Witch' type movies do annoy me. This movie feels like an indie movie but it's not because millions of dollars have been poured into this piece of dirt.

The story is about a group of twenty somethings in New York City and one of them is going to Japan because he got a promotion. They throw a going away party where one of their friends shoots the event on his camcorder. During this party, there is an explosion many blocks away. They all go out and the head of Statue of Liberty falls onto their street. Then they see some sort of giant alien but don't know what it is since the movie only shows couple of seconds of it. Then there is more explosion. The power goes off. They see the military fighting it. The people try to escape on the Brooklyn Bridge but it collapse and some of the friends don't make it. Then they try to go and rescue a girl/friend who is in the alien attack area. They find her alive and try to escape on a military helicopter but the aliens attack it and they fall back on to the ground. They survive but the one who is carrying camcorder gets attacked. I think he is killed. I'm not sure because I was about throw my popcorn at this crappy movie along with what was left of my soda drink. The friends take the camcorder and take off to who knows where. The End.

The only good thing about this movie was that the aliens looked cool.

title: Not a movie, per se
review:
I can't say I liked this, as a movie. It didn't feel like a movie, which was probably the point. I certainly didn't look like a movie, which didn't bother me. It didn't develop like a movie, or begin or end like a movie, or "work" like a movie - unless it was a movie done by 7th graders w/ mom's cheap camera... I didn't get 'attached' to the characters, and I thought their decisions were idiotic - and at the same time, perfectly rational. And that is why this "movie" worked for me.

It didn't pretend to be a "movie," - it was erratic, poorly lit, poorly shot, and - my favorite aspect - absolutely, brilliantly acted.

These people were so unbelievable real.

There were aspects which I thought were 100% realistic, like their behavior and reactions in the subway (other than the fact that they were insane to go into the subway in the first place...). I was so very, very "with them" in the subway! But that was why I didn't think of this as a movie. A movie makes you think, makes you feel, makes you connect (or hopes to). This had no such goals - and yet, I found myself responding to the events along with the characters.

I should think that generation-X which (according to marketers is all about 'experience') will ADORE this movie - nothing to think about, nothing to connect to... but lots and lots of reactive emotion.

title: It's eating people
review:
When a group of friends are at the goodbye party of Rob Hawkins (Michael Stahl-David) some strange creature attacks the city of New York. The film show to us the experiences of the friends dealing with this unknown creature.

This all the plot of this film and certainly is not the best thing of the film. But the way the film is made with the style of an amateur tape and the hand held camera is great and the visual part is just perfect. To talk about the monster is unnecessary because is still a mystery and is going to be very useful to create a franchise in a very near future. But still i think it missed something with the monster because i don't like the love story that is behind the main plot, i know that they are trying to make us feel something about the characters but for me the love history is not even credible.

The cast of the film is good, with new actors making a nice job but still nothing special and again the visual part is more important and in consequence is the best thing.

And i haven't watch a marketing for a film like this one in the last years, create almost a cult for the film before it release. I wasn't very excited about the film but i was expecting the revival of the monster film and for me in this film is missing something.

Conclusion: judging by the reaction of yesterday's audience, the result was really strange because most of the people didn't feel that the film has an end and some people was like in shock but most was really dissatisfied. I didn't feel any of those feelings and i think that is what is missing, i mean to feel really disappointed or to be in shock and confused about it. Anyway for me is a decent film but of course is not the best sci-fi/monster of the last years but still have some really interesting things. Worth watching it in the cinemas for the perfect visual part, well only before the release of "No Country for Old Men" and "There Will Be Blood" in my country. 7 out of 10

title: Worst movie I have seen in cinema
review: I'm sorry that was by fare the worst movie I paid money for. If you know Dogma movies you are sort of used hand cameras but this was really over the top. There is no real story telling you just see what going on. monsters, dust sounds.... I'm normally not very critical about movies but could I get my money and time back?? I visited the cinema with 4 friends and all of them were disappointed and I had the feeling we were part of the majority of the people. Due to this movie I registered here because I thought this movie is fare overrated on IMDb. It really never happened for me that there was such a huge difference in my impression of the movie and the average comments.

title: Full Disappointment
review: I don't see how people can consider this film an 8 out of 10. The producing of the film annoyed me, as it was very poor. I'm not talking about the camera shaking, that's supposed to be like that, but the way it shakes, the effort the producer had to make it real only made it excessively unreal.... At any time, the camera was always "moving", always pretending that it really was a legit-tape, but that was 250% exaggerated. The panic and the shouts were all very poor.. Like, the Empire State Building collapsed, everything was on fire and they say "Waw! Did you see that?", instead of "OMG, what's happening, i can't believe OMG!!!!", or of course something like that.. And what about the "sons" of the monster? Why did they look electronic? Isn't he supposed to be a King-King biological animal? What about the US Army? Did they only had rifles to kill it? The 5-10 aircrafts that showed up - are those the only one's US has? Where did the animal come from? I know this is a Sci-Fi movie but.... Other planet? No. Below the water (as said on movie LOL)? No. A mutation of a monkey/whatever lie king-kong? No. Someone said it was a 9/11-after creation, and i started to laugh. I don't seem to understand what is Hollywood making to the movies. This is just like Aliens Vs Predator: Requiem.. They have a great opportunity to make a movie like Armageddon/Independence Day/etc, and they blow it up adding actors that even godzilla don't knows, and a director that's making millions out of creating some special effects that anyone with 15 years old can do. Matt Reeves.... How could you let this be? Gosh everyone's asleep.... Sorry for bad English. Peace.

title: dire
review: I would not recommend this movie to my worst enemy. The first twenty minutes were so boring I actually fell asleep, the first time ever for any film. It would be bad enough watching this part if you knew the people in this home movie, but with complete strangers it was dire. If this had been on You Tube for free I would have turned off after a minute. I was woke up by the loud sound effects and thought at last it started, but I might as well of stayed asleep. The jerking hand held camera made it agony to watch, and I would rate this the second worse film ever made after The Blair Witch Project, which used the same dreadful camera technique. The awful camera angles must of made it easy for the special effects department as they only had to put the lights on dim, add lots of flickering lights and wave the camera about so nobody could see how bad they were. Yours very disappointedly Tony

title: Puts you right in the action
review:
I enjoyed this film, It's very different from other movies you see out there right now, in that you feel almost a part of what is going on. Its true that the camera is hand held throughout the film, but that gives it more of a realistic vibe. I can see how people would get easily sea sick, but really just closing your eyes or looking away for a second clears it up rather quickly (for me, anyways).

It is most def not your typical monster movie. There is no all powerful character on the outside summing up what the monster is, why its attacking, or anything really. This movie literally drops you into the middle of the action, where realistically you WOULDN'T have any idea what was going on. The acting is overall good-I thought that the guy behind the camera was especially realistic to how a normal person would actually react to the situation.

One scene in particular did conjure up strong memories of 9/11, but it wasn't done in a tacky way I don't think. It is true that NYC seems to be the only place that people want to destroy in movies, but I guess that was for the drama of a lot of people being trapped on a small island with a big old monster causing a ton of problems-which would be harder to do at other locales. If you are very stomach sensitive (or have an ear infection) i'd recommend waiting for it to come to DVD so you can see it at home, otherwise I enjoyed this film and recommend it.

title: One of the best movies I've ever seen!!
review: I've seen a LOT of movies in my day, but this is definitely in my top 5..actually, it's probably number 2, but that's beside the point. All I've heard about this movie was how shaky the camera was and how bad that made the movie: I find this to be inaccurate, as I could not have seen this movie in any different form. If this movie would've been in a third person camera view, it would not have been the same. It is very unique in its art form. Besides the camera view, the story was very well told. It kept me hooked for the whole ride. The actors were very spot on in their performances, especially the guy who filmed most of it. I won't ruin anything for you, but there is a slight shade of comedy at some points in this movie, which puts a lighter sense on the whole experience. Overall, this whole movie was an experience I will not be forgetting any time soon. In fact, I will be buying the DVD when it is released (hopefully they'll make a 2-disc!!) Final words: if you haven't seen this movie...go see it soon!! It is one of the best theater experiences of my life.

title: Finally, an original monster...
review:
I was very excited about seeing this film, I even had to talk my friend out of wanting to see Sweeney Todd first so we could go see this. Well I'm glad I did (I haven't seen Sweeney Todd yet, so I'm not sayings it's crap), this was one of the most exciting and original films I've seen in such a long time, well maybe apart from No Country For Old Men.

The film has a slow start, with the first 20 minutes just introducing the characters, and many people will be already put off by it's Blair Witch style camera work (all hand held, as I'm sure everyone who knows about this movie should be aware of). Though stick with it, after 20 minutes we get our first disaster scene and from then on this film rarely slows down.

First of all, the acting is surprisingly good, especially from an unknown cast. Though they seem to stupidly step into danger throughout the film, when you'll be screaming in your mind "Get the f**k out of there!".

The camera work makes it all seem more realistic and exciting than many other movies of this sort, from the first moment we see the monster attack, to the final helicopter crash, we feel as though we are being attacked too. Though I have to warn people, it may make them sick and disoriented...hell even I felt a bit disoriented at times.

Finally, the monster. There has been so much speculation as to what exactly it is...and I gotta say, it's nothing like I would of imagined. this is like the kind of deformed brother of Godzilla, but much cooler. I wont describe exactly what it is, as that'll be spoiling it for everyone. But I'll say that he is one ugly motherf**ker! Really weird looking to...

Overall I loved this movie, it had me on the edge of my seat every time something big happened. Highly recommended! This was my first ever review heh...

title: very very very good!!!
review:
The user before me wrote "don't waste your money" basically wrote the film is crap - I totally disagree, and it was his/hers review that prompted me to write mine.

the previous user said 'there was no steady cam and was shaky all over' - do these people actually have a brain? the film is completely filmed thru a camcorder hand-held, and from the point of view of the survivors from an attack - what were they supposed to go? travel to a film studio and rob a professional camera set up - I'm sorry i don't know the full terminology, but i have used a cam before, and if your running or moving fast (as you would from a explosion) its going to shake!!! anyway the film was excellent - better then i expected, i heard it was a monster film, i was worried we wouldn't actually see the monster or anything, as its from survivors point of view - they're not always going to be in best position to see stuff, well this film was very well thought out and executed, a little like a cross between the new war of worlds, and new Godzilla - taking the best bits and making one better movie. You have heard the hype for the film - you KNOW its filmed with a camcorder, go and enjoy it - If you saw avp2, or planning to see Rambo then you will not be wasting your money with this (but you will with the other 2!!)

title: Awesome
review:
@bloodmane Dude, Hud continued to film while the monster was attacking because to him it conveyed a sense of security. That little black box, too him, kept him safe and was his shield against what was going on. Thats what people do during times of disasters, they find something and hold onto it because that is what is keeping them sane.

Anyways, onto my review. The movie was amazing. It felt real, like I was actually there. This is the first time in a long time that I have built a kind of emotional attachment with the characters in the film. They weren't over the top, or action heroes, they were normal people who were just caught in the middle of something terrible. In summary, the characters were awesome and some of the best I have seen in a while.

The monster was amazing. I was expecting to see something more reptilian, but this thing kicked ass! It didn't need to breathe fire or have atomic breath to be bad-ass, it just owned everything. The scene where Hud sees it close up is fantastic, the detail of it is amazing, I think JJ Abrams has succeeded in giving America it's monster.

title: Excellent
review: I went to see this movie with a couple of friends the other week and I found it to be a superb movie, full of suspense and action. The whole videocam experience was done really well, and really added to the on edge feel that I experienced through the movie, especially when something major happens and the camera is dropped or bouncing as they are running away. These touches made the movie seem and feel more immersive and believable. Character development was well done, and, for me at least, I began to care about what happened to the characters (unlike Blair Witch). Some criticisms was basically the special effects were nothing special, and the monsters in a similar sense were unimaginative. Also the movie is not particularly long at all, and with the fast pace of the movie, leaves you wanting so much more. However these minor complaints shouldn't detract from what it is a suspenseful and entertaining horror film, and in my opinion the one of the best new films of 2008.

title: Fantastic
review:
I have read other reviews that have been quite tough on Cloverfield, I suggest you ignore them, as their main concern is on jittery camera work, which is completely irrelevant.

This is one of the best movies I have seen in a very long time, and I think I've seen them all. The way in which it is shot really captures you and make you believe that that its actually real.

The special effects are fantastic and the acting is very well performed.

There are some bits that I would have liked in there, like some better explanations, and "what happened after" the events that I will not mention.

Overall, very good, well worth you spending cash to see it.

title: Would you expect a clear ending to your own life?
review:
I have so far seen this movie twice--opening night and the weekend of February 1.

And I have loved it both times.

I would recommend this to anyone who can appreciate something different, doesn't mind a little blood, and can withstand a monster movie.

However, if you cannot handle shaky camera angles, missing information, being left in the dark in some areas, and being left speechless, then this film is not for you.

The whole purpose of it is to show what average people would go through in this sort of situation. If this were you, you wouldn't have the monster explained to you, or be told why it attacked or what happens after the camera stops rolling.

You would be going through it just to escape with your life. The few emotional scenes are as if it were you going through it, and the ending to me was fulfilling, because if it had ended any other way it would have been cheesy and without taste.

If you believe that you were going through what these people were and still have everything explained with what you consider a fulfilling ending to your own LIFE, then go ahead, bash the movie.

It was great.

title: Fresh Perspective
review:
Many people had negative comments on the movie because it was shaky, and caused nausea, giddiness and what-not, and thus they had trouble focusing on the movie. However, even though after the movie I felt a little off my feet, I thoroughly enjoyed it. In fact, it was the shakiness of the screen that impressed me most.

The shakiness comes from the video camera in the movie used to document the whole experience, thus it really makes the whole plot realistic, as if you were watching a recorded video of a toddler's birthday party. If the image was crystal clear and unmoving, it will be very obvious that they had used multiple computer graphics, and that everything is thoroughly scripted.

This however, really made me treasure my life while watching the movie, and I literally had slight breathing problems as the thrill got to me. It is no longer a normal Godzilla or alien movie, where the U.S. govt. comes up with some secret weapon to save the day, but from the perspective from innocent people that you see in movies who are running away frantically from the monster.

To say this movie stinks due to a shaky screen means either you are really prone to motion sickness, or you are childish enough to ignore the wonders of the movie.

The only thing I wonder is how a video camera could still work for so long after so many hours and damages.

title: great
review:
one of the best films I've seen in years. ignore all the kids and the losers on youtube and other sites that can't understand what this movie is suppose to be.

the movie is told from the perceptive of civilians, normal every day people; so don't expect a lot of questions to be answered. this is not bad movie making because it was intended to be done in this way!

the camera work is suppose to be shaky, and the shots are meant to be blurly; it gives you enough without showing u too much and i thought that was great.

i loved the idea of knowing only what the characters in the story knew, it felt as if i was right there with them trying to make it out of the city.

if you want everything to be explained to you because you are too dumb to come to your own conclusions, there's millions of other movies u can watch that will give u that; but if u want something a bit different, then watch this.

title: Adults don't need supervision when crossing the street!!!
review:
I'm usually a read the posts kinda guy but I got upset when reading some of the comments from people who didn't like it. Most negative opinions came from the first person camera perspective (which I admit can be nauseating if you have a condition), poor acting, and lack of character development.

The camera action I thought was a necessary component of the film and definitely served the movie - it was not just a gimmick. It explains why we are not hand-held thru some annoying and implausible back-story for where the monster came from and why I felt immersed in the action of the movie.

As for the acting, the characters are like you and me. Partygoers thrust into a situation they had no control over. They're not scientists, military, or superheroes. Just average joes trying to get somewhere, anywhere after a catastrophe.

Character development is useful in stories that span days, weeks, months, and years. In a situation of this magnitude, the characters aren't the center, the situation is the main character. Why do people think there would be time in a movie that spanned 7 hours - most of which was spent running, hiding, fighting - that any character could be developed fully.

I haven't been excited about a movie in a while and I actually avoided all the hoopla surrounding it. My girlfriend wanted to see Juno tonight and I wanted to see this because I remember my friend telling me about the teaser trailer during Transformers. Oddly enough, she preferred this to Juno and we spent the whole car ride talking about the flick. It avoided most horror movie clichÃ©s like using music to heighten tension and having a neat tidy solution to killing the monster. The thought process is simple - there is no warning, no brainiac at the party who happens to know what to do, and no superheroes. I was impressed at how well the visuals and sound added to the movie. A great experience that I will not forget for a long time. People who want explanations should go see Deep Blue Sea or some crap like that.

title: Monster Monster!
review:
So it doesn't quite live up to the hype, but nothing that's had this amount of fan-boy speculation wanked in its general direction could live up to it. The fact that it very nearly does is incredible in itself. Genius marketing campaign aside and taken on its own merits this is thrilling event cinema at its best. Having the entire attack seen from the point of view of a camcorder-wielding everyman is a masterstroke. For the duration of the film you're there at street level among the panic and smoke, only catching glimpses of the threat and thus not being able to quite grasp its anatomy or scale. It causes a palpable sense of terror and it's sustained impressively for most of the run-time, only slipping on the odd occasion when you're shown too much (which is why I'm praying all this talk of a sequel comes to nought).

Of course these shaky-cam deals aren't to everyone's taste, and the character-driven realism might not satisfy people who want some fast cuts of fighter jets and slow-mo explosions in their blockbusters, but these people would be missing out on the most visceral thrill-ride to come out of Hollywood in donkey's yonks. A genuinely frightening and unsettling triumph of a movie, so for once you can (almost) believe the hype.

title: Absolutely worth Seeing
review:
I went into this movie with no expectations,and was impressed.The story is told through the camera eye of an everyday group of people,who feel real.I found the characters to be quite believable and acting as I would expect people in their situation to act.The main character going after the woman he loves doesn't seem too far fetched, since he isn't really brave about it,he's scared,like we all would be.

As far a any "giant monster attacks the city" flick goes,you'd be hard pressed to find one that builds up the tension and delivers a very believable fear,like this movie does.

You ask for a roller coaster ride of intense and scary moments,and this film delivers.

title: An amazing experience that should be explored more often in films
review:
Oh yes, what a movie! Having waited since the first trailer in Transformers, I finally get to see CLOVERFIELD! Considering everyones been bashing it for being similar to Blair Witch, that being one of my favorite movies, you'd think I'd give this a million thumbs up. But, alas, with every movie, there is always those negatives...

THE BEGINNING: Cheesy. Boring. I can understand why they had to do this but, blah. The hype was for the monster, not the story around the people." OH NO!, THE LOVE OF MY LIFE CAME TO MY PARTY AND IS WITH ANOTHER GUY!" It should have just been 10 minutes long, at least showing the connections with everyone fast, not spread out. I think it was just to get the audience to be attached with them so that when the died, they'ed feel remorse.

THE CHAOS: Amazing. Beautiful. The first explosion got me. I could'NT wait for more and more to happen.

THE MONSTER: Good. Creative-ish. It's a good monster and not really what you'd expect, since they never really gave any details. I liked the fact that little monsters came off of it, very smart, maybe unoriginal, but smart. The way the monster is presented is in a way that every monster movie is, give a little glimpse and build up from there. all in all, its a good balance.
