I'd have to see it again, but the monster seems to change scale. At one point it looks like its mouth is big enough to swallow a couple bus's whole, but then it looks just big enough to eat a human. Also, those little monsters, which I assume were its babies. . .what kind of parent drops off its babies in the same place it's under constant attack? I like the ending too, it kind of flips it from a monster movie into a romance. . .in a twisted, Hiroshima/Nagasaki sort of way.

title: Not very original, but much better than I thought I it would be
review:
I saw this film yesterday with my wife and oldest son, mostly because my son wanted to see it so badly. My wife and I both expected a total fanboy blood & gore monster/disaster flick with a bunch of characters only there to die in a loud and gory manner. Granted, for the most part it WAS a fanboy monster/disaster flick but it did manage to impress all three of us and somehow live up to the hype. I hadn't seen or read any websites or message boards so I was able to see the film without knowing any outside theories or leaked information.

Yes, this film borrowed heavily from other films of its kind. I was reminded often of Aliens, The Blair Witch Project (itself an idea copied from Cannibal Holocaust) and the original War of the Worlds. I even saw some parallels from 9/11 video clips. It also had the generic disaster film elements of the troubled relationship that was being saved in the midst of disaster (just like Independence Day and Twister) and the heroic protagonist who disregards safety for the woman he loves. I think everyone knew that the end (spoiler alert!) would show the two troubled lovers one last time to remind us that they were happy not too long before. Despite all of this, I was still impressed with how the film was put together. They did manage to keep it all entertaining and I was never bored. I legitimately cared about these characters and the viewer felt like part of the disaster. I wanted them to escape even though the very beginning of the film had already suggested that they wouldn't make it.

I've seen better films of this genre, but I still recommend Cloverfield to anyone who likes these kinds of movies. Not exactly family-friendly (our 1-year-old didn't come with us) but an entertaining way to spend an evening. I'd probably buy it on DVD. The only complaint I'd have would be the fanboy audience made up of skinny wannabe punkers who wore jeans so low they looked like they'd pooped their pants and identical-looking underage goths talking and answering cell phones during the movie.

title: Mixed feelings...
review: I love going to movies. Flat out. I love movies, and I even get crap for loving indie films where everybody dies in the end (because that is what happens sometimes). But I don't like movies that feel as though they don't have much point. The entire movie just didn't feel like it was going anywhere. It felt a little like a dream that you wake up and don't remember much of, because there's not much for you to remember. And all kinds of controversy comes from the first person camera view. My friends and I all couldn't eat for a good hour after the movie ended. None of us really had motion sickness, but my girlfriend started getting a little dizzy and we had to duck out for a second. It absolutely adds to the intensity and effect, but at a price. Overall I did enjoy it, but it just seemed like more of a rental movie than an $8 blockbuster.

title: Disappointed
review:
The movie, despite (and certainly not thanks to) the shaky camera was enjoyable. But did it live up to the hype it tried to generate? No, at least not for me. Not even close.

The Story can be summarized in just one sentence: "Giant Monster attacks New York and a bunch of friends are caught in the middle." This is what is generally called a "pitch" in the Hollywood biz, and it is supposed to generate interest, and make you want to know more.

Alright. There's been worse teasers in the past. But what's -beyond- this pitch, this one-liner? I mean, you gotta have a script, a story, right? Not here, I am sorry to say. This one sentence, this "pitch", -is- the story, from beginning to end. Oh there are some great moments, visually very impressive, and even some genuine scares (fewer than some people might have you think). But in the end it's going nowhere fast. If you could imagine the bastard child of Godzilla (the Emmerich version) and "Friends", that'd be it, also thanks to the weirdly out of context "humorous" comments made by the cameraman (who, for someone intent on filming "how we all went down", is doing one hell of a crappy job at letting us see what is going on. I swear he was shaking the camera on purpose at times).

Acting is suitable, certainly not Oscar worthy, the script nonexistent, and some rather stupid decisions made by the characters will rapidly leave you uninterested in their fate, letting you picking while talking with your friends who did which "most stupid" action or decision.

In the end, the movie will be probably a hit due to teenage interest in great FX, mix of action-horror (kinda "light" on the horror side) and the bunch of friends stacked against impossible odds. Some could also mention the same recipe used in Lost (more questions than answers thrown in the mix) and doing something "just because it sounded cool at the time" and let people think there is something deep behind it. No wonder with J.J Abrahams at the production.

This being said, rarely have I seen such a vacuum of a story put on the big screen, and that is saying something.

In the end, I cannot bring myself to rate "Cloverfield" any higher than 6, despite having genuinely enjoyed some moments, between the headache inducing camera moves. Great visuals and a few scares do not a movie make. If you look for great visuals, an actual story where you care about people and that makes you think, try to find a theater where "The Mist" is still playing. You'll thank me later.

title: Could have been much better
review: Cloverfield has a good story line, likable characters and plenty of excitement. Unfortunately, the filming is constantly shaky which is a constant reminder that you are watching a movie and therefore you are never really drawn into the movie. In that sense, the idea of making the movie more personal and terrifying by shooting it in this manner simply does not work. As high tech as the camera was, containing infra-red, flood light, lifetime battery and media that withstands a nuclear blast, why not put a gyroscope in it so that the filming could be better than amateurish. I thought the 84 minute length would be too short, but actually it is too long, the filming gets old very quickly. The party scene was great for character development but seemed to drag out too long thanks again to the filming. It's unfortunate that a film with so much potential falls short because it resorted to gimmickery. Too bad it was not done by Spielberg, it would have been much better.

title: What did I just watch?
review: Honestly the only reason I went to see this movie was because my friends wanted to. But I came out knowing nothing more about the story then when I went in. This was just a blair witch style of shooting with an unknown monster that sheds smaller monsters that make people explode when they bite you. But what's worse then no plot is no ending. The movie just cuts off and gives you no explanation to what the monster is, where it came from or why it's tearing up New York city. The special effects were amazing, it was awesome how seamless everything was, but if you watch the trailer then you know all there is to know about Cloverfield.

title: You've got go in with an open mind.
review:
This film is in no way bad at all. The people who you hear hating on the movie have, more often than not, gone into the movie with one of three things.

1. Extremely high hopes because of the marketing campaign, which is never a smart thing to do with a movie.

2. Expecting an average, common Hollywood style movie. Which is exactly what this is not.

3. A lack of diversity in camera angles. These people have not seen enough Paul Greengrass to be prepared for the shaky camera effect.

This being said, if you go in with having a grasp on the shaky cam effect, with hopes of seeing something entertaining, and you're ready for something different, you'll absolutely love this film.

The film is, obviously, a taped recording of the new york attack, thus the tape starts, and ends. That is all there is to it. Instead of comparing this to an average Hollywood film, compare it to a taped recording of one of your family's Christmas'. When you tape that, either the tape runs out of time abruptly, or you just finish, no plausible end is in sight. Thus when this film ends, it ends abruptly and it works with this style.

This film is one you will enjoy in some way. The only way you won't is if you won't let yourself.

title: Succeeds beyond the hype
review:
What a trip. The movie that was the hype-fest of 2007 has finally hit screens, and after the first viewing it left me wanting to see it again. For those of you who aren't quite sure what this movie is trying to do, it is a monster attack from the POV of the man on the street. 'Cloverfield' is the military codename for the event in the area formerly known as Central Park. It follows a group of young people as they are caught in the middle of this disaster, all caught on a camcorder. It feels like you are there. This is not a movie with your traditional plot, nor is it trying to be artful or dodgy. If the movie had a plot, it would have been ruined. Thus, being done as it is, it's immersive (if you don't mind the shakiness at times), intense and, dare I say, realistic.

Though it starts off a bit on the slow side, it gets in your face from the moment the city shakes from its arrival. People die in brutal ways, and their emotion is so real and guttural at times that you wish you could take a nuke to that beast to end their suffering.

The direction of this movie is done incredibly well for the chaotic scenario that it is. It doesn't feel directed at all, with the possible exception of the character "Hud", who is the guy with the camera. Though almost all of his interactions are behind the lens, he still has a great amount of character. His personality comes through even with the movement of the camera. He is comic relief, but you love him all the more for it.

You may be wondering how much of the monster you actually see. Well, I'm not going to spoil anything. But you won't be disappointed in this regard. Go see the film, who cares what people are saying about it, and make your own judgment. Cloverfield is the best monster attack movie ever. It leaves you wanting more.

Great job, Drew Goddard and Matt Reeves. Here's to hoping we see more out of you two.

title: No one left the theater I was in....
review: I didn't realize so many people are afflicted with motion sickness. With the omni-present "Shakey-Cam" so popular on MTV, pretty much every Youtube video --- even in your Aunt Mildred's 75th birthday party footage has more shakes than this movie does. While I agree the beginning was a little too drawn out and the friends going back to "save" the girl was ridiculous, I wouldn't say this movie was a throw away. I saw this on a Sunday night and no one walked out. I over heard 3 people wonder why it ended the way it did (thought the air-raid sirens were "tornado sirens") this film simply wasn't made to answer questions....it was made this way to makes people think for themselves for a change. What if you found a "real" tape someone had shot, brought it home, plopped it in your player and were watching it? No one tells you what's going on...you have to watch and figure what's going on for yourself.

title: Go see it.............
review:
After reading some of the bad reviews on here and in the news paper I was kinda worried that it wouldn't live up to my expectations. I was wrong! The movie was very well done and believable. The camera work made sure you saw the necessary things and didn't frustrate you like I was worried it would.

The creature wasn't cheesy and I actually cared about the characters. The camera does jerk around some but it isn't a reason to avoid the movie and I found myself so engrossed in the story that I hardly even noticed it.

Were there a lot of unanswered questions? Sure there were but not so many that you felt cheated, just enough to make you want more. To me this played into the believability of the whole "this is a tape we found" part of the movie.

title: If your reading this... your fly is down...
review:
Umm. Cloverfield is scary and I got nightmares from it. No seriously, this movie freaked me out. I thought I was going sit in my comfy theater seat and have a good laugh as I watched an overblown version of the Blair Witch Project. I was wrong so wrong.

The fear this movie plays with is the fear of not knowing anything during a catastrophic situation. Something bad is happening and people are dying. You know there is a monster, you know that it is huge, but you don't know where it came from or why its attacking. Most monster/alien movies are told from the military or a scientific point of view and experts come up with way to defeat the beast. Cloverfield is about being on the ground level of a horrible event. It's about people running for their lives from things that they have know time to study or understand. There also parts that will be very reminiscent of September, 11 footage, which also plays into the formula of fear. As if the giant unknown monster wasn't enough there are some more nasty surprises in store.

Sure there's a love story involved. Also, in classic horror movie style, the main characters embark on a mission that places them in even greater personal danger than they are already in, but that's all par for the course. The frantic camera angles will make you kind of ill, but it was less annoying than the Bourne Ultimatum.

This was a great movie, the premise worked and exceed my expectations. This was what the American version of Godzilla should have been. Eat that Broderick! Unlike the Blair Witch, I would go see the is movie again and own it proudly. Will there be a sequel? While this movie can stand on its own, but I can see how they could "f" it up with a sequel. So in the meantime enjoy!

title: Clever, but still not enough to make it great.
review:
I would never consider myself a critic for movies, but just someone that enjoys them, and goes to them on the premise that I want to be entertained and see something cool.

Clever filming and creature design weren't enough for this movie to be worth the time or money I invested in it. It can't be helped to draw parallels to Blair Witch Project in terms of buzz or how it was filmed. As one user said before this was indeed the better movie, but I felt cheated. If anything could be learned from the home video feel that both movies have it is this - it is a gimmick. It really didn't add to the movie. I felt that it would have been considerably more interesting to have the home movie be and introduction to the main movie - cut to a recovery team. To Aliens to you? Okay... then perhaps something else. I wasn't the only one that was irritated after spending the time to watch this. I have never heard as much cussing at the end of a movie as I did after watching this all the way through. The crowd was clearly as displeased as I, and I tend to have a bit of a snobbish taste for movies, and think tailoring a movie to a test crowd is stupid, but it left me wondering what those people thought.

In the end great idea - in fact clever, but clever can't carry the movie in this instance. I felt nothing for the characters, in fact was waiting for them to get wiped out by the beasties, and was disappointed they didn't. Ending was too Blair Witch, and those that saw this you have to admit it was. The only thing I thought was worthwhile was getting to see the Ironman trailer, but still wasn't worth eight dollars to see. Rent it, don't buy it. I see no re-watch value in this.

title: Sci-Fi Thriller and Indie give birth to the exciting creature that is "Cloverfield"
review:
In a film where a giant monster attacks Manhattan, there are a lot of questions. What is it? Where did it come from? Why is it being destructive? "Cloverfield" doesn't want to answer these questions, it just wants you to ask them.

It's a hard concept to grasp, but this film, brought to the screen by LOST's J.J. Abrams and his property Bad Robot, doesn't want you to get caught up in the details. Your job is to experience what goes on and react to it and for much of the film. Sure, it's frustrating, it doesn't make sense, but Abrams and director Matt Reeves are aiming for that for a reason.

As soon as disaster strikes, images and feelings of 9/11 are conjured. With a cast of unknowns and a single camcorder as the source of the images, "Cloverfield" feels very real. While the film takes off from there as a monster attack/alien invasion, for a majority of it you are interested in what's happening to these people and how they're handling the situation. There is a lot of stuff that's hard to believe, but without it there's not much of a film. In general, the dialogue and the reactions of the people are very realistic and for a majority of the film keeps you on the edge of your seat.

In a sense, "Cloverfield" is a sci-fi, fictional United 93, a gritty retelling of events (although false). The undertones of tragedy are difficult and it's amazing how these young actors are able to convey such realism.

"Cloverfield" takes several different styles and genres and fuses them into something new and successful. It is the kind of film that if imitated in any way by any future film will clearly not get by without constant references to this film. It is exciting and innovative and exactly the kind of twisting of the norm that Hollywood needs to stay fresh while staying successful. It's not mind-blowing or genius, but it's got style. It goes to show that big blockbuster-style films can be done in small independent film-style ways.

title: I know this is Fantasy, but COME ON!!!
review: First of all, let me say that I understand the moving and shaking of the film in Cloverfield, because it is supposed to render the experience of the first person account of the beast attack on Manhattan. But COME ON!!! I realize this is a fantasy movie, but DAMN, must the characters always be in the same place the monster is? I live in New York, and anyone who has ever been here knows that Manhattan has enough places to hide, both above and below ground, and run whereby a person can avoid the beast. But these characters just happen to always end up in the right places and the right time where the monster is. Also, someone please tell me two things--why and how the dude with the camera manage to keep shooting through every attack and from hours on end, and what's with the alien, monster-sized locusts that's running around the subway tunnels? I must admit, the movie had its moments of suspense. The characters and the monster(s) needed way more development. But let me not read too much into this movie and waste anymore of my time and energy--nice idea, crappy movie.

title: Spoiler
review: I enjoyed the movie so much I watched it twice. It is amazing what you see the second time around. I thought the movie was done well. At first the camera moving around was kind of disorienting but I eventually got use to it and got sucked right into the suspense and action. It is not anything like the Blair Witch Project except for the camcorder view. I wish there were more movies like this. All too often the teasers they show are not even in the movie and this is something that ticks me off. However, this movie gave little in teasers but what they gave was in the movie. Moving along, one of the controversies is where did the creature come from. Did it come from a deep sea trench. Did it come from space. Well actually it came from space. When you see the end of the movie when Beth and Rob are at Coney Island the it shows a panoramic view of the ocean. Right before the camera pans to Beth and Rob on the ferris wheel there is a large splash out in the ocean in the upper right hand of the frame. You have to be quick to see this.

title: Everything War of the Worlds Should Have Been
review:
Wow. This is one of the best sci-fi films I have ever seen. Easily the best creature film. It was a truly intense, original, and scary experience. This film was a lot like Children of Men. It was fast paced and just didn't let up. It is done in a under utilized (thank god) style that suites it.

This film did something that I haven't seen since Alien, it didn't show the antagonist fully, until the very end of the film. All you see are little bits and pieces. This movie is all about what you don't see rather than what you do. The effects were top notch and the whole film just left me feeling drained.

This is what I was looking for when I saw the oh-so disappointing War of the Worlds. Cloverfield is much more human and in depth. War of the Worlds is for the "I need closure and happy endings like oxygen" crowd. Cloverfield is for the "I like original, daring, and revolutionary movies" crowd.

To describe it in terms of other films it's: War of the Worlds (But better)meets Children of Men meets The Blair Witch Project.

title: Wow
review:
I went into this movie expecting a decent film, instead I was greeted with something completely unexpected: a movie worth paying to see.

The point of view, while not completely original in practice, was incredibly well played out. At no time are you taken outside of the situation for any reason at all. At the same time, however, it could be slightly irritating to not see certain things clearly.

The visuals were amazing and the acting was top notch. The choice to leave out any "all star" actors from the project was an excellent choice.

I would recommend to anyone that enjoys an intelligent, as well as entertaining, night at the movies go and see Cloverfield A.S.A.P.

And for the record, although I have already seen it denied as such, it is NOT a Godzilla remake.

title: The Best PG-13 Sci-fi/Horror Film in Years
review:
Let's be totally honest here... PG-13 horror movies absolutely suck with very few exceptions. The characters are annoying and unlikable, the acting is usually bad, and the suspense is terrible. I think this is all due to toning these films down so that they're acceptable for a wider age range, but it's still a pain. This movie goes against that rule fully and completely.

I loved so much about this film. The POV cam gave it that real feeling, kind of like watching a home movie of a UFO landing or something like that. The story is simple but it has a right to be as this is only documenting a group of people trying to survive these attacks. I only have one complaint about this film and it's the acting, it was very rough at times and completely unbelievable but the rest of the film made up for it. I will definitely being seeing this again.

Anyone who is a fan of films like Gojira and The Host or The Blair Witch Project and Behind the Mask will find a place for this film somewhere in their heart. See it on the big screen!

title: The previews don't do this movie justice...
review: Cloverfield was absolutely fantastic. It was everything you could want in a movie, and more. The actors were all great, and made the movie feel as if you were there. The actors were also easy to relate to and really made you feel for them. The documentary filming aspects were cool and the special effects rocked.This is by far the best movie I have seen in years,and it may even be the best movie of 2008...I read that it's estimated to make $52million this weekend and that it could be the highest weekend box office people have ever seen.I'm ecstatic about this movie and recommend it to anyone who loves excellent films.Cloverfield has set a new boundary for films of it's kind. If you want to start the new year off right ...Go see Cloverfield!

title: Best Damn Monster Movie from Amerika in Decades
review:
After like 30+ years of being a kaiju and giant monster movie fan and an adult now that watches about like a 100 films a year in the cinema as part of my life/job - I gotta say, this ones one of the damn best monster flicks amerika has ever produced. (with the exception of one, dumb, unnecessary, 5-minute scene - you'll know what I'm talking about when you see it.)

With its inventive storytelling device *the entire film remains true to its hand-held camera first-person perspective!* (unfortunately tho' shot from the perspective of some white, financially privileged NYC kids as the protagonists, who are ridiculous/annoying unto themselves) and in doing so, its managed to revive the sense of thrill and the unknown in the genre and the overwhelming collapse of the order of expectation and delivery, while still being a totally effective genre-piece. I can't help but think that this is what "Creature from 20,000 Fathoms" or the original "Godzilla" must have been like seeing in the theatre when they came out last century.

I just witnessed it last night on the 3rd(?) largest screen/soundsystem on the west coast (yes the Cinerama!) and came out pretty well stunned. No work of high-art or whatever, but an amazing reinvention of a genre that has been pretty lame for decades. Props to Matt Reeves!

title: It was entertaining, but the logistics were off
review:
As a New York guy, I have to question not only the plan of the main characters but also the logistics. Why anyone would stay at the Spring St. stop for 20 minutes and then FINALLY start running through the subway is beyond me. And how exactly did they get to 59th st and Columbus Circle from Spring St. so quickly? And was the quarantine space in the Manhattan Mall at 33rd and B'way? If so, how did they get there? I could've ended the movie in 5 minutes - instead of going to B'klyn over the bridge, they could've walked (btw, no respectable New Yorker would "walk" anywhere in a situation like that, and the characters did nothing but walk) the opposite direction to the World Trade Center and taken the PATH Train to New Jersey, and thus we would have been able to watch the whole thing while not trying to adjust our eyes to the blur of the moving camera. Btw, Rob was selfish as hell to go after Beth the whole time - he killed Marlena and Hud because of that.

Even though I was just all over the movie for poor planning, I must say the entertainment factor was still high. It was still a creepy movie packed with great scenes and good surprises.

title: An Experiment In Film-making Indeed.
review:
Rob is about to go away to Japan for a new job, so his friends decide to throw him a good-bye party. The party is quickly disturbed by an earthquake, which is later discovered to be from a giant unknown creature terrorizing the city of New York.

To describe this film would be saying what everyone has been saying since its release. Cloverfield is Godzilla meets The Blair Witch Project. This is not a bad thing; to negatives make a positive remember? If it weren't for films like Blair Witch we wouldn't have Cloverfield, then again if it weren't for films like Cannibal Holocaust, we wouldn't have films like Blair Witch. What Cloverfield does is take this idea and spin it on its head. Cloverfield is an experiment in film-making and it is quite successful.

Just like Blair Witch the film starts off with a message that this footage was found and we are about to watch this uncut material. For the first 20 or so minutes we get character introductions, these are the people who will be seeing the destruction through; these are the eyes and ears. We don't get much characterization, but enough to know who's who in the grand scheme of things. We see a romantic sub-plot that will no doubt become more important as the film goes on; we meet our cameraman, a sarcastic guy who doesn't have the guts to talk to this one girl, this one girl who is only there to meet up with her other friends later. We also see the main characters brother and girlfriend, but we never get to really know these people. Which is fine, we only get a glimpse into their lives because it's all about the destruction right?

The destruction itself is very well done. This is where all the money went. No high tech cameras, just special effects for destruction for New York. Every bit of it was realistic. I was scared this was going to be another monster running around New York bit that Godzilla pulled on us, and yes while it is that, the film is much more. Not once did I ever believe anything in Godzilla, here I was entertain and engaged. I felt like I was actually watching real footage. The unknown actors were a good choice, it adds to the "found footage" feel.

The monster itself is cool looking as well. You never get a full view of it until the very end, but it's the bits and pieces of it that make it scary. Reeves builds up great tension as the monster is roaming the city and we see the destruction from a distance, yet we still have fear that it could kill us.

In addition to the giant creature, there are little ones. Apparently they are parasites. They seem like giant spider-crabs to me and they are quite scary. I'm glad that Abrams and crew decided to go with something original and not re-tell Godzilla. This was a brilliant choice and helped the marketing of the film immensely. The sound is sharp and loud. Specifically when the army blasts away at the creature, it makes the viewer feel like they are there.

I never once felt sick with the camcorder shaking around everywhere, but others in the theatre were. They were also disappointed with the ending, as half the theatre moaned and asked if that was it. I don't know what they were expecting, maybe some answers? Well you won't get any here. We saw the destruction through the eyes of this camera; we don't know what's going on. The characters don't know what's going on, they speculate that it could be alien, or government secret. There is no scientist with a white lab coat here explaining what the monster is or where it came from. If you're content with this then you'll love this film.

Unlike Snakes On A Plane, which I loved by the way, this film lives up to the hype expected by the fans. All the speculations can go to rest Cloverfield is here. Now let new speculations arise.

title: Cloverfield..........
review: Why do people need to have everything wrapped up in a nice neat bow for them? After reading some of these reviews for the movie I must say that America is getting dumber and dumber by the minute. Use your imagination people!!!! That's what makes the movie what it is!!! And the camera work puts you right in the middle of the action. I'm really surprised at some of the negative reaction to one of the best monster movies made in the States in a long long time. The comments about the choice of actors baffles me as well. Having virtual no-names helps to make it seem more "realistic". It gives you no clue of who is going to live and who is going to get eaten. The ending for the genre for movie is perfect, and it leaves room for a sequel.

title: Monstrous Shakycam
review:
As far as pushing the boundaries of convention goes, I've still got to give it to Blair Witch Project for a simple reason: its hand-held camera-work does not inspire me to scream "Hold the heck still!" at the screen. Hud, the cameraman in Cloverfield, has got to be addicted to caffeine for all the shakiness and inability to keep the camera on something for more than 1.6 seconds. Or else it's ADD. I'm not one of those weaklings who got dizzy from The Bourne Ultimatum, but I appreciate being able to see what I'm looking at if the whole point of shooting a movie on video is to make it feel like you're actually there. But then the producer, J.J. Abrams, is famous for never making anything too clear (as evidenced by his TV shows "Lost" and "Alias").

This is a monster movie, along the lines of Godzilla or The Host, but with a twist. Everything we see is purported to be a videotape found after the monster eats Manhattan. The video starts as a collection of farewell messages to Rob, a 20-something who has a million 20-something friends and who is moving to Japan for work. His best friend Hud is running the camera, interviewing Rob's pals, and hitting on Marlena, who ain't hitting back. Then the entire city shakes and the lights go out, rudely awakening all the characters out of an awkward situation involving Rob and his friend (and more) Beth. Everybody's probably seen what happens next - explosions in the distance, panic in the streets, and the head of the Statue of Liberty crashes in front of Rob's building. Aside from this very sentence, I'll not make any comparisons to 9/11 - scared people in a city running away from something bad does not inherently carry political or social meaning. This is a monster movie and like any monster movie, people have to run away from the monster en masse.

What makes this one different, though, is not just that it's shot with a camcorder. This is a special monster movie because we rarely see the monster and therefore are stuck with the characters and we learn only what they learn. This story is about the human tragedy that is glossed over in all the old Godzilla flicks where someone screams, "GOJIRA!" and takes off. What about that man's family? Is his home destroyed by the creature? Those other movies are usually about scientists and military people scheming to kill whatever beast is plaguing Tokyo now. From Mothra to Independence Day, that's the formula. Formula is turned on its head when we stop caring if the General will drop an A-bomb on the thing and we start seeing the battle in the streets between average people and the boar-sized insects that live on the huge thing's back. One scene in a dark subway tunnel is one of the best of its kind, where the stalking creatures aren't there and then, suddenly, they are. See The Descent for more night vision camcorder scariness...

Special credit must go to the special effects artists on this movie. With maybe a couple exceptions, everything that would be fantastical and impossible in another movie looks perfectly real here. The bugs in the subway don't look like a special effect that we are meant to admire, they look like vicious, man-eating creatures from another dimension or something and they really are terrifying, the same way a rabid dog staring you down is terrifying. The effects tricked my brain into thinking everything was real and I can't remember the last time that happened. Cloverfield has a really simple story at its core, about a small group of survivors looking for an injured friend, and it has some rather annoying camera-work (which is absolutely worse than just motion sickness-inducing camera-work), but it is effective as an intense adventure movie and the totally natural-looking effects prop up the characters who are basically operating without a plot most of the time. This isn't a perfect movie, but it is a ride; that cannot be denied. I only hope Paramount doesn't sequel-ize it and make themselves a franchise not unlike the Godzilla movies that inspired it.

http://www.movieswithmark.com

title: Top-notch 21st century monster flick
review: I was really looking forward to this movie, and it didn't disappoint me a bit. It's got everything I hoped for: an original monster, a breathtaking pace, genuine shocks and scares, some poignancy, some mystery, and absolutely no snarky condescension or cheesiness. This is a stripped-down, kick-ass dynamo of a movie experience unlike any giant creature flick I've ever seen, and I've been watching them since the 70s. It takes a little time to set up and get rolling, but once it's out of the gate it doesn't let up for a moment. The use of the hand-held camera gives it terrific immediacy and believability, since we see only as much of the creature and its rampage as the characters underfoot do. They're a pretty typical batch of well-heeled kids, used to getting immediate information on everything, and when they're suddenly plunged into violent chaos they react with terror and confusion. Yet despite that, they attempt a heroic rescue, acting with the kind of courage ordinary people show in the face of disaster every day. (Yes, some sequences do evoke the imagery of 9-11, but I wish people would quit sounding so indignant about that; surely it's off the sacred list and into the pool of legitimate film topics by now. The Cloverfield/9-11 = Godzilla/Hiroshima analogy ought to be enough to settle the point.) I liked them a lot more than I expected to (in fact I completely choked up when one character had to give his mom some very bad news) and felt completely pulled into the headlong rush of the story. It's as convincing a portrait of an event like this as I can imagine, and will leave you gasping for breath. I only have two credibility quibbles, in fact: the overly-helpful soldier and the apparent army of available helicopters. But those are minor. [[--I'm not going to say anything about the monster, except that it's none of the things people have been speculating it was, it's 100% cool, and I can't wait for the action figure.]] --I can't imagine anyone who really loves daikaiju cinema being disappointed with this: it's a fine, scary piece of work. Too nihilistic? Could be, but these are dark times, and we already know this film was intended to mirror the right-now dread and tension of our War on Terror landscape. There's no reassurance from those in power, the military doesn't know any more than the characters do, and all you get in return for facing the worst is the close-up rush of the adventure. Which, after all, may be all you ever get.

title: Cloverfield was good
review: Well, I admit, I expected to come out nauseous after this movie. Amazingly, I didn't. I thought it was perfect. Much different then what you expect. A lot of people were angry that there was no story behind the monster, well what do you expect, it is done with a hand held camera in first person, your average New Yorker won't know what's happening. A lot of people were angry at the fact that you didn't get to see the movie that much, well what do you want the camera man to do, turn around and get trampled by the monster trying to get a good shot of it? I wouldn't. The monster, even with the little screen time, was brilliant in design, the monsters it dropped were really cool, the way people would explode if they got bitten was really cool. Above all, this movie was unique and very well made. So why do i give this a 7/10 instead of 10/10, well (oh no, bad news!) Why would the group go to save a girl that across town were the monster is (I would run away).When they find the girl, she has a steel bar through her, she should have been dead of blood loss. When the monster hits the helicopter it crashes, no one should have survived that crash. Why would the monster only nibble on the camera man instead of eating him whole? To finish this off, a lot of people were disappointed with the ending, But like the the monster's origin, how would a camera capture the monster dying (if it does) if a bridge just collapsed on it? Well, I liked the movie, others may, others may not but I liked it.

title: Good, but could have been lots better.
review:
Saw Cloverfield this weekend. I was really excited about it as I have been a huge fan of J.J. Abrams. However, I did find the shooting style to be extremely distracting. I mean I agree that it added a certain visceral experience of really being there, but after a while it became obnoxious and distracting. I just think that there were better ways to tell the same story with out being so sickening with the motion of the camera. All in all I would recommend seeing it as long as you aren't given to bouts of motions sickness.

The other problem is that it becomes hard to believe that with such harrowing things happening to these people that they would make the choice to continue filming it. I mean understand the need to suspend disbelief, but this was a convention that was just a little much. At one point Hud, one of the Characters is told to put the camera down, he films himself saying if this the last they see of him he is dead, but his putting down the camera doesn't look any different than when he did have the camera. I can't believe that if people are that scared, that they would make the effort to continue filming especially while trying to outrun something that is trying to bite their heads off.

title: Pretty good, all things considered.
review:
Alright, so I've read a lot of reviews on here giving this a 1 or 2 star rating because it's not a deep, thought-provoking film wrought with wit, symbolism, or metaphors. Make no mistake, reviewers, this is not an art film; this is an unconventional action movie filmed from the perspective of a group of survivors in the case of a giant monster attacking NYC.

I see complaints that the characters make poor decisions, which I agree with. The truth, though, is that you don't know what you'd do in a situation like that, where your body is getting ravaged by inordinate amounts of adrenaline because the situation you're in is getting more and more horrible by the second. I applauded them because they had the strength to carry on, to be honest.

And to the complaint of "the camera is too shaky", THAT'S WHAT IT WOULD BE LIKE IF ONE GUY WERE FILMING THIS MOVIE FROM A HAND-HELD CAMCORDER. I was honestly more annoyed about the few really steady, spectacular shots in the film because it would have been so hard for someone to pull them off with a camcorder and no tripod.

(And here's the reason I clicked the spoiler box) My biggest problem with the movie, however, was the way Hud's death was handled. The guy froze, sure, I can believe that, but the monster didn't even try to go after Beth or Rob. It did, however, lead to (in my opinion) the best moment of the whole film though: the auto-focus that can't seem to choose whether to focus on Hud's face or the blades of grass. That shot threw shivers down my spine. For real.

All in all, I loved this movie for what it was, and I can't wait for the inevitable sequel(s).

title: What the hell was that..?
review:
What's the buzz, tell me what's a happening, what's the buzz ...

To put it simply, Cloverfield is Blair With Project and Godzilla with big budget. Everyone who saw this movie in the cinema either found it very creatively executed or a waste of time. I found it intriguing and engaging.

Although at the beginning of the movie, not knowing what to expect, I felt dizzy after a few minutes into the scenes. I had to close my eyes occasionally to keep myself from getting nauseated. Just as I was regretting a little at this technique of story telling then it got all exciting and I forgot all about the swinging and shaking of the camera.

It was done pretty well and believable throughout the entire movie. The only thing that I expected more of was the monster itself. I thought it could have looked better.

If this had been just another monster movie like Godzilla, War Of The Worlds or King Kong then there wouldn't have been so much hype about it to make it one of the most outstanding creature features for all times.

title: About to be what expected
review:
I love Monster Movies... and with the CG so highlay advanced as it is today, the effect was mind-blowing in an unsurprising way. A hint to the moviegoer: do not expect anything "Great", however, enhjoy a classic, immensely advanced 84 minutes of terror, shock, and unanswerwed qustions in the current state-of-minds from every Joe Blow paying his ticket price for this "non-beaking" film.

Before I sign off, kudos to J.J. Abramms and his geniuses practices, and "well-down" to Matt Reeves for the ride that was obviously not his movie. He hung on well as the barrier towards himself and the rest of the prying world. Kudos to yo all. Best of luck and I look forward to future projects from Bad Robot Productions and/or J.J. Abrams'. Best of Luck.

title: Cloverfield - not normally my cup of tea - but in this case.......
review:
Excellent film. A story of friendship, bravery, doing things because they are right, not because they are easy. Ultimately one of hopelessness - and I guess that would be my beef - - some indication that the humans were getting the upper hand would have been nice, and make the sacrifice of the friends worthwhile.

As it is, their friendship and subsequent "mission" to rescue Beth became futile.

The film was well made and got the viewer completely engrossed in the quartet and their progress through Manhattan. The warning about motion sickness due to the hand-held camera is well meant I am sure but after a few minutes I became used to the effect an it certainly added an element of tension. Th cut-backs to the previous film, showing the couple in happier times on Coney Island was a nice touch.

It was also good to have no overt camera product placements - but maybe a real video-camera would not have survived the things this one did, so no manufacturer could claim it!

The benefits of having a charged cell phone battery at all times led to one of the (few) humorous moments as folk were looting an electronic store for plasma TVs whilst all our hero wants is a battery.

The PG rating is probably fair - no bad language - but any parent taking an 8 year old in needs talking to!!

title: Blair Witch With Godzilla!
review:
Five young New Yorkers throw their friend a going-away party the night that a monster the size of a skyscraper descends upon the city. Told from the point of view of their video camera, the film is a document of their attempt to survive the most surreal, horrifying event of their lives.

With an ingenious trailer from J.J. Abrams himself, along with clever marketing, all of us can assume that the film may not be as good as the trailer and marketing. Well, we were wrong. Not only is the film as clever as the trailer, it's also a lot of fun! It's nice to see a great film in January, don't you agree?

If you are still in doubt of seeing the film, let me continue on my review. Here's my take on the whole handy cam: Using this in the film makes it feel so realistic. During the action scenes, you feel like you're really there! I know a lot of people said this before but it really does! My only complaint is that it's sometimes annoying when the whole camera shakes around. Some might get stomach cramps.

As for the production values, they are really well done. The visual effects are amazing. The action scenes are unbelievable. What else can I say? If you're worried about not seeing the monster, don't. You'll see it. You'll see it up close. And I thought I would never say this but I really like the character development! I would never though character development could take place in a handy cam.

I'm also surprised to say, when we feel like we're there, that I actually felt scared. I had chills in my spine when something bad is happening. I laughed when characters popped up jokes. I felt sad when characters died. Also, there's no origin to this story, if you're looking for it. The performances by the unknown cast is above average. The most notable, is Lizzy Caplan, all the way.

It's just a big monster movie! So, the film is entertaining, funny, sad, scary, heart-pulsing...The handy cam was a great idea and the action great! What else would you want from a monster movie? This is the movie to see this week! Watch it now!

title: Great movie!
review: What a blast watching this movie was! Edge of your seat the whole time. It was very unique and the action and effects were great. This is an excellent take on the modern day monster movie. The filming is a little Blair witch-esquire but it works. The characters aren't all that much to remember but the movie as a whole makes up for it. I highly recommend this movie to everyone. If your looking for a cheesy cookie cutter movie with the same plot and lame dialogue look elsewhere. It was very new and creative as well as refreshing to watch. Interesting thing is as Roger Ebert pointed out, if you watch the Government message in the beginning how does this movie ever make to the big screen?

title: Go In With The Right Concept, And You Will Not Be Disappointed!!!
review:
I went to see this movie yesterday and I have to say, it was pretty solid. Not too over the edge, but just enough to keep you interested. This is the type of movie you may watch once or twice and never want to watch it again. But I mean that in a good way.Even though the movie starts slow, it ends good. Really before I get into the comment, to everyone who says it has a lot of unanswered questions, you didn't understand the movie. The movie is from the point of view of a group of people who were affected. They didn't know what happened. They couldn't get an answer on what it was so why would you know? Thats why I say go in with a first person's view of the movie and you will like it. I must say I wont give nothing away. The monster looks OK, not cheesy or great. The story is entertaining. The actors do a great job. And despite what people say, the ending is quite good(To those who have seen it, what did you expect?).

P.S.-As a side note, I read that they are talking about doing a sequel to this movie. Not another monster, but from the same attack from a different group of people's perspective. Which i think is interesting.

title: Lives up to the hype
review:
Going into the movie, I didn't know to much about it. But when the movie first started I thought to myself this is probably gonna suck, and I thought I was right. But as the movie progressed and picked up pace I found myself at the edge of my seat and constantly wondering what was gonna happen next. The Effects were magnificent, and story was great. The best thing about the movie turned out to be the worse thing for my stomach and my head, as you will come to find out if you decided to watch it, is the camera styling of the movie is refreshing, and brings the whole experience alive making it just that more epic. But it did leave me very queasy and with quite a headache cause I get motion sick very easy, but it was well worth it, and I would gladly do it all over again.

For the first time in along time, I can honestly say the movie was well worth the 6.50 So if you haven't seen it you should cause its diffidently a movie a thousand times more amazing on the big screen.

title: Good movie..but the film type takes away from the story
review: I went to see Cloverfield the day it came out. Just like "I am Legend", its trailers were shown all over TV and the internet. It was almost impossible not to see it. I go with my friends and we get in the movie. The beginning begins with the characters getting ready for a man's going-away- party (it was hard to remember their names, as it was very fast paced). Well, this thing attacks and they're stuck in the middle of it. So this thing just starts coming at everything and destroys New York. Then, it starts dropping these little monster things and they start attacking people. They attack one of the group's friends and she eventually has to be killed...but why???? It doesn't explain anything...i mean nothing. It doesn't say why, it doesn't say how....nothing. So if you've been reading this than you're probably thinking "wow this movie must suck". Not quite, i liked it...except for that it didn't explain anything. The story was great, and I liked the Blair- Witch type filmography. But with doing it like that, they have to drop elements of the story. If you did not like how the Blair Witch was filmed, then you probably will not like Cloverfield.

title: ....This film will have impact and may keep you awake....
review:
I have never had an experience like Cloverfield before. Blair Witch didn't compare, because it was never as real as the terror I felt watching this movie.

I was there with these characters. To get as close as I can to a comparison, I would say it was like watching 9/11 videos and "The Host". But even then, don't just take it off that comparison. Watch this movie.

Even now I feel disturbed, shaky and paranoid. It was an amazing experience and the re watch value comes from wanting to see more clues and hints behind the monster and the attack. The first time you are just way too wrapped up in the drama unfolding.

And yes I can see already this movie will split people in two. Some will love it, some will hate it and both sides will be passionate.

They should be passionate, because this movie evokes strong emotions, and in my opinion, it is one of the greatest monster/disaster movies ever made.

title: Just watched the movie
review:
Hey all, just watched the movie. ( I work at a theatre and put the print together and we previewed it after i was done). I am serious and really did just watch the flick. I thought it was great and this post will have a few spoilers.

Well the big question in my mind leading up th this movie was: what does the monster look like. Well we never really get a great look at it. Which i thought was a good idea. it go myself and the other people i was watching it with into the movie because in this situation you wouldn't get a good look. Although in one scene we get a close look at one of the creatures. yes i said one of them. there are at least 2 different sizes of monster, maybe three i will have to see it again to be sure. We have the GIANT one running around the buildings, then we have th little critters(actually about the size of a big dog) and possibly one around the size of a house, maybe a little bigger. we see it on the news and Hud, the character carrying the camera gets a few good shots. I will admit i caught myself yelling at him to turn left or right so we could see the damn thing a few times.

over all it was a believable story. in a lot of monster movies you follow the military or scientists and get explanation as to what it is attacking the city. not here. i will say one of my favorite lines of all time comes from this movie. One of the girls ask " what was that?" as the monster goes by, and Hud replies " it was a terrible thing" i laughed my but off. we follow the average joes in this movie and see it from the civilian p.o.v. which i enjoyed a lot.

I liked this movie a lot and cant wait to see it again. And when the DVD comes out i am so buying it t o watch the behind the scenes stuff so i can get a clear look at those pesky critters running around NYC.

title: Worst movie of the century
review: completely spoiled my Saturday night. All the time I was watching this movie my head was spinning and my stomach went upset. I literally came back home and puked. Awful ending, awful story, there is really no story in it. What a waste of time and money. I just can't believe how it got 7.8 rating on IMDb. I felt I got cheated by IMDb users because of this rating. Is this a reflection of how bad the young people's tastes are these days. OH my God. This movie really sucks big time and I don't even want to call it a movie. Sucks Sucks and Sucks. Sucks big time. I am glad I did not see that blair witch project or whatever as someone mentioning in their reviews. please tell me people why did u like it, whats so thrilling in this movie. whoever gave this movie a good rating, I wonder are they really human?

title: A new approach to movie making and filled with strengths and weaknesses...
review: Cloverfield was my first ever movie watched in a first person's point of view. i was very impressed and engrossed into the movie as though i was also experiencing the mayhem. nice cinematography but had errors as in lack of depth in storyline and run time ( 70 minutes including a 7 minutes of credits). but once again the flaws i mentioned might not be flaws but just my lack of experience in watching such films. but in a nut shell, it was a 70 minutes roller coaster ride which roots you to your seats. could have given it a 8.5 for the rating if not for what i saw as "flaws". nevertheless watch it the Dolby surround system was a huge strength for this movie has it makes you 'feel' the movie. overall, good effort.

title: What is wrong with people?
review:
This movie and all found footage crap, is just that CRAP! This had very terrible acting. It was not scary. It was hard to watch in the first place, and that is why found footage sucks. The director cheapens the movie for this reason to make a quick buck. People fall for this crap. Nothing at all that people praise about these movies are correct. Just like smokers making excuses to keep smoking.

Waste of money. Glad I never went to the theater to see it. PG-13 so called horror, are not scary in the first place. Just a bunch of noise to make you jump, and that is it. To see this still up at 7 rating is pathetic, that people rate this crap higher than the better movies. This site is still messed up with ratings. They are never going to fix it.

The only spoiler of this movie I am going to say is it has massive amount of shaky camera that is really no need for it at all. Ruins the whole movie.

title: Unwatchable...
review:
I cannot be, of course, considered an expert in cinematography, but from my POV it was one of the worst movies I've ever seen. I understand that it was specially filmed this way, but for my own eyes it appeared to be unbearable. I couldn't watch that; after 25 minutes or so it began heavily hurting my eyes.

The plot was also quite unsatisfying - everyone is scared and keeps running, nothing is clear, etc. Pretty lame and primitive, if you ask me.

A complete waste of time in the end.

title: So Terrible
review: This film would be better when they didn't use camera to record !

title: I've seen a few annoying movies, but this one takes the cake.
review: The fact that the story is told using the "handheld video camera" plot device is bad enough— especially for an action / horror movie, where the technique stretches the willing suspension of disbelief past the breaking point — but the true weakness of this movie is that the viewer can't sympathize with the characters. In fact, this viewer was hoping after the first 10 minutes that one or more of the main characters —self-absorbed millennial yuppies — would just die, please. After 18 minutes of mindlessly banal banter at a party before anything remotely suspenseful even happens, I was also wishing the same fate on the director and screenwriter. I'll give the movie two stars rather than one because of the decent production values.

title: imagine a very good hand-held version of "The Birds"
review:
First of all, "Cloverfield" is probably the last title that I would envision for a horror/sci-fi movie. But aside from the fact that it is, there are two specific things that I find very impressive about the film. The main aspect of course is that it's shot with a hand-held camera and contains a cast of unknowns so as to create very realistic sense. But I also would say that it follows the same structure as Alfred Hitchcock's movie "The Birds". You see, during the first fifteen or so minutes, both movies look as though they're going to be romantic comedies. But then the horrific element arrives and dominates the rest of the movie. And both films have the same sort of ending (although different things happen).

Anyway, this is more than a monster movie. I totally recommend it.

title: How long until you started rooting for the monster?
review: Fabulous Idea, Stupid Execution ---------How is it possible to make such a bad film from such a good idea? How is it that the misleading trailer is the best part of the movie? How long does it take before you want the cameraman dead? When is it possible to care about these lame teenagers? Who would go back for any reason? When will this endless use of bad hand-held camera in feature films ever end? Why call it Cloverfield? How many miles can you run with a hole in your shoulder that big? How many sequels can you squeeze out of this concept? How long until you started rooting for the monster? How many times can you lean on LOST to boost your other cruddy projects? One last chance Abrams, get STAR TREK right or go back to TV.

title: Excellent Movie!
review:
I really don't understand why people didn't really like this movie. It's not your ordinary movie. The way the director set it up is you're basically watching a top secret government document. It's purpose was not to be filmed like every other movie, and in my opinion, it worked out better that way. Filming the whole movie on a video camera was the better decision. It makes it seem more real to the audience, like it actually happened. People compare it to the blair witch. How long ago did that movie come out again? I thought it was refreshing.

The actors were nothing special, which was better. They acted like normal, everyday people going through the same problems everyone goes through (minus a monster attack). Having big time actors would have made the film distracting and not realistic.

The monster itself was creative. It is not your average godzilla/t-rex man eating beast. I think it has a scary edge which keeps the audience on the edge of their seats.

There really wasn't a complete plot to the film. You know what happens to all the people but you really don't know what happens to the monster. So in that respect, its unresolved. But like I said earlier, it isn't supposed to be resolved. They filmed it so it was like the viewer is watching a government document. I don't think it could have been much better.

Overall, I thought cloverfield lived up to all the hype it created, plus it exceeded what I expected. If you go into it with the correct mind set, you will find it to be very entertaining!

title: Best "Monster Eats City" Movie Ever
review:
This movie had me at the edge of my seat and engrossed in the action from the moment the monster started taking apart Manhattan.

Many people who didn't like the movie seem to comment on how it didn't live up to the marketing, which seems odd to me. The trailers seemed kind of lame to me-- I had originally not planned to see this movie because the "promotion" didn't speak to me.

What I got was a cinematic thrill ride as the audience got dragged, knocked down, attacked, battered, and exhausted along with the protagonists as they tried to survive a mysterious and terrifying ordeal.

The handy cam style was mixed in beautifully with some of the most amazing special effects (and even more so sound effects) that made me feel like I was there, running for my life, trying to figure out what the heck was going on.

Cloverfield was one of the fun-nest movies I've every seen.

title: Brilliantly Intense Movie!
review:
We were hanging out in the mall and we had nothing to do so we decided to watch a movie. I was choosing between AVP 2 and Cloverfield, but after seeing the poster, I thought Cloverfield might be more different, so we checked it out. I must say Cloverfield really blew me away! I really liked the movie. It's an action/sci-fi/thriller monster movie. It's got LOADS of very good intense action, accompanied with flawless special effects(wait, did they use any?). The action sequences were simply brilliant! Acting was great. Not top notch, but is still good and believable. The main monster was really cool and destructive, I kept thinking "what's that thing? where did it come from? How did it get here? What will happen if that was real?" the entire time. It's also got some scary and disturbing scenes which really creeped me out. The sound effects were awesome! It would be great if you watch this in theaters to get the best from the sounds. Oh and take note that the whole movie is shot using a home camera by one of the civilians getting attacked by the monster, so you might know how shaky the camera is, so it is not recommended for people who easily get motion sickness. The camera style was really good, making you think that the movie was real. It's no Godzilla movie; Cloverfield has a more different feel. I never thought I'd run into such a big movie like this! Usually I only go to cinemas for big movies like Spider-man and Harry Potter. It took my 2008 Big-Movies-To-Watch-In-Cinemas planner by surprise.

Some people will like it, some people won't. I watched this with my mom and said that she didn't like it; nothing in the movie was good and the camera shakes were irritating. Oh well......we all have different tastes.

In my opinion, Cloverfield is a very good action-packed sci-fi monster movie that made me happy(I actually smiled the entire movie!) and made my day at the mall. It was a superbly intense roller-coaster ride. Well done Matt Reeves and J.J. Abrams! Fine work indeed.

title: So awesome
review:
I am not a man who is a fan of monster movies. I have never watched monster movies before and I even didn't want to watch '8 Legged Freaks' after my friend assured me it was funny, not scary.

But 'Cloverfield' caught my attention because of one thing. This was a review/interview in an Empire magazine. And it gripped me so much, even before I had seen a trailer!

So I went with a few friends, expecting it to be good, but I underestimated it. It was, in my own personal words, so freaking awesome.

The characters, unlike what some of the previous reviewers have said, were very realistic and I found it extremely easy to be empathetic with them, especially when they were killed off. The acting, too, made me think that these characters were real.

The way it was filmed was one of my favourite touches to the film, using only a hand held camera and having you watch the film from one of the character's point of view, making it seem like you're the person running away from whatever it is attacking New York (and don't worry, you'll see it).

And that brings me to the monster. The thing that made millions of people around the world flock to this movie. It is so amazingly well done, both graphics wise and everything else wise. It looked and acted so realistically and made me jump in my seat many times. The fact that we didn't see it outright made it even scarier.

I've read lots of the reviews on this website and I don't understand why people didn't like it! Okay, maybe the camera could have gotten on people's nerves and maybe they've watched 'Godzilla' too many times but I don't understand why they said the characters were unrealistic! They were completely human, not the scripted Hollywood clichés that clog up our screens.

In conclusion, go see this movie. It's well worth it, it's scary, thrilling and just plain awesome.

title: A twist on an old genre, Cloverfield shows that even an old concept can still sell
review:
My first reaction to seeing the "mysterious" movie trailer in which one is treated to the scene of large section of New York exploding, followed of course by the head of the State of Liberty bouncing down a street, was one of awe. Not only was this film being produced by JJ Abrams, better known in my opinion for the series Lost, but it was filmed in such a way that seemed unique. A hand held camera telling the story from the view point of one or at least a few other characters? Yes, we saw this before with the dreadfully silly Blair Witch Project. However, this was taking the concept to a whole new level even though no one had a clue to what actually was happening.

Now that the plot is known to everyone, the idea behind it is still unique. A monster movie based upon the limited view points of only four major characters? In movies such as Godzilla and King Kong the audience knew more than the characters so it was easy to dismiss their actions and thoughts if one disliked them. However, with Cloverfield the situation is different. Now the audience is forced to only know and experience what the characters themselves are facing. Frustrating to some, but I found it drawing me in further because I was so desperate to also know what was going on.

Rob (Michael Stahl-David) has been promoted and will now work overseas in Japan which of course will take him far from his brother Jason (Mike Vogel) and best friend Hud (T.J. Miller). To honor the occasion, Jason's fiancée Lily (Jessica Lucas) decides to set up a surprise party with all of Rob's close friends so they could all see him off together. Of course Rob would want to remember this so Lily convinces Jason to record the party on an hand held camera which Jason then dumps upon Hud who finds himself enjoying the new responsibility as well as the opportunity to draw close to Marlena (Lizzy Caplan).

The party is a success until the appearance of Beth (Odette Yustman) and her new boyfriend. I should back up and explain that Cloverfield starts with images from the camera of Rob and Beth together. Images that are slowly being erased as Hud continues to film but since Jason and Beth now seem to be far apart due to some strange twist in their relationship, Rob claims to have little interest in them.

As if life couldn't get more stressful for Rob, the city is suddenly rocked by a strange earthquake. What is the obvious thing to do? Well, run up to the roof to get a better view of the city which of course everyone at the party decides to do. While Hud pans over New York's night line, it is then that an explosion literally tears apart a large section of the city. Everyone screams and begins running from the roof and only stop when they reach the city street where they are joined by other New Yorkers who stare with horror as buildings seemingly fall on their own.

What happens next is captured solely by Hud who runs, trips, falls, screams, and cries as much as everyone else around him. The idea sounds silly but it actually works and also gives the characters a deeper sense of depth in that the only camera, so to speak, they are acting in front of is the small one before them. The sudden motions, fuzzy images, and dusty shots gives one the impression that for the most part something like this actually happened. Some complained of sickness because of this however I was not one of them. Cloverfield's strength is in the way it is filmed and if you didn't like that then you have no reason to like the movie at all.

The movie follows the basic idea behind an escape movie in that Rob, Jason, Lily, Hud, Beth and Marlena, must escape the city at all costs. The deaths of Jason and Marlena, as well as the rescue attempt to save Beth, drive the rest of the drama of Cloverfield. It is easy to argue that there isn't much substance behind Cloverfield but one really misses the point if that is one's feelings about Cloverfield. Once more Cloverfield is a movie not just about the monster attack itself but in how the story is told. That is where the real strengths of the movie are found.

Cloverfield isn't a perfect movie and one can argue that the idea of someone really wanting to hold onto the same camera during a monster attack is simply unrealistic. Okay, so what? How realistic is a monster attack to begin with? One shouldn't be too critical of Cloverfied but instead should simply agree with everyone that takes place and enjoy the ride. Cloverfield shows that an old genre such as monster attacks can still work even today.

8/10

title: Cloverfield
review:
WOW, what an exciting excellent movie. This is an amazing movie that everyone should go and see.

Only problem is this, if you hate an awesome movie with a not so Hollywood ending then don't go , you wont like it.

But if you like Non-stop action, suspense, terror, and surprise then put yourself in the theater and watch this movie.

You wont be sorry trust me. And please please don't compare this to the Blair Witch Craft because this beats it by a million.

So in conclusion if you like a Non-Stop action thrill ride then go to this movie, and don't forget a barf bag, and don't eat tacos before going, i found out the hard way.

title: Cloverfield flawed but good
review: This contemporarily hip, memorably dark monster genre revival has moments of cinematic mastery as well as lapses of almost laughable ridiculousness (even for a monster movie), and the combination yields a good but not great experience that sticks with you with surprising firmness. The film follows a tight-knit group of trendy New Yorkers as they try to survive a hellish assault on their city by a giant, indestructible, and viciously pernicious amphibian. The ground-level portrayal of the attack is often brilliant, using 9/11 imagery (a cloud of dust chases people after the collapse of a building, and showers of office paper flutter down from damaged skyscrapers), ominous fleeting glimpses of the gargantuan perpetrator as it stalks and stumbles through the streets, and convincing special effects that make us flinch as cars are crushed like cola cans, missiles of rubble rain into crowds of onlookers, and a mass evacuation is organized in the opposite direction of rumbling tanks and shouting soldiers. The characters themselves aren't quite real enough for us to truly care for them, but we see enough of a going away party for the main character (Rob) immediately preceding the turmoil, and glimpses and pieces of stirring humanity during the attack (Rob is called by his worried mother presumably watching news reports from far away in one of the film's best scenes), to sympathize with them adequately. The dialogue, however, is too often tortuous, and sporadic attempts at comic relief make us consider rooting for the monster. Certain scenes break the trance of terrifying realism that envelopes most the movie. And ultimately, contrary to the director's intentions, the home video style filming technique hurts the impact of the terror by making the audience merely secondary, "after-the-event" observers. In order for us to be fully engaged in the victims' plight, we had to see and hear with their eyes and ears, not their super-durable camcorder. Yes, the thing made me nauseous. The director could have preserved the laudably tragic effect of cutting randomly to home video footage of the main character's romantic day with his lover a month before the attack by giving the characters a camcorder that they turned on only occasionally. Despite its flaws, the movie is a must-see.

title: This movie is not a waste of 84 minutes
review:
If your intelligent and can catch things going on everywhere then you will see where the monster is from. Those of you who shoot down this movie because you say they leave to many questions unanswered or don't like the shaky cinematography they your both ignorant and you get motion sickness too easily.

This movie was great and it did everything it was meant to do. I will not say anything about this movie because I think everyone should feel that same anxiety, suspense, and fear that I did the first time I saw it.

Be your own judge.

title: What's Out There?
review: To me a good movie is the kind that leaves you wondering what's going to happen next. Something that makes you thinkwhat would you do if you were in that situation? How would you re-act? I liked the film. I really only had one real disappointment with this film and that was the how it was filmed through the eyes of a single camera. Some-what like "The Blair Witch Project " thankfully our camera person in this film was much less shaky then that of the Blair Witch crew so you could actually see what was taking place as it was happening. The character build up was nicely done. You're quietly introduced into the lives of a group of individuals that at a perfect time were all brought together. If not for this moment some may not even have spoken to one another. Within a second everything changes and the city feels like it's become a war zoneno one even knows what's going on. You, as well as the characters are left waiting wondering looking around for a clue as to what happenonce the chaos starts. Earthquake, plane crash, bomb? What?

title: Whats taking over The Big Apple
review:
Cloverfield was very entertaining to watch it had great special effects, It gave me Goosebumps and I liked the way the actor's really put there emotions in the story. BUT !!!

I am afraid I have 2 negative comments bothering me.

-This movie gave me the feeling I was watching the Blair Witch Project cause it has the same baseline as in the woods in Maryland USA.

-Why was there no background about the monster that attacks New York especially when I think there was a good ability to use a background even the smallest bit of information would of have it made me give at least A 8 grade.

But to keep positive this movie really entertains the people watching it there are some scary parts and shocking parts in it.

The 2 scenario's what really freaked me out when I was watching where

  • In the Subway when the camera goes to night vision


  • When the helicopter got attacked out of the air after thinking the monster was destroyed


Because this movie makes me think about a lot of things I give it a 7 cause lets be honest its one kick A## movie

title: Dizzy effect but very good
review:
I think that this movie is a very good one. But it is far from a mainstream movie. That is also the reason why I can imagine that some people do not see the point of this movie and even dislike it for that same reason. But I think that is with a lot of movies like Blair Witch Project, Babel etc. A group of people will see the point of the movie and like it and another big part sees it as some kind of strange art that they can not relate to.

The first ten minutes of the movie start slow. But with the sudden arrival of the monster the movie starts to excel both in quality and speed. The sound of the explosions can be felt in your stomach. I especially like that the tension was build up and they actually did show the monster. And as a relatively low budget movie the monster and the special effect were quite good. The actors were unexperienced but they did play very convincingly.

If you get dizzy easily this is not a movie I would recommend.

title: Unique Monster versus City Movie
review:
Some people may argue that this movie was indeed bad just because of the filming of it. To me, the filming of it, it being first person and from the people who are the victims of the disaster, really is what made the movie and really brought realism to the movie.

Not only was the movie uniquely filmed, but it also was very realistic. I know it's hard to say that a monster attacking a city is realistic, but it is quite realistic acting, and the whole storyline behind it is realistic.

This is a very good movie and would recommend it to anyone who would be able to stand the consistent waving and moving of the camera. The movie takes a lot of attention to actually "get" it, which is why some may not like the movie due to the fact that they don't actually get it (Why it happened, where the monster came from, etc...).

Anyways, if you go see it, go with an open mind, and make sure you pay attention to every little detail.

title: A Roller Coaster.
review:
I used to be an elitist sort of movie watcher, turning my nose up at any sort of cinema deemed too base, or unsophisticated. I've changed this philosophy of late, and come to appreciate that our going to the movies is no different than Romans going to watch a gladiator being disemboweled. Movies are about the thrill of being alive, and no movie yet has better embodied this notion than Cloverfield.

The hand-held camera work created a highly intimate experience, as did the characters and their simpleton problems.
